Volume 39 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle includes 193 letters and covers the period from December 1862 through December 1863. Of the 114 letters by TC and the 79 by JWC, only 7 are written to each other (3 by TC and 4 by JWC), which indicates both a significant contribution by JWC and a year spent without the customary respite of separate vacations. Remarkably, 158 (or 82 percent) of the letters in this volume are identified either as hitherto unpublished or as previously published in incomplete form. Although much of the material in this volume constitutes business as usual for the Carlyles, three events dominate the period: the illness of the Carlyles’ great friend Lord Ashburton, the publication of TC’s only direct commentary on the American Civil War, “Ilias (Americana) in Nuce” (Macmillan’s Magazine, Aug. 1863), and the catastrophic fall of JWC on 22 September 1863, when she slipped while trying to avoid a cab in the congested St. Martin’s le Grand near the General Post Office. Her excruciatingly painful convalescence during the ensuing months demonstrated the fragile condition of her health and seemed an ominous portent of the future.

For JWC, 1862 ended in a typically chaotic fashion. In December she found herself embroiled in quarrels with three of her servants, Maria, Flo, and Elizabeth, all of whom were in various stages of having their services no longer required. According to JWC, the outgoing Maria had given the incoming Elizabeth some last words of wisdom: “‘Take my advice Lizzy! and get yourself out of this Prison House as fast as you can! i have felt a great deal lighter since I knew myself going away!!’ you will never have an hours happiness in this house.’” Elizabeth, whom TC had dubbed the “mooncalve,” received her own notice after, according to JWC, she “spoiled a whole weeks bread so that it had to be given to poor people to boil—if they could.” JWC was forced to seek new help, an activity that she always found to be both difficult and distasteful. The voice with which she ends her discourse on help to Mary Russell is clearly JWC’s own: “So I am still ‘seeing servants’ which is far worse than ‘seeing a Doctor’” (JWC to MR, [10 Dec. 1862]).

The triumph of seeing the third volume of Frederick into print earlier in the spring of 1862 was affirmed in December, when TC received a letter from Emerson, the only one exchanged between the two friends during the year. In it, Emerson’s praise of the third volume is effusive, to say the least: “Tis sovereignly written, above all literature, dictating to all mortals what they
shall accept as fated & final for their salvation. It is mankind’s Bill of Rights & Duties, the royal proclamation of Intellect ascending the throne.” Later in the letter, Emerson provides TC with gloomy news of events in America: “Here we read no books. The war is our sole & doleful instructer. All our bright young men go into it, to be misused & sacrificed hitherto by incapable leaders. One lesson they all learn—to hate slavery, teterrima causa [the most dire cause]” (RWE to TC, 8 Dec. 1862, in Slater, CEC 535–36). TC had professed to his brother John in January 1862 that “No war ever waging in my time was to me more profoundly foolish-looking” (CL 38:45). Emerson’s missive did not change his mind. TC enclosed it in a letter to his brother in which he articulated continuing ambivalence toward the war: “Emerson’s letter will rather disappoint you; nothing in it, abt the Practical State of America, that is not more or less chimerical,—conquering the South, and becoming celestial by emancipating Niggers, and so forth” (TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1862). The callous acerbity of TC’s language obscures his underlying suspicions about the North’s justification for war. Begun ostensibly to save the Union from dissolution, the casus belli according to Northern supporters, including Emerson, was being transformed into a divinely mandated war against slavery. Many neutral observers in Britain, including TC, were skeptical of the contradiction. Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation, having been announced in September, became law four days later.

But the close of 1862 presented both JWC and TC with a deeper source of concern, one that transcended both the American conflict and the customary travails of Cheyne Row. From Paris, where Lord Ashburton had been for some weeks alternately turning for the worse and then the better, word came that their friend’s health had reached a crisis point. Further, as Lady Louisa Ashburton nursed her desperately ill husband, she received the news of her mother’s death. Lady Ashburton’s sister Mrs. Anstruther, unable to travel to France because of her own ill husband, urged JWC to write and ask if she was needed in Paris. To Mary Russell, JWC reports that she may have to give up her search for a new servant in order to help her friends: “And only imagine! in the midst of this botheration, it is possible I may have to go to— —Paris! Me! at this season of the year! and with my horror of sailing!” Although clearly upset at the prospect, JWC goes on to inform Russell that she indeed has written to Lady Ashburton with surely honest resignation: “If she says yes, I will go at once, and trust all the rest to Providence” (JWC to MR, [10 Dec. 1862]). The next days were full of dread for the Carlyles, especially for JWC, who writes again to Mary Russell and informs her in passing that she has dosed herself with morphine in order to sleep. She also confesses in the same letter to Russell that TC, “for all his outward grimness, has far more Hope in him than I have” (JWC to MR, [12 Dec. 1862]). To TC’s sister Mary Carlyle Austin, however, JWC expresses the depth of her husband’s concern:
“We dread now that the next post will bring the news of our dear Lord Ashburtons death. Carlyle will lose in him the only friend he has left in the world. and the world will lose in him one of the purest hearted, most chivalrous men” (JWC to MCA, [11 Dec. 1862]). Days later, JWC writes again to Mary Carlyle Austin: “[E]very knock at the door makes my heart jump into my throat, for it may be news of his death!” (JWC to MCA, [ca. 16 Dec. 1862]).

As the end of the month approached, guarded hope turned to real despair at any chance of improvement for Lord Ashburton. In a letter full of anguish, TC writes to Lady Ashburton and imparts what he believes will be the last word to reach his friend before death: “If your loved Partner is still with you, and can hear my message, let it be to him: ‘God go with you, guileless, pure and valiant man, who have accompanied me in my Pilgrimage so far, and been friendly to me like a Brother;—whom I shall soon follow. Farewell!’” TC then closes with instructions for Lady Ashburton: “You will not give way, I am sure; you will summon yourself together, for high and important duties that remain, and that will still give a sacred beauty to your days. I pray silently, yet do pray, for one and all of us. Yours and his, faithful till I also die” (TC to Lady ALLA, 20 Dec. 1862). It is a remarkably Victorian moment for both Carlyles as they consider the impending death of Lord Ashburton, with TC saying goodbye in the lofty, Hebraic tone of his attic study, and JWC expressing resignation in the practical register of daily life: “There are no words for such misfortune. Meanwhile one’s own poor little Life struggles on, with its daily petty concerns, as well as its great ones!— About these eggs, which mustnt be neglected if the Solar System were coming to a stand! …” (JWC to MCA, [11 Dec. 1862]).

JWC was much relieved when Lady Ashburton wrote to tell her that she was not to come to Paris, but another person whose presence was requested was the popular society doctor Richard Quain. Earlier in the month, JWC had described Quain as a “Little Beast” with “whom the Ashburtons are infatuated” (JWC to MR, [12 Dec. 1862]). When he appeared at Cheyne Row unannounced on Christmas day, JWC feared the worst:

My first words to him (he had never been in the house before) were “Oh Dr Quain what has brought you here?” a reception so extraordinary, that he stood struck speechless! which confirmed me in my idea. and I said violently; “tell me at once!—you are come to tell me he is dead?"—"My dear Lady, I am come to tell you no such thing; but quite the contrary! I am come, by Lady Ashburton’s desire, to explain to you the changes which again have raised us into hope—that he may recover!” Then, in the reaction of my fright, I began to cry!! What a fool that man must have thought me! (JWC to BB, 25 Dec. 1862)

Lord Ashburton was past the moment of crisis and moving slowly toward a year-long period of improvement. TC would see him at the end of July 1863 and find him to be “extremely thin and frail, but looking cheery quiet, and as if he wd daily gather more strength” (TC to JAC, 31 July). By 26 August, the Carlyles would find themselves once again at The Grange, where their devotion to both Lord and Lady Ashburton would deepen even further. And in a little more than three years, Quain would be the last physician to attend JWC.

On 11 February, JWC received an unexpected gift from “J. T.,” a professed great admirer of her husband’s works. The close of JWC’s letter thanking “J. T.” for the shawl provides a rare glimpse at an intimate moment between the Carlyles: “We are both equally gratified, and thank you heartily. When the shawl came, as it did at night, Mr. C. himself wrapped it about me, and walked round me admiring it. And what think you he said? He said, ‘I am very glad of that for you, my dear. I think it is the only bit of real good my celebrity ever brought you’” (JWC to JT, 11 Feb.). The previous week, TC had suffered a nasty fall from his much-loved horse Fritz, as JWC reports in a letter to Margaret Oliphant: “The victim himself looks tolerably composed, is ‘consuming his own smoke,’ in a manner which rather frightens me by its novelty, as my Mother once, after lecturing me on the impropriety of crying when I hurt myself, nearly fell into fits on hearing me fall down stairs and utter no cry after it. I wish he would growl a bit” (JWC to [MO], [7? Feb.]).

With TC beginning to scout out a new horse, hints begin to appear in letters between JWC and Lady Ashburton, who was able to visit Cheyne Row briefly in early May: “I must leave off writing anyhow—and I had still a good deal to say. especially about the Horse. Oh don’t, please, prosecute that inquiry so bothering for you—so out of your line! I don’t like the idea of it—and I am sure no more would he—if he knew. I was very near telling him that night, after you left, when he asked me ‘what on earth I was making such a whispering about?’ But I rather pique myself on holding my tongue, when I am told to. So I answered pertly that if he had been intended to know; why then I shouldnt have whispered” (JWC to Lady A, [ca. 10] May). Collusion was clearly afoot, and TC aware of it. He writes to his sister Jean on 16 May: “I have got a new horse sent me, as if by post!” (TC to JCA, 16 May). The same day TC writes to his brother John to report more fully on the appearance of the anonymous gift: “I privately (very privately, by Jane’s hints lately) cd guess Lady Ashburton as the kind Giver;—one of the kindest acts, [considering her o]wn state of harrassment anxiety and tribulation all this while, that I have ever known” (TC to JAC, 16 May). TC’s letter of thanks to Lady Ashburton reflects the depth of his appreciation: “I cannot enough wonder at such a thing; and, instead of speaking my thanks, am ready to blush them. That is really true” (TC to Lady ALLA, 17 May). The arrival of “Noggs,”
named for Newman Noggs, the erratic but good-natured clerk in Charles Dickens’s Nicholas Nickleby, was one of the shining moments of 1863. With the equine problem solved and Lord Ashburton clearly on the mend, life began to look brighter for both JWC and TC. Even the interminable struggle with Frederick seemed to be approaching an end. TC writes to Janet Carlyle Hanning on 13 May and announces triumphantly, “I expect to get done with my book in six or eight months. O that I saw the day!” (TC to JCHJCHA, 13 Aug. [May]).
In May, TC wrote a short dialogue that would make public his views on “the assertion of authority” question in the context of the American Civil War:
ILIAS (Americana) IN NUCE.
Peter of the North (to Paul of the South). “Paul, you unaccountable scoundrel, I find you hire your servants for life, not by the month or year as I do! You are going straight to Hell, you —!"
Paul. “Good words, Peter! The risk is my own; I am willing to take the risk. Hire you your servants by the month or the day, and get straight to Heaven; leave me to my own method."
Peter. “No, I won’t. I will beat your brains out first!” (And is trying dreadfully ever since, but cannot yet manage it.)

Following its publication in Macmillan’s Magazine later that August (8:301), a flood of angry, thoughtful, sarcastic, and parodic retorts to TC’s “Ilias” appeared throughout Britain and the United States. In the Daily News (4 Aug., 2; rptd. in the Leeds Mercury, 5 Aug., 6), a “Reader” offered a careful attempt to interpret TC’s implied view on slavery in the dialogue: “American slavery, instead of being that monstrous plague-spot on the earth towards the wiping out of which all humanity should strive, is an exhibition … of a system of social relations to some form or other of which, in spite of the present possession of all men’s minds with the ideas of liberty and democracy, the whole world must be brought back, if it will not end in wreck and dissolution.” The author goes on to place this stance on slavery within the overall context of TC’s works: “White slavery, he has proclaimed over and over again, really exists among ourselves and in other countries of Europe—only, by not calling it slavery, we lose that sense of our duty to see to its organization which we should perhaps feel if we kept the ugly name; and we allow it, under the empty dignity of liberty, to become more and more ignominious and horrible.” The unnamed writer concludes, “Mr. Carlyle speaks again in his
character as the champion of Authority, rather than of Liberty, as the true principle of human society.” In fact, neither the Southern model of authority founded upon chattel slavery nor the Northern version founded upon wage slavery would ever find a champion in TC.

In the context of the “Ilias,” the Daily News (6 Aug., 2; rptd. in the Caledonian Mercury, 7 Aug., 3) reprinted an essay entitled “Proposed Colonization of the Slaveholders,” which had been published in the Anti-Slavery Standard “at an early stage of the rebellion.” The editors of the Daily News now submitted the essay “to the consideration of Mr. Thomas Carlyle, Mr. Spence, and other philosophers.” The author suggests that instead of recolonizing the slaves (a plan proposed by President Lincoln on multiple occasions, but opposed vehemently by abolitionists and blacks alike), a “Society for the Colonisation of the Slaveholders” should be formed to deport slaveholders because through a “Darwinian process” the “steady, law-abiding, work-loving, self-controlled Anglo-American of the North has become the lazy, passionate, law-contemning, tyrannical American of the South.” A more direct and angry response came from the Christian socialist F. D. Maurice, who published his own dialogue, “An Episode in the Ilias (Americana) in Nuce,” in the Spectator (8 Aug.). In it “S” (a Southern agent) explains the casus belli of the Civil War to “H” (an aristocratic Englishman): “We affirmed that slavery itself, not the Person who suffered the death of the slave, was the corner-stone of the universe” (2348). In a reply to Maurice, the publisher of the “Ilias,” Alexander Macmillan, wrote and described his “retort” as “merited.” But he also questioned the North’s motivations in prosecuting the war: “God knows I hate & abominate slavery in every shape with my whole heart, but there are really worse forms of it than the planter form bad as it is. Modern Yankeedom will become old Rome without her dignity, unless in Gods providence something comes to stop her mad career” (qtd. in George J. Worth, Macmillan’s Magazine, 1859–1907 [Aldershot, 2003] 31). Clearly, Macmillan shared TC’s skeptical opinion of the Northern “cause."

Another Christian Socialist, J. M. Ludlow (1821–1911; ODNB), also exchanged letters with Macmillan: “I did not think your magazine would ever fall so low as to insert that thing signed T. C. in the new no.” (qtd. in George J. Worth, “Macmillan’s Magazine and the American Civil War: A Reconsideration,” Victorian Periodicals Review 26, no. 4 [1993]: 195). In his response Macmillan mildly corrected Ludlow: “He is not ‘a bad old man,’ but a very noble & useful one, and even his wrong sayings have wisdom and significance in them which are wanting in the rabid vapid utterance of deepest truths” (Worth, Macmillan’s Magazine 31). Macmillan encouraged Ludlow to respond, which he did in the 8 September issue of Macmillan’s. His dialogue is a scathing indictment of TC’s equation of slavery and servanthood:
SERVITUDE FOR LIFE (A BRIEF DIALOGUE).
Frederick Maximus. Harkee here, Dan, you black nigger rascal. You’re no longer a slave, you’re a servant hired for life.
T. C. Niger. By golly! Wife and chil’n servants for life too, massa?
F. M. Yes, all you niggers. But you must work all the same, you know. …
T.C.N. Beg pardon, massa, but what for you call me servant hired for life?

F.M. What for, you rascal? Because a great man, after whom I named you, when he had written a d—d good book on the “nigger question,” says that is all the difference between you and those mean white-livered Yankee working men, who are hired by the month or day.
T.C.N. Massa, if him book good book, why’s I not priv’leged to learn read it? (8:389)

The dialogue concludes with “T. C. Niger” looking forward to the arrival of the Yankees: “Wish dey’d gib me a rifle ’fore I dies.” Not all readers, however, thought Ludlow’s sarcasm effective. One reviewer of the September issue of Macmillan’s commented in the Derby Mercury, “Contrary to its usual condition Macmillan will be found to be flippant rather than heavy. Mr. Ludlow has a very stupid answer to Carlyle’s Iliad, which is preceded by a chapter on correspondence equally stupid” (9 Sept.).

The “Ilias” also brought forth several agonized responses from America. One letter came to TC from Charlotte Taylor, 27 August, in which she writes: “You have pained, wounded, and offended a whole Nation by your careless scoff at our present bitter struggle, … Ah, Sir, you can not dream what Slavery is or you could never speak lightly of it. The important consideration is this—where one man is enslaved no man is free—that is actually true, no mere figure of speech” (CT to TC, 27 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388); another came from Horace Howard Furness, 29 August, in which he captions a photograph of a horribly whipped slave covered with welts: “Sir, / Pray observe an instance of ‘hiring for life.’ God forgive you for your cruel jest, and blindness!, Philadelphia, [29 Aug. 1863]. Photograph enclosed of negro with welts all over his back” (HHF to TC, 29 Aug.; MS: NLS Acc. 11388; see 225). Some of the responses to the “Ilias” were sarcastically humorous; for example, “Ill Ass (Anglicus) in a Noose,” which appeared in the Boston Liberator ([4 Sept. 1863]: 143). Perhaps the most remarkable American response came from Bret Harte (1836–1902), who published his own dramatic rejoinder to TC in the San Francisco Examiner:

lg.l: It’s true that I hire my servant per day,
Per month, or per year—as he chooses;
While “Paul of the South” takes his bondman for life,
Without asking if he refuses,
T.C.,
Without asking if he refuses!
But if you are judge of the merits alone,
We surely have right to inquire
The date of your service with “Paul of the South,"
And what is the length of your hire,
T.C.,
And what is the length of your hire! (3)

div1.p: Another of the less outraged responses to the “Ilias” appeared in the Glasgow Herald. An editorial of 11 August 1863 coolly agreed that Carlyle had at least obliged the North to define “the object of the present war —namely, a simple determination to abolish slavery, and compel the South to adopt the free-labour system of the North.” TC, in other words, had accurately presented the affair “in Nuce” and had done so in essential terms, especially in the context of British neutrality. The opportunity to separate the former colonies into two countries as a way to diminish American influence and to promote British dominance offered a compellingly strategic temptation, but it was certain that Britain would never make war to support slavery. As late as August 1862, however, President Lincoln himself had continued to deny slavery as the primary cause of the war: “If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it” (New York Herald, 22 Aug. 1862). What Lincoln neglected to write in his famous letter to Horace Greeley, of course, was that he had already drafted the Emancipation Proclamation and was waiting to make it public as soon as the Union army could manage a major victory, which came the following month at the battle of Antietam (17 Sept.). With his customary perversity—and cruelty—TC had undercut the moral high ground of both the North and the South by treating an all-out civil war as a simple labor dispute. Lincoln’s shift suggests his realization that the purpose of the war would have to be redefined in order to provide the Unionist cause with a distinct moral imperative. But as the commentary surrounding his “Ilias” suggests, TC was not alone in sensing a political and an economic agenda behind the shift from saving the Union to freeing the slaves.

When TC wrote the “Ilias” in May 1863, the conditions of the war were sharply different than they were when the dialogue was published in August.
The Emancipation Proclamation had gone into legal effect without actually freeing any slaves, but the implication of the executive order was clear—the war would be prosecuted to end slavery, and the restoration of the Union was now to be a byproduct of that effort. But after a disastrous defeat at Chancellorsville in May, Vicksburg remained untaken, and the apparently invincible Army of Northern Virginia under the command of Robert E. Lee was marching north to threaten Washington. That neither the Union would be saved nor the slaves freed seemed a real possibility. Then, on 4 July, Vicksburg fell, and George Meade defeated a curiously overconfident Lee at Gettysburg. Lincoln triumphantly proclaimed that the Mississippi River once again flowed “unvexed to the sea.” Any chance of Lee’s army returning to the offensive had been lost forever. With the death of Lee’s best general, Stonewall Jackson, the “Cromwell of the South” (Reynolds’s Newspaper, 31 May, 1), the South was in a strategic sense all but finished. But the war was far from over. The casualties in the next year of the conflict would outnumber those inflicted in the first two years combined. Lincoln had presciently recognized that the only way to justify the slaughter was to elevate the cause of the war to the abolishment of slavery. He would confirm this fact for all time by declaring his commitment to “a new birth of freedom” later that November in his brief but immortal address at Gettysburg. The transformation of casus belli was complete, but the British policy of neutrality did not change, nor did TC’s stubborn insistence that the human cost of the war would never justify its prosecution, for either side.

TC would spend the rest of the war frustrating various attempts of Unionists and Confederates to win his support. All of them failed. He no doubt talked—and assuredly at great length—with others about conditions in America, but in his letters he would remain mostly silent, and in print he truly deserved JWC’s appellation of him as “the Apostle of Silence” (CL 34:49). In his reading of the “Ilias,” TC’s biographer David Alec Wilson claims that the piece “concentrated attention on the slavery question as the real cause of the war. It was plainly intended to have the effect it certainly had of diminishing the danger of the war spreading. England would never think of making war in support of slavery” (Wilson, Carlyle 5:525). Although Wilson overestimates the influence of the “Ilias” in preventing Britain’s entry into the Civil War, his analysis contains at least a partial truth, especially in terms of the significant periodical conversation the “Ilias” provoked. If nothing else, what Emerson had called “a most needless squib” (qtd. in Len Gougeon, “Emerson, Carlyle, and the Civil War,” New England Quarterly 62, no. 3 [1989]: 418n) served to demonstrate the continuing relevance of TC’s voice. When he wrote and spoke, friend and foe alike listened, and when he remained silent, supporters of both sides wondered why.

As the furor over the “Ilias” rattled noisily around them, the Carlyles’ lives seemed to be entering a rather positive phase. At the end of August, in spite of JWC suffering from what Dr. Quain diagnosed as “neuralgia” (JWC to MR, [(16 Sept.]), both Carlyles seemed to have enjoyed the three weeks they spent at The Grange with the Ashburtons. At least in her remarks to Lady Ashburton, even JWC’s opinion of Dr. Quain had taken on a brighter tone: “Decidedly Quain is very clever—very prompt and dexterous! also—he writes remarkably pretty and ingenious notes!” (JWC to Lady ALLA, 19 Sept.). But JWC’s painful arm was not improving, as she writes to her former maid Maria Chamberlayne: “I will not delay answering your letter until I can ‘tell you that my arm is better.’ For that may be a long time off—if ever! I sometimes think, this pained half-crippled arm, of now more than three months standing, is added to my Life-burden in permanency!” (JWC to MCMCH, 23 [22] Sept.). JWC clearly misdated this letter, for there is little chance that she could have written it on the twenty-third. TC’s letter to Lady Ashburton, postmarked 23 September, explains: “My poor wife had an ugly accident yesterday; in some crowded place, while getting into a street vehicle too rapidly, fell on the curb-stone; hurt her left leg and side, and was brought home to me quite lame. No bones broken, hip-joint not injured (as I feared); but very great misery of pain ever since;—and in short a bad job for us, whh we had no need of as things were. In a day or two (the Dr. promises) it will be easier to bear” (TC to Lady ALLA, [23 Sept.]).

Dr. Barnes seemed to be correct in his diagnosis for a quick recovery, at least at first. TC reported to Lady Ashburton late in September: “She is very quiet, clear of head, as ‘patient’ as the Doctor cd prescribe: she bids me tell you ‘she is going on slowly, and’ Nothing more came from her at that moment!” (TC to Lady ALLA, 30 [29] Sept.). The Ashburtons apparently felt somehow responsible for JWC’s accident, which elicited responses from both Carlyles. TC’s is directed to Lord Ashburton: “Relieve your conscience upon one score! It is absolutely certain my Wife got hurt not on your or My Lady’s busss in any sense, but altogether on her own” (TC to Lord A, 1 Oct.). JWC, in turn, writes to Lady Ashburton: “I shall be able to move in a few days the Dr says—I get hardly any sleep for the pain and your grapes are so cooling thro’ the long nights. My accident had nothing whatever to do with you—I almost wish it had had that pleasant association! as it is, it was one great stupid going to meet trouble” (JWC to Lady A, [2 Oct.]). And by 9 October, as TC reports to his brother John, “Jane’s hurt here is clearly getting better” (TC to JAC, 9 Oct.). And clearly, as the month progresses, JWC is moving incrementally toward rehabilitation: “I walk daily from my bedroom into the Drawing room Sofa—after a fashion! my sound arm round Marys neck, and her arm round my waist. I think there is more nervousness than pain in the difficulty with which I make this little journey! For the rest I dont lie much on my
sofa—but sit—on end—I cannot however sit up at a table to write with pen and ink—I must write with cushions at my back, and with the paper on my knees” (JWC to MR, [19 Oct.]).

JWC indeed seemed on the path to recovery, and by 20 November, she was back in the business of receiving much-welcome eggs from her sister-in-law Mary Carlyle Austin: “Speediest of dear little women! thanks thanks! The eggs are come and I have just unpacked them ‘with my own hands’; and there is not one broken!” The letter closes with the encouraging news that JWC has gone out of the house to walk, although she clearly remains disturbingly weak: “I am poorly today … having listened to the voice of wisdom [i.e., TC] yesterday, and gone out with a stick, to try walking in the street! I did not stay above ten minutes, … and the fatigue of the thing was very great, and so all my pains were aggravated for the rest of the day—and thro’ the night I was in a fever” (JWC to MCA, [20 Nov.]). But in a letter to Lady Ashburton on 4 December, Carlyle reports a serious relapse: “I am to write you ‘A single word’ in explantn of my poor Wife’s silence. … She seemed doing so nicely; able to walk abt with a staff; had been out driving once or twice:—but was taken with Influenza; and has since had the most miserable time. It is ‘only cold,’ the Doctor [Barnes] says; ‘whh has kindled all the rheumatic neuralgia and other injuries and ailments into a violent state’:—I was really alarmed; and questioned the man today,—who reassured me in that manner, and in fact made light of it;—tho’, I find, he has since ordered morphine” (TC to Lady ALLA, 4 Dec.).

The rest of the year was to be nightmarish for the Carlyles. On 6 December, TC writes to his brother John: “Her first sleep was two nights ago, by aid of morphine: I think they are continuing that; but indeed I do not know. She speaks little to me; and does not accept me as a sicknurse whh truly I had never any talent to be. We have written for Maggie Welsh” (TC to JAC, 6 Dec.). By 11 December it has become clear that JWC’s silence is not simply a matter of being angry with her difficult husband: “she is so low, one can get little out of her own acct; I seldom get above a word or two, hardly audible even with industry, and little elucidation of her state. Never before have I seen her in such misery so long” (TC to JAC, 11 Dec.). At this point, all three of JWC’s physicians—Barnes, Blakiston, and Quain—were in simultaneous attendance and desperately seeking to ease her suffering, with no result. TC writes to Lady Ashburton, 21 December: “We have had a terrible four weeks since you heard last! Rheumatic fever, or I know not what it is, and has been: the Doctors call it mere ‘influenza whh has kindled into a general paroxysm all the neuralgias, hurts &c’;—they are agreed. … [B]ut, alas, it seems very evidt their art can do nothing for her; and indeed all their opiates, morphines, soporifics, produced the very reverse of sleep or help,—no improvet visible till then were entirely abandoned. I never saw a being in such continuous
agony!” (TC to Lady ALLA, 21 Dec.). If “Carlyle was blind,” as his biographer James Anthony Froude claimed (Froude, Carlyle 4:273), then TC was not alone in his blindness about the truth of his wife’s perilously fragile health. On the penultimate day of the year, TC again writes to his brother John: “I know not when my poor Jane, worn down to this pitch, is fit for such heroic practice in opiates! But we will consider.— She does eat. … It is the one good symptom; and it is a good one” (TC to JAC, [30 Dec.]). It is the one glimmer of hope for the New Year to come.

div1.p: December 1862–December 1863

1862 December. TC writes to congratulate his brother John on solving his stepson’s behavior problems by enrolling him in the army, and asks him to take gifts to a childhood school friend Jane Johnston, now Otthenin, who is living in Edinburgh (4). He sees John Ruskin, and Sir Walter and Lady Trevelyan. JWC tells Mary Russell of her quarrel with her servant Elizabeth, who is on a month’s warning and will leave in a fortnight. “I am still ‘seeing servants’ which is far worse than ‘seeing a Doctor’” ([10]). JWC writes to Mary Austin thanking her for eggs from Scotland; the servant troubles and TC’s impatience make housekeeping very difficult ([11]). Even so, she seriously considers going to Paris to comfort Lady Ashburton despite dreading the journey, but Lady Ashburton writes to forbid it ([12 Dec. 1862]). TC writes to console Lady Ashburton, hope having been lost for Lord Ashburton (20). Mary, the new cook, arrives just before Christmas. JWC writes to Betty Braid with Christmas wishes and gifts (25) and to John Stodart with New Year wishes ([31 Dec.]).

1863 January. JWC writes to Jeannie Chrystal thanking her for gifts of a photograph and a kettle-quilt ([3]). TC sends his family New Year checks (6). JWC sends Dr. James Russell two photographs, of either herself or TC, and asks him to forward one of them to Walter Welsh (6). Jane confesses to Mary Austin her initial dissatisfaction with Mary, the new cook, and wishes that she had trusted her own “physiognomic instincts” rather than an “account of the four years excellent character” when employing her ([5]). In long letters to Lady Stanley ([late Jan.]) and Mary Russell ([27 Jan. or 3 Feb.]), JWC writes of her distress at discovering that little “Flo,” her young housemaid, had caused considerable unrest in the kitchen by making up and passing on complaints (supposedly made by JWC herself) to Mary the cook. Flo is duly dismissed “to the bosom of her admiring Family.” JWC sends Jane Dods cartes-de-visite, picturing JWC and TC, as “‘a suitable return’” for Jane Dods’s own photograph received in an earlier letter ([29]).

February TC writes to his brother John telling him that he has decided to part with his horse, Fritz, following the animal’s recent fall (13). In a letter to Mary Russell, JWC writes that her proposed holiday at St. Leonards was abandoned because she understood that an outbreak of gastric fever had
occurred at that resort ([17]). JWC visits and stays with Mrs. Oliphant in Ealing (25).

March. JWC and TC dine at the Forsters’ (3). JWC offers her laundress’s services to Eliza Forster ([5]). Fritz is sold cheaply to an apothecary, who rides him occasionally (5). Joseph Neuberg has been unwell, which unsettles TC, who still relies on him for research help (6). JWC writes most affectionately to Lady Ashburton in France wishing both Ashburtons were back in Britain (7). Monckton Milnes warmly invites TC and Jane to visit Fryston Hall, Yorkshire, but TC resists the prospect of the railway journey (19). JWC finds it very difficult to ensure a steady supply of fresh eggs and writes to Scotland for parcels. JWC is intrigued by Princess Alexandra, the new princess of Wales; neither she nor TC attend the public celebrations of the princess’s arrival in London, JWC being more interested in her previous poverty ([20]). James Aitken visits (20); TC, “still struggling in the whirlpool,” begins to guess he is only a few months away from the end of Frederick (26). JWC is surprised to receive a gift of violets from Charlotte Southam and writes to renew their earlier close friendship (29).

April. JWC writes to Mary Russell and informs her that she has been suffering from influenza for the past two weeks ([12]). TC sympathizes with Sir George Sinclair on the recent death of his wife (15). TC attends a reading by Dickens at the Hanover Rooms (28) and is impressed with the performance, although the “oversetting” of his evening “habitudes” badly affects his “spiritual composure” (29).

May. JWC writes another affectionate letter to Lady Ashburton sympathizing with her troubles (1). TC returns to Harriet Grote her library of Voltaire books after a long loan (7). TC’s sister Jean and her family move to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries (14). “Noggs,” successor to Fritz, is delivered as a gift from Lady Ashburton (16). TC writes to Lord Ashburton rejoicing in his recovery from dangerous illness (19). Helen Dickinsen, the housemaid from Sunny Bank, visits Chelsea, as does Capt. James Baillie; Charlotte Southam also pays a successful call after JWC’s and her estrangement (21). TC tells his brother John of the prevalence of smallpox vaccination in London (27).

June. TC goes to dinner with Erasmus Darwin and then on to hear a lecture by Ruskin at the Royal Institution (5). JWC goes to stay with Bessy and her husband, Dr. Blakiston, at St. Leonards (8). TC writes to Lady Ashburton commiserating with her over renewed fears regarding Lord Ashburton’s health (11). JWC returns from St. Leonards (13). TC visits James Aitken, who has broken his collar bone in an accident, and is able to reassure James’s mother, Jean, that her son is recovering well (14). TC writes to John
Forster that JWC has been ill and unable to take food or drink for the last fifty-two hours; the doctor blames the cause of this illness on recent “electric weather” ([18]). TC and JWC spend an evening at home in Chelsea with Ruskin and John William Colenso, bishop of Natal (19). John A. Carlyle visits Thomas Erskine in Linlathen, Dundee, late June.

July. JWC writes to Mary Russell about her visit to the Blakistons in St. Leonards and her and TC’s invitation to visit Lord and Lady Lothian (9). TC orders wine from Hutchison & Co., Edinburgh (20). TC writes to his brother John informing him that he visited the ailing Lord Ashburton “three or four times” during the past week following his return from France (31).

August. TC receives a “most magnificent” dressing gown as a present from Lord Ashburton and writes to thank him for this gift (2). John A. Carlyle visits Chelsea, and he and TC discuss various places they could sail to, but TC decides instead to go to The Grange; the Lothians’ invitation refused ([19]). TC and JWC travel to The Grange to visit the Ashburtons (24), leaving TC’s brother John at Chelsea until 1 Sept.

September. TC writes to his sister Jean, informing her of his daily routine while staying at The Grange; four hours of each day, up until 2:00 p.m., are spent working on Frederick (8). TC and JWC return from The Grange to Chelsea (14). JWC visits Lady William Russell in her London home (18). JWC sends two parcels of gifts to Lady Ashburton at The Grange; these gifts include books from TC for Lord Ashburton, a piece of cornice from Livia’s excavated villa in Rome for the Ashburtons’ museum, and a copy of Goethe’s Hermann und Dorothea, inscribed by Goethe to JWC, the latter intended as a present for Mary Florence Baring, the Ashburtons’ daughter ([21]). JWC writes a long letter to Lady Ashburton informing her of the results of a search for a lady’s maid that she has conducted on her behalf (22). Later that day (22), after visiting her cousin Mrs. Godby, JWC trips on a curbstone, while trying to avoid a cab on St. Martin’s le Grand, and injures her left leg and side.

October. TC writes to his brother John, resettled in Edinburgh for the winter; he persuades himself JWC is slowly recovering (9). He is glad to have begun book 19 of Frederick; “My slavery … will end before very long now,” he tells Charles A. Ward (18). Meanwhile JWC, out of bed most of the day, moves slowly about indoors, exchanges family news with Grace Welsh, and writes in good spirits to Lord Ashburton (22) on the same day TC goes riding with Foxton. TC sends intemperate instructions to his copyist, Mr. Bishop ([20]), which Neuberg modifies and sends on. TC introduces Moncure Conway to Neuberg (21). The Atlantic Monthly publishes a hostile reaction to TC’s flippant views on the American Civil War and the emancipation of slaves;
JWC sends it to Lord Ashburton ([22]) and TC tells John about it (23). JWC’s cousin Alexander Welsh’s son Jackie is ill in Liverpool ([27]). TC acknowledges Anne Gilchrist’s gift of Alexander Gilchrist’s Life of William Blake (31).

November. JWC writes to Lady Airlie about her accident, and in praise of Miss Bromley (2), but privately remains very gloomy about the state of her health. Isabella Simmonds asks her to be godmother to her new baby (3); JWC is very reluctant to become this or to join in the christening luncheon. She is showered with gifts, especially fruit, by Lady Ashburton and thanks her cordially ([5]). JWC acknowledges a photograph sent by Mary Russell and mentions the photograph of Auchtertool Manse sent by her cousins ([5]); TC thanks John James Garth Wilkinson for sending his photograph but refuses to be photographed by Wilkinson’s photographer (10). He begins to suspect, then to realize, that a sixth volume of Frederick will be needed to finish the job (12). Noggs and TC have a fall (14). JWC thanks Mary Austin for a present of much-needed fresh eggs ([20]) and admits that moving about is still very painful. Late November, JWC suffers a severe setback in health and takes to her bed.

December. JWC remains very ill and sleepless, TC confirms to Lady Ashburton (4). He summons Maggie Welsh as sick nurse (6), who comes from Liverpool, where she has been nursing her nephew Jackie. Dr. Quain is added to the two doctors (Barnes and Blakiston) already attending JWC and prescribes quinine (15), without much success; Barnes prefers morphine. Christmas is somber, though A. J. Symington sends two ptarmigan (from Iceland) for Christmas dinner; TC thanks him (26). There are various visitors, including Forster (29). A Catholic sick-nurse is briefly appointed but is dismissed. William M. Thackeray dies (24). TC thanks Stephen Spring Rice for his “kind words from afar” and reports on JWC’s continuing “great pain and misery” (28). TC congratulates Monckton Milnes on his elevation to the peerage as Lord Houghton (29). Lady Ashburton briefly visits London, and Lord Ashburton is reported to be “slowly gathering strength” (29). JWC ends the year with 25 drops of morphine (29) and another 25 drops to be followed by another 10 “in case of non-effect” (30), prescribed by Barnes, father and son. She is too ill to write any of her customary New Year letters.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 Dec. MS: NLS 517.42. Pbd. A. Carlyle, NL 2:214–15 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:487–88.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I was very glad to hear that you had succeeded in that military Watt business;John A. Carlyle’s youngest stepson, William Watt, had been in trouble at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; see 38:90–91TC to JAC, 3 May 1862, and 233TC to JAC, 3 Oct. 1862. it was more than I expected; and it will be very satisfactory to you,—and the saving of the poor young foolish creature, if he can now learn to be wiser, as there is some chance of his doing. Are you not to come hither abt it at all, then? I rather judge so, as you say nothing that way. It wd be pleasant to see you again; but journeying is a horrid puddle, especially at this season.

Thanks for yr industry abt the Jane Johnstone affair.Jean Johnston, now Jean Otthenin; see 38:246TC to JAC, 30 Oct. 1862, and 262TC to JAC, 16 Nov. 1862. Now that I can spell her name properly (“D’Othénir,” is it not? and “23TC wrote “23” above “23“; she lived at no. 33. Northumbd Street“?),—I may send the Books as Xmas Gift, or how I like, when there is time to write a little Note. But do you go and make some acquaintance with her,John A. Carlyle replied, 16 Dec.: “This afternoon I have seen Madame Otthennin for the first time. She received me very heartily, & we soon got to talk of old times. She has no gray hairs, the ground-work of her features is very recognisable, but over it she has many traces of the tear & wear of years, so that on the whole I should not have known her at all had I met her in the street. She has been three years here!—called once or twice for me last summer without leaving her name. Her youngest daughter [Irma] is pretty & seems clever too—speaking English pretty well. I am to see them again tomorrow, my visit today having been short & hurried.“ in the interim or afterwds, for yr own sake and mine. There is something strange & pathetically pleasant to me in the recollection of that little Bonnet at “Tom Donaldson’s,” in “the Brick House,“TC’s first school at Ecclefechan; for Tom Donaldson, see 7:346TC to DH, 19 Dec. 1834. at the distance of 60 years! You can tell her they asked me, when I came home the first day, “Who was the nicest lassie?” To whh I ansd without hesitatn, “Jean Johnstone,“—but had a great deal of quizzing to stand, whh I had not the least expected. Sixty years ago. This day is my 67th birthday. Time, Death, Eternity: what an element this is that all of us have! We are such stuff as dreams are made of; and our little Life is rounded with a sleep!Cf. The Tempest 4.1.— In my utter solitude I live much in these contemplations; whh are not joyous, but perhaps better, andAt the start of the next page, TC repeats “and” with a line over it to indicate his repetition. have a grandly quieting character, and lift one above the world and its beggarhoods. If I were
only done with my Book!Frederick the Great. But really now it is getting to be high time. My weariness of it, occasionally, no tongue can tell; at other times I am rather pleased to feel myself shaping, according to ability, so long as I live, something cosmic & true out of the chaotic mendacious and unknown. Oh that I had done with it, done!—

John GordonJohn Gordon (1797–1882; see 35:25835:biographical notes), old friend of TC, living in Edinburgh. did call one night; but we made nothing out, as he will explain. I have a copy of a curious old Drawing (whh is now in the Record Office, and was given me by Froude who found it there)—Drawing of the Kirk of Field & adjuncts to illustrate Darnley’s murderHenry Stuart (ca. 1545–67; ODNB), Lord Darnley, husband of Mary, Queen of Scots (1542–87; ODNB), was murdered at Kirk o’ Field, Edinburgh, on the night of 9 Feb. 1567. to these Official people here.The plan was drawn for William Cecil (1520–98; ODNB), English royal minister, shortly after the murder; the original is in the National Archives, London. I intend it for David Laing by the first opportunity;John A. Carlyle replied, 16 Dec.: “David Laing published last year in one of the Bannatyne club books a copy of that same Drawing of the Kirk o’ Field wh you have from Froude; so that Laing says there will be no use in sending it to him, & volunteers also to give me a copy the first time I call upon him.” Laing wrote: “For the purpose of conveying an accurate idea of the scene, a rough but spirited sketch of the Kirk of Field, and the adjoining localities, was hastily taken and transmitted to the English Court“; see Charters of the Hospital of Soltre, of Trinity College, Edinburgh, and Other Collegiate Churches in Mid-Lothian, ed. D. Laing (Edinburgh, 1861) xxxviii; see oppabove. wd have sent it by Gordon, but we failed to meet a second time. It is at prest nailed slightly to the wall of my Dressing Closet, that I may see it occasionally; Laing shall have it by the first chance.— So soon as you are thro’ that new Scottish History, tell me what it is worth.Probably Eben William Robertson, Scotland Under Her Early Kings, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1862). The reviewer in the Athenaeum, 27 Dec., wrote: “Mr. Robertson … tells his readers that the special reason that induced him to write this History was his dissatisfaction with all previous ones. … It is solely on the published sources of knowledge that he relies; he does not take the trouble and the pains of laboriously quarrying among tons upon tons of unpublished rubbish for any information which is to adorn his history. … The amount of new authentic narrative we believe to be small” (Athenaeum 840, 842). If I were off from Prussia (were light on it!), I will try a reading there.
Kirk o’ Field, Edinburgh, and the murder of Darnley
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

Ruskin is home for 3 weeks from Mornex in Savoy; but is going back to set up house there: we have seen him twice,John Ruskin returned to England, 12 Nov., and left again, 15 Dec. (Surtees, Reflections 201, 203). For Ruskin’s description of his house and garden at Mornex, see Surtees, Reflections 192. Ruskin also brought Edward Burne-Jones (1833–98; ODNB) to meet the Carlyles (Surtees, Reflections 202).—once with a Sir Waltr Trevellyan & Wife,Sir Walter and Lady Paulina Trevelyan had known Ruskin since 1847 and the Carlyles more recently; see 38:122JWC to MR, [30 July 1862]. who I think are of yr acquaintance. Wife a kind of wit, not
unamiable, and with plenty of sense; man a strangely silent, placidly solemn old gentn in lengthy black wig. Knows ErskineThomas Erskine. too;—my kind regards to E! It is time I had ended this. It is 11 p.m. & Jane gives order “Out!” The garrotting is more a terror and a rumourA recent outbreak of violent crime in London was being reported; the Times editorial commented, 7 Nov.: “Men are garrotted and robbed in the most public and well-frequented thoroughfares, not in the dead of the night, but while the streets are full.” The Illustrated London News reported, 6 Dec.: “The uppermost topic of the week—that upon which conversation has been more general, and thought more in earnest, than any other—is the frequency and frightful audacity of crimes of violence in the streets of the metropolis. … No man out of doors feels sure of his life. In broad daylight, in the most public thoroughfares, at times and in places the most unlikely, men are suddenly throttled or knocked on the head and rifled of any valuables they may chance to have about them.“ than anything very practical. But I do genlly leave my watch; carry a thick stick, and keep a sharp eye in these night walks. Adieu dear Brr; I will add a word tomorrow. / T.C.MS ends here, at bottom of sheet.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [10 Dec.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 11 Dec. 1862. MS: letter NLS 607.602; envelope NLS 608.607. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:481; Hansons, NE 503.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Darling! I wish I were beside you! I wish I were at Holme Hill! Shut up with you and the Dr in that cozy house, and no news from the outer world able to get at me! I think I shall go out of my senses if this sort of thing lasts much longer!

Where was I at, in my life, when I last wrote to you?— Maria was gone I think; and I was training little Flo, with no particle of help from the “mooncalve“;The Carlyles’ servants were Elizabeth from Haddington, referred to as “mooncalve,” June— Dec. 1862, Maria Chamberlayne, July 1861— Nov. 1862; Florence Morrison, Nov. 1862–Jan. 1863; for JWC’s recent letter to Mary Russell, see 38:264–66JWC to MR, [20 Nov. 1862]. and the mooncalve was laying all waste, and sending up Mr C’s dinners “as if they had been cooked in the Infernal Regions” he said. That was where I was at; was it not? Well! in addition to “the Infernal Regions” Cookery. I found it confirmed what I had guessed that Maria had been poisoning the mooncalve’s mind, and she again was trying to poison the little girl’s. The MotherMrs. Morrison. of little Flo came over one day, and told me she was going down to beg of Elizabeth (mooncalve) that she would give over always trying to make Flo believe the place was dull. that the girl laughed at it as yet; but, “young people being impressionable,” it might make Flo uncomfortable at last, to be always having it drummed into her, that she was “come to live in a Prison-House, and that Maria’s last words to her (Mooncalve) had been; “Take my advice Lizzy! and get yourself out of this Prison House as fast as you can! i have felt a great deal lighter since I knew myself going away!!” you will never have an hours happiness in this house“!—

I let Mrs Morrison (Flo’s Mother) go and say her say to Elizabeth But that was not enough. I called her up, and gave her my views also of her conduct. “Well, she said; it was Maria’s very words.” “Did you ever, I asked, hear Maria call the house a Prison-house, or complain of not being happy in it, until after she had offended me beyond forgiveness, and was going away?“— “No!” said Mooncalve “she never spoke that way, till she was going away. I observed that.“— “Oh—you did? and yet you try to persuade this girl that Maria went away of her own accord; because the house is “too dull for anybody to live in“! And when the Child tells you she doesnt think so, and likes the place very much; you tell her by way of encouragement; “oh youll find out soon enough
that it is a prison you are come to“!— “Well! said Mooncalve, I suppose I said it without thinking.“— The next day she spoiled a whole weeks bread so that it had to be given to poor people to boil—if they could.Isabella Beeton’s recipe for “Boiled Bread Pudding,” probably too rich for “the poor,” contained milk, bread crumbs, sugar, eggs, butter, currants, and nutmeg; see Beeton, The Book of Household Management (1861) 648–49. And that being “the last straw that breaks the Camels back“; I gave her warning! I had never engaged to keep her the second six months. And Mrs George WelshMargaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s uncle George. had told me there was a great deal of hiring by the month in Edinr now. If she did not like to return to Scotland between terms (I told her) I would put her in the way of finding another situation here. “Na Na—she said Ill gang hame to Scotland. I wish I had never left it. I can get plenty gude places there. Ill please mysell.” So I was relieved of all responsibility with her. That was a fortnight ago—so she has now only a fortnight to stay. But it is easier to turn off a bad cook than to turn on a good one. My soul is sickened with investigating this and the other “good plain cook“—without finding one that could be ventured on. I have had the offer of two very nice, clever-looking women but these were accustomed to large and expensive establishments, and even if I could have made up my mind to toThus in MS. the exorbitant wages (which I could had wages been all the difference) I could not have calculated on their being content in a house like ours. So I am still “seeing servants” which is far worse than “seeing a Doctor“—

And only imagine! in the midst of this botheration, it is possible I may have to go to— —Paris!Lord Ashburton was very ill in Paris; see 38:263JWC to MR, [18 Nov. 1862]. Me! at this season of the year! and with my horror of sailing. Lord Ashburton has not go[ne] on as the DrsLetters omitted. Lord Ashburton’s doctors were Dr. David Christison, who traveled with him, and Dr. Richard Quain; see JWC to MR, [12 Dec.]. expected. is again in a most dangerous way. And She, with the grief of her Mothers deathMary Frederica Stewart-Mackenzie d. 28 Nov., at Brahan Castle, Ross-shire. in addition to the renewed alarm about Him! Mrs Anstruther’s husband is so ill here that sheMary Frances Anstruther, Lady Louisa Ashburton’s elder sister, and Philip Anstruther; Mary had gone to Paris, 15 Nov., to help Lady Ashburton; see 38:264JWC to MR, [18 Nov. 1862], but returned because of her husband’s illness; see JWC to MCA, [11 Dec.]. cannot go back to Lady Ashburton nor can Miss AnstrutherAnnie Nairn Anstruther. go being laid up with a cold in the Country. Mrs Anstruther said, “you are the only other person that would be any good to her.” “I wish I could be with her I said.” “Oh Mrs Carlyle how thankful I should be if you were! Will you write and ask her if you shall come?” What could I do but write & ask, flinging every other consideration aside but her Lady A’s great distress—even the
consideration of Mr C and his dinners—and the new servant to be found. I dont see my way thro’ it at all! but I dont let myself think of the difficulties. It looks like throwing myself into the Sea to try whether I can swim. But I could do no otherwise than try— Even Mr C who will have, in reality, to do what he is always threatening “dine at his club,“The Athenaeum Club in Pall Mall, to which TC was elected, 1853, with his fees paid by Lord Ashburton; see 28:59–60TC to LOA, 3 March 1853, and 73–74TC to MAC, 12 March 1853. said it was right I should go, if She wished it. I cannot get her answer till tomorrow night or Friday morning. If she says yes, I will go at once, and trust all the rest to Providence
Judge if am not in “a state of mind!Coterie speech; see 23:141JWC to HW, [23 Oct. 1848]; JWC omitted “I” and closing quotation marks.
in all states
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [11 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:133–36, dated 23 Oct. Quot: Hansons, NE 503. Dated by Lord Ashburton’s illness in Paris.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Blessings on you Dear! These eggs have been such a deliverance!

Can you believe it of me? I have been in such worry of mind of late days, that were it asked of me, with a loaded pistol at my breast, whether or not I had written again after receiving your letter, I couldnt tell!! So in case I did not, I write tonight, while I have a little breathing time.

Lord Ashburton, whom we had been led to suppose out of danger, made no progress in convalescence, and then began to sink. Lady A who has had the news of her Mother’s death since his illness, was alone to nurse him day and night. Her Sister who had gone to her at Paris was obliged to hurry back to London to attend to her own Husband who is confined to bed. She told me I was the only other person whom her sister (Lady A) would like to have beside her. Would I write and ask if I might come. It was a serious undertaking for me, at this season, who had never crossed the Channel, and suffer so from sailing, and whose household affairs were in such a muddle— A servant to go away and no one yet found to replace her; but what else could I do but go to her if she would have me! Mr C too thought I could do nothing else.So I wrote and offered to come immediately. and you may think if I have not been perfectly bewildered while waiting her answer —“Seeing Servants” as the phrase is all the while! This morning I had a few hurried lines from
Her No— I was not to come “it could do her no good and would knock me up“—for the rest she was “past all human help” she said “and past all sympathy.” And the poor dear soul had drawn her pen thro’ the last words. So like her! that she mightnt seem unkind! even in her agony of grief and dread, she thought of that!

Their Doctor’s last two letters to me were very despondent; and neither today nor yesterday has there been any word from him, as there would have surely been could he have imparted a grain of hope! We dread now that the next post will bring the news of our dear Lord Ashburtons death. Carlyle will lose in him the only friend he has left in the world. and the world will lose in him one of the purest hearted, most chivalrous men that it contained.
There are no words for such a misfortune.TC wrote later on MS: “(2 fragts, Novr–decr 1863, Ld Ashbn ill;—this first.“
Meanwhile one’s own poor little Life struggles on, with its daily petty concerns, as well as its great ones!—

About these eggs, which mustnt be neglected if the Solar System were coming to a stand! I do not think Dear it was the fewness of the eggs that kept them safe so much as the plentifulness of the hay! Depend on it your womans plan of making the eggs all touch each other was a bad one. We have still eggs for a week—and then?— I know of two hens in the neighbourhood that have begun to lay but they do it irregularly. So I mustn’t trust to them! I dont think it would be safe to send the butter and eggs in the same box—a coarse basket would do as well as a box for the eggs—the difficulty of getting them sent doesnt seem to be the carriage so much as things to pack them in—if we were but nearer, I might send what the Addiscombe gardnerThe Carlyles received a weekly hamper of farm produce from the Ashburtons’ farm at Addiscombe; see 36:59TC to LOA, 4 Feb. 1860; gardener unidentified further. calls “The Empties” back again at trifling cost. I must inquire what it would cost to send empty baskets, as it is—I could take them myself to the office

Oh dear me! what a pleasure it is when one is away from home and has no servants to manage, and no food to provide! Mr C gets more and more difficult to feed. and more and more impatient of the imperfections of human cooks and human housewives!— I sometimes feel as if I should like to—run away! But the question always arises; where to?

Kind regards to Jamie and the girls. What a pleasant time I had with you all!—those nice evening drives!— Carlavarock Castle!JWC visited Caerlaverock Castle with Mary and James Austin and TC’s brother James Carlyle while on holiday in Scotland in Aug.; see 38:172–73JWC to TC, [28 Aug. 1862]. How like a beautiful dream it all is, when I look back on it from here!

p.name: Jane Carlyle
p.note: TC wrote later on the back of the letter: “fragt / (1858 or ’9 (been at The Gill).“

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [12 Dec.]. MS: NLS 607.601. Quot: Hansons, NE 503. Dated after JWC to MR, [10 Dec.], when JWC wrote about going to Paris.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I know your anxious nature Darling, and that you will be relieved to hear I am not gone, nor going on that wild journey; now that I am free to consider what it would have been for me, at this season, with my tendency to catch cold, my sufferings at sea, my ignorance of foreign travelling; I am thankful it is not required of me to go.

I inclose Lady A’s wretched little note, which came yesterday: and I beg you to observe how she has dashed her pen thro’ the words “past all sympathy“— So like her! kind, unselfish soul that she is! Even in the agony of her grief and dread, she had bethought her, that expression might seem unkind to one who was offering her sympathy; and so she would not let it stand; bless her!

But tho’ delivered from all idea of having to go, I was perfectly hopeless about Him after reading that note. and all yesterday was expecting from hour to hour a Telegram announcing his death. Mr C who, for all his outward grimness, has far more Hope in him than I have, or perhaps I should rather say, far less Fear, thought; “better news might come by the night-post“! No news of any sort came by the night post. So I—took a doze of Morphia at bed time! (the first since the night after my journey home from Scotland)JWC arrived in Cheyne Row, 11 Sept.; see 38:212JWC to MR, [15 Sept. 1862]. to prevent a third night of lying awake thro’ suspense; and procure the rest necessary for sorting up my Servant concern which Mr C would not hold me excused from bringing to a conclusion, tho the solar system should be threatening to stand still!— There were three women out of the lot I had “seen,” to be inquired into today. So I must sleep and get up with some life in me, and go out after them before eleven; when the French Post comes round; as, if I delayed till after; the letter expected might make me unfit to go thro’ such petty business. Dr Russell may depend on it; one doze of Morphia in rare and extreme cases is very good for me!Dr. Russell refused JWC morphine when she was staying with them in Aug.; see 38:167JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862]. I did sleep and did go out before eleven—and asked as many questions, as a housewife, with nothing but her housewifery to think of, could have asked! and settled, I hope, with the right servant; the least showy of the batch, and the one who had least to say for herself; but whom the Mistress with whom she had been four years had a great deal to say for. And that worrying work over, I called in at my Doctor’s daughter,Isabella Simmonds, Dr. Alfred Barnes’s da. and sat
ever so long, because I was afraid to go home, and read the letter I was sure would be waiting—

When I did read it, I found Lord A was a shade better—and not absolutely despaired of yet! Even that atom of good news made me so glad that I could hardly help—kissing Flo! the first person I saw after reading it! but I didn’t do anything so preposterous! I have no opinion of the Dr Quain, an Irishman, whom the Ashburtons are infatuated with. and who has been a second time telegraphed for from London. A silly, wheedling, making-himself-generally-useful creature! Of his mercenariness you may judge from this that Mrs Anstruther told me—Lord A gave him twelve hundred pounds for his first visit; and after receiving that large sum, he talked of “the imme[n]se sacrifices he had made to his friendship for Lord and Lady A in coming!” Little Beast! I question if his whole years practice yields him much more! For he is not a great name at all! And I suppose he will get a similar remuneration this time.Young Christison, their travelling Dr is worth a dozen of him—
But I must go to bed / your own
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [15 Dec.]. MS: NLS 607.605A. Quot: Froude, LM: 3:142–43; A. Carlyle, NLM 2:275–78; Hansons, NE 503; Simpsons 148–49.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: You would see dearest Mary by my last letter, that yours had not come before it was sent to the Post. It came some half hour after. Your letters never do come till the afternoon, which is curious, the letters from JaneJean Aitken, TC’s sister. at Dumfries arriving always by the morning post.

The news from Paris continues a little more hopeful. But with the prospect of hard winter weather setting in before He can be got to Nice; one dare not feel too elated about the present slight ammendment.

At all rates I may be thankful, that I was not taken at my word, given in a moment when my sympathy overcame my discretion. for I think now; i should most likely have been laid up at a Hotel at Calais!—which would have helped nothing, and been precious bad for myself!

Mooncalve is to go next monday. Whether to get a character, or from late shame of herself; she takes more pains now; and fewer things are cooked in “the Infernal Regions.” I dont think she can do Flo any harm; she is too great
a blockhead to be systematically mischievous; and Flo has too thorough an insight into her mooncalveism to be influenced by her. She is a very intelligent little Girl, Flo; and, I think, good. She is quite capable now of going thro’ her housemaid and parlour maid routine without my prompting; And when all that is become quite easy to her, I have no fear but she will learn to do such small jobs of sewing as are needed of her, quite as well as Maria ever did. The only objection to her that reveals itself so far, is the close proximity to her home,Flo’s mother was unwell; Flo had helped her run the house; see 38:254–55JWC to MR, [3 Nov. 1862]. If I did not give her leave to run in to see her Mother and the rest very often, the temptation to do it without leave, staying her errands &c, would be too strong for so a young creature who had never been “out” before. And her Mother tho a highly respectable and even refined sort of woman is I am afraid an excessive gossip and encourages Flo to tell her “every thing that opens and steeks” in this house. And Flo does it, I perceive, with perfect innocence; telling me again “I told Mother about Elizabeth doing this” and “I told Mother about Mr Carlyle saying that” and so on!!—and I dont like urging on her too directly, that she mustn’t carry tales to her Mother— Because so long as her Mother likes to hear them Flo would carry them of course all the same; and I should only have gained to make her do surreptitiously what she does now with childlike frankness, Besides when one says, “you mustn’t go telling things out of the house“; it sounds to uncultivated ears, as if one was afraid of what might be told. So it is better to just content myself [to]Word omitted. live in a glass house for the present of which little Flo is the unconscious show-woman!

I am very anxious as to how my prospective cookMary; see JWC to BB, 25 Dec. will turn out. With such a character as I got of her from a Mistress who seemed a sensible trustworthy woman; I should not be at all afraid that after a few weeks she would do well enough—if it weren’t for Mr C’s frightful impatience with any new servant untrained to his ways; which would drive a new woman out of the house with her hair on end, if allowed to act directly upon her. So that I have to stand between them, and immitate in a small humble way the Roman soldier who gathered his arms full of the enemies spears and received them all into his own breast!“Oh heavens, the comparison! it was too true” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:143); cf. Horatius, Roman soldier who successfully defended the bridge over the Tiber against the entire Etruscan army, ca. 505 bc. It is this which makes a change of servants, even when for the better, a terror to me in prospect, and an agony in realisation—for a time!Alexander Carlyle defended TC and attacked JWC (whom he never met) in a lengthy note: “This is of course exaggerative language. … [T]he servants at Cheyne Row were all very fond of Carlyle, and would have ‘gone thro’ fire and water’ to gain his approbation. He was uniformly kind and sympathetic, and never scolded them (unless at the instance of his Wife!) nor needed to scold; for, by a subtle influence, which may be called magnetic, he never failed to bring out a servant’s best qualities. … [JWC] too often failed, by reason of her inconstant temper, to win and hold their respect and confidence: at one time she over praised and petted them; at another, probably the very next minute, she went to the opposite extreme of censure and rebuke. This want of steady treatment is generally ruinous to the very best of servants, and was probably the chief cause of Mrs. Carlyle’s troubles in housekeeping. It is hardly possible to imagine an easier task than hers was: a small house to keep in order; no children to be cared for; a Husband whose requirements were few and whose way of living was plain and simple. Surely housekeeping under these conditions ought to have been easily reducible to a minimum of trouble!” (A. Carlyle, NLM 2:276–77).

You say get a thorough good Cook at any wages! Yes—if the wages were all the difference! But when you have agreed to give sixteen guineas a year and ten pounds more for extras (the cost of a “good plain Cook“) you find that she requires “a servants Hall” and “a bedroom up stairs” and accommodations which your house, not having been built on purpose for so dignified an individual, does not possess. And still worse you find that she objects to making bread, and that with the power of cooking some hundreds of dishes which you dont want she has to be taught to Mr C’s little plain things just as an ignorant servant would, and that she disdains to be taught, and that she thinks her gifts quite wasted on a household unworthy of them—as indeed they would be!

I saw one woman of this sort whose appearance pleased me much—and I agreed to the sixteen guineas and the ten for extras (!!!) but she was “engaged to Lord Clarendon’s CoachmanGeorge William Frederick Villiers (1800–70; ODNB), 4th earl of Clarendon, statesman; coachman unidentified further. and would like to have leave to receive his visits occasionally’! and there was no dress kitchen for such a visitor!—and no bedroom upstairs for her “great number of trunks“! And this was only “a good plain Cook“—“a professed woman Cook” gets 60 or 70 guineas a year of mere wages—no what would suit me best, if good, is what is called “a General Servant who is a plain cook” the wages of these is from twelve to fourteen pounds and “every thing found“—that is the sort of girl I have engaged with—calculating on having to teach her to make bread and most of the things Mr C requires but also calculating that she knows enough of roasting and boiling to learn these modifications without giving me too much trouble— We shall see!—
Do take care of colds I hate to think of you laid up God bless you Dear your affly
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [ca. 16 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:140–42 inc., dated Nov. 1862. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 482. Dated by arrival of new cook “next Tuesday,” which JWC called “the day before Xmas” (see JWC to EF, [18 Dec.]); Tues. was 23 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: The box of eggs came yesterday, another perfect success! Not a single egg broken or cracked! The barrel arrived today; and Mr C has already eaten a quarter of one of the fowls, and found less fault with his dinner than he is in the habit of doing now. In fact I look forward to his dinner-time with a sort of panic, which the event for most part justifies. I wish to God this long weary Book were done! for his own sake and for everybody’s near him. It is like living in a madhouse on the days when he gets on ill with his writing.

Well!— The box of eggs this time was charged three shillings and sevenpence—not a dear price for them to us; fresh eggs (if it is ever possible to get them) at this time of the year being twopence a-piece. But then there is the cost to you, and the box, and the trouble! The heavy barrel was charged three shillings and sixpence—a penny less than the light little box! Can you understand that—I cant. Nor does it matter!—

I have a new woman coming as cook next Tuesday and intense as has been Mr C’s abhorrence of the present “Mooncalve“—“Cow” “Brute Beast“—I look forward with trepidation, to having to teach the new-comer all Mr C’s things—which every woman who comes has to be taught; whether she can cook in a general way or not. If the kitchen were only on the same floor with the room, but I have to go down three pairs of stairs to it—past a garden door kept constantly open in all weathers; and at this season of the year with my dreadful tendency to catch interminable colds, running up and down these stairs, teaching bread making, and Mr C’s sort of Soup and Mr C’s sort of puddings, cutlets &c &c is no joke!TC wrote later on MS: “(fragt, 1861?).“ My one constant terror is lest I should fall ill, and be unable to go down to the kitchen at all!— I dream about that at nights! Really,

“If I were dead / “And a stone at my head / “I think I should be be—tter““[O]ld beggar’s rhyme on entering: ‘I’m a poor helpless craiture, / If I were &c. … . better (baiture!)’” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:141); see also 19:215.
There is the anxiety about dear Lord Ashburton too! that has been going on now some five weeks! sometimes relieved a little, then again worse than ever.

I have a note in my pocket at this moment which Mr C does not know of, leaving scarce a hope of his recovery! As it was not from the Dr but from Lady
A’s niece,Presumably Annie Nairn Anstruther. who expresses herself very confusedly, and might have made the case worse than it is, I decided not to unsettle Mr C at his writing, with a sight of it; and it has felt burning my pocket all day! And every knock at the door makes my heart jmp into my throat, for it may be news of his death! As this letter won’t reach you any sooner for being posted to night I will keep it open till tomorrow in case of another letter from Paris.
And if I have more to say I had better keep that till tomorrow to[o]— I write with such a weight on my spirits tonight—

ps.p: A note just come from Lady Ashburton’s SisterMary Frances Anstruther. in London, forwarding a Telegram just received “My Lord has passed a better night. Dr Quain thinks him no worse.“
So there is still hope—for those who have a talent for hopingTC wrote on reverse of the letter: “2d fragt 1863 (Ld Ashn)—“; he then crossed out “fragt.“

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [17 Dec.]. MS: NLS 553.247. Hitherto unpbd. Dated 18 Dec. 1862 on MS in another hand.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—You have conclusively settled the Librarianship of Lessing:Gotthold Ephraim Lessing (1729–81), author, philosopher, dramatist, and critic; librarian, 1770–81, of the ducal library at Wolfenbüttel; see 12:123TC to WDC, 28 April 1840; 28:88TC to JN, 23 March 1853; and Carlyle, Works 16:144. that of his “translating Law-papers in the Hirsch Case” I still take to be mythical,—if it were of any moment, whh it is not—Voltaire had any “Secretary” Richier,Voltaire (François-Marie Arouet, 1694–1778) was embroiled in a complex legal battle with a Berlin financier, Abraham Hirschel or Hirsch, Nov. 1750–Feb. 1751; he asked Richier de Louvain to recommend a German translator to assist with the case. Louvain suggested his friend Lessing, who met with Voltaire regularly until the case was settled; see Marvin Carlson, Voltaire and the Theatre of the Eighteenth Century (1998) 89. For the Voltaire-Hirsch lawsuit, see Carlyle, Works 16:277–300 and S. G. Tallentyre, Life of Voltaire (1903) 1:297–306; for TC’s previous reference to the lawsuit, see 29:54TC to EM, 4 April 1854. TC called him Hirsch in Frederick, with one reference to “named Abraham Hirsch, or Hirschel: a Berlin Jew of the period” (Carlyle, Works 16:282).—tho’ Richier, as you describe him, might possibly enough be
one of his faiseurs [agents], with Lessing for an acquaintance; but that they “went to dine with Vre” (in the King’s Palace at that time) &c &c seems to me far from likely.“Lessing often dined at [Voltaire’s] table while these proceedings were in progress” (T. W. Rolleston, Life of Gotthold Ephraim Lessing [1889] 48). Voltaire was living in the king’s palace in Berlin, Jan.–Feb. 1751, but Frederick himself was at Potsdam. Frederick was very displeased with Voltaire’s behavior; see Carlyle, Works 16:298. However, that is not of the least consequence;—and here is something that is; and perhaps may be more discoverable, if you will try for it among the Mitchell PapersSir Andrew Mitchell (1708–71; ODNB), diplomat, minister to Prussia 1756–71; TC found his papers in the British Museum of immense value; see Carlyle, Works 17:35–36. at the museum.

I have 3 Biographies of Prince Ferdinand of Brunsk;Ferdinand (1721–92), duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, Prussian field marshal 1758–66. and not one of them will tell me credibly by whom (whh might be rather difficult), or even when (whh I do consider possible) he was appointed Genl for England. Mauvillon Gesche Ferdid [History of Ferdinand] (Leipzig 1794) i. 256,Jacob von Mauvillon, Geschichte Ferdinands Herzogs von Braunschweig-Lüneburg, 2 vols. (Leipzig, 1794). TC’s copy: HCC. talks of the Hanovn Genl Graf v. SchulenburgGraf von Schulenburg unidentified further. coming to Frh on this errand at Leipzig (just before the Battle of Rossbach)For the battle of Rossbach, 5 Nov. 1757, see Carlyle, Works 17:263–93. “28 Octr. Westphalen i. 315Christian Heinrich Phillip von Westphalen (1724–92), sec. to the duke of Brunswick; wrote an account (later ed. by his grandson, Ferdinand Otto Wilhelm Henning von Westphalen) of the duke’s campaigns, Geschichte der Feldzüge des Herzogs Ferdinand von Braunschweig-Lüneberg (Berlin, 1859–72); see Carlyle, Works 17:189. calls it “1 Novr“; and a French (Brunsk) Biography by SchaperChristophe de Schaper, Vie militaire du Maréchal Prince Ferdinand, 2 vols. (Magdebourg, 1796–98); TC described it as “a careful Book; of an official exactitude, like Westphalen’s,—and appears to be left incomplete like his” (Carlyle, Works 17:284). TC’s copy: HCC. calls it Novr 6:—all of them totally dark as to the who was moving cause (George II, Frh, Pitt,George II (1683–1760, ODNB), king of Great Britain and Ireland, elector of Hanover; William Pitt the Elder (1708–78; ODNB), British statesman. Mitchell) of Ferdd’s appointment. The Printed MitchellMemoirs and Papers of Sir Andrew Mitchell, ed. A. Bisset, 2 vols.
