(1850). has nothing: but it strikes me, the Mll Papers towards the end of Octr (certainly between “Kloster-Zeven,” Septr 9–Octr 5,The Convention of Kloster-Zeven was a peace treaty between the British and French generals, signed 9 Sept. 1757, although not ratified by either court; as a result the commander of the British forces, William Augustus (1721–65; ODNB), duke of Cumberland, was summoned back to Britain in disgrace, 5 Oct. 1757; see Carlyle, Works17:228–30. and the Battle of Rossbach) will have something definite & practical; and at least give us the true date of
Schulenburg’s coming to Frh at Leipzig “in the disguise of a Dom-Herr,” & getting Frh’s assent.From various sources TC eventually decided that von Schulenburg came to Frederick between 26 and 30 Oct. 1757 (see Carlyle, Works 17:262) and that Ferdinand of Brunswick was appointed commander of the Allied Army (now including the British forces), 9 Nov. 1757; see Carlyle, Works 17:283.— — If you can find out this for me, it will be really useful.

Item. To get (in Museum) the Mémoires de Richelieu IX 175;Mémoires du Maréchal duc de Richelieu, 9 vols. (Paris, 1790–93); Louis François Armand du Plessis (1696–1788), duc de Richelieu, marshal of France. read Friedh’s Letter to him there; and see whether the “name” (of the Messenger, false name) is “Elchetet“;Neuberg read Frederick’s letter in Richelieu’s Mémoires and wrote on TC’s letter: “Je vous envoi Mr Delcheset writes Fredh—Delchezet writes Riche.” TC took the letter from Karl Heinrich Siegfried Rödenbeck, Tagebuch aus Friedrichs des Grossen Regentenleben, 3 vols. (Berlin, 1840–42) 1:313; see Carlyle, Works 17:227. The letter invited Richelieu to try to persuade his country to make peace with Frederick, which he attempted, but with no success. TC inserted a bracketed sentence into his translation of Frederick’s letter: “Sieur Balbi is the real name of him, an Italian Engineer of mine” (Carlyle, Works 17:227). Balbi accompanied Frederick on a journey to Holland in 1755 (see Carlyle, Works 16:406) and by 1756 had been appointed chief engineer of the army; see Carlyle, Works 17:33.—what you think of the story altogether. At lowest, to tell me what size the Book is, & of what year and place.Neuberg wrote on TC’s letter: “Riche (oct. 9 vol.“
Sunday Evg we will expect you with or witht news of all that.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [18 Dec.]. Addr: Montague Square. PM: London, 18 Dec. 1862. MS: NLS 1797.74. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p:
With a view to Mrs Savage;Presumably referring to a possible social engagement including Mrs. Savage, wife of Arthur William Savage, living at 9 New Sq., Lincoln’s Inn Fields, rather than a reference to Sarah Savage, b. Henry (1664–1752), nonconformist diarist, popular writer of Christian tracts, and champion of Christian holy days. I think it but honourable to tell you, as soon as I feel sure of it myself, that i am not going to be able to keep Xmas in that “happy” way. The hesitation I expressed to you that day was already a symptom of Influenza creeping over me. I had faceache and fever all night after and have not been out at all since. I think it is beaten back for the time by the judicious measures I took; but I have been, and still am, poorly enough to feel the necessity of taking care—especially as I am to have the new cook home
just the day before Xmas, and if I don’t keep on foot till I have got her trained to make the bread, and Mr C’s bread puddings, and all his things in his way—there will be, to express it in the very mildest possible form, “the very Devil to pay!“— I shall have the new cook running away—with her hairs on end!—and Mr C conveyed to a private Madhouse. Not on the representations of his ‘wife,’ but of the guardians of the Public peace—Whoever these may be!
Do come and see me in the forenoon—our only fit time for being abroad

ps.p: Lord Ashburton still in extreme danger—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 20 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 503.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Alas, dear Lady, we must take what the Eternal Ruler sends us: All-mighty He, and All-wise; what can we do, but accept in silence, in reverence!— Hope seems nearly altogether fled. Our sadness of soul is very great. If your loved Partner is still with you, and can hear my message, let it be to him: “God go with you, guileless, pure and valiant man, who have accompanied me in my Pilgrimage so far, and been friendly to me like a Brother;—whom I shall soon follow. Farewell!— —

You will not give way, I am sure; you will summon yourself together, for high and important duties that remain, and that will still give a sacred beauty to your days. I pray silently, yet do pray, for one and all of us.

closer.salute: Yours and his, faithful till I also die,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 23 Dec. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—You can take from my Printed Writings any page or couple of pages you like to select for that object;—and the signature here will serve you as Autograph.TC’s signature was duly cut off; for remaining MS, see oppabove. I absolutely have no minute of time at my disposal.
Thomas Carlyle to Unidentified Correspondent, 23 December 1862
Courtesy of Thomas Carlyle Papers, Duke University Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 25 Dec. MS: NLS 607.605B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:143–46. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:489–90.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: Here we are, you and I, again at the end of a year! Still alive you and I! and those belonging to us still alive, while so many younger, healthier, more life-like people, who began the year with us, have been struck down by Death!JWC’s friends Lady Sandwich, Elizabeth Pepoli, and Ellen Twisleton d. spring 1862; only Ellen Twisleton was younger than JWC. Can we do better, after thanking God that we are still spared, than embrace one another accross the four hundred miles that lies between—in the only fashion possible—that is; on paper!

“Merry Christmases” and “Happy Newyears“—are words that produce melancholy ideas rather than cheerful ones to people of our age and experience. So I dont wish you a “mirth” and a “happiness,” which I know to have passed out of Christmas and newyear for such as us for evermore! passed out of them along with so much else! our gay spirits, our bright hopes, living hearts that loved us, and the fresh, trusting life of our own hearts!— It is a thing too sad for tears, the thought how much is past and gone—even while there is much left to be thankful for!—and that is all the dismals I am going to indulge in at this writing!

For the rest; we have been in great anxiety about Lord Ashburton. It is six weeks passed on Monday that he has been hanging betwixt life and death—at a Hotel in ParisHôtel Bristol, rue du Faubourg St. Honoré, Paris; see 38:263TC to JAC, 16 Nov. 1862. where he was taken ill of inflamation of the lungs on his way to Nice. and all the time I have been receiving a letter from Lady A’s Sister by her directions, or from their travelling Physician Dr Christison (Son of that Robert Christison)Robert Christison (1797–1882; ODNB), toxicologist and physician; regius prof. of medicine at Edinburgh Univ., 1822–32; prof. of materia medica, 1832–77. David Christison was his 2d son; he and David lived and practiced at 40 Moray Pl., Edinburgh. who used to visit at my Uncle BenjaminsBenjamin Welsh (1796–1822), youngest brother of Dr. John Welsh; see 1:201–2JBW to EWE, 05 Oct. 1819; he and Robert Christison studied medicine together at Edinburgh Univ., Welsh graduating 1818, and Christison 1819. Benjamin Welsh probably lived at that time with his brother Robert Welsh, solicitor, 17 Howe St., Edinburgh. in your time)Betty Braid was JWC’s mother’s maid in Haddington; although JWC does not mention Betty before 1823 (see 2:306JBW to EA, 8 March [1823]), she presumably began at a time when Benjamin Welsh was living in Edinburgh. every day almost—sometimes two letters in one day!—such constant changes there have been in the aspect of his illness! The morning letter would declare him “past all human help,” and in the evening would come news of “decided improvement“! So that we couldn’t have been kept in greater suspense if we had been in the same house with him! the last three days there has been again talk of “a faint hope,” “a bare possibility of recovery.” And their London Physic[i]anDr. Richard Quain. who has been five times telegraphed for to Paris called here today immediately on his return, directed by Lady A to go and tell us his new hopes. When I was told Dr Quain was in the Drawingroom, I went into him with my heart in my mouth; persuaded he had been sent to break the news of Lord A’s death. My first words to him (he had never been in the house before) were “Oh Dr Quain what has brought you here?” a reception so extraordinary, that he stood struck speechless! which confirmed me in my idea. and I said violently; “tell me at once!—you are come to tell me he is dead?“— “My dear Lady, I am come to tell you no such thing; but quite the contrary! I am come, by Lady Ashburton’s desire, to explain to you the changes which again
have raised us into hope—that he may recover!” Then, in the reaction of my fright, I began to cry!! What a fool that man must have thought me! Poor Lady A, who is devotedly attached to her Husband, has nursed him day and night, till she is so worn out that one could hardly recognise her (her Sister writes). Next to Her and their childMary Florence Baring. it is to us I believe, that he would be the greatest loss. He is the only intimate Friend that my Husband has left in the world—his dearest most intimate friend thro twenty years now!

I told you in my last—did I not? that I had got a little girl of fifteen in place of my fine-Lady Housemaid—and that the East lothian woman, instead of coming out in a better light, when left to her own inspirations, was driving Mr C out of his senses with her blockheadisms, and carelessnessFor the servant problems, see JWC to MR, [10 Dec.].—and that, much as I disliked changes in the dead of winter; there was no help for it but to send that woman back to a part of Gods earth where she had been “well thought of” (Jackie Welsh,John Amelia “Jackie” Welsh, JWC’s cousin in Haddington. had said) and where she “could get plenty of good places” (the goose herself said! a sorry account of the style of service now going in East lothian I can only say.

I hope I shall be more comfortable now—for a while at least. The little Girl is extremely intelligent—and active and willing—is a great favourite with her Master thank Heaven! and has never needed a single cross word from me during the six weeks or so that she has been in the house! The other is a girl of 24,Mary. with an excellent three years character. whom I confess I chose, out of some dozen that offered, more by character than outward appearance— She is only on a month’s trial as yet— I rather hope she will do; but it is too soon to make up my mind in the four days she has been with me—
I inclose a post office order for a sovereign to buy what you need most, and wear it for the sake of your loving Jane W. Carlyle

ps.p: Best regards to your Husband and dear GeorgeBetty’s invalid son, George Braid.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Dec. MS: NLS 525.100. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
These Inclosures,Letters from Ralph Waldo Emerson and Jean Otthenin. and I had or have next to nothing else to send, shd have gone on friday; but, as is too usual, time failed. I make them ready agt
tomorrow,For the Monday post. before going out into the sunshine, whh we really have to a wonderful degree, worthy almost to be called “Summer,” this last Sunday of the Year. I suppose grim enough days lie beyond;—for ex-[ample]TC omitted the rest of the word at turn of page. in Novr there has been no winter yet, nor anything like frost, or need of roughening one’s horse-shoes.For roughening of horseshoes, see 37:67TC to JCA, 21 Dec. 1860.— We are both of us well, what we call well; indeed for my own part, I am really in full average case; as if I had got little or no permanent damage from this hideous pluister of a Book, whh I can hope is now looking towards its finis. I have done the Battle of Rossbach (Satan thank it!); Battle of Leuthen, Siege of Olmütz lie in the rough (not very bad, I hope): after that there is only Hochkirch,For these Seven Years’ War battles, see Carlyle, Works 17:263–435.—after whh the PrintersRobson, Levey & Franklin. pause; and I too for a couple of months. Rigorous Abridgt, after that: one short Book, I hope will then end the 7-yrs War;“Battle of Hochkirch,” the last chap. of bk. 18 (see Carlyle, Works 17:397–435) was to be followed by two further long books on the Seven Years’ War, making up vol. 6 (1864); see also TC to JAC, 29 Jan. 1863. and then in one other after that—home, like the stick of a rocket! But let me not hollah yet; for I am not yet out of the wood by a long way.For a detailed breakdown of volume and book divisions of the first edn. of Frederick, see 37:259–6037:appendix. On the upper side of my right elbow, outmost ‘process’ of the fore-arm, I have an unpleasant stiffness (something rheumatic is it? got in holding the bridle?)—it is not 2 square-inches in area, and is often practically as if gone altogether: that, and a decided shakiness in my right hand (especially in certain directions, not at all in writing, as you see) are almost my only Friedrich specialties as yet. A musca volitans [spots before the eyes], ever since the French Revolution, has kept me company,See 9:320TC to MAC, 22 Sept. 1837. as you may have heard:—Was thut’s [What does it signify]; keep never minding!Coterie speech; see 22:161TC to JF, 18 Nov. 1847; “Paddy’s rule: Keep never minding“; see JWC’s “Note-Book,” A. Carlyle, NLM 2:110.— I believe it is the Horse Fritz that has kept me alive all this while; salutary, tho’ grown inexpressibly wearisome.

Madame Jane’sJean Otthenin wrote, 23 Dec., thanking TC for his “kind and valued present. … I shall now be able to judge for myself of these tallents, I used to hear with much pride so extolled by others“; presumably books by TC that he intended sending to her; see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. She continued: “[T]he ‘Wee lassie, and her Wee Bonnet’ shall have much satisfaction in renewing an acquaintance so early begun.“ Letter is really gemüthlich [good natured] in spite of the spelling &c: ask her what her children are & how many; especially that “second
daughter” whom Eugène Cavaignac was sponsor for:Otthenin wrote: “Perhaps you are not aware that my second Daughter [Irma], is the God Daughter of General Mr de Cavaignac.” Louis Eugène Cavaignac (1802–57; see 9:91TC to MAC, [25 Nov. 1836]), French politician and general; brother of the Carlyles’ friend Eléanore Louis Godefroy Cavaignac (1801–45; see 7:53TC to JSM, 17 Dec. 1833). how strangely things do jumble abt in this world! And say, some time, that if there are Cartes de visiteVisiting cards with a small photograph on one side; cartes de visite were duly sent; for Madame Otthenin’s, see TC to JAC, 29 April 1863, and for Irma’s, 173TC to JAC, 8 Aug. 1863. A photograph of Margaret Otthenin, the older and ill da., was apparently not sent. of Mother and of Children, I will with pleasure take all of them I can get. And do you “enliven the society“Otthenin wrote: “I count on [your brother] with his gaiety to enliven our little society this winter.“ &c as you are expected!—

Emerson’s Letter will rather disappoint you; nothing in it, abt the Practical State of America, that is not more or less chimerical,—conquering the South, and becoming celestial by emancipating Niggers, and so forth.Emerson reported, 8 Dec.: “The war is our sole and doleful instructor. All our bright young men go into it. … One lesson they all learn,—to hate slavery. … We must get ourselves morally right. … But even the war is better than the degrading and descending politics that preceded it for decades of years.“ Once I find him entirely sincere: where he says I have made a covt with my eyes;Emerson complimented TC’s third vol. of Frederick: “You have lighted the glooms, and engineered away the pits … and have let sunshine and pure air enfold the scene. … I find, as ever in your books, that one man has deserved well of mankind for restoring the Scholar’s profession to its highest use and dignity.” But he continued: “I find also that you are very wilful, and have made a covenant with your eyes that they shall not see anything you do not wish they should.“—not true, I hope, but evidtly sincere.— — I desire more & more details abt Jamie & Household,Their brother James and family living at Scotsbrig. abt native Home in genl;—and send my kindest brotherly regards to one and all. Adieu, dear Brother; I can write a word on the margin tomorrow.TC added no postscript.— Yours ever— T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir WCTSWCT, 30 Dec. 1862. MS: Trevelyan Papers, Robinson Lib., Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SIR WALTER CALVERLEY TREVELYAN

docBody.p:
Accept many thanks for the trouble you have been so kind as take in regard to those Cromwell Documents.Unidentified further. They are curious to look into as footprints
of the actual man;—interesting specimens of his punctual correctness in regard to all matters of justice between self and neighbours,—very little attended to by many Captains of War, especially of Civil War, while fighting for their life and cause!—

Our news of Lord Ashburton are later than your own, but, I fear, not better, if perhaps so good;—at least the last Newspaper paragraphs go beyond what we dare believe.The Daily News reported, 30 Dec.: “The friends of Lord Ashburton will be happy to learn that there is every prospect of his lordship recovering from his recent dangerous illness. The accounts received from Paris on Saturday and the preceeding day were of a more favourable tenor. The noble lord is staying at the Hotel Bristol, but it will be some weeks before he can be expected to leave for the south of France with Lady Ashburton.“ We had a Letter yesterday from Dr Christison, whh I designed to enclose for My LadyLady Paulina Trevelyan. and you, but it has fallen aside:—and I can only find two others, from Mrs Anstruther, a week earlier in date, whh will shew you how very bad things then were. The Dr, who dates Sunday & Saturday last, reports some improvement of symptoms; and still seems to have a hope,—as I too struggle to have, tho’ both Mrs A. and my Wife seem to have little or none; there being such utter weakness; and signs of dropsical swelling in the hands and feet, a thing whh all Doctors regard as of the worst omen in heart-diseases. These dropsical signs, it appears, for a week past, are rather diminishing than otherwise; and the poor Patient still has appetite, still gets sleep; and is heroically calm, and indeed latterly has not much pain.— I myself know not what to think; except that the danger is very great,—but that hope surely is still there, and for the last six or seven days appears to have been increasing rather than otherwise. In my ignorance, that of taking daily a due portion of nutritive food (soups, mutton, game, &c, in fair quantity) seems to me a symptom of high value. But alas, alas—! In fact we do not know!—
With many regards to her Ladyship & yourself, I remain Sincerely yours T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS [JRS], [31 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7012. Pbd: E. B. Chalmers, “Mrs Carlyle’s Letters to John Stodart,” Times Literary Supplement 25 June 1971:740, dated 31 Dec. 1863 (Stodart wrote “1863” in error on the MS). John Riddle Stodart (1793–1871), Writer to the Signet and notary public; JWC’s old suitor; see JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1849, and JWC to JRS, [30 Sept. 1849]. Their last recorded meeting was Aug. 1857; see JWC to TC, [20 Aug. 1857].
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN STODART

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea last day of the Year [31 December 1862].
docBody.p: “A good new-year to you, dear John!“JWC was replying to Stodart’s long letter, 25 Dec., which acknowledged her “scribble in Autumn“; her opening words refer to his closing: “I suppose you never see our old friend Mrs Aitken—they have very poor health & are watering abroad The Doctor had a bad attack of bronchitis in Spring in Edinh, when I saw them both, half dead—he with the complaint & she with watching him—They want stirring up & more variety—Adieu—God bless you tho I reached 70 a few days ago I am hail & hearty & equal to working for my daily bread—Let me have some of your scribble at your leisure & now wishing you a merry Xmas & a happy new year again adieu.” David Aitken (1796–1875) was m. to JWC’s childhood friend and John Stodart’s cousin Eliza Aitken, b. Stodart (ca. 1794–1869); cf. JWC’s description of the Aitkens’ visit to Chelsea, 1858, see 34:33JWC to TC, [11 July 1858].— There!— I can make no nearer approximation, under existing circumstances, to being your “first foot“!— I hope you may find me, so far as I go, a lucky one.

I will write you a nice long letter someday. Today I have been provokingly and unfeelingly interrupted. But it don’t much matter—does it?—whether you and I break silence or not? Each knows that the other is always the sameStodart also wrote: “[T]he fates have decreed that we should have little, very little intercourse, but this has not disturbed my quiet passion, which being somewhat Ideal, is not much affected by the material.“—

The Memorandum in your pocket-book is wrong my Dear! It was on the fourteenth of July, eighteen hundred and one that I, poverina, [miserable little one], had the fatal rashness to get myself born.Stodart mentioned that he had found “in an old memorandum book … the following entry ‘1816 Dec 25 became acquainted with JBW born 17 July 1800.’” He replied, 1 Jan. 1863: “Many thanks Dear Jeanie for your first foot. It is a dear foot with white heels as you mentioned on a former occasion—the Phot. is excellent quite yourself in your best mood—the one you sent me some years ago was une peu dur [a little severe], but the present is pleasing indeed & shall be preserved with all care / ‘Faithful for ever’ & affly / yours / JRS / I shall make the correction on my entry—your note is precious & your letter will be still more so.” JWC presumably sent him one of the most recent photographs by William Jeffrey (see 38:225JWC to JCA, [30 Sept. 1862], and JWC to JDJAD, [29 Jan. 1863], rather than Thomas Douglas’s Aug. 1862 photograph (see 38:178JWC to TC, [31 Aug. 1862]).
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC [JW], [3 Jan.]. MS: NLS 1893.302. Pbd: Huxley, JWC 370–71 inc.
div3.head: JANE WELSH CARLYLE TO JEANNIE CHRYSTAL

docBody.p:
That Photograph gives me the queerest unearthly feeling!For a photograph of Jeannie Chrystal’s da., Mary, see oppabove. I seem to be pitched suddenly back into the year 1820, and seeing yourself—as you lived and looked, when—“what shall I say“?Coterie speech; see 17:36JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1843.—coquetting with Dr Carson or some other of your early admirers.Presumably Dr. James Carson (1772–1843; ODNB), Liverpool physician; for his supposed attraction to JWC, see 5:317TC to JWC, 11 Aug. 1831, and 413TC to JWC, 11 Sept. 1831. I never saw a more perfect likeness—of you!
Mary Chrystal, 1862
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
Mary Chrystal and dog, ca. 1862
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Thanks for sending it, and for sending it on newyear’s day! Your packet and a letter from MaggieJeannie’s sister Maggie Welsh. were the only “delicate attentions“Coterie speech; see 34:50JWC to TC, [16 July 1858]. paid me this newyears day. And my “first foot” was a woman who bores me to death,Unidentified. and who performed that mission quite unconsciously. Well! the newyears day before—I had a quite satisfactory first foot; and beautiful newyear’s gifts—and a great many charming letters,—and God knows the good luck spent itself all on the first day! Three of those who tried to make my year lucky to my imagination, and sent me gifts and letters, were dead, one after another, within two months after! Countess Pepoli, The Countess of Sandwich, and Mrs Twisleton, and except that I got to Scotland for a little change and rest sorely needed, it has been a luckless year, the last, all thro’!— It is time to give up speaking about luck when one has got past sixty— Indeed I am somewhat of the Suffolk Girl’s opinion who justified herself for strangling her aunt and robbing her;Untraced. on the ground that “such old creatures shouldn’t be allowed to live“!

By the way are you not going to get that old Fleming tried and hanged?James Fleming was originally suspected in the murder of Jess McPherson, but instead Jessie McLachlan was found guilty and sentenced to hang; there was some doubt about the conviction and strong public feeling against the sentence, so it was commuted to imprisonment. Many people continued to believe Fleming guilty; see 38:226JWC to JCA, [30 Sept. 1862], and 251JWC to LAI, [30 Oct. 1862]. See also The Trial of Jessie M’Lachlan, ed. William Roughhead (Edinburgh and London, 1911). I can’t conceive how any mortal could believe him innocent! Does he get leave to walk about without stones flying after him?

It is a beautiful kettle-quilt!Pot or kettle holder. so firm, and the pattern so handsome! And I
was needing one! a kiss to the Princess RoyalMary Chrystal; for another photograph of her, with a dog, see oppabove.—and thanks for her bonny little portrait. Kind regards to your HusbandAndrew Chrystal. and a good newyear to you all—/ yours affly/ Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [5 Jan.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:278–79 inc. Quot: Simpsons 149; Hansons, NE 503. TC wrote on MS: “(fragt, 1862—3 Ashbn).” Dated a few days after 1 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
Dear little Woman. A letter was to have preceded that box—a letter of apology for its rubbishy contents—only to be excused indeed by my knowledge from of old, how you could make somethings out of nothings! a capital talent! which I dare say is inherited by these remarkably “world-like” girls of yours But I had been kept in such a constant bother with teaching the new CookMary began work 23 Dec.; see JWC to MCA, [ca. 16 Dec. 1862]. how to make bread and to make everything, that was wanted of her; that I never could find time for writing. and now your kind acknowledgement of the said rubbish shows that my apology was not needed. Oh those Servants! Pity me my Dear! I took this new woman, against my own physiognomic instinct, on account of the four years excellent character given her by her last mistress; and now I am rather afraid my physiognomic instincts are going to be proved the better authority! But I wont lose hope of her in the first month— A person in the early stage of “bettering herself” has a good deal to confuse her. The rough and ready hard-work of a Tradesman’s House and “the curiosities and niceties” of a Gentlemans HouseCoterie speech; TC’s father’s phrase; see 16:322JWC to TC, [28 July 1843]. —not to say the eccentricities of such a house as ours! are so different in their requirements! that patience and effort are needed in both Mistress and maid. And alas! the result is never—at the present day—anything like so remunerating, as it is made in Miss Muloch’s Tale,Dinah Maria Mulock (1826–87; ODNB; see 24:288–89JWC to JF, [13 Nov. 1849]); her novel Mistress and Maid (1863) was serialized during 1862 in Good Words, an Edinburgh monthly magazine. For JWC’s comments on Mulock’s early work, see 24:304JWC to HW, [2 Dec. 1849], and 27:386–87JWC to HW, [30 Dec. 1852]. that your girls were so interested in!— But why not have taken a cook ready trained out of Gentlemens family? simply my Dear, because Cooks ready trained out of gentlemens families, have wages entirely disporportionate to any work they would have here—twenty pounds at the least; andthat is not the worst! all their accommodations are expected to be in keeping
with their wages; and they would look down on people living so economically and quietly as we do! Now, I think it is more pleasant, or rather, less unpleasant to look down on ones promoted “maid of All work,” than to be looked down upon by ones “professed Cook“!

The news from Paris continue more favourable—but it strikes me the DrDr. David Christison sent regular reports to the Carlyles; see TC to Sir WT, 30 Dec. 1862. never quite believes himself the hope he gives to others. There is always a hollow sound in his words about recovery Mr C is angry at my hopelessness. he has so much more hope in him about every thing than I have? Who would believe that to hear how he talks!
I am beginning to receive small contributions of newlaid eggs—I hope I may not need to trouble you for more but will if the hens strike work again
The best of newyear good wishes to you all / yours affly/ Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 6 Jan. MS: NLS 517.43. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:216 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Accept this little Gift,TC’s customary New Year gift of money; he noted: “6 jany 1863 / to Sister Jean (Dumfries) / £10..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). He probably enclosed the check, “6 jany 1863 / to Sister Mary / £10..0..0,” with JWC to MCA, [5 Jan.]. The third check was “6 Jany 1863 / to Jenny (Niece) / £2..13..0” (TC’s checkbook); James Carlyle’s da. Janet (Jessie or Jenny). in memory of the Year just past, and in prospect of the one now to come. We have surely been mercifully dealt with, as our dear Mother used to say!Margaret A. Carlyle; see 18:277TC to AC, 3 Dec. 1844. Often when I look around me, and witness the courses of this world, I am filled with a kind of pious terror; and am ready to denominate myself, as I have heard people do in old days, “a monument of mercy.“See Margaret A. Carlyle to TC, 15 Nov. 1823; Early Letters of Thomas Carlyle, ed. Charles Eliot Norton (1886) 2:242. That is true in spite of all the sorrows & the fightings one has.

I may surely now & then indulge myself with the hope of getting a sight of you again, this year; but I promise myself nothing,—let me only fight along towards doing my own part of the matter, while permitted. Seeing or not seeing, I know the affection you, and all the others, regard me with at all times; and truly it is among my principal possessions still left me. To say and pray, All good be with you, is a very natural thing: it is saying, All good be with myself too.

We continue both of us in tolerable health; Jane taking always rather better with heat, almost at any price. I am kept in perpetual “worry” (as they call
it here); you have no idea what a herd of pigs I have to drive before me thro’ the mud!—

As you saw the Letter to Jack, it tell[s] you all I had to say. He has written half a word to me from Edinr the day of his arrival; nothing at all since. We saw yr Jim,James Aitken, who lived in London. abt a week ago; whole and well.
The news from Paris,About Lord Ashburton. if not quite desperate (whh Jane thinks they are, tho’ I will not let her say so), denote lingering, and very feeble hope. We must take what is appointed.

Adieu, dear Sister. May all good be with you and what belongs to you. I specially send James my kind regards. As poor Edward Irving used to say, “May the worst of our days be past!“Coterie speech; see 32:67TC to RF, 1 Jan. 1857.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JR [DRJR], 6 Jan. MS: NLS 608.607. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:146–48 inc; Simpsons 212 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO DR. JAMES RUSSELL

docBody.p: At last I send you the promised Photograph.Of JWC (or possibly TC) by William Jeffrey, taken Sept. 1862. Ellenor Ruding apparently sent copies Nov. 1862; see 38:253JWC to ERU, [2 Nov. 1862]. For one of TC, see 38:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 38. For JWC’s description of being photographed by Jeffrey in her “last winter’s gown,” see 38:219–20JWC to MR, [21 Sept. 1862]; for one of JWC, see 38:225JWC to JCA, [30 Sept. 1862]; for another, see 30above. It goes along with this note.

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle, by William Jeffrey, September 1862

docBody.p:
You was meant to have had it on newyear’s day but I need to go out for the sheet of millboard,A thick pasteboard to prevent the photographs being bent in the post. and then to cut it the proper size, and all that strange to say took more time than I had at my disposal. You wonder perhaps what a woman like me has to take up her time with. Here for example is one full days work—not to say two— On the newyears morning itself, Mr C “got up off his wrong side” a by no means uncommon way of getting up for him—in these over worked times! And he suddenly discovered that his salvation here and hereafter depended on having, “immediately!—without a moments delay” a beggarly pair of old cloth boots, that the street sweeper would hardly have thanked him for, “lined with flannel and newbound, and repaired generally“! and “one of my women, that is my one woman and a halfFlorence Morrison and Mary. was to be set upon the job! alas! a regular shoemaker would have taken a whole day to it—and wouldn’t have undertaken such a piece of work besides! And Mr C scouted
the idea of employing a shoemaker, as subversive of his authority as Master of the House—so neither my one woman nor my half one having any more capability of repairing “generally” these Boots than of repairing The Great Eastern,For the steamship Great Eastern or Leviathan, see 33:128–29TC to JAC, [7] Dec. 1857. there was no help for me but to sit down on the newyears morning, with a great ugly beast of a man’s boot in my lap, and scheme, and stitch, and worry over it till night and—next morning begin on the other! There you see were two days eaten up very completely and unexpectedly—and so it goes on “always a something” (as my dear Mother used to say)Grace Welsh; see 11:170JWC to TC, [18 Aug. 1839].

But you will find two portraits—what is the meaning of the other?— The meaning of it is; to save myself cutting and hewing at another sheet of millboard, which makes my fingers sore for hours after! The second photograph is for my cousin WalterJWC’s cousin Rev. Walter Welsh, minister at Auchtertool, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Kirkcaldy, Fife.—and when you have taken your choice, I thought you would send on the one you liked least, wrapt up, with the same piece of board (without which they would be crumpled purposely by the letter Carriers who detest such packets[)]—you know his address Auchtertool Kircaldy— I enclose the necessary stamps— The accounts from Paris continue “more favourable” But they sound hollow to me somehow love to Mary
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: why on earth did you send a Dumfries Courier with the Herald dated 12th August! the day after I arrived at Holme Hill!JWC stayed with the Russells 11 Aug.–1 Sept. 1862.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCM, 6 Jan. MS: Robinson Lib., Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd. James Augustus Cotter Morison (1832–88; ODNB), author.
div3.head: TC TO J. COTTER MORISON

docBody.p: I yesterday recd your Book;James Cotter Morison, The Life and Times of Saint Bernard of Clairvaux, A.D. 1091–1153 (1863), which was dedicated to TC; see 38:96TC to JCM, 2 June 1862. and have to return you many thanks for yr kindness and politeness in regard to that affair throughout.

I have the farther pleasure of being able to assure you that I think it very well done, and likely to prove a good Book and extensively acceptable. I read a good way into it last night,—in fact, was cut short by my candles going out;—and this is the judgt I formed, more and more confidently, by degrees. The
style of delineation (not of language only) is clear and solid; the superfluous has been faithfully hammered away; faithful labour everywhere discloses itself to the initiated; and to all classes of honest readers, the narrative flows on with an agreeable charm, as of candid insight, well-regulated sympathy, brevity,—truth in short, whh means everything. I hope well of this Book; and farther that it may be the beginning of still greater from you, in long series thro’ years to come.Morison continued to write, producing many articles, reviews, and short works, including Gibbon (1878) and Macaulay (1882) in the “English Men of Letters” series, ed. John Morley.

closer.salute: Believe me / Yours with much regard/

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [8 Jan.]. Addr: 140. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 8 Jan. 1863. MS: NLS 553.248. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: That miserable PreussJohann D. E. Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse, eine Lebensgeschichte (5 vols. Berlin, 1832–34). contains somewhere the celebrated passage of LoudonBaron Gideon Ernst Loudon (1717–90), Austrian field marshal, who invaded Silesia, spring 1760. the Pommern Regiment “Wir wollen ihm was [We will for him something]—!“The reply made by the heavily outnumbered Prussian Pommern Regiment Manteuffel of Foot to Loudon’s suggestion that they should surrender, 15 March 1760; TC translated as “We will for him something ineffable concoct” (Carlyle, Works 18:211–13). Pommern, on the southern shores of the Baltic Sea, was the German name for the duchy of Pomerania, then divided between Sweden and Prussia, now between Germany and Poland. But I can nowhere lay hold of it (sorrow on all jackasses that write disorderly books and put no index to them!) Perhaps you cd hunt me the passage out; I want to identify the particr Pomern Regt, & see whether it was the one at Leuthen or another.The same regiment that fought at the battle of Leuthen, 5 Dec. 1757; see Carlyle, Works 17:303–4. I am sunk to the centre amid thousandfold rubbish. Ah me!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Pray return me the Emerson LrEmerson’s letter, 8 Dec. 1862; see TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1862 when you have read it.Frederick Pollock (1815–88; ODNB); see 38:95TC to [JHO], 31 May 1862) noted a visit, 9 Jan.: “9th January 1863.— Dine with Froude, and with him to Carlyle at Chelsea” (Sir F. Pollock, Personal Reminiscences [1887] 2:109).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 21 Jan. Addr: 140. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 22 Jan. 1863. MS: NLS 553.249. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I suppose the inclosed is abt our old friend Matinées du Roi de Prusse?TC presumably enclosed the article from Home and Foreign Review (Jan. 1863) by John Emerich Dalberg Acton (1834–1902; ODNB), historian, about his new edn. of Les Matinées Royales, ou l’art de régner, opuscule inédit de Frédéric II (London and Edinburgh, 1863). According to Acton, the manuscript was found at Sans-Souci in 1806 and transcribed by Claude François Méneval (1778–1850), baron de Méneval, private sec. to Napoleon I (1769–1821), emperor of France. Several edns. of Les Matinées du roi de Prusse, écrits par lui même (Berlin, 1766) had been published since its first appearance. TC believed it was not by Frederick, but was a satire, probably by Zacharie Pazzi de Bonneville (1710–80), sec. to the maréchal de Saxe (1696–1750); see 31:89TC to JN, 9 May 1856, Carlyle, Works 12:169–171 and Carlyle, Works 18:181–84. Acton later also came to believe Frederick’s authorship was unlikely. The British Library catalogue classifies the first Les Matinées and all subsequent edns. under “doubtful and spurious” works. I had already seen some glimmer of it in some Newspr lately.William Henry Doeg, booksellerbank clerk, of Barlow Moor, Manchester (see Carlyle, Works 19:188), sent TC a clipping of a letter from the Manchester Examiner about the new edn. of Les Matinées; see TC to AI, 18 March. Are we never to get done with that enormous Platitude, coming out always as a grand Discovery! Human patience fails.

You shd write some brief emphatic Letter to The Times (Times wd be best; but Athenaeum or some place,—and always inclose yr Card of Address in these cases); and put an end forever (signing yr name, as Translator of Frh if you like).Neuberg’s letter, referring to the article in Home and Foreign Review, appeared in the Athenaeum, 17 Feb.; he began, “Will you spare me room for nailing a false shilling to the counter?” (193), detailed the arguments for its inauthenticity, and signed it “the German Translator of Carlyle’s ‘History of Friedrich’” (194).— — At all events, look in upon Wms & Norgate;Williams & Norgate, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden, was the publisher of Acton’s edn. of Les Matinées and of Home and Foreign Review; they were also sellers of foreign books and often acquired books for TC. find what it is;—and let them know what a mighty Pair of Ears (bigger than those of Balaam’s Ass)Cf. Num. 22:21–33. their “Editor,” “Contributor,” their &c &cJohn Acton was ed. of the magazine, author of the article, and ed. of the new edn. of Les Matinées. have put upon themselves!— Yours always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea 21 jany 1863

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [27 Jan. or 3 Feb.]. MS: NLS 608.608B. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:279–84 inc; Simpsons 150–53 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 503. Dated the last Tues. in Jan. or first Tues. in Feb. by similarity to JWC to EWAGW, [2 Feb.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea Tuesday [27 January or 3 February 1863]
docBody.p: You thought I must be ill that I did not write; and now that three days have brought no answer to your inquiry, I shouldn’t wonder if you are thinking I must be dead!

I am only very stupid Dear! uncommonly stupid! not to have learnt, by this time of day, to write off a few lines, when I am hindered by business, or illness, or anything, from writing a good long letter— But there I go on, from day to day, holding my peace, because the season is not convenient for saying all I want to say—leaving my friend to frighten herself at getting no letter at all, just because nothing would content me but that she should get a good long one!— I really must try ammend this stupidity, the result in part of having lived and learnt to write letters, long before the era of Rowland HillRowland Hill (1795–1879; ODNB), civil servant; postal reformer responsible for introducing the penny post, 1840.—when the postage of a letter from London to Scotland was fourteen pence halfpenny and to be paid by the receiver;Until the introduction of the penny post, “postage on letters … varied according to distance and the number of sheets of paper” (M. J. Daunton, Royal Mail: The Post Office since 1840 [1985] 6). so that nobody with a conscience would have dreamt of dispatching letters of only a few lines!

Yes, Dear, you were quite right in thinking things must be wrong with me; when you were so long of hearing. And if you were to guess far into next week, you wouldn’t guess what the matter has been! The first thing to imagine, in the course of nature, especially in midwinter, is, that I have been ill. And in truth I have been far from well—with my old sickness very bad on me, and a weary pain in my back besides; a thing I never had before. But it hasnt been the winter that has hurt me—indeed we have had no winter here yet! only fine spring-like weather, in which even I couldnt manage to be laid up with my usual cold. The illness I have had, and am still having has been caused, palpably enough, by a mental shock which struck me deadly sick at stomach, and struck the pain into my back, in the first moment of it; And tho’ my mind has recovered its balance, these consequences still remain.

One expects to hear of something sentimental, romantic, at least exciting; when anybody speaks of having had a great mental shock. My Dear! lower
your expectations, bring them down to the level of the meanest prose!— For what I have to tell you is again about—my Servants!!! But take up the Servant as a human being—a fellow creature—and read my paltry tale as a phsycological illustration; and it is enough to throw one into a fit of misanthropy—besides making one sick at stomach and breaking one’s spine in two!

When I wrote last, I was looking forward to better times below stairs.JWC’s previous letter may have been JWC to MR, [15 Dec.], when she wrote about the engagement of Mary, the new cook. The new cook seemed a decent young woman, not bright or quick; but who would, with a little teaching and a good deal of patience be made to do— “Flo“Florence Morrison. was clever, and assiduous, and thoughtful and helpful. the only thing to be guarded against with her, was the tendency to praise and pet her overmuch, and so—spoil her; as I had spoilt Charlotte!Charlotte Southam. But I was helped in that by the want of personal attraction for me in the Child. There was something dry and hard, something unyouthful in her manner, and voice, which coupled with her extraordinary cleverness and assiduity, sometimes reminded me of the ‘Changelings’ in Fairy Legends.

Well! As the days went on “a change” seemed to come over ‘the Spirit of’ the new Cooks ‘dream.’Cf. Byron, “The Dream” line 75. She grew more and more gloomy, and sullen, and indifferent; till she grew exactly into her Scotch predecessor translated into English—minus the utter blockheadism!!! I was careful to make no remarks on her before Flo; but Flo was constantly blurting out aggravating instances of negligence and disagreeableness on the part of the new comer. At last one day my dissatisfaction reached a climax; and I told this Mary, that I perceived she would not suit, and that I thought it best to tell her so in the first month. And again my weary Spirit was wandering thro’ space in Search of a Cook, beset by far greater difficulties than “Celebs in search of a Wife“Hannah More, Coelebs in Search of a Wife (1809). The only person that looked delighted was Flo, as delighted as she had looked when I gave Elizabeth warning.For Elizabeth’s dismissal, see JWC to MR, [10 Dec. 1862].

Next day I was just putting on my bonnet to go out on this miserable search, when the Cook said to me; she thought it very strange to be going in this way! that she had “never gone out of any place before in less than a year at the least.” “Whose fault is it?” I said— “Do you consider it possible for me to keep a woman, who shows no sort of interest in doing or learning the work she has undertaken to do here“?— “Well said the woman, with a half sob, I am aware I have made myself very disagreeable; but it wasnt easy, to be good tempered and to try to please; with Flo, every time she came down stairs
telling me the dreadfulest things that you said of me, and of every thing I did“!!! “that I was “nothing but a stupid dirty maid-of-All work, fit for nothing but a Tradesman’s house where I could get tumbling about among a lot of rough workmen“—and Oh far worse things than that!“— astonishment took away my speech for a moment; I had not said ;one word of the woman to the Child—knowing that she carried every thing to her Mother.

I rung the bell for Flo.— “What is all this, I asked that you have been telling Mary—as said of her by me?” “Well Mam said Flo very red, I couldn’t help it! Mary was always asking me what you said about her—you know you were Mary! (like a viper); and I was obliged to tell her something“! “You were obliged to invent horrible lies, were you?“— “If I didn’t tell her something, Mam, she wouldnt leave me along“!— “Oh you wicked girl!” burst in Mary, “What was i asking you when you tried to set me against the Place and the Mistress from the first night I entered the house“!— “i said Flo—“I only repeated what Elizabeth said! “And the Mistress would be a little surprised, said Mary, if I were to tell Her what you told Me!“— “Oh I will tell her myself,” said Flo; “if you please Mam, Elizabeth said, a woman that was her fellow-servant in Scotland, told her before she came here that you were a She-devil! And Elizabeth said that tall chair (pointing to a prie Dieu) was for strapping you to, when you were mad!!!“— It was at this point that the sickness came into my stomach and the pain into my back! “Good God” I said, when I could speak, is it possible that you who have lived beside me these two months, who have never got a cross look or harsh word from me who have seen my behavior to that very Elizabeth, could say the like of this?” “If you please Mam it wasn’t me that said it, it was Elizabeth“! “Oh you lying bad girl” broke in Mary. I see it all now! that you were set on driving me out of the place, and I shouldnt wonder if you did the same by Elizabeth.“

The same thought had just flashed on myself. It was from the day Maria left and this child came, that Elizabeth began to grow, from a mere obedient blockhead, into a sullen, disobliging, blockhead, seeming to rather take pleasure in poisoning Mr C than not!

In her case there wasnt even invention needed. The imp had only to do what I was constantly warning her against viz: to repeat the strong things Mr C said of Elizabeths cookery and self generally, to drive the woman to fury, and make her the unbearable creature she became!

—Flo seeing herself unmasked began to cry very hard—repeating again and again, “you will never be able to bear me again, I know! I have been so treacherous! You were so kind to me! and I was so fond of you! and I have been so very treacherous oooh-oooh oo—oh.“— I didn’t know what on earth to do— I didn’t feel justified in turning her off on the spot— And to keep her was like keeping a poisonous viper at large in the House— The only thing I was clear about was to withdraw my warning to Mary, whose behaviour had been
sufficiently excused by the influences acting on her. Flo’s Mother, hearing of the row came over to try and shift the blame on Mary— I rung the bell and said to Mary, “Mrs Morrison has accusations to make against you Mary—you had better hear them yourself, and answer her—as I know nothing about it.“— And then ensued an altercation, between the two women, (while I sat with my feet on the finderThus in MS; for “fender.“ and my back to them) in which Mrs Morrison came by the worse; having only drawn out a fuller statement of Flo’s horrid conduct. She went away imploring me to “try her (Flo) a little longer—it would be a lesson she would never forget &c &c” And I said “she can stay—for the present, till I see what comes of her.” But three days after the Child herself said “I can never be happy here after having been so treacherous and I had better go away.” I am glad you think so I said so the sooner you go the better today if you like—and in an hour she was gone! My paragone little Housemaid! Three days after she came over—tears all dried—looking hard and bold, to ask me to “see a Lady” for her. “What sort of Character do you think I can give you I asked—“— “Well! said the Child I have told a few lies and I have been treacherous; but that is all you can say against me“! The dreadful child!

I saw a girl,Lizzy. that I thought would suit me, the same day Flo left; but she couldn’t come for a month, and her AuntMrs. Winslade; see JWC to MR, [17 Feb.]. who wished me to wait for her, offered to come and help Mary—till the girl was free— So I have a great jolly clever elderly woman in the kitchen except for the two last days of the week when she is engaged elsewhThus in MS.—and Mary does nicely up stairs— This woman is a capital Cook and I almost wish the present arrangement, tho’ an expensive one, could last—now that I have got used to the big woman, who “thoroughly understands her business“— But she has a Husband and couldn’t stay with me in permanence
Now; do you wonder I fell ill?— (Think of Mr C’s impatience as a running accompaniment to all this disgusting worry!)

Marion’s announcementMarion Kirk, Mary Russell’s servant, apparently thinking of going to America; see JWC to MR, [12 April]; unidentified further. was vexatious enough—but there was no ‘treachery’ to turn your heart upside down.— Still I am very sorry she has taken such a whim in her head; for she saved you a deal of trouble—and your establishment was all so settled looking—that I often envied you in my own changings

You have plenty of time before you to look out; that is one comfort; and another is, taking a new servant in the country where she is known is not such a leap in the dark as taking a Town one; and the greatest comfort of all is; your
Husband is not so awfully impatient as some people’s Husbands, and is a help to you rather than a hindrance in difficulties! But I shall be very glad when you can tell me you have heard of somebody likely to suit—
Lord Ashburton’s convales[c]ence is at a stand— I have never been able till lately to feel the hope of him that Mr C and others felt—and now the accounts are ominous again—
I have written all this at intervals—my back aching too bad for sitting straight up long together
Write to me soon— I need a letter—
I owe your Husband sixpence—please give him these six Stamps—they were left out of my letter to himSee JWC to JRDRJR, 6 Jan. by mistake
God bless you both
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JN], 28 Jan. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s memorandum was almost certainly to Neuberg.
div3.head: TC TO [JOSEPH NEUBERG]

docBody.p: Mem. Mr DonneWilliam Bodham Donne. has more than once told me that Gibbon quotes (or menions with thanks and something of approval) the Mémoires Militaires sur &c (Greeks and Romans) of Guichard,Karl Gottlieb Guichard (1724–75), military writer and soldier who served under Frederick in the Seven Years’ War; Mémoires militaires sur les Grecs et les Romains (The Hague, 1757). Edward Gibbon (1737–94; ODNB) wrote in a footnote that Guichard “treated the subject like a scholar and an officer,” The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776–88) 1:26. —the “Quintus Icilius” of Friedrich.For Frederick’s nicknaming of Guichard, see 28:141–43TC to JWD, 15 May 1853, and Carlyle, Works 18:26–29. Mr Donne wd do me a very special favour if he cd préciser all this for me; i.e. refer me to the pp. (specifying what edition, of the Gibbon Book or Books);For Donne’s reply, see TC to WBD, 9 Feb. so that I cd mark it in a note (in trust on Mr D).
Chelsea 28 jany 1863

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Jan. MS: NLS 526.2. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have got two pleasant little Notes from you; you are very good to write witht ansr. I did intend, last Friday, to ansr; and had laid all my plans: but on proceeding to act, and inquiring what day of the month, I found that it was already Saturday! Such things often enough befal; I am kept in such a hurry and a flurry, not a moment but what is screwed from the press, by force of art! Tonight (Thursday night) I take time by the forelock.Proverbial. Will add, can if needful, a word tomorrow.

We are both tolerably well;—not quite up to par, Jane,—nor I either (broken sleep &c);—but struggling along, not so ill as is often enough one’s case. This tepid Winter has suited Jane extremely: she has never had a cold once that fairly lasted; she hopes now we are past the worse.Thus in MS. Latterly the weather has been really beautiful; clear cool west winds, extremely dry and comfortable; more like Spring than January. This evening I rode by Wimbledon, thro’ the fine solitary roads & Park; all the woods were clean, the fields dry and bright;Presumably Wimbledon Common, SW London, between Putney and Wimbledon, rather than the smaller Wimbledon Park nearby. Wimbledon Common and the neighboring Putney Common were 1,140 acres (460 hectares). in some of the warm spots there seemed even a colour of new green; and birds here and there were attempting a slight note or two of song to one another,—evidtly under the idea that pairing-time was just come.

I had very near decided this week to commence my Two Months now:Printing was to stop for a while after TC wrote the section on the battle of Hochkirch, end bk. 18; TC had hoped to pause also for two months; see TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1862. I am thro’ the Battle of Leuthen,For the battle of Leuthen, see Carlyle, Works 17:309–31. and a very great deal of boggy thickets and difficult places: and some fifty pages more lay to be done, more unmanageable than any. However, I decided, driven by despair, to get thro’ these also before ending; & am now fairly in again (whh is a comfort in comparison). I shall not get loose therefore till well on in February,—abt p. 300, with Hochkirch ended,There are 76 pages between the battles of Leuthen and Hochkirch in Frederick, 1st edn.; for the battle of Hochkirch, see Carlyle, Works 17:397–424. and a new Book waiting me. The new Book abt 100 pages shd end the 7-Years War: it will require all my art of condensation to to“To” repeated on turn of page. pack the
thing into such compass: but I hope I can do it; I must try my very best!Two more books and 583 pages were required to reach the end of the Seven Years’ War; see Carlyle, Works 18. There will be no holiday for me; none;—but I shall not have the printers continually on my heels: and hope in the course of “two months” to have got a good start again, and the hideous busss a good deal subdued! Till fairly out of it, there can be no real rest to me. A wholesome law too I reckon it, That every interest and wish is towards brevity. Courage, Courage yet a little!—

You are perfectly welcome to do what you like with Emerson’s Letter;—if Stirling care to see it, yes by all means.Probably William Stirling (1818–78; ODNB), historian and book collector; M.P. for Perthshire, 1852–68, 1874–78; elected rector of St. Andrews Univ., 1863; old friend of both TC and John A. Carlyle; see 37:104TC to RWE, 29 Jan. 1861. John copied Emerson’s letter, presumably to send to Stirling (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). What you write to me abt the Otthenins has always an interest. I enclose Madame’s Letter to me; don’t be sorry that she wrote it, I got a real pleasure from it;—say I will ansr one of these days; and in the meanwhile that I want (unless it is unpleast to Madame) all attainable Cartes & authentic representatns of Fact.— Poor Lady: something really gemüthlich [comfortable] tho’ terribly jumbled! Good night. Yours ever

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], [29 Jan.]. MS: NLS 1797.148. Hitherto unpbd. Dated in another hand; 1863 confirmed as the correct year by the exchange of photographs.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
My Dear! Having lived so long out of Scotland,—“away amang tha wild Folk” (as our dear old BettyBetty Braid. described my present position) it is not surprising that the greater number of “the three thousand Proprieties“Cf. “Three thousand punctualities“; coterie speech; see 27:279JWC to JRS, [10 Sept. 1852]. should have fallen obsolete for me! But I still recollect and conform to a few of them; from the force of Early Training. This one, for example; to always “make a suitable return“Coterie speech; see 19:227JWC to JW, [29 Sept. 1845], and 24:283JWC to JAC, [10 Nov. 1849]; phrase of William Gibson (see 19:20TC to JCA, [17 Aug. 1835]), old friend of the Welsh family. got itself stuck into my mind ineradicably at Haddington, where it was proper for nobody to just take a hospitality—a kindness, and be pleased with it, and humanly grateful for it; but immediately there must arise the thought of “a suitable return” and the hospitality, the kindness must lie a burden on the squeamish conscience, till it was paid back! And this “suitable
return” has been a source of occas[i]onaly worry to me up to the present date; tho’ the “wild Folk” I have lived amongst for nearly thirty years have not the phrase in their vocabulary, nor the idea in their minds; so far as I have observed; and tho’ the kindnesses they have lavished on me have mocked all idea of possible ‘return’!— What is all this leading to; you wonder! upon my word I don’t know myself, what it is leading to!!! I have so overshot the point I had in view at starting!, which was simply to excuse my delay in answering your kind letter and thanking you a thousand times for the enclosure; on the ground that I had been waiting till the Photographer had light and leisure to print me some more Cartes of Mr C and myself, that I might show my scotch breeding in sending you a pair,Presumably two of the photographs taken by William Jeffrey, Sept. 1862. as—“a suitable return“— That I should have contrived to spread such a speck of meaning into two pages of writing seems to indicate a talent for writing Three Vol: Novels, which might have made a rich woman of me if I had cultivated it! And if I had become rich, by that, or any other means, wouldn’t I have built, immediately a pretty Cottage by the sea shore, somewhere between North Berwick and Dunbar;Small towns on the East Lothian coast. and gone to it every summer; and set up a pony carriage; and driven all the roads, I used to go with my Father!See Carlyle, Reminiscences 67–68. Bless me! If I had thought of that use of money sooner I would positively have tried to make some!— I am afraid it is too late to think of it now! too little life left me, for making anything better of, than what it is!— To keep it what it is I find difficult enough!—

But your photograph looks as if you had no weight to carry. So bright, and elastic! It is a capital photograph and a capital likeness! a pleasing one too which photographs of women very rarely are.No photograph of Jane Dods survives in JWC’s albums.

If you have one of your Husband, like the one you gave me, I wish you would send it, and I would return the former one, which has got a little of the carte cut off at the top, which gives me the feeling of his being in a room with a painfully low ceiling! It happened thiswise; when I was last in Scotland I set up a second Photograph book for relations and very old friendsPossibly bought in Edinburgh, Sept. 1862; see 38:196JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1862]. JWC bought her first album April 1861; see 37:140JWC to IEB, [3 April 1861]. For an untrimmed photograph of William Dods, see 64JWC to JAD, 21 Feb.. and I thought your Husband would be better placed there, than between Lady Ashburton and the Editor of The ExaminerJWC probably refers to the Carlyles’ close friend John Forster, editor of the Examiner 1847–55. The current editor was Henry Morley (1822–94; ODNB). with neither of whom he had the slightest affinity. Besides I was being constantly bothered by people taking him for Lord ElginJames Bruce (1811–63; ODNB), 8th earl of Elgin. and wondering they “hadn’t known till now, that
Lord Elgin was a friend of mine.” So I transfered him from the one book to the other, and in the course of the operation injured the top, and had to cut off some half-inch.

I had such a dear long letter from Mrs D DavidsonJanet Davidson (1782–1869; see 32:196TC to JWC, [23 July 1857]), Craighope House, Court St., Haddington; a friend of Jane Dods and aunt of David Davidson (1811–1900; see 35:25525:biographical notes), rtd. maj., army engineer, and inventor, childhood friend of JWC. whom I had taken it into my head I was never to see the handwriting of anymore—
She asks me for a photograph, bless her! I would have sent her one without asking; if I had fancied she cared about such things admist her weary pains!

Remember me very kindly to your sister.JWC probably meant Jane Dods’s eldest sister, Marion Wilkie (1803–78), who lived in Haddington with the middle sister, Mary Ann Wilkie (1806–82); see 36:34JWC to JAD, [31 Dec. 1859].— As for your Husband, he has grown so grumpy, that the most charming message from me would be thrown away on him. So I content myself with wishing him heartily well, and the utmost satisfaction in his grumpiness
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [late Jan.]. MS: NLS 517.67. Hitherto unpbd. Dated with reference to the pause in the printing but not in the writing of Frederick and to the mild weather with west winds; see TC to JAC, 29 Jan. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 30 January 1863.]
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Alas, dear Jean, yr kind prognostications and anticipations are affecting to think of; and make me sad as well as grateful. There is no “holiday” in store for me this great while; far enough from that! The “two months” I had and have in view, are two months of freedom from the Printer trampling on my heels; but not from the intolerable mass of confusion whh I am bound to work at, all days and hours, till I get it ended, and it go thundering downhill forever and a day, like Christian’s Burden in the Pilgrim’s Progress!Cf. Bunyan’s hero, Christian, in Pilgrim’s Progress; see 36:222TC to LLA, 2 Sept. 1860. No rest is possible for me in the world till then. Let me stand to it with the whole strength left me, and get rid of it in the name of Heaven!— My heart, I calculate, will not quite break; tho’ truly I have eaten much more dirt by the long adventure than I durst have calculated as being able for. Courage, courage still!— — It will be abt the end of Feby before I dismiss the Printers; half of the Vol. (or in bulk nearer ¾) fairly printed and done: but what remains will then need my very best judgt, and I doubt be the heaviest pull of all. I am pretty well in health,—only under a kind of intestinal crisis just now
(a Spasm of contradiction to what has gone before), whh I think will perhaps improve me before long. Our weather is much better than yours; dry generally, with beautiful sunshine by times, and almost always brisk westerly winds. I rejoice to hear of the new House; and to anticipate seeing it before very long! Tell James to call on me; he has been absent long.James Aitken visited around New Year; see TC to JCA, 6 Jan. I am excessively busy; but write you this flying scroll before beginning anything else. Eggs daily, and Notes often, bring me in mind. Blessings with you. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [late Jan.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by the servant crisis and similarity to JWC to MR, [27 Jan. or 3 Feb.]. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 31 January 1863.]
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: Another instance of what I was telling your DaughterProbably Kate Stanley, who lived with her mother at Alderley Park, Cheshire; JWC also corresponded regularly with Lady Airlie, another of Lady Stanley’s das.—that I had degenerated from a woman into a sort of paper kite, blown wherever the wind of Circumstance listed!—a particularly flagrant instance too; considering how pleased I was to receive your letter; and how it somehow went to my heart! (for even in my paper-kite phase I have still some heart “to speak of“)Coterie speech; see 17:63JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1843.

There was here and there, in that letter of yours, a soft sad tone, that I never heard come out of you before, and which gave me the impression of having been struck from your heart-strings by some sharp touch of suffering bodily or spiritual. I wished myself beside you; that I might pray you to tell me where the ache was; and see whether I had perhaps some comfort for it—out of my own experience of suffering! And yet I have not so much as thanked you for that letter till now! poor human paper-kite that I am!

The hindrances to letter-writing in these last days have been not a whit more dignified than old-boots to mend! But I begin to think that any woman “here down“Coterie speech; see 17:33JWC to TC, [9 Aug. 1843]. For the “old-boots to mend,” see JWC to JRDRJR, 6 Jan. (as Mazzini says), who objects to putting herself to undignified uses, may as well send at once for sixpennyworth of arsenic, and carry herself and her Dignity “where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary are at rest!“See Job 3:17.

If I were in good spirits I could make an amusing story for you out of my last troubles. The materials are lying there invitingly. But I am in the worst of
Spirits — I have just been deceived, betrayed, made a fool of! and my present mood is more like that of Timon of AthensIn Shakespeare’s play, Timon of Athens was a man driven to misanthropy by the false and treacherous behavior of people he had thought were his friends. (!) than anybody I could name! And the individual who has converted me into a Mrs Timon of Athens for the time being is — a child!! a small Girl of fourteen,Florence Morrison. whom I took some three months ago, to train into a housemaid, and attach to us while her heart was impressionable, and that sort of thing! (Conceive such egregious folly at my age!) This little girl was more like a Sprite than a mortal child; so clever! so assiduous! so thoughtful! so helpful! She learnt far faster than I could teach, and subdued even Mr C’s impatience with new servants, which keeps me in a continual tremor for the first month. Lying awake at nights I sometimes thought it would be advisable to make some sort of Adoption of this Child—at all rates, that I would leave her a small annuity when I died (a very small one it would need to be!) and my only difficulty with her in the meantime was to keep myself from spoiling her with too much praise and indulgence. In this I was aided by the girl’s want of personal attraction. There was something strangely dry, hard, and unyouthful in her manner and voice; tho her face was honest and open as day! In fact she often reminded me of the Changeling in old Fairy ballads.

But as little “Flo” grew in favour, the Scotch CookElizabeth. grew out of favour. She had always been a Blockhead,—A “Mooncalve,” Mr C said—but now she exhibited a sulkiness, a doggedness which coupled with dinners that looked (I quote again from Mr C) “as if they had been cooked in The Infernal Regions“—(so burnt and blackened every thing was!) became unbearable, and tho’ horrible the idea to meCoterie speech; see 18:83JWC to TC, [25 June 1844]. of changing in winter, I gave her warning next! A new cookMary. stept on the scene, who had a good three years character and for the first few days I augured well of her; but by the end of the first fortnight, she had turned to be exactly like the Scotch one translated into English! the same sullenness and doggedness, and indifference whether Mr C was ” poisoned” or not!— I began to think the House was bewitched; and to wish myself any where else,—in a model Prison,JWC and TC visited the Pentonville Model Prison, 2 Jan. 1851; see 26:4TC to JAC, 1 Jan. 18511 Jan. 1851, and 8–9JWC to JWE, 7 Jan. 1851. or a Private Mad House, or, say, in that Picturesque Hospital for Ideots!!Possibly a lunatic asylum that JWC had seen with Lady Stanley during her visit to Alderley Park, 22–28 Aug. 1860; she also wrote favorably of the Lunatic Asylum, Wandsworth, Surrey, where she visited and walked in the gardens with Richard Plattnauer in 1844; see 18:191JWC to JW, [22 Aug. 1844]. Any contact with a “Private Mad House” is unidentified, but JWC might have known one that Plattnauer was admitted to during one of his breakdowns. Meanwhile I told
the new Cook she wouldn’t suit, and lay awake all night wondering if any body ever would “suit” again! But “it is a long lane that has no turning“!Proverbial. Next morning the Cook came to me, to say; she “was aware she had made herself disagreeable, but that it wasnt easy (with a sob) to be good tempered and to try to please, with Flo every time she came down stairs repeating dreadful things I said about her (the Cook) and her performances“! I had never spoken one word about the Woman, either to The Changeling or in the Chang[e]ling’s presence. But she had invented such clever, cruel, stinging speeches for me! that when she was called up to be charged with them, and could not deny them, I stood amazed before that Child “as in Presence of The Infinite“!Coterie speech; see 35:38JWC to GEL, 20 Feb. 1859. — A “searching cross examination” brought it clearly out that my paragon of a Child, that I was thinking of leaving a small annuity to when I died, and who had seemed ready to fly up the chimney for me—or anything—while I yet lived, had occasioned the dismissal of the Scotch Cook, and all but done the same by the present one. and was the most cold-blooded, systematic Imp of mischief I ever heard tell of in such small compass! When completely unmasked she turned on me a look that suggested arsenic, and said “Well! I have told a few lies, and I have been treacherous—very treacherous—but that is all you have to say against me!!“— This explosion (with strong smell of sulphur) of my ideotic dream, to attach a servant to me while still a Child, occurred on the same day that I received your letter, and made me so ill,—so sick at heart and at stomach,—so sleepless,—so humiliated in my “finer sensibilities,“Coterie speech; see 30:167JWC’s Notebook, 13 April 1845. that I could settle to nothing; not even to answering that kind letter of yours; but went mooning about, doing “here a little and there a little“See Isa. 28:10. in the Housemaid line—to cover, so far as Mr C was concerned the deficiency of service produced by the Changeling’s sudden restoration to the bosom of her admiring Family. For the rest, the disenchanted Cook works so well and willingly by herself, that I am reminded of Rowland Hill’s saying; “If you want to be well served keep one servant; keep two and you will be half served; keep three and you may serve yourself“!Elizabeth Welsh wrote to JWC, 1 Jan., commenting on her servant situation: “The secret of their doing better at first than afterwards is, their willingness to do their work for a while, after going to a new place. I am almost glad we cannot afford to keep more than one. Even that I would dispense with if I could, sometimes. You have probably heard Rowland Hill’s opinion of servants, it was this, keep one servant, and you will get your work done, two and you will get it half done, three and you may do it yourself.” Rowland Hill’s saying otherwise untraced. I often
wonder how rich people who, like you, keep a whole regiment of servants manage to get their work done! Perhaps with servants as with Lovers, “there is safety in numbers“!Proverbial.—

Such has been the terrific Tempest (in a Teapot) which it has required all my strength of body and mind to merely stand up against! Better perhaps to have said in two polite lines; that I had been suffering from a severe bilious attack which had made it impossible for me to write, or do anything with my head— Certainly better; had I been writing to a mere fine Lady; but your charm for me, dear Lady Stanley, is your intense humanness! and it is in virtue of that, I am giving you these human, tho “ungenteel” details.

“Let us now ascend the steps of the social ladder“! (as an americain Miss Sedgwick wrote in a Book, when about to describe, a party at Lansdowne House, after describing “a Tea at the Carlyles“)Catherine Maria Sedgwick (1789–1867) wrote: “[W]e have scaled the ladder of evening entertainments here, going from a six—o’clock family tea up to a magnificent concert at L— [Lansdowne] house; and the tea at this home-like hour was at Carlyle’s. He is living in the suburbs of London, near the Thames; my impression is, in rather an humble way; but when your eye is filled with a grand and beautiful temple, you do not take the dimensions of surrounding objects; and if any man can be independent of them, you might expect Carlyle to be” (Letters from Abroad to Kindred at Home [1841] 1:85). For Sedgwick’s visit to the Carlyles, 25 June 1839, see 11:142TC to RWE, 24 June 1839; see also 13:250; for JWC’s earlier reference to Sedgwick’s comparison, see 26:276JWC to HW, [22 Dec. 1851]. Lansdowne House was the London home of Henry Petty-FitzMaurice (1780–1863; ODNB), 3rd marquess of Lansdowne, politician; one of the most influential men of the age.— My last letter from Dr Christison, dated three days back, represented Lord Ashburton as still progressing tho’ slowly towards recovery. He (Dr C) had no hope of Lord A’s being able to reach Nice. The greatest change he contemplated for him, was removal to some sunnier part of Paris.The Ashburtons moved to a house in the rue des Bassins, Paris, in Feb.; see JWC to MR, [17 Feb.], and Surtees, Ludovisi 93. “By the time he (Lord A) could be hoped to have stren[g]th for a further journey the Nice Season would be over.” Yesterday I had a few lines from Lady A herself—chiefly to ask if I was ill, that I had not written—but, without entering into any particulars, she said Lord A’s state “was not so satisfactory” and her “hopes were very low“! But Dr C cautioned me against being alarmed by any despairing expressions of Lady A’s, unless he wrote to confirm them. She was so devoted to her Husband he said, and so nervous from the long anxiety about him, and great bodily fatigue she took on herself; that her spir[i]ts were raised and depressed without any adequate cause.

Poor Lady William Russell hardly ever quits her bed now—and only to be
wheeled on a sofa into a room on the same floor!Lady William Russell presumably did not remain an invalid; for JWC’s visits to her, see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187. And she was the “bright peculiar Star“For “bright particular star,” cf. All’s Well That Ends Well 1.1; for “bright peculiar star,” see Charles and Mary Lamb, “All’s Well That Ends Well,” Tales from Shakespeare (1807). of London once! What strange sad dreams of bygone times she must have on that bed of hers! What a strange sad world it is! faithfully yours anyhow Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW and GW [EWAGW], [2 Feb.]. MS: NLS 608.614A. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:497–98. JWC wrote on “Monday night“; dated here by the servant crisis.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZABETH WELSH AND GRACE WELSH

docBody.p: If any one had told me, when I was so glad over your nice, long clever letter,Elizabeth Welsh wrote 1 Jan. that I shouldn’t answer it till the first day of Spring;In the ancient Celtic calendar, 2 Feb. was “Imbolc,” the first day of spring, halfway between the winter solstice and the spring equinox. JWC’s last letter, arriving at the Welshes, Wed., 31 Dec., was probably written either 29 or 30 Dec. 1862. She apparently enclosed a copy of vol. 3 of Frederick as Elizabeth Welsh replied: “I received your letter yesterday, with the accompanying Book, for which I return you many thanks. I do not know whether I shall like the Book, or not, but I appreciate the kindness which prompted you to send it. I am glad to hear that your health is pretty good at present, and that your new domestics are installed into Office.” Further comments indicated some of the contents of JWC’s letter: “Poor Lord Ashburton, I am afraid his course is nearly run, if not already finished, his death must make a great blank, to you and Mr Carlyle. I was amused with your account of Mr Alexander’s introducing himself to Mr Carlyle he is very eccentric, but withall, has considerable ability.” For the Rev. Thomas Alexander, see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March. I should have been tempted to box his, or her ears, for a prediction so improbable, and so discreditable to me, as a niece, and as a human-being!— Yet; so it is! And looking at my delay, from the point of view, of one informed of all the facts of the case; I am not so troubled in conscience as you might expect!

But it is difficult, within the compass of a letter, to lay the facts of the case before another; the more; that the facts are rather contemptible in themselves, and can have no interest for another, except thro’ that others sympathy with my own trouble— —some share in them.
