And alas! it is not always, that others, even Aunts, are in a sympathetic mood! or that oneself is in a mood to rely on sympathy!— But here I had better say, to myself, what Mr C often says to me; “For God’s sake my Dear! do hasten to the Catastrophe!“Coterie speech; see 20:6JWC to TC, [1 Oct. 1845]; cf. Sartor Resartus 111 and Frederick, Carlyle, Works 17:263.—

Well my Dears! The roof has been nearly blown off my House! (figuratively speaking) and I have had a severe bilious attack from the shock (without figure of speech). and am still as far from well as a woman, making no outcry, and sitting upright on a chair, writing a letter to an estimable Aunt, could easily be!

When I last wrote to you, there was no indication of Storm brewing in my household. On the Contrary a blessed Calm had fallen on Mr C’s temper, and speech; during dinner-time especially! He seemed to take it for granted no more “poison” would or could be presented to him, since “Mooncalve” had taken her departure. The new Cook tho neither an experienced or clever servant, got on, with my instructions quite as well [as]Word omitted by JWC. I had expected, and her attention and willingness gave promise that she would soon be able to get on by herself. As for the little Housemaid, she had been satisfactory from the first hour; learnt faster than I could teach her; was assiduous, thoughtful, helpful!— The only danger I foresaw in her case was the danger of spoiling her by over-praise and over-indulgence. I found a certain protection against that, in the child’s want of personal attraction for me. In spite of her honest open face, and tidy figure; there was something hard, dry, unyouthful in her appearance and voice, which often reminded me of the “Changelings” in Fairy lore! But I had had enough of “the finer sensibilities of the Heart” with Maria!Maria Chamberlayne. I was better pleased that her small successor should be service able rather than loveable, or loving. Such was the state of my domesticities at the beginning of the year; and such as it was I was thankful for it!

But presently a shadow fell on the new Cook, and darkened day by day; till I found her spiritless, careless, disobliging—in fact exactly the Scotch Elizabeth (mooncalve) translated into English. Finding no improvement on the woman, after a week of this sort of thing, I decided—with horror—but still decided to part with her at once— So I told her “I was sorry to find she would not suit, so she had best know it in the first month.” She looked surprised, but made no answer. Of course I got no sleep that night for thinking about having to go forth into the wide world again in search of a Cook; and wondering if I ever would find one “to suit” again!— And whether the Frost would come first, and lay me on my bed, with the house in this unsettled state! I did not talk to Flo (the Changeling) on the matter, because I knew she had a gossiping Mother who encouraged her to tell every thing out of the house; but the Child showed her sympathy by redoubled attentions, and by blurting out in the most innocent way her indignant feelings towards this fellow servant who “wasn’t in the least fit for a gentleman’s house.” The next day I was getting ready to go out on my irksome business when the Cook came to me, and
asked in a subdued tone, when I was intending that she should leave? “After a months warning of course“— She still hung about, and then said plaintively; it was the first time she had ever left a situation in less than a year at the least. “I ask yourself, I said, was it possible for me to go on with you; when you neither do, nor show any wish or intention to do the duties of the Place you had undertaken?“— “Oh, said she, with a half sob, I know I have made myself very disagreeable; but indeed Mam, it wasn’t easy to be good tempered, and have any spirit for my work, whenFlo—every time she came down stairs, repeated such dreadful things you said about me, and about everything I did! That I was nothing but a dirty Maid-of-All work—only fit for a Tradesman’s House where lots of rough workmen were tumbling about me—and Oh far worse than that!” I could only utter, aghast, the one word ‘Flo’?— But I rung the bell, and when Miss Flo answered, I said, “what on earth is all this? What have you been telling Mary, as said of her by me? me who have never made a single remark on her to you, or in your presence!“— “Well Mam, said the Changeling flushing scarlet, I couldn’t help it! Mary was always asking me what you said about her— You know you were Mary!— And I had to tell her something or she wouldn’t let me alone“! “Oh you bad wicked girl! broke in Mary; what was I asking you, when from the first days I was here, you were always trying to set me against the Mistress and the place. The Mistress would be a little surprised if I were to tell her all you said to me.“— “Oh you may tell her said Flo, at bay; I will tell her myself! If you please Mam it wasnt I that said anything against you; I only repeated what Elizabeth said. She said, if you please Mam, that a fellow servant she had in Scotland, knew all about you, and told her before she came here—that you were a she-Devil!! and known all over Dumfries, where you came from for that! and Elizabeth said it must be true, because she had seen plenty of letters come to you with the Dumfries postmark!!! (Elizabethian logic!)— I turned deadly sick at this point, and a pain struck into my back; which sickness and pain havn’t left me to the present hour! “Child Child! I said is it possible that you who have never had a cross look or a harsh word from me, whom I have treated more like a Mother than a Mistress who saw my behaviour to that very Elizabeth, could speak of me with such disrespect“?— “It wasnt me that said it—I only repeated what Elizabeth said—” I took no further part in the dialogue; I was too sad and sick; but Mary took it up, and said what had just flashed on myself, “Nobody knows what Elizabeth said or didn’t say! I only know you have been trying all along to drive me out of this place; and I dare say you did the same by Elizabeth! that you made her bad, with your lies and tale-bearing, just as you were making me. I have no doubt she did, the little Imp of Satan! It was after that Flo came, that Elizabeth from being simply a Blockhead became a sullen, disobliging Blockhead, to whom I was forced to give warning! The altercation between the two, carried on, in my presence, disclosed depths of deceit and
falsehood and malevolence in that Child—that has made me misanthropical ever since! Finding herself unmasked, and the warning to Mary withdrawn, the Imp took to weeping and shrieking, “Oh she had been so treacherous! so very treacherous! And I had been so kind to her—so very kind! and she had been so fond of me! and I would never be able to like her again! hoo—hooo-hoooo!” This sort of thing went on at intervals for two days—while I was considering what to do with her. The voice of Nature was for packing her neck and crop out of the house! It was like having a serpent gliding at large about one’s room. But her Mother came and whinnered and besought me to “think it over“—and while thinking it over, I was fortunately cut out of my difficulties by the Imp herself, coming to me, all dried up, and defiant, to say she “had been so treacherous (odd word for a child) that she could never be happy beside me again, and so had better go home.” “You are right I said and the sooner the better—today if you like“!— And in half an hour after, the paragone of small Housemaids was gone! A few days later she came to ask me to “see a Lady” for her—what sort of character do you expect me to give you“? I asked— “Well! said the Imp with a toss of her head, “I have told a few lies, and I have been treacherous; but that is really all you have to say against me!” The discomfort of this explosion has been chiefly mental it sickened me to the heart, and still worse to the stomach. But the House has been going on far better than usual. I engaged a girl of seventeenLizzie. the very day of Flo’s departure but couldn’t have her for a month; and in the meantime the girls Aunt, an elderly married womanMrs. Winslade. who had been Cook in “Gentlemens Family” comes every day to officiate in the kitchen while Mary grown altogether pleasant and serviceable is what they call “up stairs.“— The arrangement is a rather expensive one; but oh! the comfort of it to my body and mind, wearied with such a long spell of running after and looking after!— For this elderly woman is a servant of the old school, who “thoroughly understands her business,” hates being a minute idle, has every thing bright as a new pin, and sends up little dinners, which, consist of what they may, are perfect “works of art!“

In calculating the cost of her, I should count in capital lessons in cookery thus given to my own Woman, if she have the sense to attend to them! Besides my own woman is learning meanwhile her new functions under most favourable auspices. The Girl coming in a fortnight is engaged as kitchen-maid—to be under Mary—that I may have as little bother as possible with her; and Mary is to be house-maid, parlour-maid, valet, Ladys-maid, and needlewoman, as well as head-Cook! She likes this arrangement; so I look forward to the new girl with less nervousness than new girls and new
anythings usually inspire me with. But tho’ the house is going smoothly, and Mr C has nothing to drive him wild, (which is easy enough to do); the sickness at stomach and pain in my back, struck into me by the shock of finding “that bit wise lassie” (as Mr C used to call her) a bit wise serpent; still hang about me, after all the practical disturbance of her has passed away!
I have had to write this long screed at thrice, not being able to sit straight up for half an hour together.
Since I began the last little sheet, I have received a volunary letter from Grace. So I will devote the remaining white paper to her.
Your loving Niece Jeanie Welsh Carlyle
Monday night

My dear young woman!Elizabeth was the eldest and Grace the youngest of the Welsh sisters; like JWC, Grace was b. 1801. I make you my compliments and shall get to have some faith in you (as a correspondent) if this sort of thing goes on! But I wish you could have given me a better account of yourself. I know what a wearing misery that neuralgia is! I too have had it in my head and face, till I have been nearly, indeed once altogether delirious. My long winter illness usually commence in that way—an intense toothache (as it were) all thro’ my head and face that leaves me no moment’s ease, day or nightElizabeth wrote: “Grace’s complaint is chiefly rheumatism in her head or something of that character. She suspected the root of a decayed Tooth was the cause of her uneasiness, and had it taken out, but it has failed to give the relief she expected.“— Sometimes I have had morphia given for it—and derived from it the questionable benifitThus in MS. of having that form of my illness changed into some other form, as ill to bear! Besides where it is, as in your case, a malady of long continuance, Morphia would be unsafe to take for even temporary relief. What my Dr recommends is very nourishing diet in the most concentrated form. No weak broths! or what we used to call “slaisters“!—but soup strong enough to be called “essence of beef“—juicy mutton chops and that sort of thing and two glasses a day of good sherry— I dare say you are, as I used to be, unwilling, and ashamed to be at much expense with yourself. But every consideration is to be postponed to the duty of keeping ones soul in a healthy body if one can. Do feed yourself up—if milk agrees with you; there is nothing more nourishing than a tumbler of new milk with a table spoonful of rum in it—twice a day.

I was meaning to give Elizabeth a lecture about her carelessness in feeding herself—with such a bad digestion as she has!Elizabeth wrote: “There are few things I dare eat, and these I am obliged to take so sparingly, that I have constantly to practice self denial, and yet with all the care I take, I cannot ward off these fits of indigestion. I think fatigue, and cold, are predisposing causes.“ I am sure if she would take
her nourishment in a more concentrated shape, she would find a difference! I dont believe Mr C could have lived thro this Book if it hadn’t been for his horse exercise and his almost daily breakfast cupful of clear essence of beef. When I told him about Elizabeth’s attacks, he said “did you tell her to take my strong gravy soup? write and tell her, that; i can match anybody in the British dominions for a bad digestion; and I consider myself to have been kept so long alive, by that one article of food.“
If you would like our receipt for making it, tell me—
And now my letter has reached a length very incompatible with a backache

You say no word of Ann?Elizabeth wrote: “Ann is often ailing, but when she wishes to do any thing, she breaks through all restraint, and goes out.“ My dear love to you all and severally.Elizabeth wrote: “I agree with you about the folly of wishing people happy new years. I rather think I go beyond you, for I am persuaded that since Adam fell, no human being, young or old, has had one day of unbroken satisfaction, much less a year of happiness. We must look to another world than this for happiness. Now for my good wishes, I wish you may have fewer annoyances this year, than the last, a moderate share of bodily health, and as Free ‘Church people would say’ that your Soul may be in health and prosper. My Sisters unite with me in love and good wishes to you, and Mr Carlyle.” The Welsh aunts were evangelical members of the Church of Scotland. Your affectionate/ Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW [TWO], [5 Feb.?]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated very tentatively here, with reference to the mild winter and to Mary, who was at Cheyne Row between Dec. 1862 and Nov. 1864. Woolner was away in Jan., but returned by the beginning of Feb. (Woolner 230).
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: Dear Mr Woolner your umbrella was recognised by Mary and put carefully away for you
Your note came yesterday I believe but I have only seen it within this hour having had a bad fit of illness—caused my DrDr. Alfred Barnes. says by the heat!
I am getting better—but not able to be up yet
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[MO], [7? Feb.]. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 1:131–32. Recipient identified and letter dated “Autumn, 1843 (?)” by A. Carlyle; JWC did not know Oliphant until 1860; see TC to UC, 6 May 1861. Dated here by the description of TC as a “victim” from his accident on Fritz, 6 Feb. (see TC to JAC, 13 Feb.), and JWC’s sickness in reaction.
div3.head: JWC TO [MARGARET OLIPHANT]

docBody.p: Dearest—Your kind words would waken “a soul under the ribs of death,“See Milton, Comus 11.561–62. and I am not dead, only extremely sick, having been shattered all to shivers yesterday, and having slept none or next to none last night.
You may fancy my desperation to have been considerable, when I rose in the middle of the night, and took some doctor’s stuff with prussic acid in it, by guess, in the dark!

The victim himself [Carlyle]A. Carlyle’s insertion. looks tolerably composed, is “consuming his own smoke,“Coterie speech; cf. 7:33JWC to EA, [9 Nov. 1833]. “To consume your own choler, as some chimneys consume their own smoke“; see Carlyle, Sartor 113. in a manner which rather frightens me by its novelty, as my Mother once, after lecturing me on the impropriety of crying when I hurt myself, nearly fell into fits on hearing me fall down stairs and utter no cry after it. I wish he would growl a bit.
Margaret Oliphant, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

God bless you and keep you always as happy as one can be in this weary world; for you do what is possible to make other people happy.For a photograph of Margaret Oliphant, possibly taken around this time, see 54. I will speak about Saturday on Friday.— Here come people.— Oh me!

div3.sourceNote: TC-[WBD], 9 Feb. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [W. B. DONNE]

docBody.p:
Many thanks for your prompt kindness in the matter of Quintus Icilius.Karl Gottlieb Guichard; see TC to [JN], 28 Jan. This is amply all I wanted about him; and it comes perfectly in time;Donne wrote, 5 Feb.: “I believe the extracts herewith inclosed contain all you may wish for. But if you would prefer a transcript of all that Gibbon says about Quintus Icilius I will most gladly send you ‘all’— What follows is an account of the contents of the Mé moires Militaires. / I wish you had set me a more difficult task than this, in order that I might the better prove my esteem and respect for you.” Donne enclosed various quotations from Gibbon’s Memoirs of my Life and Writings, 2 vols. (1796), including: “I diligently read and meditated the Mémoires Militaires of Quintus Icilius (Mr Guichard) the only writer who has united the merits of a professor and a veteran” (MS: NLS 1768.45; Gibbon 1:97); see also Carlyle, Works 18:29. so that I
have him now altogether in hand without farther trouble. His Book is not in the Museum; but ought to be,—if there were anybody studying Ancient History with a real desire to understand it. I believe Guichard is the one Writer hitherto who understood both Greek and the Art of War;—a man of real sense, too, whh is another singularity.

Since you left No 12,Donne was chief librarian, London Lib., 12 St. James’s Sq., until 1857. I have hardly seen yr face at all;—indeed had you staid, I had been little better off; being constantly sunk to the centre amid sordid Prussian rubbish ever since, and without society except my Horse and the Nightmares. If I were out,—as ought to happen now before very long,—I will hope to see you sometimes as before. Hear of you I did, once, a good while ago,—thro’ an excellent Essay on Cowper and his Time;William Cowper (1731–1800; ODNB), poet, was a distant cousin of Donne; Donne’s essay, “Cowper’s Poems,” was pbd. in Fraser’s Magazine 64 (Dec. 1861): 700–717. of whh I easily divined the author, and retain still a lively remembrance.
With thanks and good wishes
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JT, 11 Feb. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:148–50; Wilson, Carlyle 5:499–500; Bliss, JWC 301–2; Simpsons 97–98. Recipient apparently unknown to the Carlyles; presumably not John Tyndall (1820–93; ODNB), an admirer of TC from the 1840s (see TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1852), who knew them from about 1855 (see TC to JF, [1 June 1855], TC to GHL, 3 Nov. 1855, and TC to JF, 2 Jan. 1856); Froude noted: “The following letter has been forwarded to me by a gentleman who modestly desires that his name may not be mentioned” (Froude, LM 3:148; the letter, pbd: Froude, LM 150–51; Simpsons 98).
div3.head: JWC TO J.T.

docBody.p:
I wish, dear sir, you could have seen how your letter brightened up the breakfast-time for my husband and me yesterday morning, scattering the misanthropy we are both given to at the beginning of the day, like other nervous people who have ‘bad nights.’ I wish you could have heard our lyrical recognition of your letter—its ‘beautiful modesty,’ its ‘gentleness,’ and ‘genuineness;’ above all I wish you could have heard the tone of real feeling in which my husband said, at last, ‘I do think, my dear, that is the very nicest little bit of good cheer that has come our way for seven years!’J.T. wrote, [9 Feb.]: “Unwilling to interrupt your husband in his stern task, I take the liberty of addressing you. … My obligations to your husband are many and unnameably great, and I just wish to acknowledge them. … If high respect, love, and good wishes could comfort him and you, none living command more or deserve more. … You can take a fit moment to communicate to your husband my humble admiration of his goodness, attainments, and great gifts to the world.“ It might have
been thought Mr. C. was quite unused to expressions of appreciation from strangers, instead of (as is the fact) receiving such almost every day in the year—except Sundays, when there is no post. But, oh, the difference between that gracious, graceful little act of faith of yours, and the intrusive, impertinent, presumptuous letters my husband is continually receiving, demanding, in return for so much ‘admiration,’ an autograph perhaps! or to read and give an opinion on some long, cramped MS. of the writer’s; or to—find a publisher for it even! or to read some idiotic new book of the writer’s (that is a very common form of letter from lady admirers)—say a translation from the German (!) and ‘write a review of it in one of the quarterlies!’ ‘It would be a favour never to be forgotten!’ I should think so indeed.

Were I to show you the ‘tributes of admiration’ to Mr. C.’s genius, received through the post during one month, you, who have consideration for the time of a man struggling, as for life, with a gigantic task—you, who, as my husband says, are ‘beautifully modest,’ would feel your hair rise on end at such assaults on a man under pretence of admiring him; and would be enabled perhaps, better than I can express it in words, to imagine the pleasure it must have been to us when an approving reader of my husband’s books came softly in, and wrapped his wife in a warm, beautiful shawl,J.T. wrote: “[I] hope you will accept from me a woollen long shawl. … I hope the pattern will please you, and also that it may be of use to you in a cold day.“ saying simply—`There! I don’t want to interrupt you, but I want to show you my good-will; and that is how I show it.’

We are both equally gratified, and thank you heartily. When the shawl came, as it did at night,J.T. sent the shawl by “the Parcel Delivery Co., carriage paid.“ Mr. C. himself wrapped it about me, and walked round me admiring it. And what think you he said? He said, ‘I am very glad of that for you, my dear. I think it is the only bit of real good my celebrity ever brought you!’
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Feb. MS: NLS 526.3. Pbd. Froude, Carlyle 4:269–70 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Accept a poor small word for FridayTC usually wrote to John A. Carlyle on a Friday; see TC to JAC, 28 Dec., and TC to JAC, 29 Jan. rather than none at all. I have no Horse today.—alas, no Horse more!—but my fire is out (high time I were “out” too), I am very cold; have been foiled in work,—and seldom was in worse key or more short of time.

Since I wrote last, there came a crisis (you know what that is) of the interior, whh had to be followed by blue-pill with the trimmings:TC took “blue pill” (a compound containing mercury) and castor oil for his digestive upsets. —never mind, that is all over now, and I feel clearly better, not worse. Jane too, who had fallen utterly weak, is a little fresher;—in short we are at par on the health side, and our weather is favourable tho’ cold. It is an insoluble piece of bother,—that of the Siege of OlmützFor the siege of Olmütz, see Carlyle, Works 17:350–73. to be done in little,—that torments me; that first,—and then secondly, I have been very unlucky, or my excellt old horse was, twice over last week! Tuesday and then Friday (this day week): only think as you read!— Tuesday I had let the old fellow rest thro’ monday; I tumbled out, and finding rain, snatched my mackintosh Cloak, and got away. Fritz very lively, wind so loud that (being then in crisis of interior) I resolved to go at walk. Well, till the Marble Arch Hyde-Park we did very well; but there, wind being right ahead, and mackinth given to rattle, the old scoundrel determined on a caper; my hat blew off me, hands under the mackinth &c: a labourer picked up the hat, tried to wipe some of the mud off it, Fritz prancing all the while,—I had no copper in my pocket; drew out my purse for sixpence to the man: crushed-on the hat, and galloped home with the old scoundrel. At night I discovered that I had no purse! In the tempest of rattling & pracingThus in MS; for “prancing.“ & embarrassed hurrying I had stuck it not into my pocket agn, but past my pocket, and it was gone: 12 or 10 shgs in it: that was misshanter first,—nichts zu bedeuten [that means nothing] in comparison.— — Till friday I daily rode the old scoundrel; on friday, in the Regents’ Park, witht the least warning or cause, he came smash down; lying flat on the ground, lying flat on the groundTC’s repetition. like a salmon on its belly (for one quarter of an instant),—had done me no mischief at all; sprang up and trotted on half a mile (greatly ashamed of himself I suppose), when looking over his shoulder, I saw the blood streaming over his hoof, drew bridle, dismounted found the knees quite smashed,—and, except slowly home, have ridden no more since! One of his knees will always have a mark, I am told; the other not: both are mending perfectly;TC wrote “(2)” here, at the top of his 2d page, a separate sheet of paper. and there is no intrinsic damage, only a fairly greater liability, whh was already (with the 2 years back) too great. Jane will not hear of my ever riding him agn; nor in real truth is it proper. Finis therefore in that departt! I have been extremely sorry for my poor old four-footed friend,—gar treu [very faithful] he constantly and wonderfully was;—and now what to do 1° with myself (take to my feet agn or not? I can get a horse doubtless if I make stir),—but 2° what is still more embarrassing how to
dispose of poor Fritz. Of course I can sell him, have him knocked down at Tattersll’sTattersall’s, horse auctioneers, Hyde Park Corner, Knightsbridge; est. 1766 by Richard Tattersall (ca. 1725–95; ODNB). for a £10 or an old song;—and then (as he goes delirious under violent usage, and is frightened for running swift in harness) get the poor creature scourged to death in a horrible way, after all the 20,000 faithful milesSee 38:22TC to EF, 7 Dec. 186[1]. he has carried me, & the wild puddles and lonely dark times and tempests we have had together! I cannot bear to think of that.— He is a strong health[y] horse; wd work in a cart Silvr thinks,John Silvester, livery stables. Frederic Chapman tried unsuccessfully to break Fritz to harness, summer 1860; see 36:169–70JWC to TC, [10 Aug. 1860], and 193JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1860].—loyal and peaceable he is, and wise as horse ever was.— — I am going to write to Jamie abt him:—but can so seldom find a minute! Mention him if you are writing. Adieu dear Brr/ T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 16 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have very little time; but I must tonight, what I have been meaning for a week past, consult you a little about the care of my worthy tho’ unfortunate old Horse, who is giving me some trouble at present. About ten days ago, the poor old fellow came slap down with me, for no particular reason at all, and broke both his knees, so that one of them, it appears, will never quite recover the hair;—and on the whole, owing in part to Jane’s anxieties, I am not to ride him any more. He is but 12 years old, and is very strong and healthy; is considered to have good hoofs, too, tho’ a little particular abt the shoeing of the fore feet: but horses, I find, soon ruin their bones on these hard streets and roads: and, in fact, I have found for two years past that my poor old friend made a great difference between hard ground and soft, and was stumbly and numb; and was dangerous for falling,—has been down at least 3 times, tho’ never badly & completely till this last. He has carried me above 20,000 miles (when I count up the last 7 years), without fault or failure, wd always rather have hurt himself than me;—and I am truly sorry abt my poor old four-footed still more than abt my own concern in his late misfortune. But the question is now (and I want yr candid deliverance upon it) What is to be done with him?

His knees will be mended abt the end of this week; and I cd then send him to the Auction, and at once get rid of him for what he wd bring,—perhaps £10
or some such sum. Whh I shd at once do, if I had no regard for him, and the miseries I see lie ahead for him! He will be put into cabs,—will be found not to work (on acct of terror, not of ill-nature, they tell me); will be flogged, sold again, tormented out of his poor existence, in a way I am shocked to think of after his giving me the flower of his poor days so faithfully!

The stable-keeperSilvester. here who is a very good skilful and honest old man says he is of opinion the horse wd work in “slow-harness” (that is, carting, harrowing,—I think always I cd make him work in a gig too, for he is the willingest and loyallest of animals);—and that he might have a chance to be able to make his bread in the country on quieter terms. He is perfect in teeth in stomach, a very strong pretty horse of the riding or carriage type, abt 14½ hands; has been well worth his é50:—he is in good conditn, not clipped; passionate for green & soft feed: é5 more will bring him to Carlisle; whh I will cheerfully lay out upon him, if you (upon candidly and vigorously considering the case) can fairly see a better time and line of industry ahead for him in the scene you are acquainted with. Think of it for two days, then tell me; about Saturday I must decide. John or Jenny will write me your verdict; whh, I know, will be to yr best judgt, and whh I shall be very apt to follow.— No more tonight. All well; & wishing blessings on you. / Your affectionate Brother,
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, [17 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the day after TC to JC, 16 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I wrote the inclosed last night in very great hurry; and now a Stranger man (Neuberg not a stranger to me) has come in; and I have not time or room for one word!

Don’t think me sentimental about the poor horse. Consider fairly what wd be likely to be his fate, if I let you try yr hand with him in Annandale. And as soon as you can,—answer. I find you will not have two days; that, if you wrote on Thursday it wd be better: they tell me the creature might be ready to travel on Saturday.— This day, too, I have heard of an eligible WaggonerUnidentified further. that might be got to make trial of him.

I can get another horse, I think; so soon as I am loose of this. I had not the
least damage from my tumble; the poor quadruped started up agn at once, seemingly quite ashamed of himself; & went trotting on better than before for half a mile,—till I noticed the blood on his hoofs!— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [17 Feb.]. MS: NLS 517.44. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Fritz’s fall, Fri., 6 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Inclosed is a lock of my hair—or rather the average of two locks, clipt off by Jane this morning when yr Letter came. All grey you see; not quite so grey on the hind head &c; but a little grayer still (than this) on the halfits (half-heads or temples!)— I wish you joy of it, and your ArtistUnidentified. as much.
My very candles are going out; and I must be content to write such a letter as seldom came to you by post! I am horribly bothered and tumbled abt in late days;—health well enough, thank Heaven.
My Horse fell with me ten days ago,—most complete break-down, not the least ill done to me, but horse quite ruined; has not been ridden since, nor is to be agn.
Good night dear Sister: I am really weary and the light (up in my garret here) is going out.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [17 Feb.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N B. PM: London, 18 Feb. 1863. MS: NLS 608.609. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Darling! It is quite unacountable, being the sensible woman I am thought, that I should do this sort of thing over and over again; seeing the stupidity of it!— I mean that I should let alone writing altogether when I dont feel equal to writing a good long letter! I have been thinking letters to you for the last two weeks, but putting them on paper needed an impossible exertion—or I felt it an impossible exertion which amounts to the same—practically! I have not caught cold, I have not been confined to my sofa or even to the House—entirely— I go out most days about twelve o’clock for a short drive or little
creeping walk. But all the while I have been feeling myself a HerioneThus in MS. unappreciated! that if the people about me had any idea how sick and weak, and nervous, and all overish I was; they could not but lyrically recognise my struggle to keep my legs and to hold my tongue! Not having the least idea of it, of course there was only virtue’s “own reward“Proverbial. for me—and I confess to having always found that a very insipid business!

Knowing how good in these cases, (and that there is nothing else any good) is a change of air and flinging off ones home worries for even a few days, I tried to bring myself to a short retirement at the sea side somewhere—so long as that capital elderly CookMrs. Winslade. was here to keep Mr C in clover—went the length of having lodgings at St Leonards investigated for me, the only place where I could endure to think of going into a lodging alone. And the reason of my preference was, that at St Leonards I should find Bessy Barnet—(Mrs Blackistone you remember?)Bessy Barnett was the Carlyles’ servant June–Dec. 1834; she reappeared, Aug. 1862, about to marry Dr. Peyton Blakiston; see 38:150–51TC to PB, 21 Aug. 1862. They lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, a seaside resort in Sussex. But that speculation was cut short by a call from Mrs Latham (one of the Mcdiarmids of Dumfries) who with her husbandJamima Burns, b. McDiarmid (1826–77), da. of John McDiarmid (1790–1852), author, and ed. of Dumfries and Galloway Courier. She m., 1862, Dr. Peter Wallwork Latham (1832–1923), asst. physician at Westminster Hospital. had just been to St Leonards and driven away by the prevalence of gastric fever! Now if I was going to catch anything, that was just the thing I felt at the moment up to catching! So I gave up the scheme, and could never get getRepeated by JWC. up any other in its place— Now my “sacred month“The term alludes to Ramadan, one of the “sacred months” of Islam; for TC’s earlier use, see 26:229TC to LA, 14 Nov. 1851; see also 33:260TC to JWC, 28 June 1858. of the capital Cook is drawing to a close— The day after tomorrow comes the new girl!Lizzie. And I look forward, with what heart you may imagine, to the breaking out of new jealousies, and wranglings, and bedevilments! no sort of treatment—no amount, or lack of discretion on my part seems to make any difference! I am arrived at utter despondency on the subject of new servants! Well! Blessed are they who do not hope, for they shall not be disappointed!Cf. Matt. 5:3–11.—

Mary, the successor to scotch Elizabeth, goes on moderately well—as general Servant—which I mean her to be, with the new girl as kitchen maid— There is no cleverness or activity of mind or body about her (Mary) to make one afraid of her coming to mischief!— She is slow, she hasn’t a notion of
doing anything out of her own head—but she does what she is told as well as she can— She is perfectly honest I think, and doesnt waste and doesn’t want to gad about, and on the whole when once got into a groove she may run on pretty smoothly I think—provided she doesn’t wreck on the rock of jealousy! She is very sensitive—not to be clever—and Mrs Winslade (the present Cook, who has been her own friend for years) tells me she is the most jealous girl she ever saw in her life!— Indeed I have seen her turn pale as ashes, when I happened to praise some dish which Mrs Winslade had sent up! What is one to do with such a character? I suppose a cleverer Mistress of a house than I am, would fall on some mode of treatment to bring good out of so much selflove rather than evil!— But for me, I despair of getting anything but the evil out of evil passions!— The less I bother myself about their nonsense the better!

Lord Ashburton continues in a most precarious state. All the serious maladies he had in succession have left him—even the dropsy has gone away!! except for the swelling of the joints caused by the gout there is none any more—he is fed with the most nourishing food every hour—takes twice as much food as he did in his healthiest times—and yet—his convalescence makes no way—there he lies week after week, unable to move, unable to feed himself, for weakness! he was carried from the Hotel where he fell ill to another in a better situation and was not the worse—but he gains no strength! It is a strange case, and no Dr thinks about it the same as another. LocockCharles Locock (1799–1875; ODNB), retired obstetrician who had been Lady Harriet Ashburton’s doctor; see 36:147JWC to LLA, [11 July 1860]. who saw him a fortnight ago said he saw no reason why he should not be as well as before this illness— But Christison, whom I believe in more, shakes his head over that. Poor Lady As health has been much broken no wonder! for six weeks she never slept in a bed. only took snatches of sleep with her clothes on, lying on the floor beside his bed— What a sad world it is— Tell me about your cold Dear— God bless you and the Dr Your own / JWC
Again I have forgotten to tell you something you will be amused to hear.

Imagine that woman NancyAgnes McCaig (1810–86), known as “Thornhill Nancy,” the Carlyles’ servant at Craigenputtoch May 1832–Dec. 1833; see 6:150–51TC to MAC, 1 May 1831, and 7:48TC to MAC, 3 Dec. 1833; see also JWC to MCA, [26 Feb.]. whom I went about seeking in Thornhill, and who had made a second marriage and gone to Sanquhar, returning my call here!

I was told “a Lady” wished to see me for a few minutes I asked “is she a Lady? do you mean?” “Well— No!” said Flo (it was in her time—“she isnt like a Lady“— I came in to find a great fat coarse woman whom I wouldnt have recognised—but for the voice in which said “Eh—Lord keep me!” with a look
of absolute terror and horror — “Are you—Nancy?” I asked “yes am I—but Oh I would never have kenned ye!” I was heartily glad to see the woman—and she, after the first, shock to see me— She hadnt come from Sanquhar on purpose but to keep the wife of her Husbands SonJames Pearson and his unidentified wife; see JWC to MCA, [26 Feb.]. in her first confinement She had been in Town five weeks and that was the first day she had been out— I sent [her]Omitted by JWC. away very pleased

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], 21 Feb. MS: NLS 1797.77. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
Thanks, Dear! The new photographOf William Dods; see oppabove. TC misspelled Dods’s name in his later annotation. has been done on a clear day, and is much better printed than the former one; besides that the additional eighth of an inch of head room enables me to breath more freely, in looking at it!
Giuseppe Mazzini, ca. 1863
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

But few I dare say, if any, of your Husbands Friends have such a nervous Imagination, and such intense physical Sympathy as I have! One such woman, born with no skinJWC considered herself and TC very thin-skinned; see 25:228JWC to TC, [23 Sept. 1850]. ‘to speak of,’ is enough to have among one’s “respectable” acquaintance! So the lowness of the ceiling will cause no sensation of choking to those other friends of his and yours, one of whom may be made happy by the photograp[h] which I spoiled for myself,For JWC’s trimming of the original photograph, see JWC to JDJAD, 29 Jan. and accordingly I place it at your disposal. And along with it the best likeness of Garibaldi, and a tolerable likeness of Mazzini—for your Book;Photograph album; JWC possibly sent Jane Dods another copy of the Mazzini photograph inscribed to JWC that is in her second album; see 63. Garibaldi’s “likeness” untraced.—if it be set up on the usual principle of receiving Celebrities, whether personally known or not.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p:
My Book is the most exclusive I have ever seen; Besides that I admit nobody that is not my own friend, I make the additional exaction that the photograph should have been given me by the person’s self—and yet it has got filled! Fifty Friends! How nice! and the photographed ones are a mere fraction! Don’t you think in my progress from the great original Oyster (according to Darwin)JWC believed that Darwin’s Origin of Species (1859) stated all human life evolved from oysters; see 36:53JWC to MR, [28 Jan. 1860]; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 137. Charles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB). I must number among my Ancestors “The Hare with Many Friends“?Story from Aesop’s Fables; see 38:253JWC to ERU, [2 Nov. 1862].— But all that doesn’t prevent me from feeling very poorly in this unnaturally soft winter. I
have been trying to muster courage to go into a lodging, by myself, for a week, somewhere at the Sea-side. A breath of Sea-air being worth any number of my Dr’s bottles of “Strengthening mixture—for Mrs Carlyle“! But strange to say; for all so many years as I have lived “here down” (as Mazzini would say) that is a thing I never did—to go into a lodging, alone! and flesh and blood recoils from the notion when I try to “carry it out“Cf. Charles Dickens, Great Expectations chap. 25.— The nearest approximation I ever made to it, was once, going by myself, “for change of air,“Coterie speech; see 27:121TC to JAC, 26 May 1852. to Hampstead, and dining on a horrid tough chop at a little wayside Inn; and taking a ride on a— —cuddy! with a Boy shouting and beating it on with a stick; while the chop was being cooked; but I returned to my own house to tea.Presumably the occasion referred to in JWC’s Journal, 24 April 1856; see 30:246TC to MAC, 12 Dec. 1852. There too, you see, the inconvenience of having no skin to speak of comes out strong— How I admire my Aunt Ann, who whenever she gets low at Morningside, packs a carpet bag and trots off to Portobello or Bridge of AllanAnn Welsh; see JWC to EW and GWEWAGW, [2 Feb.]. Portobello, seaside resort now part of Edinburgh; Bridge of Allan, spa town nr. Stirling. or somewhere, and makes herself at home in a lodging that may be full of bugs for anything she knows, and whose La[n]dlady she never before set eyes on!
Good night it has just struck midnight You will all be sound asleep in my little Birth-placeHaddington. and none of you dreaming of me I could swear.

p.name: J W Carlyle
p.note: Charlotte Cushman wrote to a friend, 19 Feb.: “I heard the other day from the Dilberoglues that Mrs Carlyle wondered why she had not heard from me—so I wrote her a little tiny rattling good for nothing note! But darling—if she wanted me, she would write me!” (Markus 164).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [26 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:151–55. Quot: Bliss, JWC 302–3.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
I promised you a “voluntary“Coterie speech; see 32:48JWC to IC, [10 Dec. 1856]. letter, Mary dear; and after all the waiting you are going to get a begging letter, which is nothing like so pleasant for either the writer or the receiver!— But those London hens!—they are creatures without rule or reason! I had just made an arrangement with a grocer,Unidentified. who
keeps a lot of them, to let me have at least seven newlaid eggs a-week; and the very day the bargain was concluded, the creatures all struck work again “except one bantam“! So we are eating away at yours, without any hope of reinforcement from this neighbourhood. Jane,TC and Mary’s sister Jean Aitken. in a letter to Mr C kindly offered to send a second supply from Dumfries but as She does not lay them “within herself” (as an old LadyUnidentified. at Haddington used to say) it seems more natural that I should apply to you who do!— We have still enough to last about a week.

There! I have done my begging at the beginning of my letter, instead of reserving it for a post script—the common dodge which deceives nobody! And now my mind is free to tell any news I may have.— You would hear of my incomparable small housemaidFlorence Morrison. having turned out an incomparable small Demon. People say these wonderfully clever servants whether old or young are always to be suspected. Perhaps!— Still a little cleverness is much nicer than stupidity to start with. Any how I don’t need to live in vague apprehensions about either of my present ServantsMary and Lizzie. on the ground of cleverness. But I am well enough content with them, as servants go. I have arranged things on a new footing, which I am in hopes (“hope springing eternal in the human mind)“Cf. Alexander Pope, An Essay on Man line 95. may work better than the old one. I have made the CookMary. who came in place of the Scotch one,Elizabeth. a general, or upper Servant; she does all the work up stairs, the valeting &c, besides the cooking; and the new girl is a sort of kitchen maid under her—on this plan, there cannot be the same room for jealousies and squabbles for power, which have tormented me ever since I kept two.

I had a visit the other day which turned me upside down with the surprise of it! I was putting on my bonnet to go out early in the day when MaryJWC previously wrote that it was Flo who introduced the visitor; see JWC to MR, [17 Feb.]. came to say there was “a Lady at the door, who would like if I would see her for a few minutes“

The hour being unusual for making calls & the message being over-modest for a caller; I thought it might be some “good Lady” with a petition, a sort of people I cannot abide. So I asked; “is she a Lady, do you think?” “Well—no Mam—I think hardly; said Mary, she wouldn’t give her name; but she said she came from fishshire, or something like that!“— “Fishshire? could it be
Dumfrieshire?” I said with a veritable inspiration of Genius, “Show her up!“— And I heard a heavy body passed into the Drawingroom. I hastened in and saw, standing in the middle of the floor a figure like a hay-stack, with the reddest of large fat faces, the eyes of which were straining towards the door, The woman was dressed in decent country clothes and bore no resemblance to any “Lady” in the created worl,” but looked well to do. I stared; I didn’t know the woman from Adam (as the people here say)! But she spoke— “eh!!” she said “Lord keep me! Is that you?“— And there was something strangely famliar in the voice! I stared again, and said—“Nancy??“— “Atweel and its just Nancy” answered the haystack! and then followed such shaking of hands, as if we had been the dearest friends! Do you know who it was? not the little Nancy we used to call “pigy” at Craigenputtoch but the great coarse Nancy with the beard.The Carlyles had had two servants called Nancy; for the first (from about 1829), known as “Piggie,” see 5:40JWC to MAC, [15 Dec. 1829]; TC described the second, “Thornhill Nancy,” as spoiling his razors, “privately dealing with a beard she had“; see 6:44JWC to MAC, [Nov. 1831]. She, who said she “never kenned folk mak sic a wark aboot a bit bee as we did“! She left Craigenputtoch to marry an old drunken butcher at ThornhillJohn Kirkpatrick; they m. 1834; see 7:87TC to MAC, 28 Jan. 1834. who, happily for her, died in a few years and then (as she phrased it) she “had another chance, and she just took it as she thocht it might be her last.” That is; she married again A very respectable manJames Pearson (1805–90); they m. 1841. of her own age who is something in the Dukes mines at SanquharWalter Francis Montagu-Douglas-Scott (1806–84; ODNB), 5th duke of Buccleuch, owned lead mines at Wanlockhead, 8 mi. (13 km.) W of Sanquhar. — She bore him one son, who is well educated, and Clerk in the Sanquhar Bank!John Pearson (b. 1842); a clerk in a lawyer’s office in Sanquhar (1861 census), he might have changed to a position in a bank in Sanquhar by 1862. He had been at Holme Hill, on some bank business just before I was there last year, and Mrs Russell had him to tea and said he was “a nice gentlemanly lad“— Well done Nancy,—beard and all the rest of it! Her Man had been married before, as well as herself and had a Son,Pearson’s first wife, m. 1830, was Grizel Lorimer (b. ca. 1810); their son was James Pearson (b. 1834). who is a haberdasher “on his own account” in this neighbourhood,The 1881 census lists James Pearson as a draper, 11 Trevor Sq., Knightsbridge. and he had married and his wifeMrs. Pearson, not further identified. was being confined; and Nancy had been sent for up to “take care of her.” She met one of the Miss WighamsThere were four Miss Whighams: Mary, Jemima Lucy Maxwell, Georgina Helen, and Elizabeth, all living at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire; JWC had visited them in Aug. 1862; see 38:149JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1862]. on the road before leaving home and made her “put down my address on a bit of paper,” and so there she was! the first day she had crossed
the threshold after being in London five weeks! I was really glad to see the creature! she looked so glad to see me; except for the shock my personal appearance manifestly was to her! I gave her wine and cake and a little present, and she went away in a transport!

I slept away from home last night! I had gone to a place called Ealing, some seven miles out of London to visit Mrs Oliphant—she who wrote the Life of Edward Irving—and it was too far to come back at night—indeed I never go out after sunset at this season. She is a dear little homely woman, who speaks the broadest Eastlothian scotch, tho’ she has lived in England since she was ten years old! and never was in East-lothian in her life; except passing thro it in a railway carriage!!!— But her Mother was an Eastlothian womanMargaret Oliphant was b. in Wallyford, East Lothian, ca. 7 mi. (11 km.) E of Edinburgh; she lived there, and then in Lasswade, Midlothian, until she was six. Her mother, Margaret Oliphant Wilson (1789–1854), was b. in Pittenweem, Fife. I wish to heaven I had any place out of London, near hand, that I could go to when I liked—I am always so much the better for a little change. Life is too monotonous, and too dreary in the valley of the Shadow of Frederick the Great!Coterie speech; see 36:44JWC to LLA, 16 Jan. [1860]; cf. Ps. 23:4. I wonder how we shall live, what we shall do, where we shall go, when that terrible task is ended? Kindest regards to Jamie and the bonnie lasses your affectionate/ Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [28 Feb.]. MS: NLS 1797.79. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: When I had told him, in a seductive, persuasive way, what was wanted of him, he made no difficulties at all; but answered; “Yes! I will go“!To dinner at the Forsters, 3 March. with an alacrity and emphasis that quite took away my breath!—
So—! on Tuesday “gin we be spared“!Cf. 28:141JWC to JF, 14 May? 1853. You didn’t say what hour?
I trust Lady Airlie didnt suspect the drift of our confabulation! for I had just refused an invitation to the Stanleys’ on the ground of the General Rule to go nowhere!—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GW [GWE], [late Feb.]. MS: NLS 608.613B. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after the arrival of the new servant Lizzie, 19 Feb. TC wrote on MS “(abt 1860?” [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 28 February 1863.]
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE WELSH

docBody.p: My dear Grace, I take up my pen (a very bad one, and i can’t mend it!) to write to you; without any question of whose turn it is; but simply out of a natural, wholesome human wish to have a little talk with you; altho’ the “reciprocity must be all on one side.“Coterie speech; see 19:196JWC to CGD, [15] Sept. [1845]. I never sit down at night, beside a good fire, alone, without feeling a need of talking a little, on paper, to somebody that I like well enough, and that likes me well enough, to make it of no moment whether I talk sense or nonsense, and with or without regard to the rules of Grammar

But it isn’t once in a month that I find myself so situated. There is always a good fire and I am always sitting by it. but so is Mr C, on the opposite side of the table; correcting proofs, or reading; and tho’ the fact of his being their hardly makes any difference in the feeling of being alone; as he neither speaks nor lets himself be spoken to; it does, I find, make a material difference in any good one can get out of one’s aloneness. He never visits,—is at home of an evening from months end to month’s end. Only sometimes, as to night, if he have been prevented from getting his hour’s sleep before dinner, he takes it after—and puts off his tea till after nine o’clock. I take my tea when he dines—at 7–and am ready for a little porridge and milk at eleven, making the porridge myself on the Drawingroom fire.

—In my last letter I remember I was urging on you, the wholesomeness of concentrated nourishment especially of essence of beef.See JWC to EW and GWEWAGW, [2 Feb.]. Oh my Dears do try it! After writing that letter, it struck me that I myself had better take the advice I was so liberal of to you; and put away entirely my porridge and broths and favourite messes, and betake myself to curing my own fit of indigestion with essence of beef! I dined on it and supped on it (in very small quantity) for about a week; and by that time my appetite had come back, and my nights were delivered from positive torment; and I might return to the porridge, my taste for which is always a good symptom with me. Our dear Lady Sandwich who was the weakest human being I ever saw live, with some appearance of enjoying life in spite of her many ailments, was fed almost entirely in her last years, by Dr Ferguson’sProbably Dr. Robert Ferguson (1799–1865; ODNB), physician; see 16:297–98JWC to TC, [20 July 1843], and 24:100JWC to TC, [5 July 1849]. orders, on essence of beef, and weak Brandy in
water. The way Ferguson desired it should be made for her, was to take a pound of juicy beef without any fat, cut it up into little bits put the bits in a bottle—without any water or anything; cork the bottle well, and boil it (the bottle) in a panful of water for seven hours. She used to take about a table spoonful at a time—sometimes she had the pure essence diluted with an equal quantity of boiling water—and about three times a day, she had a teaspoonful of brandy in a wineglassful of water and a tiny biscuit. We have our soup made with vegetables of the hard sort, carrot, celery, herbs and seasonings, boiling for seven hours till the meat is gone to perfect mush and taking great pains with the skimming. Then it is poured out into a large basin, and the next day the fat which will have risen to the top is taken off. Then it is boiled up and poured into as many basins, of the size to be used each time it is wanted, as it will fill—from six pounds of the fleshy part of shin of beef we should have five little basinsful. It was dear miss Jess Donaldson, who had to have a constant supply of soup for her sister,Jess and Jean Donaldson, old Haddington friends of JWC, who both d. 1860. who told me about pouring it at the first into seperate basins or teacups; and I have found it a great improvement on the old plan of pouring it into one large tureen; for the strong jelly which it ought to be when cold, (if the soup is strong enough) when broken into gets watery, and spoils as fast again. Now do please try this receipt and above all make Elizabeth try it. I am so sure you would both derive the same benefit from it that Mr C and I do.

Miss Wilson told me the other day that her BrotherJane Wilson (1790–1890; see 34:4JWC to TC, [1 July 1858]) and her brother Thomas Wilson (ca. 1788–1872; see 8:152TC to JAC, 15 June 1835); the death date of 1871 given at 30:225 is incorrect. had had several letters lately from Bishop TerrotCharles Hughes Terrot (1790–1872; ODNB), bishop of Edinburgh, Episcopal Church of Scotland; see 16:197–98JWC to JW, 15 June 1843.—who never wrote the scrape of a pen to him, tho’ his oldest friend in the world, all thro the period of his married life (last married life) The letters she said were filled with the most enthusiastic laudation of his deceased (second) wife!Charlotte, b. Loader (ca. 1819–62), m. Terrot in 1859. he had never, he says, in one letter “enjoyed the advantage of living for so long a time beside a woman of such refined manners, such high intellectual power, such personal attractions, and such affluent circumstances(!) (strange if he had! his first wifeSarah Ingram, b. Wood (d. 1855), m. Terrot in 1818. having noneof these things.) and now that she has been taken from him, his life is filled and made happy for him by the recollection of her perfections“!!— “She was far higher in a religious and in a moral sense than himself” he said (and that might easily be!) “and he felt himself drawn upwards by her companionship,” Whatever that woman was else, she must have had a talent for captivating
Husbands and fascinating them when caught,Charlotte married four times; Terrot was her last husband. beyond anything I ever heard of out of a French novel! It was a pity she did not survive the Bishop; it would have been so curious to see who or what she would have married next!

Do you remember Margaret Veitch at Haddington,Margaret Veitch (b. ca. 1801), presumably one of the 11 children of Robert and Agnes Veitch; see 13:69JWC to MSC, [March 1841]. who married “the English Clergyman” (Mr Trail)Rev. James Traill (1791–1849), minister of the Episcopal church in Haddington 1819–49; JWC uses “English” to mean the Episcopal Church of Scotland.— I had her here at early dinner with me the other day, not having seen her since I was married! The shock the sight of her changed appearance was to me, was only equalled by the shock my changed appearance was to her! But she is the same woman as ever in point of emotionalness; Mr C came and spoke to her for a few minutes as he was going out to his ride—and as the door closed after him she threw herself on my shoulder, and exclaimed with tears, “Oh Jeanie, how well he looks! What a fine colour he has!“— I couldnt see anything to cry about in that!— I think I like honest vulgar thickskinned Ann (Mrs Archy Dunlop)Anne, b. Veitch (b. 1795), m. Archibald Dunlop, former Haddington distiller, now living in London at 5 Gloucester Ter., Bayswater; see 37:150JWC to WDO, [15 April 1861]. best of all the lot of Veitchs— They seem (the Dunlops) now reaping virtues own reward in the shape of a handsome house, and three servants, one a man—&c &c— What is that dawdling Mary HogganMary Hoggan (1796–1875) had said that she would leave her brother’s house since his wife had come to live with him; see 38:137JWC to TC, [13 Aug. 1862]. going to make of herself? She will stay on there hithering and thithering in intention; till like the Pigs, she gets “used to it“Coterie speech; see 20:153JWC to MAC, [28 March 1846].— I had a call the other day from a most surprising Phenomenon, A woman who was my servant at Craigenputtoch, called Nancy who was with us when we staid under the bad woman in, I forget the name of the street; and afterwards at a lodging in Gt King street.The Carlyles lived in Edinburgh for four months, early 1833, first at 18 Carlton St., Stockbridge, in a house belonging to Mrs. Colquhoun (see 6:286–87TC to EA, 26 Dec. 1832, and 6:290TC to JAC, 8 Jan. 1833), which they left because the floor above them was let to a “woman of bad character“; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833, and 6:341JWC to EA, [9 March 1833]. They then moved to lodgings at 4 Great King St., owned by JWC’s old school friend Mrs. Blacky; see 6:341JWC to EA, [9 March 1833]. She left me to marry a horrid old Butcher at Thornhill (her native place) and he happily dying, she married, in spite of the most terrific black beard I ever saw a woman blessed with, a very respectable, better sort of Man of her own age, at Sanquhar—and her only Son is now a clerk in the Bank at Sanquhar! and Mrs Russell, with whom he once took tea when sent on some Bank business, pronounced him “a very nice gentlemanly lad.“

I had never seen the woman since she left Craigenputtoch! And when I
went into the Drawingroom where she had been shown under the vague denomination of “A Lady from feefshire—or something like that,” and saw her standing developped into a great haystack, with the redest of faces; I stood amazed—“as in presence of the Infinite“! What was she? what did she want of me? But when she opened her lips and said “Eh!—Lord keep me! Is that you?” there was something strangely familiar in the voice, and after another stare I said “Nancy?“— “Atweel and am just Nancy!” and then we shook hands like long parted lovers. Tho heaven knows I didnt find her loveable at Craigenputtoch! She had come to London to superintend the Confinement of her stepson’s wife (the Husband had been married before as well as herself)—and that was the first day she had crossed the threshold, tho she had been in London five weeks. I was quite turned head over heels by the small felicity of seeing the great coarse goodnatured Sumph who looked so glad to see me and who talked to me about Templand, and long ago! I gave her wine and cake and a little present; and sent her away light and pleased.

My kitchen affairs are “looking up“— The successor of the Scotch Cook seems really a good trustworthy creature, and has picked up a great deal from the experienced woman I have had for a month, till her protegé could come. So that her cooking is quite satisfactory now, and she is a very tidy house maid; while the new girl stays below as a sort of kitchen-maid—she too looks promising enough, but I have next to nothing to do with her directly—she having been engaged to be “under the Cook.” Perhaps I may by this arrangement avoid the jealousies and battles for supremacy which have beset my “establishment” for so long—ever since I kept two— The present arrangement reduces things as much as possible to the old style of thing your loving niece/ Jeanie Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JD [JODO], 2 March. Addr: 18. Glo’ster Road / Upper Holloway / N. PM: 3 March 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN DOWNES

docBody.p: I read the Wilson,Unidentified. not yet knowing whose it was, or who had sent it,—simply as the one Piece I cd get the least good of: the other Papers, one and all, border on the unendurable to me.

I am very happy to hear that you are doing well, and find the ground getting firmer under you.In 1862 TC tried to help Downes find outlets for his writing and recommended him for an English professorship in Calcutta; see 38:39JWC to AGIL, [25 Jan. 1862], and 92TC to JODO, 8 May 1862. Honest diligence, modesty, discretion, and
discernment will do a great deal for a man, even in that slippery element, in these bewildered days.

You are very wise to seek out some Biographical or Historical subject, with a view of consecrating to it all the time you can save, and doing yr very best upon it: Marvel is an honest solid kind of man, the ideal of a good Yorkshire Burgh Member,Andrew Marvell (1621–78; ODNB), poet and politician; M.P. for Hull, Yorkshire, 1659–78. in an age of Prose and minus Quantities: but on the whole there is not any surprising degree of heroism in dining on cold muttonOne of the stories about Marvell’s honesty was his response to the offer of a gift of £1,000 from the Treasury. Marvell asked his servant: “‘Jack, child, what had I for dinner yesterday?’ ‘Don’t you remember, Sir? You had the little shoulder of mutton that you ordered me to bring from the woman in the market.’ ‘Very right child. What shall I have for dinner today?’ ‘Don’t you know, Sir, that you bid me lay by the blade-bone to broil.’” Marvell turned to the messenger: “‘My Lord, do you hear that? Andrew Marvell’s dinner is provided; there’s your piece of paper. I want it not. I know the sort of kindness you intended. I live here to serve my Constituents; the ministry may seek men for their purpose; I am not one’” (John Dove, The Life of Andrew Marvell [1832] 29). (I know a couple of men who are equal to that feat as well as Andrew, and never mention it to the King!)Charles II (1630–85; ODNB), king of Great Britain and Ireland.—and in fine I am afraid the Marvel heroism has been already recognised and abstracted as far as it will go;As well as Dove’s original Life of Andrew Marvell, there was another edn. with additions by Hartley Coleridge (Hull, 1835), and Edwin Paxton Hood’s Andrew Marvell, the Wit, Statesman and Poet, His Life and Writings (1853). and that there wd not be interest in it for the prest generatn. Much, however, very much depends on the interest you really take in it; if you really in yr heart feel it admirable and adorable, there is always good chance of yr making us admire and adore. This in fact is the question of questions in regard to such a choosing of subject. Do you know anything of Willm of Wykeham (founder of Winchester School)?William of Wykeham (1324–1404; ODNB), bishop of Winchester; see 35:74TC to JN, 13 April 1859. Winchester College was founded 1382. He is one of the finest men I know in English History, as good as unknown (that is, invisible) to everybody at present. A beautiful, pious, massive architectonic kind of mind (indeed architectural by profession, a good deal). Bishop Lowth has done an excellent summary or skeleton of his Life.The Life of William of Wykeham (1758), by Robert Lowth (1710–87; ODNB), bishop of London 1777–87; see 22:145–46TC to FM,4 Nov. 1847. To put flesh on it wd be fine, but difficult—need a great deal of reading and study to resuscitate the times of Edward III and Richard II!Edward III (1312–77; ODNB), king of England 1327–77, and Richard II (1367–1400; ODNB), king of England 1377–99.

Do you know St Colm of Iona;St. Columba (Colum Cille) (ca. 521–97; ODNB), founder, 563, of the monastery at Iona, island off the west coast of Mull, Inner Hebrides, Scotland. St Cuthbert of Durham (born near
Haddington I found);St. Cuthbert (ca. 635–687; ODNB), bishop of Lindisfarne, whose relics are in Durham Cathedral. His birthplace is unknown, but the ODNB suggests the Lothians (Haddington is in E. Lothian), which were then in Northumbria. or have you looked into Bollandus, Acta SanctorumJohannes Bollandus (1596–1665), Jesuit scholar; he compiled five vols. of Acta Sanctorum, lives and works of the saints organized chronologically by their saints’ days; the volumes were continued by the Société des Bollandistes; by 1863 there were 57 vols., taking the work as far as 24 Oct. It was finally completed in 1940, with 68 vols. at all? There is an immensity of noble matter, Historical, Biographical, waiting there to be disemprisoned by fit hands!— In effect I can only wish you “a happy choice” and good success to it. Yours very sincerely
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GW [GWE], [2 March]. MS: NLS 608.601B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:155–57. Quot: Hansons, NE 504. Dated by the dinner at the Forsters, 3 March.
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE WELSH

docBody.p:
You say that you have sent me “them,“Photographs. and you have only sent me it; and you say “the head” is thought a good likeness and I have got only a standing figure.Possibly the photograph of Grace Welsh standing (JWC’s third photograph album); see 76above. JWC accompanied Grace to a photographer in Edinburgh, Sept. 1862; see 38:196JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1862]. Was it an involuntary omission, on your part; or did you fall away from your good intention to send “them.” revise it if you did—for I want very much to see the likeness of the young man which is considered the best. I should like much to see the young man himself for me as for you a certain melancholy interest attaches to the last of so large and so brave a family.Robert Welsh, JWC’s cousin; “Robert Welsh’s second son: he too is dead; died shortly before her [JWC] own departure out of vale of sorrow” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:156). JWC’s uncle Robert Welsh had eight children, and was himself one of 15. There are no photographs of Robert Welsh in JWC’s photograph albums. Don’t wait till you have time and heart to write me another nice long letter, but put “the head” in an envelope and send it at once.
Grace Welsh, [1862?]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Mr C was again laid hold of by Mr AlexanderRev. Thomas Alexander (1817 or 1821–72), who later became friendly with TC (see Wylie 344); originally from Dundee, he trained in the Free Church of Scotland and was an assistant to the Rev. Robert Candlish (see JWC to BB, 22 May); he then became minister of Ranelagh Presbyterian Church, Chelsea, ca. 1850–65, and lived at 13 Royal Ave., King’s Rd., Chelsea. the other day in the Kings Road and escorted by him all the way to Regent street! “Really a good innocent-hearted man! very vulgar; but he can’t help that poor fellow“!— I have never once met him in the Street since I made up my mind to speak to
him, and invite him to call for me —which Mr C hadnt the grace to do— I used never to walk out without meeting him—but this winter I have taken my walk early in the forenoon—when he is busy I suppose—just once I saw him pass the Butchers doorsPossibly John Maynard, 42 Paradise Row; see 25:189JWC to TC, 2 Sept. [1850]. when I was giving directions about a piece of beef! He had a pretty young Lady with him on whom he was “beaming” benevolence and all sorts of things!

I was away a day and night last week, at Ealing visiting Mrs Oliphant—Even that short “change of air and scene” did me good. On the strength I got by it I afterwards went to a dinner-party at The Rectory,With the Rev. Gerald Blunt, rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, and his wife, Frances. and I am to dine out again tomorrowDinner at the Forsters; see JWC to JF, [28 Feb.]. to meet Dickens and nobody else, The people send their carriage for me and send me home, so in this mild weather the enterprise looks safe enough—

Such a noise about that “Royal Marriage“!The marriage of Albert Edward, prince of Wales, to Princess Alexandra was to take place, 10 March, in St. George’s Chapel, Windsor. I wish it were over! People are so woefully like sheep!—all running where they see others run and doing what the[y]Letter omitted. see others do.

Have you read anything about that wonderful Bishop Colenso?John William Colenso, Anglican bishop of Natal, S. Africa, 1853–83. Such a talk about him too! And he isnt worth talking about for five minutes—except for the absurdity of a man making arithmetical onslaughts on the Pentateuch,Colenso was accused of heresy after arguing in the first 2 vols. of his The Pentateuch and Book of Joshua Critically Examined (1862 and 1863) that, if it could be proved that factual statements in the Bible were untrue, one need not be bound by the principles depending on them; he taught mathematics in his youth and wrote two books on the subject, and many of his proofs against factual statements in the Bible were numerically based. with a Bishops little black silk apron on!!The bishop’s short cassock, worn with knee-breeches and gaiters. — dear love to you all— your affectionate Jeanie W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JAF, [ca. 2 March]. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:264 inc. Dated by similarity of content to JWC to GWE, [2 March].
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
Oh, my dear Mr. Froude, I surely couldn’t have looked so bored as that. I couldn’t because I wasn’t. I own to feeling rather antipathetic to that
anomalous bishop.Bishop Colenso. Froude wrote later: “I knew Colenso; we [TC and Froude] met him in one of our walks. He joined us, and talked of what he had done with some slight elation, ‘Poor fellow!’ said Carlyle, as he went away; ‘he mistakes it for fame. He does not see that it is only an extended pillory that he is standing on.’ I thought and think this judgment a harsh one. No one had been once more anxious than Carlyle for the ‘Exodus.’ No one had done more to bring it about than Colenso, or more bravely faced the storm which he had raised, or, I may add, more nobly vindicated, in later life, his general courage and honesty when he stood out to defend the Zulus in South Africa. … Partly, I believe, at my instance, Mrs. Carlyle invited Colenso to one of her tea-parties, but it was evident that he suited her no better than her husband. I told her so, and had this note in reply” (Froude, Carlyle 4:263–64). Colenso presumably gave JWC the carte de visite in her second album; see oppabove. A man arrived at the years of discretion wearing an absurd little black silk apron, disturbs my artistic feelings to begin with.
John William Colenso, bishop of Natal, ca. 1863
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Then consider whom I am descended from, the woman who when King James offered to make her husband a bishop if she would persuade him to return to his country and be a peaceable subject, held up her apron and answered, ‘I would rather kepp his head in there.’Elizabeth Welsh, b. Knox (1570?—1625), wife of John Welsh the Covenanter (1568?—1622), from whom JWC wrongly believed she was descended; see also 16:41JWC to JW, [2 Feb. 1843], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 74 and 438–39. For the tale of Elizabeth Welsh’s defiance, 1622, of James VI of Scotland and I of England, Wales, and Ireland (1566–1625; ODNB), see 32:13JWC to RMM, [17 Oct. 1856?]. Add to all this that I strongly believe with a German friend of mine, that it is the mixing up of things which is the Great Bad!Count Oskar von Reichenbach’s phrase; see 30:224JWC’s Journal, 26 Nov. 1856. and that this particular bishop mixes up a black silk apron with arithemetical confutation of the Bible, and you will allow that I have better reason than a woman usually has for first impressions, why I should not take to Colenso. But I was really not bored that day. You came with him; you were there; and, without meaning to say anything pretty (which is far from my line), I am always so pleased to see you, that were you to come accompanied by the—the—first gentleman in England,Phrase commonly used to refer to the king. I should rather than that you didn’t come at all.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [2 March]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 3 March 1863. MS: NLS 608.601A. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:284–85.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea TuesdayJWC was apparently writing on Mon., 2 March, the day before the dinner at the Forsters, Tues., 3 March. [2 March 1863]
docBody.p:
I should be glad to hear you were quite done with that cold. I hate to think of your coughing—for in all my life I never heard a cough that had such a
sound of tearing the person’s inside into twenty pieces! “The Doctor” says it doesn’t do you any harm. but I should need to have been married to you as long as he has been to believe that! We have the finest weather here—bracing as well as mild; and my sickness is gone for the present, and I feel stronger.

I went to Ealing the other day to visit Mrs Oliphant and staid all night— Even that short absence from Chelsea did me ever so much good! and on the strength of it I went after to a dinner-party at the Rectory—and tomorrow I am going to dine out again, at the Forster’s to meet Dickens and nobody else— They send their carriage for me and send me home at night; so in this mild weather I trust no harm will come of it.

I was in Swan & Edgars shopSwan & Edgar’s dept. store, corner of Piccadilly and Regent St.; Mr. Swan (d. 1821), draper, and William Edgar (1791–1869), haberdasher, opened their first store at 20 Piccadilly in 1812. the other day, and a nice looking ladProbably William Corson (b. ca. 1841). was serving me with tapes and things, whose speech tho’ doing its best to be anglified sounded homelike— “You are Scotch,” I said; without consideration for the mortified vanity of a Youth trying to speak fine; “Yes I am;” answered he tartly. “I should say you come from Dumfrieshire“? I went on, with the same inquiring inhumanity, “Yes—I do“; he answered with an almost startled look. “Dumfrieshire is partly my country too—you are from Nithsdale—from near Thornhill, are you not?“— The young man stared, quite subdued, and answered meekly that he did come from near Thornhill!—from a place close to DabtonDabton, an estate in Morton parish, 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) N of Thornhill. if I knew where that was. “Oh didn’t I!“— Then I asked him if he knew Holme Hill? And so subdued was he, that he answered in the most unadulterated Scotch “Oh fine! Dr Russell’s—I know it fine! I told him I had been there for three weeks last August—and then left him—thinking me, I have no doubt, a very odd woman! Do you know who it would [be]?Dabton, an estate in Morton parish, 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) N of Thornhill. he said they came there about the time of Mr Crightons deathMajor Thomas Crichton (b. ca. 1778) d. 1848; see 9:161JWC to JWE, 4 March [1837].— What is that poor little Mrs Graham to bring up all those children on?Margaret Graham (b. 1808), widow of Rev. James Graham (1808–63), minister of Penpont; he d. 1 Feb.; they had 11 surviving children. The 1861 census lists only three remaining at home, Janet (b. 1834), David (b. 1848), and Elizabeth (b. 1851). How on earth will she live? I have often thought about it.

What is come of Mary’s BrothersMary Russell’s servant Mary; her brother unidentified. leg—that Mr GriersonPresumably Dr. Thomas Boyle Grierson (1818–89; see 37:26JWC to LAI, [24 Oct. 1860]). wanted to cut off? give my kind remembrances to Mary—good little soul! it is a comfort to think of your having such a good girl beside you. Dont forget to tell me when you find a Cook— My own affairs are “looking up” (as they say of the funds)—
There has been no quarrelling between the Cook and the new girlThe Carlyles’ servants Mary and Lizzie. as yet; at least I hear of none which is all the same. She seems a quiet polite girl—not very bright—but I have next to nothing to do with her; as she is not house maid but kitchenmaid under Mary—who is “General Servant” I hope they will at least just go on— Goodby Darling—love to the Doctor Your faithful friend/ Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 March. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am in my average health again (if I ever was much below it), and have got rid of my Horse, and of various difficulties;—and will surely write to you at greater length before I be much older! But I have had a most troublesome, bad time; my Proofs tenfold more unmanageable than I had calculated on,—oh such a quagmire agn, left chaotic by all men, till unfortunate I shd make it cosmic if I cd! The Horse too was a bitter botheration; & liver and nerves seemed to add themselves in threatening posture:—at last however, since Tuesday Evg last, the poor Horse is provided for (a magnificent £9 falling to my share for him),—and the Battle of ZorndorfFor the battle of Zorndorf, 25 Aug. 1758, see Carlyle, Works 17:373–97. is all but done, not two hours of it left for tomorrow!— Jamie’s advice abt Fritz was very wise and candid, “Not the least hope of a livelihood for him in Scotland“: then I heard from Chapman of some Wandsworth Paper-maker,Unidentified. who had “light wagons,” in whh it was judged the poor Horse might work witht being lashed to death: endless waiting and bothering & half-consenting (on Paper’s part) abt that;—at length an innocent ApothecaryUnidentified. close by in Chelsea, willing to go at a foot-pace on horseback, offered to buy him “for riding,” wd put him to grass, wd &c &c—in short was anxious to have him at £9; and has him, with my blessing. I was three new times on his back; except look, he is not sensibly worse.
