And I believe, may be safe at a walk, for many years to come: but the evident fact was, he had for two years back being growing stiffer & stiffer (meta-tarsal or -carpal bones jarred by the hard ways here); and was unsafe as well as unpleasant in the least liveliness of riding;—and might easily have fallen, and broken one’s bones, instead of saving them. A more complete fall I never sendThus in MS. than that finishing one. Basta [enough]!—
My “two months of holiday“—alas, alas, the Battle of Hochkirch is still to write first! You shall hear by and by.

Laing’s Drawing & Pampht came: the former evidently means the same thing as Froude’s,For the drawing of Kirk o’ Field, see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1862; David Laing’s “pamphlet” was possibly his “Edinburgh in Early Times, with illustrations,” read to the Royal Society of Antiquaries, 8 Dec. 1862, but apparently not pbd.; otherwise unidentified. but is very much less distinct,—some of the labellings I cannot yet read. And the thing I wanted was to have that Old Locality put down disinctly in the Edinr of Today;—whh is not done at all; till I see the Printed Essay,—if Laing will lend me that?The printed essay was part of Laing’s Preface, Charters of the Hospital of Soltre, of Trinity College, Edinburgh, ed. D. Laing (Edinburgh, 1861) xxxiii—xlii; see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1862.—— My very kind regards to Mme O & Mlle:Jean Otthenin and her da. Irma. good souls, stranded far away! Our weather is too hot. You may return me that German LetterUntraced. interpreted in the worst path. Adieu T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [5 March]. Addr: Montague Square / Hyde Park. PM: London, 5 March 1863. MS: NLS 1797.81. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: I have been over at my Laundress’s today, and found her so far from meaning to die,According to TC, Mrs. Cook, about 78 in 1863, was in a workhouse (“some Kensington Union“), 1865; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 186. that she was making a lamentation to me that she hadn’t work enough!— “Mine wasn’t enough for her“! She spoke of putting an Advertisement in the Times I told her to wait till she heard from me again—for I thought if your laundress was not satisfactory, you had really better have mine—at all events I wouldn’t let her engage with other work till I gave you the refusal of her—

So please send me word Yes or no— Neither of us was the least the worse for our lark on Tuesday— Indeed Mr C to my unspeakable astonishment declared “he was the better for it“! had “had a much better sleep than usual“— I hope in Heaven you were not tired out— I had a sort of remorse in thinking of you after—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 6 March. Addr: 140. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 7 March 1863. MS: NLS 553.250. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—We must give up Hubertsburg,Hubertsburg, a castle in Saxony, about 25 mi. (40 km.) ESE of Leipzig, used as a hunting lodge; sacked on Frederick’s orders 22 Jan. 1761 (Carlyle, Works 18:344–47), and later the venue for the peace talks at the end of the Seven Years’ War, 30 Dec. 1762–15 Feb. 1763 (Carlyle, Works 18:487–90). Presumably TC means that they could not find a map of Hubertsburg. then; it is probably small loss. I have lodged with LarkinHenry Larkin. yr Map Tickets, in case he shd have to apply abt Olmütz.Olmütz, Austrian town, besieged unsuccessfully by Frederick in 1758; see Carlyle, Works 17:350–73; for the map, see 17:opp. 394.

Can you tell me, or do you know no vernacular German soul who cd tell me, what a “gras teufel” (grass-devil) is?Neuberg did not find out; TC wrote: “I never know whether insects or birds“; see Carlyle, Works 17:379. It is written down (Preuss ii.149, near top) in a dozen Books as if everybody knew it; and, out of all my sad Dictionaries & with all my guessings, I cannot ascertain whether it is an insect or a bird or what on earth!— A week hence, it will be too late altogether.
I am sorry to hear you are in ill health. I suppose it must belong to the Season, and perhaps to the unusual weather:—I am myself too much in that way, tho’ not so ill as you.
Pray shew face agn so soon as you can; Sunday evg next, if it may with propriety be.Signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 7 March. MS: NLS 517.45. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I suppose the DrJohn A. Carlyle. may be still with you on Monday when this gets to hand, tho he leaves you at night. I am bidden send itUnidentified. you at once; whh I do, after reading it with real satisfaction. You can wish the Dr a good journey and thank him in my name.

I felt yr advice abt the Horse to be wise, and faithful; perfectly true: Noprospect of a livelihood for the poor animal in Scotland! What settlement Idid get made, John will have told you. Looking back now, I find it very lucky;
and that my fall was really one not to be repeated at any price; nor to be risked again (the like of it) at all at all! You never saw a more complete smash-down; in a moment, witht cause assignable, poor Fritz in the mud, nose, one hock and both knees, —flat on his belly like a fish (tho’ he started up, poor fellow, much ashamed of himself);—it cd not be expected that, next time, he wd keep me quite perpendicr on his back, & with no damage whatever!— — I think I can get another horse; and that I shall have to do it. But, at present, walking is such a delightful change!—

This day all creatures off to “the Prince of Wales”;The procession through the streets of London of the prince of Wales and Princess Alexandra; she arrived at Gravesend, Kent, where she was met by the prince; after traveling by train to the Bricklayers’ Arms Stn., S London, they processed via Old Kent Rd., London Bridge, the Mansion House, Cheapside, St. Paul’s Churchyard (see 86), the Strand, Trafalgar Sq. (see above), Pall Mall, Piccadilly, and Hyde Park to Paddington Stn., from where they took a train to Windsor; thousands of people lined the route. and I am bound in the opposite directn.
Blessings on you all.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA] , 7 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd. Hansons, NE 504 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
My dear, dearest Lady Ashburton A thousand thanks for the card, and the lines! which arrived with the oddest, most perplexing appearance of the ink being still wet! (I actually touched them with my finger to feel if they were wet!)— Yes! the card was a godsend as a sign of your remembrance—that it was also an admission to what I had heard people longingly aspiring to as a new seventh Heaven did not so much signifyLady Ashburton sent JWC a card for admission to Bath House to watch the procession of the prince of Wales and Princess Alexandra. for I have still a good deal of the Great Original Oyster in me!See JWC to JD JAD , 21 Feb.
— Could not get up a sentiment or even a sensation about that “procession”! was not meaning to go near it—and have not gone! even with that card for the new seventh Heaven, in my pocket!— If you and Lord Ashburton had been at Bath House; it would have been a very different matter! Then I should have let nothing hinder me—not even the idea of a crowd, which has more terror for me than the idea of an Earthquake! I should have been delighted to add this one more sight from those windows to those I had already seen from them,—(the Duke of Wellington’s Funeral the last!)Arthur Wellesley (1769–1852), 1st duke of Wellington; his funeral procession was 18 Nov. 1852; see 27:359–60 JWC to HW, 14 Nov. 1852
, and 362 TC to HHM, 16 Nov. 1852
. But that scaffolding, prepared in your own absence, and own troubles, for the amusement of “others”!—

And the empty, sorrow-struck House, looking out over it, made me like to cry, every time I have driven past— And while so many people were ready to do the most impudent things to obtain a seat there, I have felt that if I were sitting up there, in the present state of the dear old House; I should be able to do nothing but cry. That was not a feeling to “go out for to see” a show with! so I am at home, writing this note to you instead. Oh Darling! Your face, with all the anxiety and trouble taken out of it, And Lord Ashburton’s dear face with its sweet patient smile, would be a sight for me, worth all the Royal Processions that ever were got up!— When will you come back? Oh when will you come back? “I am to be patient, Dr Christison says, and set an example of patience—and it will be all well!” I try—but I cannot help its asking itself every now and then in my heart; “When? oh when will it be all well?— God keep you strong and brave—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [10 March]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries N.B. PM: London, 12 March 1863. MS: NLS 608.611A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: A letter was to have been written to go with the Coronet;Possibly the headdress referred to at the end of the letter. but some one interrupted me at the right time—and since then I have been in perfect misery with a violent Influenza—in my mouth! Positively there, and in no other part of me; except that pain in one place tingles thro’ all ones nervous sy[s]tem, and makes one generally indisposed. It is just as if I had taken a great bite of Influenza! and couldn’t swallow it, or spit it out or great rid of it anyhow! First my tongue swelled, and got raw on one side, so that when it touched my teeeth in speaking or eating it felt like being sawed into; then the soreness spread down to the roots of my tongue, and my jaws fell to aching and every one of my teeth! And there the cold stopt! It is a little better today, but yesterday I had to restrict my speech to monosyllables. Did you ever hear of such an absurd case? I have been so glad I did not go out on Saturday to see the triumphal entry of the young Princess;For two of the Illustrated London News’ series of full page engravings illustrating “The Reception of Princess Alexandra (Princess of Wales) in London,” see 84TC to JC, 7 March, and oppJWC to LLA, 7 March. for it would have made me still more comfortless to have had myself to blame for this torture. I had cards for the Scaffolding in front of Lord Ashburton’s House, one of the best sites for seeing, but even if I had liked the fuss of the thing; I think I should have felt horribly sad, sitting amongst gay rejoicing people, under the shadow of that empty sorrow-stricken House; thinking that they whose kind consideration had prepared that balcony for others, were themselves kept away by sickness and trouble. So I staid quietly at home, and wrote to Lady Ashburton instead. Lord A’s convalescence has now continued so long, tho’ at a rate of progress not perceptible from day to day, but only from week to week; that I feel some real hope of his return among us. Dr Christison thinks he will recover, and I have great reliance on his calm clear judgement, young tho’ he is. The Ashburtons themselves swear by Quain who flies back and forwards between London & Paris, like a weaver’s shuttle, making a pretty fortune out of this one case; and he too says Lord A will recover; but Quain is a slippery Irishman, and Christison is—a Scotchman! I trust him, and the other I think an entire Humbug.See JWC to MR, [12 Dec. 1862].
You have answered all my questions but one—about Mary’s Brother’s leg? mind that next time.

I assure you my Dear! Mary Hoggan will just stay on at Bellvue— She will hesitate and speculate till without meaning it, she has become reconciled to her circumstances where she is. There is a want in all the Hoggans.

Don’t be fancying you wont find as good a Servant as MarionMarion Kirk; see JWC to MR, [27 Jan. or 3 Feb.].— We all think that of a servant going against our own wish and as often as not we are agreeably disappointed

I thought the headress would suit you—when I was buying one for my-selfPossibly referred to in a fragment of MS in another hand: “(sent with a very handsome head-dress of crimson ribbon & velvet)” (filed with TC to UC, 27 March; MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib.). It can be made into ever so many different looking headdresses by adding black lace or white lace God bless you—love to the Dr
docBody.name: your JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-CTB, 16 March. MS: Mrs. A. A. Robey. Pbd: Charles T. Brooks, Poems, Original and Translated, with a Memoir by Charles W. Wendte (Boston, 1885) 60–62 inc. Charles Timothy Brooks (1813–83), Unitarian clergyman, poet, translator. He traveled in Europe 1865–66, visiting TC twice in Oct. 1865. TC wrote, top left of the first page: “to Chs T. Brooks Esq / Boston, U.S.”
div3.head:
TC
TO CHARLES T. BROOKS

docBody.p: Finding yr Translatn of such quality, I took steadily to reading it,—steadily gave myself abt an hour of it, the last thing every night, by way of washing down the bitter dusts of the day with a cup of right wine before going to bed! I am sorry it is done long since; for indeed I had not had any such reading for years back—and cd not but acknowledge, spite of all my criticisms, that here was more of real human stuff than in all the Novels written in my time. The Book is beautifully printed, too; every way an exquisite handful for a good reader.

You have been wonderfully successful; have caught a good deal of the tune of Jean Paul, and have unwinded his meaning, in general with perfect accuracy, into comfortable clearness, out of those coils he involves it in. I did not keep the original open all the way; but had a feeling that I was safe in yr
hands. One or two little specks I did notice,—nothing of any consequence:—Bouverot, whom you call “the German Gentn” is in reality the Teutsche Ordens herr; that is to say a “Teutonic Knight,”Brooks responded in his book: “The translator was aware of this, and used the word “Gentleman” in the most general sense, as we call a Senator ‘The Honorable Gentleman.’ Besides, to call him the Knight might have confounded him with Gaspard, who was also callused thus” (Brooks, Poems 61).—imaginary in everything, except his idle debauched way of life, and obligatn not to marry. His ehelosigkeit, I observe (once only), you have read as ehrlosigkeit; TC’s lines over the 2d “e” in “ehelosigkeit” and the “r” in “ehrlosigkeit,” indicating Brooks’s error. “scandal” instead of “celibacy.” Pray correct Bouvt in yr next editn. I once read “fixings,” too, in some Speech: do make it “trimmings,” or any equivalent English word; “fixings” came like a momentary splash of cold water on the skin; painfully reminding one, “Ha, it is not Jean Paul’s self that you are reading, then; it is an American Translatn of Jean Paul!

In conclusion I will congratulate you on having added a highly recognisable new item of good reading for the whole English Genealogy of us (now a most extensive Body of People in this world);—and with the hope of perhaps seeing a Hesperus Brooks replied, 20 May, thanking TC for his “most cordial letter,” and giving as partial excuse for his slowness in replying “that your word decided me to take hold of Hesperus, which has taken hold of me to such an extent that I do not always sense the flight of time nor the call of friendly obligations.” Brooks pbd. his trans. of Richter’s Hesperus, 2 vols. (Boston, 1865). from you some day, and certainly with many thanks, remain— Yours sincerely,—
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GW [GWE], [17 March]. Addr: Craigenvilla / Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 17 March 1863. MS: NLS 608.611B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:157–60. TC wrote on envelope: “Before St Leonds / 1863.“
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE WELSH

docBody.p:
I am wanting to know if your pains keep off.Grace suffered from pain in her head; see JWC to EW and GWEWAGW, [2 Feb.]. I hardly dare to hope it in these trying east-winds, which are the worst sort of weather for that sort of ailment. The last ten days have been horrid with us. all the worse for coming after such a summery February. My own head has been in a very disorganized state indeed! The cold came first into my tongue! swelling it, and making it raw on one side; so that for days, I had to live on slops and restrict my speech
to monosylables! then it got into my jaws and every tooth in my mouth; and that is the present state of me! I am writing with my pocket-handkerchief tied over my lower face, and my Imagination much overclouded by weary gnawing pain there. Decidedly a case for trying your remedy, and I mean to. have been thinking of realizing some chlorodineChlorodyne was invented, 1848, by John Collis Browne (1819–84; ODNB), physician and patent medicine manufacturer; also known as “Collis Browne’s mixture” it was composed of laudanum, cannabis, and chloroform; initially used to treat cholera, it came to be used in the treatment of insomnia, diarrhea, neuralgia, and migraines. all the week. But either it has been too cold for me to venture up to the Druggists in Sloane Square,Charles Rowett Quiller (b. 1829), chemist, 15 Sloane Sq. or I have had to go somewhere else. It is a comfort to reflect anyhow, that I have not brought these aches on myself, by rushing “out for to see,” the new Princess; as the rest of the world did; or to see the Illuminations! I had an order sent me from Paris for seats for myself and “a friend” in the balcony errected at Bath House—the best for seeing in the whole line of the procession. But first I have no taste for crowds; and secondly I felt it would be so sad, sitting there, when the Host & Hostess were away in such sickness and sorrow. and thirdly I was somewhat of Mr C’s opinion, that this marriage, the whole nation was running mad after, was less really interesting to every individual of them than setting a Hen of ones own on a nest of sound eggs would be!!

The only interest I take in the little new Princess is founded on her previous poverty, and previous humble homely life.Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, Princess Alexandra’s father, was from a junior branch of the Danish royal family and did not become heir until 1852, ascending to the throne Nov. 1863. He and his family had lived on his pay as an army officer. I have heard some touching things about that, from people connected with the Court. When she was on her visit to the queen after her engagement. She always wore a jacket. The Queen said to her one day; “I think you always wear a jacket; how is that?” “Oh, said little Alexandra, I wear it because it is so econmical! you can wear it with any sort of gown—and you know I have always had to make my own gowns!— I have never had a Ladysmaid—and my sistersAlexandra’s sisters were Daymar (1845–94), m., 1866, Alexander III of Russia (1845–1894), becoming Empress Maria Fyodorovna; and Thyra (1853–1933), m., 1878, Prince Ernst August of Hanover (1845–1923), 3d duke of Cumberland. and I all made our own clothes—i even made my bonnet!“— Two or three days after the marriage she wrote to her Mother.Princess Louise of Hesse-Kassel (1817–98). “I am so happy! I have just breakfasted with Bertie (Albert, her Husband) and I have on a white muslin dressing gown, beautifully trimmed with pink ribbon!“— Her Parents were not so rich as most London shopkeepers—have from seven hundred to a thousand a year! That interests
me—and I also feel a sympathy with her in the prospect of the bother she will have by and by with that mean-natured, half distracted Queen.Queen Victoria, in deep mourning for Prince Albert since his death Dec. 1861.

You have never found the missing photograph?Photograph of Robert Welsh; see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March]. I am so sorry aboutit!— Please write—ever so little—but I want to know if you keep free of pain. I am not up to a long letter. I am glad you are going to the Bridge of AllanSpa town 2½ mi. (4 km.) NW of Stirling. — It will do Ann good for certain and you probably And you will be able to judge of Grace’s“One of Robert Welsh’s daughters who also died” (TC’s note; Froude, LM 3:160). Grace Dobie d. 2 Oct.; she was this Grace Welsh’s niece and JWC’s cousin. health with your own eyes which are better than other peoples reports— I have seen noth[in]g of Mrs George“Welsh (of Richmond)” (TC’s note; Froude, LM 3:160). Margaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George Welsh. lately tho of course she would [be]Word omitted. in at the show love to you all your affectionate
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AI, 18 March. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:186–88; Conway, Carlyle 216–17 inc. Alexander Ireland (1810–94; ODNB), journalist; see TC to JCH, 28 Jan. 1847.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER IRELAND

docBody.p: I am glad to hear of you again; and much obliged for those toThus in MS. Portraits of Emerson. The Painted one I cannot endure; but the actual Shadow by the SunA “sun picture,” i.e., a photograph. The photograph albums have several photographs of Emerson, including one with TC’s comment underneath: “Very bad Picture of R. Waldo Emerson (Concord, Mass)” (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 4, no. 2, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). (who aims at nothing but the truth) is beautiful and really interesting to me. Wonderfully little oldened; has got a black wig, I see; nothing else changed!—

Two or three weeks ago a Mr DoegW. H. Doeg; see TC to JN, 21 Jan. forwarded me a clipping from yr NewspaperIreland was the publisher of the Manchester Examiner. (I think, yours); some Letter from somebody, abt a wonderful self-condemnatory Ms.Les Matinées Royales; see TC to JN, 21 Jan. by Frh the Great, gathered at Berlin by some Duke
de Rovigo,Anne-Jean-Marie-René Savary (1774–1833), duc de Rovigo, French general and diplomat under Napoleon Bonaparte; he was also supposed to have stolen the document from Frederick’s writing table in Sans-Souci in 1806; see J. W. Whittall, Frederick the Great on Kingcraft (1901) 9. for the endless gratitude of the curious. I had not heard of the monstrous Platitude at all till then, but guessed then what it wd be,—an old acquaintance of mine, truly a thrice-brutal Stupidity, whh has had redhot pokers indignantly run thro’ it abt 10 times, but always revives & steps forth afresh, with new tap of the parish-drum, there being no “parish” in the universe richer in prurient darkness and flunkey malevolence than ours is!— I set Neuberg upon it, in the Athenaeum; but know not what he has made of it. No Editor, in my time, has crowned himself with such a Pair of Ears as he of the Wms and Norgate Periodical.John Acton and the Home and Foreign Review; see TC to JN, 21 Jan. It is a clear fact, tho’ not clear in Engld, that here is the most brutish of Mooncalves lately heard of in any country; that to have one moment’s belief, or doubt, on such a subject is to make affidavit that yr knowledge of Frh and his Affairs is zero and less! Wd to Heaven I were “done with them“! I never in my life was held in such hurry,—to last 6 months yet. Yrs ever, T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, 19 March. MS: Trinity. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:94; Wilson, Carlyle 5:523. Quot: Hansons, NE 504.
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: It is “no go“!Milnes invited the Carlyles to visit him at Fryston Hall, Yorkshire: “But Carlyle was deep in his ‘Frederick,’ and sternly withstood the temptation” (Reid, RMM 2:94). I was a fool to hope that anything so pleasant could get “carried out“; and the ghost of that old Prussian déspot still unlaid!

I have introduced the subject at every least unauspicious moment presenting itself, since the night you were here; but every time with more determined ill success. “It is such a distance!—“Fryston is about 190 mi. (306 km.) N of London. “Well! what of an hour or two longer on the road when we are once started“?— “Oh very easy for you to say that, who rather like railway travelling; but for me who hate it; a-bo-minate it; am driven perfectly mad by it &c &c &c“— And in short he thinks to give a week of his time at EasterEaster Sunday was 5 April. for the good of his health and the assuagement of his soul would be a sort of school-boy truant-playing—unworthy of a
Historian! and so God help him!—and God particularly help me! for (in the words of an Annandale Poet not sufficiently known to Fame)

lg.l: “I’m a poor luckless Cretur
“And if I were ded
“And a stone at my hed
“I think it would be beter!See JWC to MCA, [ca. 16 Dec. 1862].

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JA [JAUS], [20 March]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan / N.B. PM: London, 21 March 1863. MS: NLS 608.612A. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:286–87 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:496.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Thanks for your letter. I shall be glad to have more, and favourable news of the poor wee Bairn.Mary Stewart, da. of Jane Austin’s sister Margaret; she was apparently born with some kind of growth on her head; see 38:214JWC to MCA, [15 Sept. 1862], and TC to AC, 31 March. It will be a great mercy to have that lump removed; but it is very sad to think of so wee a creature being subjected to such pain.

The last eggs arived in comparitively good condition. There were just eight broken ones, and they were not wasted, being still whole enough for puddings. The carriage was four shillings this time—one can never understand the rules of “Karag” (carriage) as John MacNight used to spell it.John McKnight, letter carrier between Dumfries and Thornhill; see 4:438JWC to TC, 30 Dec. [1828]; for “Karag” or “Kerrag,” see 7:42TC to JAC [18 Nov. 1833]. I sincerely hope that by the time this supply is consumed the Chelsea Hens will have got into some regular habit of laying. I know at present of only one Bantam that does “what England expects of her“!Coterie speech; see 33:13JWC to TC, [7 Aug. 1857].—and you may imagine what would be Mr C’s ferocity, if he were [to] sit down to a daily Bantam-egg!

We are very thankful in this house, to have got done with “the Royal Marriage” Tho neither Mr C nor I “went out for [to] see” any part of the business, we could not get out of the noise and fuss about it. “Very curious! Mr C said; There is not a single Individual of the whole Nation, running mad after this marriage; for whom it would not be in reality more interesting to set a hen of ones own on a nest of proper eggs!“

The most interesting part of the Princess Alexandra to me, is not her present splendours but her previous homely, rather poor life, which makes
such a curious contrast! Her Parents, “royal” tho they be, have an income of just from seven hundred to a thousand a year! When she was visiting our Queen after the engagement, she always came to breakfast in a jacket. “My Dear, said the Queen to her one day, you seem very fond of jackets! how is it that you always wear a jacket?” “Well, said little Alexandra, I like them, and then you see a jacket is so economical! you can wear different skirts with it; and I have very few gowns, having to make them all myself! My Sisters and I have no Lady’s maid, and have been brought up to make all our own clothes. I made my own bonnet!“— Bless her!

Mr C goes on very contentedly without a horse. Did you hear that he sold his beautiful Fritz for nine pounds?! But the Apothecary who bought him was to ride him and better he should have him for nothing than that he had been sold at ever so much to be lashed into drawing in a waggon, I would rather he had been shot than that. Meanwhile Mr C walks and—rides in Omnibuses!! and finds the variety amusing— He “now meets human beings to speak to!” How long he will be able to enjoy walking I cannot predict. Love to you all
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [20 March]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. N.B. PM: London, 21 March 1863. MS: NLS 608.612B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:160–61 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 505.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Yes, my dear Dear, the Dr was right; the cold in my mouth was symptomatic of nothing but just cold in the mouth! I was afraid myself, for some days, it might turn to a regular Influenza: the only time I ever had the same sort of thing as bad before, being in the course of that dangerous Influenza I had, a good many years ago, when I had first to call in Mr Barnes.April 1859; see 35:81TC to JCA, 20 April 1859. But I have got off with the ten days of sore tongue and faceache, which is almost cured by the west wind we have had for the last two days.

My Aunt Grace has “suffered Martyrs” (as a french friendCoterie speech; Etienne Paulet (d. 1850; see 25:34025:biographical notes), Swiss French businessman. of mine used to express it) from faceache and pains of the head during this last winter; and cured herself (she believes) in a day, by the new-pet-medecine Chlorodyne. She was in an agony that could no longer be born; and invested half-a crown in a small bottle of Chlorodyne; and took ten drops every two hours, till she
had taken as many as fifty; and then fell into a refreshing sleep and (when she wrote) had had no return of the pain for three weeks! I haven’t much faith in medecines that work as by miracle; and am inclined to belive that her pain having reached its height had been ready to subside of itself when the Chlorodyne was taken— Still as there might be some temporary relief, more or less, in the thing, I too invested in a small vial and took ten drops when I was going to bed one night; and the only effect traceable in my case was a very dry, dirty mouth next morning To the best of my taste it was composed of Chl[o]roform, Strong peppermint, and some other carminatives. Has the Dr used it? The ApothecaryCharles Quiller. here told me it was not sold much by itself, but that a great deal was used in the Drs prescriptions— As you seem to have some loyalty towards the new Princess from your wondering I didnt “go out for to see” the rather stupid Prince and her drive along the street in an open carriage; I will tell you something told me about her, on Court authority, which did interest me, much more than the accounts of her endless presents of diamonds, and all the rest of her honours and glories.

When she was on her visit to the queen after the engagement, She always appeared during the day in a jacket. One time the queen said to her, “My Dear you seem very fond of jackets; how is it that you always wear a jacket?“— “Well, you see, said little Alexandra, a jacket is so economical! you can wear it with different skirts! and I have very few gowns; having to make them all myself! My Sisters and I have no Ladysmaid and we have all been brought up to make our own clothes. I made my own bonnet!“

In fact her parents are very poor—poorer than most of your Gentleman-Farmers. They have from seven hundred to a thousand a year. Imagine how bewildered she must feel in the midst of her present splendours.

Three days after her marriage she wrote to her Mother from OsborneQueen Victoria’s residence on the Isle of Wight. “I am so happy! I have just breakfasted with Bertie (Albert—her Husband) and am dressed in a white muslin dressing-gown beautifully trimmed with pink ribbon.“— Rather cold for the Season one would say; but I dare say she looked very pretty in it. Did I tell you that Mr C’s Horse came down with him one day and cut its knees to the bone and has been sold for nine pounds! It cost fifty and was cheap at that My Aunt Grace writes that “Mrs FergusonA former servant of JWC’s aunts; see 38:255TC to LALA, 5 Nov. 1862. is still praying diligently for Mr C and that perhaps it was due to her prayers that Mr C was not hurt on that occasion“!!
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WBC, 20 March. Copy: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. John Downes wrote the copy on the reverse of TC’s covering letter (see TC to JODO, [21 March]) and headed it “Copy of Testimonial in my behalf for the Examinership in Logic & Morals in the London University.” William Benjamin Carpenter (1813–85; ODNB), biologist and university administrator; registrar of London University 1856–79.
div3.head: TC TO W. B. CARPENTER

docBody.dateline: To Dr Carpenter &c. &c. (at Burlington House).The offices of the Royal Society, of which Carpenter was a fellow, were at Burlington House.
docBody.p: In late years I have had the pleasure of occasionally conversing with Mr J. Downes, as well as of reading some of his Writings in Reviews; and am able to testify that he is a man of good faculties industriously cultivated; altogether intelligent, solid, honest in his ways of thinking, and I believe of acting and living. General report speaks him well read in Metaphysical philosophy; and I can myself perceive that he is very definite and perspicuous in Knowing whatever he knows. As College Examiner on such subjects, I should think him likely to do skilful and faithful service.
docBody.name: Ths Carlyle

ps.p: 5, Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea, 20th March 1863.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JD, [21 March]. Addr: 18. Glo’ster Road / Upper Holloway / N. PM: 21 March 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN DOWNES

docBody.p: I have written a hasty word for you, whh is here inclosed.See TC to WBC, 20 March.
I sincerely hope you will get this Office; it seems peculiarly suited for you as you for it. If I cd help in any way, it wd give me real pleasure.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 23 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:496–97; Hansons, NE 505–6 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I wonder if you are returned to Paris? I wonder if you are better? I wonder if the wee darling knew you?Lady Ashburton had been to Nice to see her da., Mary Florence, who was there in the care of her sister-in-law Maria Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie, known as “Mrs. George“; see 38:256JWC to MR, [3 Nov. 1862], and Surtees, Ludovisi 94. oh I wonder so many things!— It wouldn’t surprise me to find, you that youThus in MS. hadn’t been able to let the little “lump of delight” out of your arms, after having again got her into them; and so; that she had accompanied you back to Paris! Oh what a pleasure it will be to think of you all under one roof again, and a roof of your own! The Grange!—oh to be going to see you,—to be with you all at the Grange—again—after all these troubles and terrors! I think you scarcely take in the deep, glad interest with which your return is looked forwarded to. “People are so illnatured“! Ay, that they are!—illnatured and disloyal—most of them! but People are human! are capable of being touched by noble patience, and warm-hearted devotion! I know not the man or the woman who speaks of Lord Ashburton and you, in these sad times, otherwise than sympathizingly and reverently. Even Women, whom envy and jealousy made spiteful towards you before, have quite changed their tone, and speak of you now as fellow-women not as rivals!—

I dare not ask Dr Christison to “predict” any more; but surely when Lord Ashburton is got the length of cutting up the leaves of books again predicting must be beginning to assume less unfeasibility even for men “only educated at the Edinr College of Medececine,“Thus in MS; Dr. Christison had studied medicine at Edinburgh Univ., 1848–51. as he said.

Mr C is really thriving (for the time being, on his horselessness! finds it “an unspeakable deliverance” he says “to be no longer strapped to the back of that miserable quadruped, as he had been for the last eight years, but at liberty to walk out into the streets and speak to human beings!” So he has taken no steps towards replacing ‘Fritz,’ nor will, so long as the novelty of walking pleases him. “It will be time enough to return to his dreary isolation” he says, when his health seems to require horse-exercise again So you see—! Most generous of created women!Presumably Lady Ashburton had offered a horse for TC; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 1 May, and TC to JAC, 16 May. Lord Ashburton had also offered one the previous autumn; see 38:252TC to LOA, 2 Nov. 1862.—

Poor Fritz was sold to a neighbouring Apothecary for nine pounds!!! Mr C rode him once, before he was sold “just to sooth the poor quadruped’s feelings, by showing him he was forgiven“! I wonder what Biped he would have done as much for? The Town has been much enlivened by the “Convicted Felon” at the Drawingroom.Samuel Tillett (b. 1791), despite being convicted of forgery and fraud, July 1853, at Chelmsford Assizes and sentenced to seven years’ transportation, was presented at the levée held by the prince of Wales on behalf of the queen, 25 Feb. His presentation was then “cancelled” (London Gazette, 6 March). I was told that it was the Chief BaronSir Jonathan Frederick Pollock (1783–1870; ODNB), lawyer and politician, lord chief baron of the exchequer, 1844–66, had tried Tillett and was present at the levée. TC knew his eldest son, Frederick Pollock. who sentenced him who recognised him there! Dramatic if true!

I have a photograph of you—but I dont think it half so good as the one on the hearthrugJWC had asked for a copy of a photograph of Lady Ashburton lying on a hearthrug, June 1860; see 36:138JWC to LLA, [16 June 1860].
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 March. MS: NLS 526.4. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I am still struggling in the whirlpool; but shall now for certain be out soon,—Hochkirch all on paper; and the anchor actually to drop (on spring cable) after that. I am not ill in health; seem to agree with walking almost better than horse-exercise hitherto: I calculate on getting on a great deal faster, were I once on tabula rasa [clean slate] with my implements (not dove-tailing and in-laying in this sad way,—all along up to Hochkirch),—especially were I thro’ the 7-Yrs War to whh I allot 150 pages now, less if possible, not more by any means! Some way or other, within the next 6 or 8 months, thro’ I will be, if alive: that I count upon as certain. And at times, my “joy” in the prospect—is nothing like so lively as I often thot it might have been. Out of that huge Enterprise,—but into what? Old age and nothing at all?— Not quite; “wir heissen euch hoffen [we bid you hope],“Cf. 9:53TC to JOST, 11 Sept. 1836. Not quite!—

Nothing cd be clearer than your brief readings and commentaries Nos 1, 2, 3, upon the Darnley-Murder Engraving:See TC to JAC, 5 March. I undersood it all like a bit of Euclid;TC presumably refers to the fact that the original plan (see 3) was in fact two separate drawings joined together at right angles, so they needed to be taken apart and realigned in order to understand them; see Henry F. Kerr, “The Kirk-of-Field and the University of Edinburgh,” University of Edinburgh Journal 5 (1932–33): 223–27. did not find a single error or oversight,—except the very last
extraneous hint, whh was extraneous and of no moment: viz. That Adam Square (north of the College) instead of College-Street (back premises abt middle of College Street)Adam Sq., built 1764 and demolished 1871, NE of the college, behind College St. N (now Chambers St.). was the scene of the explosn,—whh latter exactly agrees with the locality assigned by Robertson: “Principal’s House” (i.e. old Anatomy Fyfe’s House, whh was standing in our time).“The place prepared for [Darnley’s] reception was a house belonging to the provost of a collegiate church, called Kirk of Field. It stood almost upon the same spot where the house belonging to the principal of the university now stands” (William Robertson, The History of Scotland [1794] 1:410). The Principal’s House, demolished 1818, was on the S side of the college buildings, and the actual site of the murder, the Prebendaries’ House, was in the SE corner of what is now Old College. Andrew Fyfe (1752–1824; ODNB), anatomist, held the post of dissector, principal janitor, and macer, 1777–1812, which gave him a free house in the college. TC attended Edinburgh University, 1809–14; and John A. Carlyle attended, 1822–26.— Froude came here the night after yr Letter came; he agreed in every particr; took yr notes with him to correct his own DrawingFroude was working on vols. 7 and 8 of his History of England (1863), which included Darnley’s murder; for his description of the scene, see History of England 8:361–62. by (and mine also); and has not yet returned anything of them.

Our weather is very pretty: it is time I were out into it,—“past 3” before I began upon you here. Yesterday, in my eagerness to finish Hochkh while the iron kept hot, it was near six or five! But that is quite a rare & seldom permissible case. Last Sunday, for instance, I went abt idle all day.

You will pehaps be able to do something for JamieTheir nephew James Carlyle worked for William Baird & Co., an ironworks company based in Gartsherrie, Lanarkshire; see 38:101–2TC to JAC, 18 June 1862. Currently employed at the Muirkirk site, in Ayrshire, he hoped to be moved to their estate at Ury, nr. Stonehaven, Kincardineshire. John Gordon wrote to John A. Carlyle, 23 Feb.: “I was at Gartsherrie today. … [James] is exceedingly well liked by all the people he has to do with—and considered most intelligent and clever. … It is Wallace’s design … to have him manager at Urie, but the Laird is not so immediate in his necessity. My impression continues that James should keep firm hold where he is,—and in the nature of things his advancemt must take place shortly” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086); probably David Wallace (d. 1877); see 38:102TC to JAC, 18 June 1862. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 17 April: “young James of Scotsbrig … is … still at Muirkirk, & has got an increase of salary.“ at Glasgow; at any rate, we shall hear more distinctly how he stands. Jamie Aitken (after long delays, twice written to in vain) came on friday last: looking well in health, but strangely silent, absent-looking, indistinct,—as if he had perhaps fallen in love? Jean and her PainterTheir sister Jean’s husband, James, was a house painter. we have often heard abt: Jean seems the cheeriest of us all just now.

A Letter came from Madme Otthenin this morning;—genial really, tho’
confused: —Jane had it and is out, so I cannot send it. My compts there; and “will write.” Cannot you get the poor Lady to drive out into the Sun; 2 hours even in Omnibus, much more 2 spent calling &c wd do her much good. Call & see her! Everything you write on that topic interests me. Adieu, dear Brother. T. Carlyle
Kind unvarying regards to Erskine & House.Thomas Erskine and his sisters, Christian Stirling and David Paterson.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 27 March. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd. For the fragment in another hand, filed with this MS, see JWC to MR, [10 March].
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—You are not to stumble at that Passage.Unidentified. It means only that there is pity in our heart for all the dead, and no angel more;—whh I think is true withal, tho’ it might have been more carefully expressed.
In great haste

ps.p: Chelsea, 27 March 1863—

div3.sourceNote: TC: Memoranda on the Keiths [ETWI], 27 March. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Written for Edward Twisleton, it was enclosed in TC to ETWI, 28 March.
div3.head: TC’S MEMORANDA ON THE KEITHS TO EDWARD TWISLETON

docBody.p: memda Concerng Feldmarschall Keith.TC wrote a similar memorandum for Lady Ashburton, 26 Jan. 1861; see 37:100–103TC to LLA, 26 Jan. 1861. James Francis Edward Keith (1696–1758; ODNB), Prussian field marshal; see 34:195TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858.— Born at Inverugie, Aberdeenshire (not Fetteresso, Kincardineshire, as the Dictionaries say) june 1696; fell (shot “thro’ the left side,” heart or nearly so?) ;6½ a.m. 14 Octr, 1758, a little way to the east of Hochkirch Church and village (whh is 40 miles or so to n.e. of Dresden): Buried there next day; but taken to Berlin, 3d feby following, and re-interred with all manner of solemnity in the Garnison-Kirche (Campus Martius of Pra).See Carlyle, Works 17:423. — His Brother the Earl MarischalGeorge Keith (ca. 1693–1778; ODNB), 10th Earl Marischal; Jacobite army officer, and diplomat in the Prussian service. seems to have been abt 4 years older;—died 22 May 1778, age I think abt 86. Both were great favourites; James a man of much real faculty, culture and worth.

They had two Sisters:Lady Mary Keith (ca. 1695–1721), m. John Fleming (ca. 1674—ca. 1743), 6th earl of Wigton; and Lady Anne Keith (d. 1728), m. Alexander Stewart (ca. 1694–1773), 6th earl of Galloway. the elder married the then Earl of Wigton,—and left
one Daughter, Clementina Fleming; who married the Lord ElphinstoneClementina Fleming (1719–99), m. Charles Elphinstone (1711–81), 10th Lord Elphinstone. of her time: the children, I observe, are looked upon by the old Marischal as his heirs:Neither George or James Keith had children, and the title died with them. one of them (a cadet Elphinstone) became famous in the Navy; “took the Cape of Good Hope &c &c;—and was raised to the Peerage, by the title of KeithGeorge Keith Elphinstone (1746–1823), Viscount Keith, naval officer and politician. (own Xtian name was Keith, & his Grandmother’s people had stood Marischals regni Scotiae [of the Kingdom of Scotland] for 700 years): this one was the Father of the Lady Keith-Flahaut.Margaret Mercer Elphinstone (1788–1867), m., 1817, Auguste Charles Joseph (1785–1870), Comte de Flahaut (Flahault) de la Billardrie, former aide-de-camp to Napoleon I, and French ambassador to Italy, Austria, and Great Britain. — — —Feldmll Keith was Grandson’s Grandson of him who founded Marischal College, AberdeenMarischal Coll., Aberdeen, founded 1593 by George Keith (ca. 1549–1623; ODNB), 5th Earl Marischal; see Carlyle, Works 18:203. (honour to him also). (This Mema is for E. T.’s self; who asked me, when I cd not tell. What follows he knows what to do with, in time & place).Twisleton had asked for this information so that he could pass it on to Emily Jane, b. Flahaut (Flahault) (1819–95), Lady Lansdowne, m., 1843, Henry Thomas Petty-Fitzmaurice (1816–66; ODNB), 4th marquess of Lansdowne; she was the eldest da. of the count and countess de Flahaut de la Billardrie, and great-grandda. of Lady Mary Keith. Twisleton sent the Memoranda to Lady Landsdowne, 29 March, describing them as “the Autograph of a remarkable Man respecting a remarkable Hero of your own family” (MS: EUL).

1° Keith’s Letters (I think all to his Elder Brother) are the one merit of Lord Dover’s Histy of FrederickGeorge James Welbore Agar-Ellis (1797–1833; ODNB), 1st Baron Dover, The Life of Frederic the Second, King of Prussia, 2 vols. (1832). (so say all the Germans; I myself never saw the Book; tho’ I have many, probably all, of the Letters in difft Books.) They are excellent Letters, intrinsically, extrinsically; and others exist in the Mitchell PapersSee TC to JN, [17 Dec. 1862]. &c &c. A careful Collection shd be formed of them, one and all (Copies, where the Originals cannot be had), and carefully kept. They will grow in value, for a long time to come yet. In short, they are historically important.

2° One WeidemannWeidemann not further identified. was James Keith’s Secretary, for I know not how many years; and kept a Diary (Weidemann’s Tagebuch,) whh is sometimes quoted by Preuss; apparently a very intelligent punctual Diary,—“whh ceases on the Day of Hochkirch” or the day after. If I were a certain Lady, not to say if I were the King of Pra,Wilhelm Friedrich Ludwig (1797–1888), king of Prussia 1861–88. I wd give a great deal of money for that Ms.! It cd be accurately copied at least, witht very much expense. When Preuss wrote
(in 1838) it was in the hands of a “Captain Gansauge” (Rittmeister, Cavalry Captn);TC wrote “Goose-eye!” above “Gansauge.” Probably Hermann von Gansauge (1799–1871), German cavalry officer. (Preuss, Friedrh der Grosse, 5 voll. ii. 140n.) Preuss is still living, Historiographer Royal; a faithful tho’ a dull man.Johann David Erdmann Preuss (1785–1868), German historian whose works TC consulted extensively; see 30:139TC to JN, 12 Dec. 1855, and Carlyle, Works 12:324. The Prussn AmbassadorAlbrecht von Bernstorff (1809–73), Prussian statesman; ambassador to Great Britain 1854–61 and 1862–73. cd easily inquire it out.

3° (Tho’ this is quite a small matter). There shd be a Photograph taken by some Tourist (or better, by some Artist sent from Dresden for the purpose) of Keith’s fine little Monument and itsTC wrote: “(t. o. invert)” here. surroundings, in the Church of Hochkirch. I remember it with a kind of pious pleasure. A little Urn of white Marble on a Pedestal of I think grey; Letters in Gold,—and one of the finest Inscripions I ever read (is printed, right all except a “Qui,” whh is redundant, in Sir Robt Murray Keith’s Correspondence, London, 1849, i.151 (was set up by that Sir R., end of 1771)).TC’s double bracket.—“Dum, in Praelio non procul hinc, Inclinatam aciem suorum restituebat, Mente, manu, voce et exemplo, Pugnans ut Heroas decet, Occubuit. Die XIV Octobris” [Who, in battle near this spot, rallying his nigh-desperate men, by head, by hand, by voice and example, fighting as beseems heroes fell, 14 October] (that is my remembrance of it,—like the sound of steel)—For TC’s earlier description of the monument (where he says the urn is of black marble) and inscription to Sir Robert Murray Keith, see 37:101–3TC to EMK, 26 Jan. 1861; the word order of the inscription was slightly different.
Enough, enough. (27 March 1863. Midnight) / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-ETETWI, 28 March. MS: Harvard. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD TWISLETON

docBody.p:
To finish the little matter we spoke of, the other evg, and wash my poor hands of it whh are dyed with so many other things,—I took pen yesternight, the last thing, down-stairs; and (on such scandalous scraps of paper as lay about) put down the inclosed small Memoranda, whh include the essential of that business.Edward Twisleton had asked Carlyle for information on Marshal Keith and his family; see TC’s Memoranda, 27 March. And lest you do not come to me agn for some time (you faithless individual), I send the matter off to you at once by such Address as I
have.Twisleton lived at 3 Rutland Gate but traveled frequently. Your or other people’s matter henceforth; not mine any more. In another week I expect to have done with the KeithsTC was still writing about the Keiths in the last book (21) of Frederick (see Carlyle, Works 19). for all time; and except as a good citizen and Terrae filius [son of the land] of the Planet and Country whh produced them, have no concern farther.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], 29 March. Pbd: Blunt, “CLC” 416.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: It was a nice thought in you to send the violets. A kind little practical thought!—just like my little Charlotte in her good Time; when she was a bright, loving girl, full of aspirations after knowledge and refinement,—before she had become stubborn and callous on my hands and taken up with people and things unworthy of her,—quite beneath the sphere in which Nature, by endowing her so richly with taste and intelligence, seemed to have appointed her to ‘live and have her Being!’Cf. Acts 17:28.— Oh child! child! you have no idea of the disappointment, the heart-sorrow you caused me! I had set so much love on you, and so much hope! So much permanent good was to have come out of our chance-relation for both of us! And all ending in a mere vulgar common-place disruption betwixt Mistress and Maid!—in a mere vulgar common-place attempt on both sides to “better oneself“!Charlotte, dismissed in May 1861, “‘bettered herself’ shortly after leaving Chelsea, by taking a place as under-housemaid at the Marquis of Camden’s Kent house, The Wilderness” (Blunt, “CLC” 416). George Charles Pratt (1799–1866), 2d marquis of Camden.—no!—not ending all and absolutely in that!— There are the violets!—and this letter!—so much (alas! how small a thing!) saved from the wreck of my sentimental venture!

Do you know the violets found me breakfasting in bed, (the first and only time I have breakfasted in bed these twelve months!) and their sweet smell reminded me somehow of your kind nursing in my long Influenza.Either JWC’s illness, July 1858, just after Charlotte’s arrival (see 34:8JWC to TC, [4 July 1858], and 24–25JWC to TC, [10 July 1858]), or her illness, Aug. 1860, after Charlotte’s dismissal, when she came back to nurse JWC (see 36:201JWC to MCA, [25 Aug. 1860]). No one has nursed me as kindly and as cleverly since!

I was so sorry for your Mother’s terrible loss!Mrs. Southam’s loss unidentified. it has told on her looks
poor woman! I hope you write to her often and are all the comfort you can be to her.
docBody.name: JANE W. CARLYLE.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 31 March. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 740–41.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p: Chelsea, 31 March 1863.— My dear Brother, Jean, you perceive, has sent this around by me, th[at]MS torn. I might add a “message“: but she has not left the smallest particle of margin, and I find it is unsafe to add half a grain to her weight! However, I have found a scrap of the thinnest Paper in the world, whh may hold a poor word.— Did you know before about the “new House“? (it stands on the Lochmaben road,James and Jean Aitken were building a house in Dumfries; see 38:62TC to JCA, 17 Feb. 1862, and 164TC to JCA, 27 Aug. 1862. Lochmaben, town, 9 mi. (14.5 km.) NE of Dumfries. as I understand, a gunshot or two beyond the railway station, say three gunshots beyond the last houses of the Town, and looks towards the west, from the east side of the road). Or about Margt Austin’s Husband? (one Stewart son of some Ayrshire Milk people, neighbours to Gill, said to be a very good man of his kind). Of this House and poor Child’s Head,Mary Stewart; see JWC to JAJAUS, [20 March]. we here have heard a great deal, tho’ we (at least, I) never saw either of them.

For our own part, we are as you last heard of us; Jane sometimes very sleepless, feeble, tho’ she has got better thro’ the past winter than usual,—one of the warmest winters, or the very warmest ever seen.See TC to JAC, 28 Dec., and TC to JAC, 29 Jan. I am within 8 months (as I strive to believe) of ending my terrible Book. It has nearly ended me: never in my life had I such an adventure. My poor old body seems broken, my poor old heart broken. However, I have but one course: to sprawl forward, while there is isThus in MS. the breath of life left in me, and try to finish. I think I shd then grow a little better, old as I am.— I read yr Letter as it passed; with great thankfulness to see so comfortable a glimpse of you all. “Eight months hence” (if I live to finish), I will write a deliberate Letter of my own to [you]MS torn. Jack lives habitually in Edinr, these last two years; I live the loneliest life here,—am obliged to do it. Al[l my mo]mentsMS torn. are for work (or shd be).— God’s blessing be on you, dear Brother, and on all yours. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, [late March?]. MS: Osborn Coll., Yale, inc. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by TC’s having worked on Frederick for “ten years and more“; placed here because of his hope that he would be finished in “some 6 or 8 months more,” as he also wrote in TC to JAC, 26 March, and TC to AC, 31 March. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 31 March 1863.]
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: These ten years and more, I have lived sunk into the abysses, a subterranean life, amid Prussian Nightmares, and Human Stupidity, in every form of Dragon & Python and foul Lindwurm [dragon]:—a terrific process that of fishing up any poor Hero from such an element!— In some 6 or 8 months more, if things go well, I hope to revisit the upper Air for good; and enjoy my Friends agn, while they and I are alive together.
With many good wishes & regards, spoken or not spoken, I remain always, dear Madam,

ps.p: blessing from me, or from another, in that extraordinary character, alto-This partial sentence is possibly another fragment from the same letter.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], [early April]. Pbd: Ruskin’s Works 17:lxx inc; Cate 103–4 inc. Ruskin accidentally destroyed a letter from TC; he included his reconstruction of it in a letter to his father, John James Ruskin, 7 and 11 April 1863. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 4 April 1863.]
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
There is a felicity of utterance in itRuskin’s last of four “Essays on Political Economy,” Fraser’s Magazine 67 (April 1863): 441–62; see 38:80TC to JAF, 14 April 1862, and 107TC to JRU, 30 June 1862. The essays were eventually pbd. as Munera Pulveris (1872) and dedicated to TC; see 37:29–30TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860. … here and there, such as I remember in no other writer, living or dead, and it’s all as true as gospel. … What enlightened public will make of it, I know not. To be visited with such a dividing of joint and marrow!Cf. Heb. 4:12. so quiet, so sudden, fatal as the swordRuskin noted: “[H]ere a proper name for sword I could not read“; presumably the word was “Balmung” or “Mimung.“ … to the unhappy smith who only knew he was killed by feeling the iron in his inside, and had to shake himself before he fell in two.For the story of the Sword Balmung, or Mimung, see “The Nibelungen Lied” (Carlyle, Works 27:233). Euge! I tell you I know nothing like it for felicity of expression; John MillJohn Stuart Mill, one of the political economists against whom Ruskin wrote; see 37:30TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860. keeps not closer to his dialectics, and he but with one gift, while here are so many;—a man who comes on etymologically,
phantastically, propheticallyRuskin noted: “I am not sure of this last word—could not decipher it; if it is right, it means ‘eloquently,’ but is stronger.“ … all at once. Glad I am that you are in for a continuanceThis was the last of Ruskin’s essays to be pbd. at this time; as with the earlier articles in the Cornhill Magazine (see 37:29–30TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860, and 38:107TC to JRU, 30 June 1862), public outcry stopped publication; Ruskin wrote in the preface to Munera Pulveris: “Then, though the Editor [Froude] had not wholly lost courage, the Publisher [John William Parker] indignantly interfered; and the readers of Fraser, as those of the Cornhill, were protected, for that time, from farther disturbance on my part” (Ruskin, Munera Pulveris xxiii). John William Parker (1792–1870; ODNB; see 21:209–10TC to ES, 14 May 1847).—I care not now at what interval: I have lived to see it said clearly that government.Ruskin noted: “I forget the exact phrase following, but it meant the assertion of authority generally over mob.“

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [12 April]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 13 April 1863. MS: NLS 608.613A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: You were right my Dear! It was Influenza—in my mouth! At least that absurd tongue was the beginning of a series of woes that finally gathered themselves together into a regular attack of Influenza from which I am now recovering hardly recovered. I couldnt write nor do anything for a fortnight. So, if you were taking it into your head I was forgetting you (I know you are capable of strange ideas) here is my silence explained in a more creditable manner.

Since the East wind left off blowing the rheumatic part of my illness has cleared off—and at present I have nothing to complain of but some cough and the weakness and lowness that Influenza always leaves.

I cannot then write you a comfortable letter tonight—only a note, with nothing in it, as an acknowledgment that I owe you a comfortable letter and mean to pay the debt, when I shall have taken a few more bottles of “tonic mixture,” and derived strength therefrom or from—something else! nature perhaps Meanwhile please write to me. when I am ill more than at any other time I feel to get good of your letters—which is a compliment to your sympathetic nature.

Has MarionMarion Kirk, Mary Russell’s maid; see JWC to MR, [27 Jan. or 3 Feb.]. not repented yet of her American speculation— I dont think america in these times is a place for any one to go to who can get staid away. How restless the women of this generation are! My SarahSarah Piggott (b. ca. 1844), the Carlyles’ servant Sept. 1860–June 1861. (the nice girl who
went away ill)—sailed for Melbourne soon after my return from Holme Hill. She promised to write to me immediately on her arrival—and hasn’t—and I begin to fear she may have died. Now, the welch girl Margaret,Margaret Sullivan (“Button“) (b. ca. 1841), from Limerick, Ireland; servant at Cheyne Row from early June 1861 (see 37:163JWC to JGCO, 7 May 1861) until June 1862; her sister Ellen was already in New Zealand as the servant of Walter Mantell. the predecessor of “Mooncalve” is preparing to sail for New Zealand! “Mooncalve” reminds me of Jackie Welsh (my illegitimate cousin at Haddington) who sent her here. Poor soul! she has had a great calamity, has lost her auntJane Scott (1787–1863) d. 20 March. who brought her up, and lived with her, and has thro’ life been all in all to her. So suddenly too—the Aunt went to bed in “her frail ordinar,“Coterie speech; see 36:18TC to EF, 30 Nov. 1859. woke Jackie about six in the morning, complaining of a violent headache— Jackie got up and made her some tea the Aunt afraid of Jackie taking cold ordered her to come back to bed which she did—a little while after Jackie thought the aunts breathing sounded strange she got up again, and when she turned to look at her she was dead!—one would need to know the strange isolated life of Jackie with no mother to respect,Jackie Welsh’s mother, Elizabeth Scott, lived with Jackie and her aunt Jane, but seems to have been mentally unstable; see JWC to BB, 22 May. no Father to claim, nobody to belong to but that Aunt—to estimate the greatness of her loss!
God bless you—love to the Dr
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO] , [ca. 12 April]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen, 290. Dated by JWC’s slow recovery from influenza; see JWC to MR, [12 April].
div3.head:
JWC
TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: Your bits of violet-letters have made me both glad and wae— Do you know what “wae” means?— It is the Scotch word for sorry; but it comes from the heart, ‘wae’ does, and goes to the heart; whereas ‘sorry,’ for most part comes from no further than the lips and goes to no further than the ears!

You will easily understand why I should be glad at your letters. You have known me long enough and well enough, to believe in the constancy of my affection where it has once been seriously given. And granted that I care for you always; it is only human nature, that I should be glad of any token that you still care a little for me!— The waeness too will be intelligible for you, being the clever little soul you are! We needn’t say more of that!
Yes, come and see me. I have no immediate prospect of going from home, tho’ I much need a change of air and scene. The Influenza I am just recovering from has made me very weak and low.
But I left Mr Carlyle alone last summer for five weeks, and I haven’t the face to propose doing that sort of thing again, so soon!

Mrs Royston has got the beautifulest Baby,Isabella, b. Harris, wife of William Haylett Royston (1822–71), m. 1847; they lived at 1 Cheyne Row; their son, William Haylett Royston, was b. 19 March. I ever set eyes on! after having been married and childless for fifteen years! I thought, when I went to see her and it, that I should find her in Paradise. And she looked in Paradise, lying on her sofa, in the Drawing room with the wax-work-looking baby in a pretty pink and white basket placed on a chair near her—her whose life looked always so lonely and empty! But when I said, “Oh how happy you must be”! she answered in her old wailing tone, “I suppose I ought to be! But the poor child causes me such unsufferable agony, with this bad breast, that I almost shudder when they bring him near me,”— I believe it is a terrible business suckling a child, with a sore breast. Anyhow I couldnt help thinking; how good care is always taken that nobody should be in Paradise, in this Life! Whatever happiness is granted one; there is ever some pain, or some sorrow, or some anxiety, or something, to set off against it, and keep one in mind, that Earth is not Heaven! and that no amount of wishing, and hoping, and striving can ever make a Heaven of it for us!

Mrs Larkin has also a small son,Alfred Edward Larkin, b. March. and her breast, so far as I know, is in good order, and she is in every respect, to look at her, as strong as a horse. But doubtless she too has drawbacks to perfect felicity, tho’ I am not sufficiently intimate with her to know what they are are! or to care!

The poor Horse, that you groomed so cleverly and kindly, fell with Mr C one day in the Park, and cut its knees to the bone, and had to be poulticed and nursed for three weeks and then sold—being no longer safe to ride. A chemist in the Kings Road bought him for nine pounds (he had cost fifty guineas and was considered very cheap at that). But we liked better to sell him for next to nothing to a person who would ride him—than for more money to some one who would have thrashed him into a drawing a cab—which, you remember, he had an insuferable repugnance to.See TC to JAC, 13 Feb. ; for Fritz’s failure at training to draw a carriage, see 36:193 JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1860] . Mr C said it was “the saddest thing that had befallen him since the death of poor little Nero.”Nero, JWC’s dog, d. 1 Feb. 1860; see 36:67–68 JWC to LLA, [12 Feb. 1860] .

Your MotherElizabeth Southam, Charlotte’s aunt. is looking much better. I saw her one day bargaining with an
Image BoyA young hawker selling mass-produced lithographs and photographs. for some little naked child or angel that had taken her fancy. Good by / affectionately yours /
Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 [13 or 14] April. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; dated after Sir George Cornewall Lewis’s death, 13 April, 2 p.m.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: You are very good to write me, never so briefly, when I cannot manage writing to you at all. Owing to what you may naturally think idleness,—whh it is in part, conjoined with weakness, with utter weariness and confusion! Upstairs here, late at night, with my cape abt me (agt cold), I will send you two articulate words, to keep down anxiety, if nothing more.

There is nothing the matter with me more than usual,—except it be a very flutter and pluister abt actually beginning Book 19, instead of sitting reading for it at all hours, and looking at it, as has been going on for above 2 weeks past,—a paltry burble still lying in the hands of Robson withal, who has been playing truant with me till few days ago. What he still has will not now detain me many hours; and I shall probably have it this week. Last half of Vol V: that is what now glares yawningly upon me;—and the truth is, I have got so miserable upon it, I actually burst into it today; and meant to write to you the instant I cd say “I have fairly begun!” Cosa fata ha capo.Cf. Dante, Inferno 28:107; TC translated the phrase in 1853 as “A thing that will end must begin“; see 28:68TC to JAC, 10 March 1853. I shall agn have a dreadful tussle;—but this is the last: six months more of real industry, and the weary weary thing is done. Tour-de-force,TC means literally “do by force,” rather than “feat of strength” or “amazing feat.“ I have had no other method of getting thro’ the horrid quagmires of this Task from the beginning, and to the end it is the same. If my health don’t fail altogether, I shall manage; walking seems hitherto to do as well, or nearly so, as riding did; and it is nothing like so dreary, weak as my poor tabernacle has got for that object.

Last Sunday I met Henry Watt, Wm, the new Wife,John A. Carlyle’s stepsons William and Henry Watt, and Henry’s wife, Jane; they m. 9 April in Craigcrook, 2½ mi. (4 km.) W of Edinburgh. John wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 24 Feb., about Henry’s engagement to “Miss Hunter of Craigcrook. Her father [John Hunter] is an old friend of [John] Gordon’s & mine, & is Auditor of the Court of Session. The courtship has lasted some three years—more or less—Miss H. is about 18 months older than Harry, & is a very well educated clever girl. I was not directly consulted in the matter by either party, & was rather surprised to hear of the success. It may be the means of giving Harry the quiet sobriety he has had so much need of” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). John Hunter invited John A. Carlyle to the wedding, 26 March: “I need hardly say that Mrs [Helen] Hunter & I expect that you will give us & the young Couple the honour & gratification of your presence & Countenance on the occasion” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). & two other
peopleUnidentified. escorting, in Kensington Gardens. They looked all cheery and well to live. ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley. was with me, but did not recognise them;—was filled with admiratn, when I rejoined him, at yr perseverance & success in getting Wm reinstated after his escapade;William was in trouble in 1862 at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1862. thinks he will now probably do well, unless utterly a lost sheep. The yg Wife was very nice, poor little creature; perhaps she may produce improvts when she is bestowed.TC may be using this word in its archaic sense of giving birth. I have not seen ArthurHenry and William’s brother, Arthur Watt. yet.— — Do you ever hear of Jamie Aitken here; is he fallen in love then or what?John replied, 17 April: “I had a letter from Jean this week, enclosing one from her son James. It seems that he is only very busy at present & rather overworked, & at the time you saw him last some proposal had been made to him of going out to Ceylon with a Mr Laidlaw—his best friend in the office—who has an uncle there, engaged in the cultivation of coffee on the high grounds of the island which have the reputation of being very healthy. That uncle is soon to be in England, & is to see James & talk with him on the subject; but James wants to have nothing said about it to any one at present.“ Jamie Carlyle will likely get to Ury:See TC to JAC, 26 March.—he might study a great many useful things in the interim.

Poor Lady Sterling (Anty’s Wife) is dead;Charlotte, wife of Sir Anthony Coningham Sterling, d. 10 April. had her senses for the last week, had not had for a year before. Poor soul;—they say Anty too is very ill abt it.— Jane’s cold is gradually growing well. She gets out if the day is fine. East wind we have, of a frosty type, sometimes combined with sun of a torrid.Word missing. Sir George Lewis is dead:Sir George Cornewall Lewis (1806–63; ODNB), politician and author, d. 13 April. TC had known him since the mid-1830s; see 9:52TC to JOST, 11 Sept. 1836. alas, alas, what are earthly “successes,” as they are called. My kind regards to Madame & Daughters.Jean Otthenin and her das. Margaret and Irma. It is ½ past 11.

p.name: T.C.
p.note: John thanked TC for “the enclosure from Dickens“; TC possibly enclosed Dickens’s note, 13 April, from Gad’s Hill: “I should be very glad if you would come to one of my Readings one night. I think if you would come some evening when I read the Trial from Pickwick, you would find a healthy suggestion of an abuse or two, that sets people thinking in the right direction. // Georgina being all but quite well now, I look for that long-delayed visit from you and Mrs. Carlyle, this coming summer. This is really a pleasant place, and as good a little house to work in—or to do what you like in—as you will find anywhere. I am always reading you faithfully, and trying to go your way. / Affectionately Yours ever.” Georgina Hogarth (1827–1917; ODNB), Dickens’s sister-in-law, managed his house at Gad’s Hill. For the reading, see JWC to JPJSP, [29 April].

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS [SGS], 15 April. MS: NLS 2883.236. Pbd: Grant, Sir George Sinclair 427–28; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:188–91. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:502.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p: We read in the Newspapers, with a lively sympathy, the announcement of what had come upon you.The death of Sir George Sinclair’s wife, Lady Camilla, 17 March, was widely noted in Scottish newspapers and the Illustrated London News (11 April). It is a heavy loss and a very sorrowful: the parting with a loved soul, who has been yr companion so longThey had been married for almost 47 years. thro good and evil; who was such a bright being when you first found her, and has had to fade away, under many sufferings and sorrowsLady Camilla had been ill for about 10 years. whh you have shared with her and leave you alone for the remainder of the pilgrimage. “It is the way of all the earth“;Cf. 1 Kings 2:2. yes, and has been since man was first made;—and yet there is a strange originality in it to every one of us, when it comes upon him in its course. I grieve to think how sad you are:—I myself remember the good Lady and her very great goodness to me while herself so heavy-laden; and the thot that I shall never see her again is painful and pathetic to me.TC visited the Sinclairs in Thurso Castle Aug.–Sept. 1860; for TC’s comments on Lady Camilla, see 36:160TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1860. Words are very idle, so are wishes; I will say no more on the subject Time, by degrees, smooths away the first asperities; then Death has a kind of blessed aspect, most sad but also most sacred: the one haven of rest appointed for us all.

I am still kept overwhelmingly busy here; my strength slowly diminishing, my work progressing still more slowly,—my heart really almost broken. In some 6 or 8 months,—surely not longer than 8!—I hope to have at last done: it will be the gladdest day I have seen for ten years back, pretty much the one glad day! I have still half a volume to do; still one furious struggle, and tour-de-force (as there have been many), to wind matters up reasonably in half a volume. But this is the last,TC was working on vol. 5 of Frederick, but would not finish until vol. 6 was pbd. in 1865. if I can but do it: and if health hold out in any fair measure I always hope I can.

Yr Pampht on NapoleonSinclair pbd. a number of pamphlets critical of both Napoleons, including Legitimacy, Citizen Kingship, and Imperialism (1862), The Bonapartes Contrasted with the Bourbons (1862), Le Tartufe impérial (1862), and Ought France to Worship the Bonapartes? (1863). has never come I am happy to agree entirely in
what you say abt that renowned Corsican Gentn (“Play-actor-Pirate,” who, after all, found dishonesty not the best policy), and abt his Sham synonym of these present times,Napoleon’s nephew Louis Napoleon (1808–73), pres. of France 1849–51, Emperor Napoleon III from 1852. Sinclair had long been a public critic of him; see 36:119–20TC to SGS, 24 May 1860. whom I still more heartily dissent from, and even take the liberty of despising. Probably nothing can be written upon them that will do much good. There is such an outpouring of disloyal platitudes, and vocal jackassery of every figure in these times, as quite disgusts one with the pen, and almost with the tongue itself. Farewell dear Sir; may yr pious heart soon compose itself, and be able to say (what Wisdom has, in all dialects, prescribed since Wisdom first was) “Good is the Will of the Lord!“Cf. the words of the father of the covenanting preacher Richard Cameron (1655–80), killed on the orders of Charles II; see 31:184TC to CBU, [20 Aug. 1856], and John Howie, The Scottish Worthies (Glasgow, 1775) 372–74.—I am yours very sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JP [JSP], [29 April]. Pbd: James S. Pike, “Dickens, Carlyle, and Tennyson,” ed. Harold Davis, Atlantic Monthly 164 (1939): 812.
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES SHEPHERD PIKE

docBody.p: My husband, in virtue of his humanness, bids me say that he will be glad to see you to tea at eight o’clock on Friday next (1st May).James Pike wrote to TC, 28 April: “I am an American. I had the pleasure to see you at Mr Dickens reading this evening and observing that you are Human I beg to ask if you will allow me to come and see you and if so, when?” TC wrote on the letter, “‘Ministre Residt des Etats Unis à la Hague,’ his Card calls him.” Pike described TC and the reading in his notebook, 28 April: “To-night I saw the greatest thing in London. It was Dickens reading Pickwick’s Trial to Thomas Carlyle. I thought Carlyle would split, and Dickens was not much better. Carlyle sat on the front bench and he haw-hawed right out over and over again till he fairly exhausted himself. Dickens would read and then he would stop in order to give Carlyle a chance to stop. … The reading consisted of the Trial and the Christmas Carol. … [TC] was dressed in a long snuff-colored frock coat, with a long old-fashioned velvet collar, that looked as if it might have belonged to his grandfather. He had on a thick cloth vest well buttoned up, a high standing collar, and an old-fashioned black stock loosely buckled round his neck. His hat was felt, with a sugar-loaf crown, and he kept it on one knee while his legs were crossed, the top hanging perpendicularly down, showing the shrunken shank. He had a full shock of iron-gray hair and whiskers and moustache with scissors, giving his face an expression approaching the haggard. His shoulders were rounded up and narrow and his joints seemed loosely set. His whole aspect was that of a seedy scholar” (Atlantic Monthly 164:811). For TC on the reading, see TC to JAC, 29 April.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 April. MS: NLS 526.5. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:270.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: It is a shame that I do not oftener find some half-hour to send you some word of myself, in ansr to yr kindness in writing! The truth is I am very weak and languid as well as busy; hanging on like a worn-out old garron that will not lie down and be beaten, but tugs feebly at the collar-chains, tho’ making hardly the least perceptible way. My progress is indeed mournfully slow; RobertsonPresumably in error for Robson the printer. too is bothering me still with some dirty tagraggery of Proof-sheets, whh interfere between whiles, at the wrong time: his blame, not mine;—but it is nearly over; and shall not recur, for I will now stop him altogether; and not start agn, till my Mss. is abt ready, and can employ whole dozens upon it!— I am making some progress (to be in the heart of KunersdorfKunersdorf, village 4 mi. (6.5 km.) E of Frankfurt an der Oder, where Frederick was defeated in battle by the Russians and Austrians, Aug. 1759; see Carlyle, Works 18:64–86. this week yet; after whh there are only two Battles,Battle of Liegnitz (Carlyle, Works 18:251–78) and the battle of Torgau (Carlyle, Works 18:296–330).—and the rest shall all be summary!). I am sensibly weaker than last year, in fact the heart almost quite gone out of me; such a relaxed, weak-limbed, disconsolate “old quarryman as is not in the whole Howrigg!” (You don’t remember Archy White?)Archy White, mason of Howrigg, in Annandale, “the tightest old quarry man“; TC’s father was probably the source of the phrase; see 37:144TC to LS, 6 April 1860.— However, I generally think I shall get done too, before I be myself quite done. Courage still!—

I had to go yesterday to Dickens’s reading: “8 p. m Hanover Rooms“;Dickens invited TC, 13 April; see TC to JAC, 12 [13 or 14] April. Thomas Woolner reported that JWC called on the afternoon of 28 April: “She wanted me to take tea at her house and go afterwards with her husband to the Hanover Sq. Rooms to hear Chas. Dickens read, as she said Dickens had sent Carlyle 2 tickets with an intimation that it would do him good to hear a little reading.
