She was not strong enough to go with him, and he had made it a condition that she must persuade me to go with him or he would not go himself. I went to Chelsea, had tea, and we took a cab to Hanover Sq.” (Woolner 233). —to thecomplete oversetting of my eveng habitudes, and spiritual composure. Dickens does do it capitally (such as it is); acts better than any MacreadyWilliam Charles Macready (1793–1873; ODNB), actor manager, now retired; old friend of the Carlyles. in the world; a whole tragic-comic-farcic theatre visible performing under one hat;Woolner wrote: “Carlyle had nothing but praises to bestow upon it“; he reported TC’s words, “‘Charley, you carry a whole company of actors under your own hat,’” but was worried about “the effect of these readings upon the writer’s health” (Woolner 233–34).
and keeping us laughing (in a sorry way, some of us thot) the whole night.He is a good creature too;—and makes 50 or £60 by each of these readings. You see by the inclosed what has followed for me out of it!Presumably James Pike’s request for a meeting; see JWC to JPJSP, [29 April]. And readings. You see by the inclosed what has followed for me out of it! And have to dine out tomorrow: a certain good Miss Bromley Davenport whom I compare to a “flight of Larks“;—her grandfather was Rousseau’s Host at “Wooton (Staffordshire)“;Caroline Davenport Bromley’s great-great-grandfather Richard Davenport (ca. 1705–71) leased his house, Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, 1766–67, to Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712–78), French philosopher; see 38:227–28JWC to MR, [30 Sept. 1862].—she wd have fled away in terror forever had I refused. Probably nobody there but her Brother the new Laird of Wooton,William Davenport Bromley; their father, the Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley, d. 1 Dec. 1862.—a raised looking but benevolent gentn; threatening to go into the Philanthropic line. Emerson’s NoteProbably Emerson’s letter of introduction, sent with Moncure Conway, an American visiting Britain to deliver a series of lectures promoting the position of the Northern side in the Civil War. Conway wrote later: “Emerson … gave me letters of introduction to Carlyle and others“; he described Carlyle as “the man to whose wonderful genius more than to any other is to be attributed the intellectual and spiritual activity of his generation” (Conway, Autobiography 1:346 and 351). you need not return. Jane clubs the two Yankees in one, for Friday night,Fri. was 1 May. The “two Yankees” were James Pike and Moncure Conway. Conway wrote of this first meeting: “A strange thrill passed over me when I first stood face to face with these grand features. … [H]e met me, pipe in mouth, cordially. For a few moments I was left with Mrs. Carlyle, who was too thin and pale to preserve traces of beauty, but had a look of refinement and dignity. … Cheerful, kindly, witty, and frank, she conversed pleasantly of the habits and labours of Carlyle. She thought the Life of Frederick a terrible piece of work, and wished that Frederick had died when a baby. ‘The book is like one of those plants that grow up smoothly and then forms a knot, smoothly again and then forms another knot, and so on; what Carlyle is when one of those knots is being passed must be left to the imagination.’ Carlyle was a picture of meekness when his wife said this” (Conway, Autobiography 1:351–52). and I will try (really!) to sit nearly dumb.— — We have seen J. Aitkn agn; all right with him specially; I shd say Ceylon has good promise: but we shall see. I wrote to Madme on her Carte arriving:John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 April: “I enclose you a photograph of Made Otthenin, which I got from her last night. It is by no means a bad one, though she has hitherto been averse to sending it, as she thinks it does not do her justice.” This is presumably the “carte” that TC means, otherwise untraced. TC later wrote on John A. Carlyle’s envelope: “Mme Otthn / Photograph” “found agn, Septr 16; / and put into Jane’s Book“; on the reverse he wrote “Mme Otn’s Photograph found, & taken out! In Jane’s Book now.” Jean Otthenin’s photograph (see opp.above) is in album 4, with one of Irma Otthenin (see 173) (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). one cannot make much of it; but she was very kind to send it.John also reported, “She and Irma have been in better heart of late,” and enclosed a note from Irma Otthenin.—

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: There is a very good little Danish Dicty here (by Repp,Thorleifus Gudmundsson Repp (1794–1857), librarian and linguist, who worked in the Advocates Lib., Edinburgh, 1825–34; see 5:338–39TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831; with J. S. Ferrall he pbd. A Danish-English Dictionary (Copenhagen 1845). John A. Carlyle wrote, 17 April: “Of late I have learnt Danish & Swedish; and now I think of having a little spell at Icelandic“; in his letter, 22 April, he mentioned that someone had lent him “a Swedish dictionary & offered other books.” He replied, 30 April: “I have had Repp’s Dictionary for many years, & it is on the whole very good; but I have another (German-Danish) by Grönberg which contains more words, & is on the whole quite as good.“ print too small); item a good Dh Book (Sagabibliothek),Peter Erasmus Müller, Sagabibliothek; see 16:143TC to KAVE, 1 May 1843. In his letter of 30 April, John A. Carlyle wrote: “Müllers Sagabibliothek will be welcome to me whenever you can find time to send it. I made a high offer for Dr Irving’s copy, which was on fine paper, but it went to some one else.“ & perhaps another: if you want any or all of these, speak!

Send word of me to Jean;John A. Carlyle wrote: “I was very glad to see your letter this morning, & I have forwarded it to Jean, that she may not be without news direct from you.“—oh what neglect there!— Yours & hers T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 1 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Hansons, NE 506–7 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Oh my Darling! my Darling! I know the effect that a letter from you has now always on me; it makes me long to take you in my arms, and hush you to sleep, as if you were a tired wee child, and kiss off all tears from your eyes! But the last letter excites beside this longing, another not less vehement longing which is, to shake some others within an inch of their life! Good Heavens! I cannot understand what these others are made of, or who made them; that knowing,—seeing how you are situated, and how you bear, and strive, and love, and are more like an angel than a grand Lady, they still cannot put away their jealousy and envy of you.Probably referring to Lord Ashburton’s brothers, Francis (1800–1868) and Frederick Baring (1806–68), who always rather resented Lady Louisa Ashburton. Yes! It must be so! that they envy you your very troubles; because you take them in a way to make you doubly dear to Him, and to all who have hearts to be warmed by your untiring devotedness! Don’t think of them! they are so small! Think just of what you are to Him, your Husband; you are his Consolation, his Hope, his Life! without you he could not have lived thro’ all this! would not have cared to live! and it may well comfort you, under worse than the coldness of these others, to feel that you are all in all to that man; who in nobleness, and unselfishness, and gentleness of heart is not surpassed, I firmly believe, in God’s Earth! and think, if you
like, of the brotherly sympathy and affection that is cherished for you by some who do not open their hearts to such sentiments lightly; and who are not “small.“

I have seen my Husband’s eyes fill with tears, in speaking about you! and I have heard Mr VenablesGeorge Stovin Venables; Venables was one of the executors of Lord Ashburton’s will; see Surtees, Ludovisi 106–10. warm to enthusiasm in your praise! Oh you do not know how we all care for you! You must come home, to read it in our faces.— “The end of June,” that is the first set time I have ever heard spoken of. Miss Bromley told me last night, it was hoped that you might come then. I wish she could have staid with you longer, she is such a pleasant companion, and she loves you so much!

And how lonely she seems here, in that large house; with the Pictures “all to be sent to Christie’s“!Caroline Bromley’s father, Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley, a renowned collector of early Italian Renaissance paintings; 174 pictures were sold after his death by Christie, Manson & Woods, art auctioneers, 8 King St., St. James’s Sq., 12 and 13 June. The Bromleys’ London home was at 32 Grosvenor St. — Mr C and I went and dined entirely alone with her yesterday! and the thing was wonderfully successful!— Mr C, of course, did most of the talking himself! but that is no hardship to him if he be well listened to, and Miss Bromley listens to perferfection!Thus in MS. “She says little herself (he remarked on the way home) but she gives the clearest evidence of understanding and taking interest in everything one (he) says to her! A real bonnie woman too! And with a fine, elegant, quite superior, modest dignity about her.“— And it is you we got her from—so that I always delight in her, as I do in my flowers,—with a mental reference to you.

I must leave it to Mr C to speak for himself, about that horseLady Ashburton was about to give TC a horse; see TC to Lady ALLA, 17 May. when he shall be told about it; for, indeed, I have more thanks to render you, already, on my own account, than power of putting them into words! I often wonder that I should not feel oppressed by your kindness, almost irritated by it; so being that I am without ability to repay it, or even to adequately express my sense of it!— Often wonder what it is in you, that makes it possible for me to be always your debtor, without fuming or wincing in the position! It is not enough to esteem or even love a person; something more, that I cannot define is needed to make gratitude a pleasant, even a bearable feeling for me!

Oh my Heavens No! He didn’t sell poor Fritz for the money! the money was but nine pounds!! But he thought him too young for being invalided at grass—said to turn him out for the rest of his life would be “like turning an old servant into the Workhouse,” he sold him for anything he liked to offer to a respectable man in the next street who meant to ride him—not punish him
into drawing The poor brute looks so well in his new service Was brought to our door this morning to report himself.
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

ps.p: I shall write this day to Dr Quain as you bid me. tho I am very ignorant about horsesThe connection between Dr. Quain and the horse is unclear.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MC [MCON], 3 May. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. TC presumably intended the note to be used as an introduction to Ballantyne.
div3.head: TC TO MONCURE CONWAY

docBody.p: Dear Sir, —Subjoined is copy of an Address, left for you a day or two by the owner of it; whh I forgot, last night.Conway’s first visit was Fri., 1 May. Mr Ballantyne is an Editor of respectability, a very kindly pleasant and lively man; concerns himself much abt American matters; and might, for aught I know, be of use to you in yr prest objects.Conway came to Britain to put the Union case in the Civil War to the British public.— In haste
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
T. Ballantyne Esq. / St James’s Chronicle Newspr Office,
13 Tavistock Street/ Covent Garden
By Mr M. D. Conway (from Boston) / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 May]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 8 May 1863. MS: NLS 608.614B. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
How are you? What are you doing? A stupid CuratePossibly the Rev. Thomas Alexander; see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March]; otherwise unidentified. whom I met in the street the other day saluted me with; “Ah Mrs Carlyle! you were brought very plainly
before my imagination lately; in reading the Life of Edward Irving.“Margaret Oliphant, Life of Edward Irving (1862); for Oliphant’s contact with JWC about Irving, see 37:62–65JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860], and 155–58TC to LOA, 27 April 1861. So, might I say—if I were a stupid curate—you were brought very plainly before my Imagination two days ago, in receiving a call from—Miss Jemima Wigham!Jemima Lucy Maxwell Whigham. with the difference, that as I don’t ever pass a day without thinking of you, having imagined you once in a way was nothing to brag of! Miss Jemima came with the Miss MurrayProbably the Miss Murray referred to atin 35:28JWC to MR, [ca. 8 Feb. 1859]; unidentified further. whom she is on a visit to. who said she had often seen me long ago. She had the advantage of me in remembering; for I have no recollection of having ever seen her in my life. Whether it was the influence of her old governess or of London, generally, I can’t say; but certainly Miss Jemima was far more subdued in manner than when I saw them dashing about in Nithsdale.JWC visited the Whighams with Mary Russell in Aug. 1862; see 38:149JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1862], and 158TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1862. I mean to return her call tomorrow or next day, and ask her, by herself, to spend a day or part of a day with me. I couldnt make any engagement with her then, having just received a note from Lady Ashburton at Paris, saying “dont be frightened if you see me walk in to you in the course of the next two or three days“—till she came I would not even go out for a short walk—for as she was only coming to London “for a few hours” (her note said) I should not see her at all if I missed her once. All yesterday I sat listening to every carriage that entered the street; and as the Devil would have it there was a constant succession of carriages; owing to the parallel thoroug[h]fare having got itself laid with new broken stones! How many more such days of waiting should I have?

No more!—for after the clock had struck eleven at night, the right carriage stopt at the door, and the dear Soul rushed into my arms. It was difficult to help crying a meeting her after all these dreadful months she had passed! She staid till one in the morning! Today she is off to the Grange where she sleeps, and tomorrow she returns to Paris! She is in good hopes now that Lord A will recover, to about the same state of health that he was in before this illness, But there is no chance of his being able to return home for a couple of months yet. He is still so weak, that it is as much as he can do to walk, with support, from his bed to the invalid chair in which he sits up for two or three hours a day

Is your Husband allowed to sleep at home yet every night?Unexplained. How glad you will be to have him, to talk to, when you waken up!Mary Russell was in the habit of waking her husband during the night to talk to him; see 35:28JWC to MR, [8 Feb. 1859]. Or, in the nights you have had to sleep alone, has your heart come to any adequate sense of the sacredness of a man’s sleep? And will you treat him better henceforth?— Certainly for any ease your Husband seems to have got by giving up his practice, he might as well have kept the name of it as he has kept the trouble. But I dare say the satisfaction of helping his suffering fellow-creatures who trust in him
so entirely, is the greatest such a Man could find for himself in life, if he even consulted only his own pleasure!

I have made a few acquaintance that I like. Mrs Dunlop (Ann Veitch,For Ann Dunlop, see JWC to GWGWE, [late Feb.]. the Hoggan’s connexion)Possibly Mary Hoggan was a friend of Ann Dunlop; although Mary was from Thornhill and Ann from Haddington, Mary did visit London; see 34:243JWC to JPR, [23 Nov. 1858]. came one day bringing with her a young Lady whom she introduced by a name I did not catch; but I took her to be the ‘Companion’ Mrs Dunlop had got; since her DaughtersOne of the das. was Anne Sharp Dunlop (b. 1830); the others are unidentified. were all married off. Having a great sympathy for gentlewomen filling that function, and the girl looking infinitely more a gentlewoman than her (supposed) Mistress, I received her and addressed her with more cordiality than is usual between strangers. “She might well praise her “Companion” I thought, as I was more and more struck with the girls elegant simplicity of manner, and cultivated intelligence. After a while my attention lighted on her dress; deep mourning; but with extremely expensive furs. Just as I was reflecting, how inconsistent with the ‘situation’ was that fine seal-fur pelisse; Mrs Dunlop said “Miss LaurieMargaret Laurie (b. 1834). was kind enough to offer me a drive in her carriage; so I asked her to bring me here.“— A Miss Laurie, with a carriage!! that put the Companion out of all question. “And I was so glad to come” said the young Lady; Mr Carlyle knew my dear Uncle. I found among my dear Uncles papers several letters from Mr Carlyle.” “May I ask the name of your uncle?“— “Oh—Sir Peter Lawrie.“Sir Peter Laurie (1778–1861; ODNB), saddler and politician; he was Margaret Laurie’s great-uncle. (the Magistrate who used to amuse the public, by ordering the criminals brought before him to have their long beards, or long hair cut off, the first thing!Sir Peter was a magistrate in London; on 14 Nov. 1841 a tailor “with a profusion of long hair, combed down in long straight locks, was brought up for being drunk and disorderly. … Sir Peter said he considered ‘a man who wore his hair like he did, was capable of doing anything. Nothing makes a man look more contemptible than wearing his hair in such a fashion. He supposed he wished to be taken for a German student.’ … Sir Peter said he should fine him 5s. for his conduct, but ‘if he would go and have his hair cut off, he would forgive him altogether.’ Whereupon the defendant ‘bowed, stepped down, a barber was sent for, and he was speedily cropped.’ Upon his return into Court, Sir Peter congratulated him, and said he ‘looked more like a man now,’ and he was discharged with a caution” (Peter G. Laurie, Sir Peter Laurie: A Family Memoir [Brentwood 1901] 205). A Scotchman who came to London without even the usual “two half crowns“—got to be a journeyman Saddler—then a Master-saddler then an Alderman—and Magistrate and ever so rich. His old UncleUnidentified. who was jailer at Haddington used to tell us of “Sir Peter,” as if he had been the good boy of a Fairy Tale!

Mr C made his aquaintance long years ago thro Edward Irving, and entertained “a certain esteem for him“—but had declined his invitations to dinner —and so the thing had dropt;See 25:47TC to SPL, 12 March 1850, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 282–83. and a year and half ago Sir Peter died. his Niece one had never heard of)

I told the young Lady at parting I should be glad to see more of her. And a week after, she came again, to say she was going to Edinr for a fortnight, and could she do anything for me? She spoke of Scotland so lovingly that I asked if she had been born there? “Oh yes“— “Where“?—“at Haddington“!— “Goodness then you are my townswoman!—where did you live at Haddington I knew everybody there—but that was before you were born!“— “Oh you could know nothing of my FatherAndrew Laurie, joiner.—he was quite a poor Man—a joiner— and we lived in quite a little house beyond the tollbar, that I dare say you would never notice.” This was said with no affected humility but quite simply, and just as she might have said her Father was Lord so and so and lived at Castle, for she looked like Lady—Anybody! A real nice girl! Her Uncle Sir Peter adopted her.Margaret lived with Sir Peter and his wife, Margaret, b. Jack (m. 1803; d. 1848), from 1845. had her educated in the best style, and when he died without children of his own, left her, it seems, his grand House in London,At 7 Park Sq. West, Regent’s Park. with Carriage and horses, and silver-plate, and fifty thousand pounds! She has had no end of offers (of course) but wont marry, till she can find a man who will guide her and be an intelligent Companion to her.Margaret Laurie m., 1865, James Augustus Grant (1827–92; ODNB), explorer in Africa; she outlived him. See also Carlyle, Reminiscences 283.

I found in my blot-book the other day an envelope addressed to you—in which were some letters from Dr Blackiston (Bessey’s Husband) which by some oversight never got sent—I inclose them now, and you can burn them.
I will tell you more of her next time—but this letter is long enough for you to read and for me to write. God bless you Darling—love to the Dr / Your ever affectionate JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 May. MS: NLS 517.46. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Your Note came this afternoon: thanks always for any word however brief. I am sending you (near 11 p. m. down stairs here) one
still briefer;—having a little bit of busss, nothing that will much burden you. It is this merely.

To send me, from one of yr Banks, a £10 payable to Jenny at Hamilton in Canada on presenting it. You have sent me such a thing before: I pay you by return of post; and this (in spite of Ransom,Ransom, Bouverie & Co., bankers, Pall Mall. TC previously used them for sending money to John A. Carlyle in mainland Europe; see 5:5TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1829. and Larkin,—who mistook the spelling last year) is really my briefest method of getting thro’ the thing,—whh has been lying on me ever since Newyearsday time!TC regularly sent his sisters checks for New Year. You have no conception of the feckless ever-puddling overwhelmed existence I lead here: in the unutterable confusion of my present job, in the almost bankruptcy of physical and spiritual strength. Ten pounds as above, and I will end one little tagrag.

My Americans went off well enough:James S. Pike and Moncure Conway visited 1 May. Pike is a very fine fellow, of grave years and breeding; the other a kind of Yankee Gambardella,Spiridione Gambardella, Italian political exile and portrait painter, friend of the Carlyles in the 1840s. He originally met them through a letter of introduction from Emerson, autumn 1841; see 13:300TC to RWE, 19 Nov. 1841. For his 1843 portraits of JWC, Jeannie Welsh, and John Welsh, see 17:frontispiece, 18:frontispiece, and 19:frontispiece, available in the CLO on their respective table of contents pages. rather amusing than otherwise.— I have a new Horse on trial (Fredc Chapman’s); have ridden him these two days: so-so; but he does me a great deal of good; and I believe I must have either him or another, now that the weather is getting hot. I am hard at work: “Kunersdorf all alive!” Kind regards to Erskine and Madame.Jean Otthenin. Ever your affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HG, 7 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11438. Hitherto unpbd. Harriet Grote (1792–1878; ODNB), writer.
div3.head: TC TO HARRIET GROTE

docBody.p:
At length I return you all yr Voltaire Books,TC borrowed books on Voltaire from Harriet Grote in 1855; see 29:247TC to HG, 8 Feb. 1855, 30:7TC to HG, 10 July 1855, and 36:125–26TC to HG, 30 May 1860. See also TC to HG, July 1855, Posthumous Papers: Comprising Selections from … Correspondence … and Compositions by the late George Grote, ed. Harriet Grote (1874, for private circulation) 138–39. —or all except one (“Vie de Vre par T.I.D.V.“;—2d form of the “Vie par M. xx,“Théophile Imarigeon Duvernet, La Vie de Voltaire (Paris 1797), revised and expanded 2d edn. of M***, La Vie de Voltaire (Geneva 1786) (TC’s copy of the first edn.: Carlyle House, Chelsea); in 1855 TC hoped to get a second copy for writing in its margins; see also 30:7TC to HG, 10 July 1855. He describes both edns. in Carlyle, Works 14:182. whh, having two copies of it, I
have taken the liberty to offer you): it may happen, but is not likely, this left one may still, a few months hence, be of some momentary use to me: however, if it will please you to have it back at once, pray say so without scruple, and it shall come. You have been admirably patient with me; & indeed I cannot enough praise your kind conduct in regard to this Voltaire matter throughout.

In the old Carpet-bag, whh was carefully wrapt together and laid away, I understood always that there was an Original List (perhaps in yr own hand); but this some housemaid, dusting too assiduously, I now find, has shaken off into Limbo;—so that I have had to substitute a poor Pencil-List of my own, not so comfortable, tho’ I believe exact.

VoltairianaVoltairiana, ou éloges amphigouriques de Fr.-Marie Arrouet (Paris 1748), written by Louis Travenol and Louis Mannory under the pseudonym Timorowitz Ablabew. is reckoned a curious Piece,— upon “Procès Travenol,” by two blackguard Advocates of that Opera-Fiddler:The Procès-Travenol was a lawsuit involving Voltaire and Louis Travenol, a fiddler at the Opera, in 1746; see Carlyle, Works 16:210–11.—as I shall never need it more, I beg you to take it off my hands.
Please offer my kind regards to Mr Grote;George Grote (1794–1871; ODNB), historian and politician. and accept many yourself from me, and from Wife, in case she shd not see you on attempting.
In sad haste still, and sorrowfully driven abt by work of an unpropitious nature, I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWJWHI, 9 May. MS: Manchester Public Libraries. Hitherto unpbd. TC frequently wrote out “Simon Brodie had a Cow” as an autograph; see TC to MSSLT, 16 Sept.; cf. JWC to TC, [14 Sept. 1851], and TC to LS, 12 Aug. 1860.
div3.head: TC TO JEMIMA WHIGHAM

lg.l: Simon Brodie had a Cow;
He lost his Cow, & he could na find her;
When he had done what men cd do,
The Cow cam hame, & her tail behind her.

ps.p: Chelsea, 9 May 1863
To Miss Jemima Lucy Maxwell Whigham with many kind regards.—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [ca. 10] May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated just after Lady Ashburton’s brief visit to London.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: There! You have come! and you have gone! and it isn’t a dream!— You have really been in this room, with your dear sweet eyes, and musical voice, and adorable ways! But the whole apparition is dream-like, for all its reality! I have dreamt dreams, in my sleep, about you and Lord Ashburton, while you have been away, that felt just as real at the time, and looked as real in retrospect as your visit the other night.Lady Ashburton visited late Tues. evening, 5 May; see JWC to MR, [6 May]. The waiting for you, with ones heart in ones mouth, till the case looked desperate; and then Mr C rushing off like a maniac to resume his coat; and your dark figure in the stairs, so beautiful, in the absurd whirlwind of coat-confusion around you;—all that was so like the sort of things that happen in dreaming!— I knew I should not see you again. With so many people to see, and so much to do; the wonder was, you found a possible hour to come to Chelsea. I had hard work to keep myself from going up to Bath House on the Friday morning, to wait till you should be up, and get one more look of you before you started; but the dread of being inconvenient, and bothering you restrained me, tho’ I rose at seven, with the wish!— I went at one o’clock when sure you would be gone; to hear from HannahHannah Hall, servant at Bath House. if it were all right. And it was all right she said; you had been near missing the train she said, but “the Coachman was a good, clever man(!) and wouldn’t let my Lady be disappointed if he could help it!” She also told me with immense glee that there “had been five letters from my Lord— And that, Mrs Car-lyle,JWC writes the name thus, to indicate pronunciation; see also 37:111JWC to LLA, [early Feb. 1861]. is more than any of us ever expected, at one time“!! Poor Hannah seemed much elated by your coming; “I can’t say, Mrs Car-lyle but I am rale pleased that my Lady has been! It just makes one feel as if they hadn’t quite forgotten us!“

Ach! Here is a young lady from Nithsdale,Jemima Whigham. dropt in “promiscuous,“Cf. “quite promiscuously“; coterie speech; see 10:72TCJWC to JCA, 1 May 1838. to spend “a long day“! What shall I do?—send for “a neat Fly,“Coterie speech; see 35:3TC to WC, 4 Jan. 1859, and 22JWC to MCA, [7 Feb. 1859?]. and take her a drive in the Park to see the “pretty Horse breakers.““Pretty horse-breakers” was a euphemism for the upmarket prostitutes who rode in Hyde Park; one of the most renowned was Catherine Walters, also known as Skittles (1839–1920; ODNB); see 34:12334:biographical notes. That is Nature’s
first desperate suggestion to me. In the evening couldn’t I take her to Cremorne?Amusement park in Chelsea.— I must leave off writing anyhow—and I had still a good deal to say. especially about the Horse.See TC to Lady ALLA, 17 May. Oh don’t, please, prosecute that inquiry so bothering for you—so out of your line! I don’t like the idea of it—and I am sure no more would he—if he knew. I was very near telling him that night, after you left, when he asked me “what on earth I was making such a whispering about?” But I rather pique myself on holding my tongue, when I am told to. So I answered pertly that if he had been intended to know; why then I shouldnt have whispered.

He is getting more reconciled to Mr Chapmans horse “It is nothing like so soft a creature to ride as poor Fritz was; and hasn’t a tithe of his sense and discrimination—but he has far more go and shakes him up better.” So I dare say as this Brute can also go in harness he will end in buying him.
Oh my young Lady she is sitting opposite staring
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 May. MS: NLS 517.47. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Many thanks. I will answer at once, in the essential form, tho’ witht time for a word. Better that you shd have no doubts abt safe arrival of cash. Inclosed is the Draught.John A. Carlyle wrote, 10 [9] May: “Here is the order for £10 which I got yesterday immediately after receipt of your note. It is from the Commercial Bank wh has direct correspondence with the Canada Bank at Hamilton, & will most likely be paid at once when it reaches its destination.” TC sent a check to John: “10 May 1863 / (£10 for Jenny) To / Dr Carlyle Edinr / £10..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Send me a Newspr, or anything that will signifyThe Carlyles put pen strokes on newspapers (sent free of charge) signifying all was well. as this does the practical fact: I will attend to Wednesday; and this small Canada fact shall be done.

We are tolerably well,—that is, for us. My horseThe horse borrowed from Frederic Chapman. stalks and ambles (a real “pace” properly so called, whh is pleasant and his one smooth step), can gallop & trot in a great rough way, fast & far: I find him wholesome; take him patiently if only as physic.

From Jean this morning I have a Letter. All alive abt the flitting of Thursday next. I never saw Jean in such an excitatn abt anything as abt this new
House:The Aitkens’ new house on Lochmaben Rd.; see TC to AC, 31 March. occasionally it strikes a kind of fear thro’ me, in my own extinct conditn of nerves and heart; and I silently pray, “May you be no worse there, my poor Jean; that will make me thankful in this change of yr life!“— — The truth is, I am as weak as water; nearly quite worn out in nerves and heart; probably few mortals, in all her Majesty’s Dominns, more longing to be out of their harness, and stretch their galled backs in the grass,—free from an intolerability of 10 years in the finis of their Life. But on,—no words!

With best respects to MadmeJean Otthenin. John replied: “I have not seen Made O. for some days.“ & to Erskine,John wrote that he had seen the Rev. F. D. Maurice (1805–72; ODNB) and he and Thomas Erskine intended hearing him preach at St. John’s Episcopal Church, Sun. 10 May; “Mrs Stirling is at Portobello for warm Sea-baths, & he [Erskine] is alone in a lodging.” Erskine and his sister had been in their house in Charlotte Sq. until the end of April. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: [½ p.m.; task not yet quite done!]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCHJCHA, 13 Aug. [May]. Pbd: Copeland 229–31 inc. Either TC or Copeland misdated the month. In his letter of 9 [10] May, John A. Carlyle advised TC that post days for U.S. and Canada were Wed. and Thurs.; 13 May was a Wed.
div3.head: TC TO JANET CARLYLE HANNING

docBody.p: Dear Sister Jenny,—It is a long time since I have had on hand to send you the little bit of remembrance marked on the other page, but I am held in such a ferment of perpetual hurry and botheration here and have grown so weak and weary of my sad work, (till it do end), that I have seldom five minutes to dispose of in my own way, and leave many little jobs undone for a long time and many little satisfactions unenjoyed for want of a bold stroke at them. Finally I bethought me of the Dr. in Edinburgh and he has now got me your little paper into readiness for sending.For John A. Carlyle’s arrangement of a money order for Jenny, see TC to JAC, 7 May, and 10 May. I understand you have nothing to do but present it at the Bank and at once get payment. If, (till you have time to write a long letter of news, which will be very welcome), you at once address me a Canada newspaper with three strokes, nothing more will be necessary in regard to this little bit of business.

I expect to get done with my book in six or eight months. O that I saw the
day! I can and have been working thitherward with all the strength that I possess, to the hurt of my health as well, but I calculate when the end have once come I shall begin directly to improve more or less, and perhaps by degrees get very considerably better again. I had an excellent horse who had carried me 7 years and above twenty thousand miles, his hoofs were got spoiled on the stone hard roads. He came plunging down with me one day, (not throwing me nor hurting me in the slightest),—a most decided fall for no reason whatever—upon which I had to sell him (to a kind master for an old song), and for the last six weeks have been walking, which was a great enjoyment by way of change. It would not do, however, and since about a week I am mounted again:—very swift, very rough (in comparison to my old friend), but good natured, healthy, willing:—and must continue adding a dozen miles daily to the twenty-thousand already done.

We have had such a winter for warmth as was never seen before, not very healthy, I believe, but it has agreed well with Jane:—and indeed the kindred, I think, are all well. Poor “Wullie Carlyle” (if you remember him at all) died lately at Edinburgh,William Carlyle (1797–1863) from Ecclefechan (see 4:322TC to MAC, [3 Feb. 1828]), d. 27 April, 17 Lothian Rd.; apparently a dog dealer because recorded as a “keeper of canine repository” (1861 Edinburgh Post Office Directory). an old man, as we are all growing hereabouts.

Tell AlickTheir brother Alexander. about my affairs and this last news you have had. That I never do or can forget him, he need not be told. I hope your lasses are doing well and that RobertRobert and Janet Hanning had four das. and all of you are pushing along patiently, faithfully as heretofore.Copeland omitted the signature.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 May. Addr: 67. Hanover Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 16 May 1863. MS: Bavarian State Lib., Munich. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Nothing of Dickens’s turns up here but that old Cover of a Letter from Paris. That, with this, will suffice for Autograph to Mr Laing’s Munich Friend,Unidentified further. in the present hurry. With many kind remembrances to Mr L.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, 16 May, 1863—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 May. MS: NLS 517.48. Hitherto unpbd. Apparently enclosed with TC’s brief note written as an autograph for a German friend of David Laing; see the first TC to JAC, 16 May.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—In case there shd be haste with the Autograph, I despatch it at once. I have been quite tumbled abt today; have got almost no work done;—and am in such a flurry, I may as well go out at once (or after writing a small line to Jean), tho it still wants half an hour of my time. I am thro’ the Battle of Kunersdorf;—shd get on faster, were it not for tagraggeries.

My new Horse (i.e. Chapman’s whh is not mine) proves to be a swift rough-footed willing creature; and does me, I think, perceptible good by his jolting velocity.— And lo! abt 2 hours ago there rode up to the door a handsome young Gentn, unknown; who said he had a Packet for me, if I wd come down. The “Packet,” on my coming down, proved to be a very pretty little Chesnut HorseThe horse was a gift from Lady Ashburton; it became Noggs, named for Newman Noggs, the “gentleman by nature” in Charles Dickens’s Nicholas Nickleby; see Wilson, Carlyle 5:498. whh the yg Gentn was riding, “sent you by I am not at liberty to mention whom!” I privately (very privately, by Jane’s hints lately) cd guess Lady Ashburton as the kind Giver;—one of the kindest acts, [considering her o]wnMS cut away to remove signature on reverse of page; missing words inserted in another hand. state of harrassment anxiety and tribulation all this while, that I have ever known. Of course, Chapman’s quadruped will go away on Monday;—today I am to try this one: Heigho, if I only had a little more natural strength left!— But surely it is but embarras de richesses [embarrassment of riches] this new event; much better than do of poverty!—

closer.salute: Good bye, dear Brother / Your affecte

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 16 May. MS: NLS 517.49. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I am very glad to find, by a Note of yrs to John, whh he incloses this morning, that you are fairly in yr new Habitatn; and have escaped the wildly wet weather in going thro with that Operatn. Here it was on Thursday, and still is, very muddy, blusterous; heavy plunges latterly; excellt weather for forTC repeated “for” at turn of page.
brearding Corn, but the very worst for flitting furniture!— I wish, you with my whole heart, many good days in yr new Dwelling, and still better prosperities than in the Old,—tho’ these also have not been bad, have been good even as things go. One point struck me the name, “Mainhill.“Mainhill, 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Ecclefechan, was the farm leased by TC’s father, James Sr., 1815–26. I know why you have called the Place so; but surely you might get some name more descriptive of it: “Hill belonging to the Manor-House” (Matthew Sharpe’sGen. Matthew Sharpe (1774–1846), landlord of Mainhill Farm; there were serious disagreements with him when the Carlyles left; see 3:408–9JCE to MASH, 7 Nov. 1825, 437TC to JJO, [17 Dec. 1825], and Wilson, Carlyle 399–400. Mansion or Mains), that is the meaning of Mainhill! But you were young bairns there, you and James, and have no sorrow or displeasure in the remembrances belonging to the Place.Jean was 16 when they left Mainhill, and possibly unaware of the difficulties. The house was to be called The Hill. Birk-Hill, Birk Brae (if you liked to plant a few Birches) Birk Knowe, Beech Knowe; Gowan Brae; Broom Brae, Brm Bush; Whin Bush;—not to speak of “Lodges,” “Cottages” with an Epithet &c &c: there are abundance of names for the choosing! However, Mainhill, if it please yr own ears, will do perfectly well; and soon it will grow smooth enough to us all.

I have got a new Horse sent me, as if by post, this morning! The Doctor will explain; probably will send you a little Note I have just written to him. I must send away my former horse, of course, the first lawful day: Be off with the old love, before you be on with the new! He has already done me good; tho’ I confess myself totally saddle-sick; that is tired to death of riding,—abt 20,000 miles by myself, and often in the dark, during the last 7 years!

I am fighting on with my Residue of Book; surely it shall not beat me if I can help it.— The new Horse is coming round in 5 minutes.— It is shameful that I write to you so seldom, in return for the many Notes you send me. Goodby’e dear Jean,— Your affecte Brother
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady ALLA, 17 May. Addr: Rue des Bassins / à Paris. PM: London, 18 May 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 507; Surtees, Ludovisi 95.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Here are—what shall I say,—strange doings surely! Yesterday morning, after I had got to my work up here, there came from the street door a mysterious polite message from “a young Gentn, who had a Parcel for me, if I
wd please to step down.” I tried to put it on the Wife; but had to step down myself. And there sure enough sat a very civil handsome young gentn, handsomely mounted; who informed me that the “Parcel” was this beautiful bay-chestnut Horse he was riding, whh had suddenly become mine, by deed of gift somewhere! From whom? Whence How, what? To none of these questions was the handsome young gentn permitted to make any ansr; his one request being, That I wd inform him where the stable was;TC’s horse was kept nearby at Silvester’s livery stables, Upper Church St. permit him to deposit the superb little Horse, and then to vanish. All whh had to be done; his terms being peremptory.— The wonder of my mind was, of course, great,—tho’ I soon guessed (Wife readily confirming) that there was but one person in the world capable of such things

At 3 p.m., the usual hour, I had my new Horse brot round (grooms full of admiratn); and tried him in the Park, and up and down, wherever soft roads were discoverable. Beyond question, one of the prettiest little Horses in the world, and far the prettiest I ever had; nothing in him but loyalty, elasticity, dexterity, and the wish to gallop with me, in the most exemplary manner, to the end of the world. Bay-chestnut; of such symmetry, such breadth and depth; only five years by mark of mouth: strong as a little dromedary, swift as a roe;TC conflated several biblical quotations here and in TC to JCA, 20 May; cf. “swift dromedary,” Jer. 2:23, “swift as the roes,” 1 Chron. 12:8, and “as light of foot as the wild roes,” 2 Sam. 2:18. He also used “swift as a roe” about an earlier horse, Bobus; see 19:82TC to AC, 17 June 1845.—in fact he looks like one of those incomparable light horse I have ridden at The Grange in a certain Lady’s company (one of whh, I think, almost died for me, at Addiscombe last year!)The Carlyles had visited the Ashburtons at Addiscombe, 26–30 April 1862.—and it is certain the Queen herself or Princess Alexandra and Prince of WalesFor the recent marriage of Princess Alexandra and the prince of Wales, see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March]. do not as prest possess a better article for riding.— Fallen to me, out of the skies, in this manner! It is very strange: and when I think of all the miserable anxieties you have had to struggle with, of your own, in the late time, and all the tragedies you have been begirt with, I cannot enough wonder at such a thing; and, instead of speaking my thanks, am ready to blush them. That is really true.

I am now completely mounted for the latter half of Vol V; my four-footed support unsurpassable,—whh will be a most importt help on the side of health thro’ summer. And now if you will bring home that GentnLord Ashburton. “at the end of july” as promised, able to let me see him at The Grange, and look up agn in the world, I will count you a truly Victorious Woman,—worthy to have altars, if that were now the fashion.— Yours most sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LLA], 19 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 499.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: The sight of your handwriting again is precious to our eyes,—more valuable than the signatures of Bank-of-England Notes! It is like the actual break of day, visible to one’s own eyes, after a night whh threatened once to be final! For about a week, at the worst time, I was as good as desperate; my Wife for above three weeks: I believe there seldom was a narrower escape than you, and all that depend on you, have had. I hope we are all thankful;—or, as a poor beggar-woman once said to my Mother, who had done something for her, “if I’m no rightly thankful, I’m sure I’m very glad!“See 1:334TC to MAC, [March 1821].— You too, you will be more cautious and reasonable, won’t you? With thoroug[h]lyTC omits “h.“ good behaviour on your part, we have now the steady expectation that things will all be well again. That we shall see you again in july; “beginning of july,” say the sanguine; “some time in july,” says everybody: a most blessed change of aspects from what there once was! But, for God’s sake, do be cautious, and run no risks that can be avoided by human prudence. I hope you won’t:—it is one of my two hopes, pretty much all I feel to have in the world at present; first that I shall see you at The Grange one day soon as I saw you last, or gradually coming round to that pitch; and second (whh runs into the first, and is somehow almost one with it), that I may then have my sad work behind me, and be out of this imprisonment, whh has really been like a kind of living burial to me for long years past. Life has really nothing in it that is brighter to me than these two outlooks ahead, whh run into one in that way. Poor souls that we are!

Here has been a day worse than December: wild northwind rocking the steeples all night of Monday; deluges of blowing rain towards morning, as if direct from the north pole; wind still piping (11 p.m.);—in the afternoon such gusts of it as were like to blow me off my Horse; in Hyde Park two huge old trees flung down.The Times, 20 May, noted that about 3 a.m., Tues., 18 May, “a heavy gale burst over London, and continued to blow with unabated fury during the whole of the forenoon. It blew from the E.N.E.“ I had a wild ride; but a very pretty too, and a wholesome,—thanks once more to the skies for raining down such a Horse to me! Three rides now; fast friendship rising more and more betwn my excellt little servant and me.

I have still a great deal of stiff labour ahead;—hope you will be home long before I have done; shall be happy to come and finish beside you if you like!
May God grant these little bits of wishes of ours: to us they are very considerable, the greatest now left to us little men. I purpose to write again soon to one or other of you Two; but am in genl awfully busy & gloomy. Yours ever/ T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 20 May. MS: NLS 517.50. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—Don’t bother yrself about names: Mainhill will do perfectly well; if anything do really please yr own fancy, that is the name to take.— I have flung down (here inclosed) a few more specimens and send them off witht a word farther: 11 a.m., and not a word of my task yet done! The new Horse is one of the best in all the world; “strong as a little dromedary, swift as a wild roe“;See TC to Lady ALLA, 17 May. loyal to the bone;—abt a hand lower than I cd have liked (for being well out of the mud):—otherwise, close (t.o.)TC wrote “(t.o.),” indicating the paper should be turned over and upside down to read the other side, but then omitted “to.“ perfection. I have ridden my little gentn thrice; go agn today, tho’ it is muddy (after such a tempest of northwind and rain as we seldom saw): that and the week’s previous riding is already doing me visible good.

Get settled in yr new House, then rest and be thankful.Words carved on a stone bench at the top of Glen Croe, Argyll, placed there by soldiers building the first military road over the pass between Loch Long and Loch Fyne, after the defeat of the Jacobites in 1746. Enough
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Chelsea Wedny 20 May / 1863

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AM, [21 May]. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Lady Ashburton’s arrival in London, 20 May.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNABELLA MILNES

docBody.p: I am sorry I didn’t discover sooner, years and years ago; that one’s best chance of getting Mr C to accept an invitation, is to take for granted that nothing can induce him ‘to’; and to refuse for him without giving him time to refuse for himself! I had not relied enough on the spirit of contradiction that is in Human Nature and especially in Husband Human Nature!

When I told Mr C that you and Mr Milnes had been here, and had invited us to dinner; he broke in hastily, with; “and of course you explained that I never &c &c—?“— “Of course“; I answered, with an air of supreme indifference. “I said, your going was quite out of the question! and as they kindly asked me to come by myself, I don’t mind this time whether you go or not!” “Oh! hu—m! you engaged to go, did you?“— “Yes! I engaged to go! have you had a pleasant ride?“— After a while he returned to your invitation “quite promiscuous” “You engaged to go then? and were to write to say whether i would come or not?“— “No!— I left the matter settled as to your not going“!— “And if I go—you will write I suppose?“— “Do you really mean to say you are going?” “Well—Yes—certainly“—

Do you know that Lady Ashburton is in London? She arrived at six o’clock in the morning yesterday, at her SistersMary Frances Anstruther. Lady Ashburton arrived early 20 May; see JWC to MR, [3 June]. in Norfolk Street— Mr Anstruther being at the point of death.Philip Anstruther d. 22 May. What fatigues she does undergo!— She will stay with her poor Sister, I suppose as long as she is absolutely needed— She can leave Lord A without anxiety now—as, besides being so much better, he has the child and Mrs George Mackenzie with him. I have not seen her, only had a message from her Yours faithfully/ Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 22 May. MS: NLS 608.629B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:162–66 inc. Quot: Blunt, “CLC” 416.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p:
I am wearying for some news of you. I never could lay that proverb “no news is good news” sufficiently to heart. Whenever I am feeling poorly myself (and I should be almost ashamed to sayCf. coterie speech, “I’s ashamed to say“; see 36:12TC to JCA, 28 Nov. 1859. how often that is the case) I fall to fancying that you are perhaps ill, and nobody to tell me of it! And I so far away! It is so stupid of Ann & Grace, who take so much fatigue on themslves, in visiting about in their “district” and attending all sorts of meetings, that they don’t take a walk out of their district now and then, to see how you are going on, and tell me, when they write.Betty Braid lived at Greenend, Liberton, about 2½ mi. (4 km.) SE of JWC’s aunts in Morningside. Some news of Betty would make a letter from them infinitely more gratifying, than anything they can say about
Dr Candlish,Robert Smith Candlish (1806–73; ODNB; see 31:183JWC to EDO, [20 Aug. 1856]), theologian; minister of Free St. George’s, Edinburgh, 1843–73, moderator of the general assembly of the Free Church of Scotland 1861, and principal of New College, Edinburgh, 1862–73. “While preaching, he had an awkward way of habitually shrugging up one shoulder, which made it look deformed; he would begin to scream or screech, and would gesticulate wildly. But once these mannerisms, which remained a life-long feature of his preaching, ceased to be regarded, many were convinced that a great preacher had appeared” (Michael D. McMullen, ODNB). and this and the other Preacher and Prayer; and would certainly inspire me with more Christian feelings. But once for all, it is their way, and there is no help for it!

When I came in from a drive one day lately, I was told “a person” was waiting for me, and on opening the dining-room door, where the “person” had been put, to wait; I saw sitting, facing me, Helen Dickinson, the Sunny-Bank Housemaid!Helen Dickinson, maid at the Donaldsons’ house in Haddington; she had left ca. 1860. It was such a surprise! I never liked Helen so well as Marion the Cook,Unidentified further. but anyone from dear old Sunny Bank was a welcome sight to me now. She has been for some years in charge of some children at a Clergyman’s in HampshireHelen wrote to JWC from her new position in Hampshire, April 1861; see 37:150–51JWC to WDO, [15 April 1861]. and was passing thro’ London with the children
and their Father, who was returned from India—on their way to an Aunt’s near Peebles— She would go on to Haddington she said “just to look in on them all,” but she wouldn’t like to stay there now—“oh no“!— She was grown very stout and consequential.

I took her into my Bedroom to show her my picture of Sunny Bank which hangs there, and another of the Nungate Bridge;Nungate Bridge crossed the river Tyne near St. Mary’s Church, Haddington; for JWC’s exploits on it when a child, see Carlyle, Reminscences 43, 69. See oppabove. and while looking about she suddenly exclaimed “I declare there is Mrs Braid!” you too are framed in a gilt frame, and hung on the wall. The likeness must be very good that she knew you at once; for she had only seen you twice she said, “when you came to breakfast.” Her fine talk will astonish the Haddington people when she “looks in upon them!” She spoke very respectfully of Miss Donaldson; “Miss Jess,” she said hadn’t the same balance of mind that Miss Donaldson had“!! But she was no favourite with Miss Jess, and knew it.

Poor Jackie Welsh has lost her auntJane Scott; see JWC to MR, [12 April]. who had been more than a Mother to her all her life. and she seems quite crushed to the Earth with her grief. no wonder! she is so much in need of some one to sympathize with her and nurse her in her frequent illnesses. And that one Aunt was the only person on Earth that she felt to belong to, and that belonged to her! Her Mother is still alive, but her Mother has never done anything for her but what she had better have let along—brought her into being! And now she, the mother, is past being any good to anybody—quite frail and stupefied.

Oh Betty! do you remember the little green thing that I left in your care, once while I was over in Fife, and when I returned, you had transplanted it into a yellow glass, which I have on my toilet table to this hour, keeping my rings &c in it? Well! I must surely have told you long ago, that the little thing, with two tiny leaves, from my Fathers grave, had after twelve months in the garden at Chelsea, declared itself a gooseberry bush! It has gone on flourishing, in spite of want of air and of soil, and is now the prettiest round bush! quite full of leaves.In 1856 JWC took it as “a weed” from St. Mary’s churchyard, where her father was buried; see 32:28JWC to MR, [5 Nov. 1856]. “It still stands there, green and leafy, and with berries; how strange and memorable to me now!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:164). I had several times asked our old gardnerJoseph Edwards; see TC to JWC, 10 June, and 36:219JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1860. if there was nothing one could do to get the bush to bear. If it were only one gooseberry?— But he treated the case as hopeless—“A poor, wild Thing!— No! If you want to have gooseberries Mam, better get a proper gooseberry-bush in its place“! The old Goth! He can’t be made to understand that things can have any value but just their garden value! He once in spite of all I could beg and
direct, rooted out a nettle I had brought from Crawford Church yard,In 1856 JWC brought the nettle from Crawford churchyard, where her mother was buried; see 32:28TC to IC, [5 Nov. 1856]. and with infinite pains got to take root and flourish— But—I was going to tell you—one day Lizzy, my youngest maid, came running in from the garden to ask me had I seen the three little gooseberries on the gooseberry bush? I rushed out as excited as a Child to look at them!—and there they were! three little gooseberries sure enough! And immediately I had settled it in my mind, to send you one of them, in a letter, when full grown! But alas! whether it was thro too much staring at them, or, too much East wind, or thro’ mere delicacy in “the poor wild Thing,” I can’t tell! only the result; that the three bits of gooseberries instead of growing larger grew every day less! till they reached the smallness of pin-heads, and then dropt on the ground! I could have cried when the last one went!

You remember my little Charlotte?Charlotte Southam; see JWC to CSCSO, 29 March. I had a visit from her yesterday and she looks much more sedate and proper, than when I had to put her away. She is “third Housemaid at the Marquis of Campden’s, and lives in the country; which is good for her. She sent her compliments to “Betty“

My present pair of Girls go on very peaceably.Mary and Lizzie. They are neither of them particularly bright; but they are attentive, and willing and well behaved. I often look back with a shudder over the six months of that Eastlothian Elizabeth!The Carlyles’ cook during the latter half of 1862; see JWC to MR, [10 Dec. 1862]. Her dinner blackened to cinders! her constant crashes of glass and china! her brutal manners—her lumpish insensibility and ingratitude! And to think; that woman must have been considered above the average of Eastlothian Servants; or Jackie Welsh wouldn’t have sent her to me! What an idea it gives one of the state of things in Eastlothian!

Do you remember Capt Baillie (My Mother’s Cousin, who was so handsome, and dressed so distractedly, and had so many little dogs)?James Augustus Baillie (ca. 1800–1873), spendthrift and dandy; see 3:149–51JBW to TC, 17 Sept. [1824], Carlyle, Reminiscences 49–55, 74–75, and K. J. Fielding, “Captain James Belial Baillie—Jane Carlyle’s Wicked Cousin,” Carlyle Newsletter 4 (1983): 2–11. For the most recent mention of him, see 30:236–40JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855. He was living in Dover; see JWC to MCA, [28 June]. According to the 1861 census, he was “late Capt. 16th Queen’s Lancers,” a lodger in St. James St., Dover. By 1871 he and his common-law wife, Anna Maria (b. ca. 1812), lived in 12 Caroline St., London (1871 census). I often see him now—and you would be astonished to see how handsome he still looks! and how young! Not a whit less absurd than of old, but with far less means of making his absurdity conspicuous. He squandered his own large fortune in a few years and how he has contrived to live since, even with a certain
pretension to his old Dandyism, is a profound mystery to me! I suppose the woman he married (if he ever did ‘marry’ her) must have had some remains of fortune that he couldnt make away with!Anna Maria was a widow whose fortune would be forfeited if she remarried; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 53. Certainly he looks always like a gentleman and has the best spirits and best temper I know.

In fact there is hardly any difference on him since he was staying with us at Haddington, except that his clothes are less brilliant—and that one knows him to be sometimes at a loss for—a sovereign! What a wasted Life. with such good abilities, and good looks as he has!

And now goodby Betty Dear! There is a long letter for you; which will, I hope, soon draw me a few lines from you in return— I am anxious to know how yourself and your Husband and George have stood these cold spring weeks. My kind regards to them. Your ever affectionate/ Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 May. MS: NLS 517.51. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here has been agn a miserable waste of a Day; not one word got written; nothing but labouring and plunging, hither, thither, thro seas of forgotten blockheadism, to get some reconcilet effected between honest blockheads, and attain for myself the small privilege of writing right not wrong abt a small matter! The Siege of Dresden under Schmettau in 1759:The siege of Dresden, 26 Aug.–4 Sept. 1759; the Prussians, under Gen. Karl Christoph, Graf von Schmettau (1696–1775), surrendered to the Austrians; see Carlyle, Works 18:104–18. alas, alas, I have little to do with it; and my poor “Days” get more and more valuable to me. Wd to Heaven I had honestly done to all Eternity with these beggarly matters! But peace; let me throw you a line, whh is well due,—tho’ “the Horse” will be here, before I can finish even that.

The Horse proves one of the finest little fellows you ever saw; not a better goes in the world; full of waygate, of alacrity;—quite a pleasure to ride, in comparison; and does me evidently a good deal of benefit. That, therefore, is all right; and in fact my health is not to be complained of,—whh surely is something, and a considble thing! I must canter abt 5 or 6 days of the week, therefore; and hope, before the good weather end, to have done. I do shudder at another Winter’s riding, in storms and rains, in darkness, in mud: I have had enough of that— Jane too is tolerably well; tho’ complaining of our
weather, whh is mainly sunless, and extremely cold, when (as sometimes) our n. wind gets high. Me it suits very well; and the bursting out whh will send me down into the Garden is what I dread

Jean writes to me this morning; has had a bad time, seemingly, and much confusion with her young folk all in smallpox. Everybody here too is getting vaccinated,The Dumfries and Galloway Courier noted, 19 May: “[F]or some time past there had been a considerable number of cases of small pox in Dumfries.” Hansard recorded the government’s answer in Parliament on vaccination, 24 April: “[T]he misfortune of the question of Vaccination was that in quiet times no trouble was taken about it, and it was only when disease appeared in all its horrors that applications were made to the Government for legislation. … The House was aware that there was already in existence a measure for compulsory vaccination. That measure was not, in all respects, satisfactory; but the fault connected with the present spread of smallpox was not so much attributable to the state of the law as to the neglect of the local authorities on whom devolved the working of it. Unfortunately, there was no law on the subject in Scotland. The question of providing a law for Scotland and amending that of England was under careful consideration” (Hansard 170:673).—not I, who had inoculatn of the natural smallpox, and so finished.

I am greatly obliged by yr little sketches of Edinburgh and yrself and neighbours there.— My Emerson man came back,Moncure Daniel Conway. insisting on “a Walk” with me; and got his poor heart shocked by my views upon the Nigger Question, upon Philanthrophy &c &c:Conway recalled their conversation: “When we started on our walk he began at once upon America, the ballot-box, and negro emancipation. … ‘Nothing I have ever witnessed so fills me with astonishment and sorrow as the present condition of things in America. I see it all as fire rained out of the heavens.’ I said I quite agreed, but should probably differ from him as to the evil the fire was raining on. He said, ‘Ah, I was once an emancipator, too … but I came to see that I was following a delusion.’ // It was impossible not to love this man, however much I might deplore his opinions about slavery, so entirely was he speaking what he regarded as truth, and so guileless was his whole expression. // I soon perceived that the vehemence of Carlyle in discussing public affairs was due to the torture he suffered in seeing the errors and agonies of mankind. I resolved not to put him on that rack, and although when we met some mention of events in America was inevitable, and I might be wounded, the boulders were left behind and I passed, as it were, into beautiful walks and swards, with which Carlyle restored and delighted the soul he had just troubled” (Conway, Autobiography 1:352–55). a good creature but extremely mad.— I have sent a guinea to poor Airds “Testimonial” or Symbolical Farewell from the Dumfries neighbrs.Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833), writer; ed. of the Dumfries Herald 1835–63 old friend of the Carlyles. “Mr. Thomas Aird was entertained to a public dinner [on 29 May] in the King’s Arms Hotel, Dumfries, and presented with a testimonial, on the occasion of his retiring from the editorship of the Dumfries Herald, which he has held for 28 years.” He was given, “in the name of a numerous body of subscribers … two elegant and massive pieces of plate, which, along with a valuable gold watch and chain, and a time-piece, form the testimonial” (Glasgow Herald, 2 June). TC noted: “27 May 1863 / to S. Adamson (for Aird Testimonial) / £1..1..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20573). Samuel Adamson (1831–80), British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; son (not nephew as previously noted) Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical notes).— Paper done, Horse here!— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-GS, [late] May. Pbd: George Strachey, “Carlyle and the ‘Rose-Goddess,’” Nineteenth Century 32 (Sept. 1892): 485 inc. Dated late May by TC’s mention that he had “six or eight months” more to work on Frederick; see TC to JCHA, 13 Aug. [May]. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 29 May 1863.]
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE STRACHEY

docBody.p: I am struggling, with all the strength I have, to get that unutterable book gathered into finis in some honest way. For six or eight months to come, my slavery is far beyond that of any penal colony or treadwheel: but then perhaps I shall get done.Strachey introduced the excerpt: “[B]eing … in Holland I stumbled on some original documents of value relating to his nightmare, which were placed at Carlyle’s disposal. He replied in a letter from which the following characteristic sentences are taken” (Strachey, “Carlyle and the ‘Rose-Goddess’” 485). He had previously written to TC from Holland offering to look out for documents that might be of interest; see 38:268TC to GS, [25 Nov. 1862].

div3.sourceNote: TC-WDC, 2 June. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. William Dougal Christie (1816–74; ODNB), diplomat and author; known to TC since 1840; see TC to WDC, [26 Feb. 1840].
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DOUGAL CHRISTIE

docBody.p: I have known little of Thn Hunt,Thornton Leigh Hunt (1810–73; ODNB), journalist. The Carlyles were sympathetic to George Henry Lewes when his wife, Agnes, b. Jervis (1822–1902), also a writer, had children with Hunt; see 29:184TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1854. these many years; indeed ever since his Father’s death.James Henry Leigh Hunt (1784–1859; ODNB), poet, essayist, and journalist; m., 1809, Marianne, b. Kent (ca. 1788–1857). They first met the Carlyles 1832 (see 6:135–36TC to JHLH, 20 Feb. 1832) and lived at 4 Upper Cheyne Row 1833–40; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 138. Thornton Hunt edited a revised edn. of Leigh Hunt’s autobiography (1860) and his poetry (1860). TC’s last contact was apparently in 1862 via Forster, about letters for his edn. of Hunt’s correspondence (1862); see 37:136JWC to JF, [25 March 1861]. I used to think him an extremely ingenious quick-witted man; of loyal dispositions and intentions;—given up to Journalism, this long while past; and grown to I know not what in that turbid element of things. Somebody told me, not long since, that he was a “Writer in the Dy Telegraph“;Thornton Hunt was leader writer and ed. of the Daily Telegraph 1855–73. it is very possible he may be Editor too,—at least if talent in such matters carries the prize.

We are very glad to hear of you on British ground again.Christie was recently retired from the diplomatic service after constant difficulties in Brazil where he had been envoy-extraordinary and minister-plenipotentiary since 1859. He possibly wanted contact with Hunt to gain support for his campaign against the proslavery policies of the Brazilian govt.; see Christie’s letter to Lord Palmerston, Notes on Brazilian Questions (1865) xxi—lxxi. We are at home
nearly every Evg; Tea at 8 p. m.,— and shall be very happy to see you, safe after so many adventures.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea, 2 june 1863

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady T [LT], 2 June. MS: Robinson Lib., Univ. of Newcastle. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 292–93 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY TREVELYAN

docBody.p: It was a lovely thought in you, to write me a letter!— I was most agreeably surprised! having been told just a day or two before that you had “hidden yourself among the Swiss mountains“!The Trevelyans had gone to the Auvergne, central France. I should say however, in strict truth, the surprise became agreeable only after opening your letter and seeing your name to it! A first sight, that letter gave me a dreadful fright! brought my heart bang into my mouth; it had such a look of another letter from Dr Christison, following his last with a rapidity that suggested his own metaphor of “Mother Carey’s Chickens“!“Mother Carey’s chickens,” sailors’ name for stormy petrels, also often used to mean snowflakes falling with great rapidity. The envelope was the same as his envelopes, in shape and size! the same postmark ‘Paris’!The Trevelyans stayed with the Ashburtons in Paris late May; see Surtees, Reflections 213–14. the same handwriting (positively!) except that it was more easy; which with a rapid stroke of genius in the imaginative line, I imputed to Dr C having written this time in haste and agitation!! Had he not, in his last, expressed disappointment at some hitch in Lord A’s progress? Had the slight derangement he spoke of become already serious? Decidedly, it was with my heart in my mouth that I opened your letter! and then I drew myself suddenly up at the first line; and then I looked for the signature; and then I drew a long breath; and then I felt glad—and grateful for a letter “out of your own head” (as the children say) “all to myself“!Coterie speech; see 13:284JWC to TCH, [22 Oct. 1841], and 34:233JWC to MR, [30 Oct. 1858].— It was really very nice of you to write it—and I will tell Mr Ruskin.

Oh my Heavens! how I do wish that he maynt breakdown again on Friday
evening:Ruskin’s lecture on “The Alps of Savoy,” at the Royal Institution, 5 June. that the shadow of his last disastrous Lecture may not fall upon this one! I suppose there is no hope of Lady Eastlake or Mrs Millais,For an account of Ruskin’s lecture of 19 April 1861, when he had “broken down” in the presence of his former wife, now Effie Millais, and her friend Lady Eastlake (1809–93; ODNB), see 37:152–53TC to JAC, 23 April 1861. William Brookfield noted in his diary, 17 June: “Sat an hour with Carlyle. … Speaking of Ruskin, he said that the last lecture was a sort of set off against the breakdown which he had achieved in consequence of Mrs. M. going with a termagent of a woman called Lady E. to a former lecture on purpose to disconcert him” (Brookfield, Circle 2:500). or both, being laid up with small-pox or scarlet fever!

Mr C thinks that your sword must be one of those swords that were made in great number, in 1741 at the grand Insurrection for Maria Theresa.For the “Insurrection for Maria Theresa,” when the Hungarian Magyars joined her army, see Carlyle, Works 4:260. Pandour is the generic name for a Hungarian infantry soldier—“a great, helpless, hulking, very ugly fellow, Mr C says, who went swaggering about with a long gun, and numerous Butcher’s knives stuck in his belt, and pistols, and a short sword, a sort of — Garibaldi (!) of these days—and just as much of a swaggering Ass, (Mr C ventures to say) as our Garibaldis of the present day!!“— The Hungarian Cavalry soldiers were called Hussars the Infantry Pandours—oh no! they didn’t belong to Frederick they were the admiring subjects of Maria Theresa and Frederick was once very nearly belonging to them! they had very nearly taken him prisoner,For Frederick’s near capture by the Hussars, 27 Feb. 1741, see Carlyle, Works 4:86–87. An impertinence which Mr C cannot get over seemingly. Your letter dated Saturday reached me only yesterday.JWC writes on Tues. With kind regards from Mr C Yours very truly / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [3 June]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 3 June 1863. MS: NLS 608.615A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:166–69 inc; Simpsons 153 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I was very glad to get your letter; for I had begun to fear you were ill; or the Doctor ill! You see I have such faith in your constant remembrance of my small self, that I need to fancy extreme reasons for any unusal delay in answering my letters! And this time there had been grave reason enough tho’, not exactly physical illness.

Poor Mr Maxwell! his life had been so long filled with pain;William Maxwell (1807–63; see 14:91TC to WIMA, 26 March 1842), duke of Buccleuch’s factor at Thornhill, d. 21 May from kidney disease. and so little hope of any other deliverance from pain, but that which has come; that I should think even those, nearest and dearest to him must think it well as it is!— What a comfort your Husband has been to him, and to his wife!Mary, b. Clark (b. ca. 1818), m. 1847.— I know nobody that seems to me so helpful to his fellow creatures as that Dr of yours! God bless him!

You perhaps saw in the newspaper the death of Mr Anstruther. Lady Ashburton had just got settled in Paris after her hurried visit to England, when she received the news of his being at the point of death! and back she came, to be with her Sister in her extreme need! He died on the second day after her arrival, and on the following day she returned to Paris! What that woman goes thro in the way of fatigue to body and soul is quite astounding! I said so to Monkton Milnes, and he answered coolly; “oh! well! you know she is scotch! these scotch women have enormous strength! nothing can knock them up!“— “For example!” I said, pointing to myself, who am always receiving compliments on the wretchedness of my looks, and who to say the truth havn’t the strength of half a sparrow in these scorching East winds!
I must try sea-air for a few days; I know of nothing else that has a chance of doing me good.

I had something to tell you which did not find room in my last letter. The name of Mrs Oliphant’s Publisher is Blacket, and he has a smart wife,Henry Blackett (1826–71), coowner, with Daniel Hurst (ca. 1802–70), of the publishing firm Hurst & Blackett, 13 Gt. Marlborough St., London; his wife was Ellen Blackett. Margaret Oliphant moved to Ealing 1861, to be near the Blacketts: “I had got very intimate with them somehow. … Mrs. Blackett was about my age, and a fine creature, very much more clever than her husband, though treated by him in any serious matter as if she had been a little girl,—a thing quite new to me, and which I could not understand” (Oliphant, ed. Jay, Autobiography 101). who came with him to dinner at Mrs Oliphants when I was there.JWC visited Oliphant in Feb.; see JWC to MCA, [26 Feb.]. They were very (what we called in Scotland) ‘up-making’ to me, and pressed me to visit them, at Ealing. Which I hadn’t the least thought of doing. Well! some weeks ago, Mr C, was just come in from his ride, very tired, and, to do him justice, very ill humoured, When Mary put her head in a the Drawingroom door and said “Mrs Blacket wished to know if she could see me for a few minutes.” I went out hurriedly, knowing Mr C’s temper wouldn’t be improved by hearing of people, he didn’t want, coming after me! Told Mary to take the Lady into the Diningroom, (where was no fire) and before going down myself, put a shawl about me, chiefly to show her she mustn’t stay! On entering the room, the Lady’s back was to me, and she was standing looking out into the (so
called) garden, but I saw at once it wasn’t the Mrs Blacket I had seen. This one was very tall, dressed in deep black, and when she turned round, she showed me a pale, beautiful face, that was perfectly strange to me! But I was no stranger to her seemingly; for she glided swiftly up to me like a Dream, and took my head softly between her hands, and kissed my brow again and again, saying in a low dreamlike voice; “Oh you Dear! you Dear! you Dear!— Don’t you know me?” I looked into her eyes, in supreme bewilderment! At last light dawned on me, and I said one word—“Bessey?“— “Yes! it is Bessey!“—and then the kissing wasn’t all on one side—you may fancy! It was, at last, Bessey, not Mrs Blacket, but Mrs Blackiston who stood there, having left her Husband in a cab at the door, till she had seen me first. They were just arrived from Cheshire where they had gone to see one of his sons; who had been dangerously illPeyton Blakiston had four sons; it was probably the 2d son, Peyton, who was ill and d. 1865. and were to start by the next train for St Leonards where He is the chief Physician—they had only a quarter of an hour to stay. He is a good intelligent looking man; and while he was talking all the time with Mr C, Bessey said beautiful things about him to me, enough to show that if he wasn’t her first loveHer first love was John Badams (ca. 1792–1833), chemist; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 297–300; she was rumored to have been his mistress; see 7:216–17TC to JAC, 17 June 1834. he was at least a very superior being in her estimation. They pressed me to come to them at St Leonards, and I promised indefinitely that I would.

About a fortnight ago, Bessey walked in one morning after breakfast. She “had had no peace for thinking about me, I looked so ill, she was sure I had some disease? had I?” I told her; “none that I could specify except the disease of old age! general weakness and discomfort.“— Reassured on that head she confided to me that I “looked just as Mrs BlackistonFrances Blakiston. had looked when she was dying of cancer;“!! and she had come up certain that I had cancer to try and get me away to be nursed by her, and attended by her Husband! Besides she had heard there was so much smallpox in London “and if I took it and died before she had seen me again she thought she would never have an hours happiness in the world again!” Oh, Bessey Bessey! just the old woman; an imagination, morbid almost to insanity!— “Would I go back with her that night anyhow“? “Impossible!” “Then when would I come and she would come up again to fetch me?“— That I would not hear of, but I engaged to go so soon as it was a little warmer. and today I have written that I will come for two or three days on Monday next—

She is not still wearing mourning for Mr Badams—but for the MotherAnne, b. Rochefort (ca. 1762–27 Nov. 1862), m., 1782, Sir Matthew Blakiston (1761–1806), 2d bart. and
Eldest BrotherSir Matthew Blakiston (1783–23 Dec. 1862), 3d bart. of her Husband who have both died since her marriage. and who received the announcement of that event “very coolly“—(not to be wondered at—being an old Baronet family—) Dr Blackiston a second son of a Baronet.Blakiston was the fourth son. and now I mustnt begin another sheet—I shall be anxious to hear how your new Cook shapes
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 June. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got your second Note a couple of hours ago; I meant, at any rate, to write you a longish acct today,—for I am not riding (going to hear Ruskin lectureSee JWC to Lady TLT, 2 June. tonight);—but, alas, alas, my time is all gone to 5 minutes; the whole blessed day spent boring and bothering over maps and blockhead intricacies: close now upon 5 p.m., walk to take, in dirty windy rain:—& in fact, and short, I must restrict myself to the needful two words.

Did I ever tell you abt Bessy Barnet? Surely I did once? She is now the wife of a Dr Blakiston, once of Birmm who has been here repeatedly with her; a sonsy“Sonsy,” applicable to men and women, has many meanings in Scots, including buxom, cheerful, comely, handsome, hearty, and pleasant. solid rather hard-voiced, restless, but really good kind of man, who has been residt at Hastings (not at Birmm any more) for some years. Jane is going to them next week, for 3 days of sea-air; whh I much applaud.
