He in the meanwhile has left for you,—with Jane, who thot she wd read it in passing (as she has not done)—a Medical BookPossibly by Blakiston; his most recent was Practical Observations on Certain Diseases of the Chest, and on the Principles of Auscultation (1848); otherwise unidentified. (title unknown to me); she wrapt it yesterday in brown paper; I, a moment ago, to be in time for the post here, have sent it thro’ to get an 8 penny stamp put on it: if I can reach Sloane SquarePresumably the nearest post office from where a parcel could be sent. with this Note still in time there, you will get both together; if not, you must just continue perhaps wondering a little & guessing over the Book phenomenon, till monday morning solve the mystery.

My horse is very useful to me: I am in genl getting on, a degree faster,—not too fast yet! All is at least on its average with us; no news but what you already
have got indicated. DarwinErasmus Darwin (1804–81; see 8:152TC to JAC, 15 June 1835, and 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837), the Carlyles’ close friend since 1835. is to dinner us today, and take us to the Ruskin Albemarle streetAlbemarle St. was the address of the Royal Institution. adventure: Ruskin, just home from Savoy,Ruskin had been in mainland Europe for the past year, returning to England early June. we have not yet seen. I inclose a scrap of Newspr Cover from Jenny in Canada.— My kind regards to the Otthenins: Erskine I suppose is beyond them. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9 June]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea London. PM: 9 June 1863. MS: NLS 608.615B. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:288–89 inc. TC wrote later: “(I think) (1): july 9, 1863.” He also numbered two of JWC’s other letters from St. Leonards in 1863: JWC to TC, [10 June], and JWC to TC, [12 June].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: 6 Warrior Square St Leonards on Sea [9 June 1863]
docBody.p: All right, Dear! You would see from the newspaperPresumably sent by JWC on arrival at St. Leonards. that I had arrived at the far end. Tho’ only a journey of two hours it seemed a dreadful long one; from which was to be inferred that I am not even up to the mark of “my frail ordinar” at the present time. Dr Blackiston was waiting for me with the carriage, and gave me the frankest welcome. I felt quite at my ease with him before I reached his house.

Bessie wasn’t allowed to come having a headache, but she met me on the steps of the front door. So well she looks in her own house! and a very suitable Mistress of it; altho’ it is quite what the auctioneers call a “large aristocratic Mansion.” The Situation is first rate; close on the Sea, at right angles to it, in a square of large handsome Houses.

The bedrooms are beautiful and must be very quiet as a general rule; at present there are pipes being laid along the road by the Sea, and the rivetting makes a disturbing noise in the morning—but during the night it was as quiet as at Cheyne Row—

—I have been out in the carriage today twice—before dinner and after—and I have had a doze of pepsine administered to me by the Dr whom I take to be a very clever Dr. And Bessey is always feeding me with dainties, calves foot jelly &c &c as if I were a young Bird! Nothing can exceed their kindness— I only fear that I cause a good deal of trouble.

I have not said anything yet about going away, but I shall tomorrow, and tell
you when to expect me— Pray dont sit up till two—nor take in a sixth cup of tea—nor comit any indiscretions in your management of yourself— The thought of your being “left to yoursell“Coterie speech; variant of “mostly work in a place by himsel’“; cf. 8:21TC to JCA, 28 Jan. 1835, 10:9TC to MAC, 21 Jan. 1838, and 25:143JWC to TC, 6 Aug. 1850. is the only drawback to my content Yours ever JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 10 June. Addr: Dr Blackiston / &c &c / St Leonards / Hastings. PM: 12 June 1863. MS: NLS 616.575. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks dearest! You sent me a beautiful little Note, to season my coffee for me. Oh that I had five minutes to write you the smallest reasonable ansr. But agn it is “your dinner, Sir!” amid the wash of paper-clippings here; and ye must just excuse us.Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834.— Not a word of news at any rate: all well; going reasonably, I,—do not doubt it. You say nothing how you slept: but from the pipe-rivettings in the morning I draw auguries not of the best. Surely the sea-air will help you. Don’t hurry, if so: I will consent to be a “desultory widow“Coterie speech; see 16:182JWC to JW, [27 May 1843]. how long you like on those terms,—on those, but not on other of any sort. Last night I made a great effort for a word or two of articulate human speech; and did get to ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley. abt 10. Might as well have staid at home. Jingle-jangle, “head bad, dogs noisy, a martyr of suffering; but ho’ver!“—that was all I got plus bad allowances of gas to breathe.— — I go punctually to bed; but sleep rather under par: the fruits of last FridayWhen TC went out to dinner and to Ruskin’s lecture; see TC to JAC, 5 June. (for certain),—think whether I ought to rejoice in going out. The little DarlingJWC’s nickname for Edwards, the gardener. has shaved the Garden into perfect propriety for you. Three persons have called (to my certain knowledge by their cards), Brookfd, Froude, Jula Sterling:William Brookfield, J. A. Froude, and Julia Sterling. & Letters are come (the Edinr one this morning). To me nothing but yours, and a wretched missive abt Matinées du Roi de PrusseSee TC to JN, 21 Jan. (from a spiteful child of the gutters),—whh also I inclose,—but cannot inclose the joke of his method of sending it (till we meet). God bless you
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: My kind regards to the Dr and Mrs Bn, regards & thanks say

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 June]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea London. PM: 10 June 1863. MS: NLS 608.615C. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote “(2 & 3)” on envelope, and “(2)” at the bottom of JWC’s letter; possibly the third letter, JWC to TC, 11 June, was also in the envelope at one time.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Thanks for the little scrap; it was a deal better than nothing. The Newspaper I examined with the attention only possible to utter idleness, without finding anything that could justify its being sent to you;Unidentified; apparently forwarded to JWC by TC. unless the blockhead who drew a comparison between Cromwell and Stonewall JacksonThe death, 10 May, of the Confederate general Thomas Jonathan “Stonewall” Jackson (1824–63), from wounds received at the Battle of Chancellorsville, was widely reported in Britain. The Bristol Mercury commented, 30 May: “[T]he premature death of one who combined the best qualities of Rupert with the nobler genius of Cromwell, is justly deplored by his friends as an almost irreparable calamity.” Prince Rupert (1619–82; ODNB), royalist cavalry commander during the English Civil War. Lloyd’s Weekly Newspaper noted, 31 May: “[T]he slain are counted by tens of thousands, and not an advantage gained to the federal cause save the death of Stonewall Jackson, the Cromwell of the South.” The comparison between Jackson and Oliver Cromwell (1599–1658; ODNB) had been current for some time. The Times pbd. a report from their New York correspondent, Charles Mackay (1814–89; ODNB), 20 Sept. 1862: “[T]hey who have seen and heard him uplift his voice in prayer, and then have witnessed his vigour and prompt energy in the strife, say that once again Cromwell is walking the earth and leading his trusting and enraptured hosts to assured victory.” Alexander Pendleton (1840–64), Jackson’s staff officer, wrote to his mother, 8 Oct. 1862: “I have been reading Carlyle’s ‘Cromwell.’ General Jackson is the exact counterpart of Oliver in every respect, as Carlyle draws him” (William G. Bean, Stonewall’s Man: Sandie Pendleton [Chapel Hill 1959] 81). thought that deserving of your notice!
I am making good use of my time. Today again two carriage drives—a doze of pepsine—jellies wine &c every two or three hours—besides champaign to three o’clock dinner!

You will not be surprised that in such a paradisical state of things, my usual stiffness in keeping my word should have given way, and I should have yielded to the kind pressing to prolong my stay. I have agreed to stay till Saturday and then I shall certainly come.
If you would like a fowl tell Mary.The Carlyles’ maid. She will do to the best of her ability everything you bid her. only she has no habit of thinking for herself—

I have left my spectacles in the Drawing-room, and if I go down for them,
it maynt be so easy to come away again—so I have written this with half sight— —and “shall add no more but remain your obedient humble servantCoterie speech; the ending of a prayer by a “young Preacher” used by JWC to conclude her “Simple Story of my own first Love“; see 30:194JWC’s Simple Story.
docBody.name: Jane W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [11 June]. MS: NLS 1774.246. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on the reverse of Caroline Davenport Bromley to JWC, [10 June].
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Dearest, all is right, your staying till Saturday, and all,—except that I have less time to write to you than ever before! In fact at ¾ to 3 Anthony Sterling came daundering in; cut short my work (eheu [alas]!) &c &c till Mary came up,—and this is written, after my dinner, see if you wish it continued.

No more news from Paris: shall we take Miss Bromley (see this, inverted)TC wrote in pencil next to Bromley’s dating of “Wednesday“: “came by a groom & horse, on Thursday 9½ a.m. I ansd you were gone to Hastings till Saty—ansd thro’ Mary vocally, ‘with Compts.’” Thurs. was 11 June. as a contradictn of our yesterday’s posts?Bromley wrote: “I was relieved to hear a good acct again today fr[om] Paris“; next to this TC wrote: “does that mean Thursday?” TC opened a letter, 10 June, from Lady Ashburton to JWC, apparently with not such good news; see TC to Lady ALLA, 11 June.— I did not write to Lady A. (spent the night study-studying); I hope you have?— Saturday then, what hour? T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [11 June]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: 11 June 1863. MS: NLS 608.616A. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on envelope: “St Leonards / 1863,” presumably underlining “3” because JWC also stayed in St. Leonards in 1864.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
What a nice packet to be laid on one’s bed of a morning, this would have been, if only the news from Paris had been less anxious! I dont mind Lady A’s note very much. She is so soon alarmed; but Dr C’sDr. Christison; see TC to Lady ALLA, 11 June. is disheartening. However, as all the unfavourable symptoms may, he says, be produced by the coming on of gout, I put my hope in that and dont give up the prospect of seeing him home in July. I gave Dr Christison’s note to Dr Blackiston, and he asked if the “albumen” spoken of was constantly there; when I said no, he
declared that intermittent albumen was not at all serious—and did not see anything alarming in the note.
I suppose that my taking not dispairing view of the interruption to his improvement is due to the improvement in my own health, effected by these few days of good nursing and good doctoring

I am bringing you some pepsine in the form of pills. Dr Blackiston says he can always tell from a person’s complexion when pepsine will agree with him—that he had no doubt of it in my case and was pretty sure it would be an unspeakable comfort to you too. But what is the use of getting ones appetite made like a young wolf’s, if one is never to eat anything but fried mutton, and poultice puddings, and brown soup!—one must get poisoned in the course of time by such monotonous diet!

One of my letters was an invitation from Lady Airlie to you and meto attend her “at Home” this day between 4 and 7 “guy idle o’ wark“Coterie speech; favorite expression of TC’s mother; see 9:161JWC to JWE, 4 March [1837]. I should say.
I will certainly come on Saturday— / Yours ever/ J W C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], [11 June]. MS: NLS 20767. Quot: Ashton 427.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: (“Thursday June 11th“) That is today! when your note of invitationSent on by TC; see JWC to TC, [11 June]. reaches me here—at the seaside!— I fled from Chelsea last Monday. to save my Life! (As if it were worth saving!) feeling on the brink of a nervous fever!— And since monday, I have been in Paradise! Comparatively! For I am living in a delightful large House within a stone-cast of the Sea, with the best Physician of the place for my Host; who gives me miraculous medecine, that takes away from me all desire to commit suicide! and makes me so hungry! while his wife (the Heroine of the very most interesting Romance I ever came accross!) feeds me up every hour or two with jellies and all sorts of dainties as if I were an unfledged bird!
Oh dear! It is so pleasant to be nursed, and made much of! My only regret is, that I must go home on Saturday and take up with the opposite of all that!

Mr Woolner was at Cheyne Row the night before I left, and as he was going away he flung back savagely these words. “You can tell Lady Airlie when you see her, that she has given me a confounded deal of trouble! I have
gone and made a new sketch of my Godiva,Woolner’s half-lifesized marble statue of Godiva was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1878; see Woolner 307. in consequence of those criticisms of hers“!
I said I was delighted to hear it, and thought the Committee of Public Morals should give you a Testimonial!
In breakneck haste / your ever affectionate/ Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 11 June. Addr: Rue des Bassins / à Paris. PM: London, 12 June 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Letter of yesterday afternoon, which I broke open (knowing the hand, and Jane being away at Hastings), made me very gloomy in my solitary evg here. Dr Christison, always clear, candid and cautious, was somewhat reassuring:Christison also wrote and enclosed a note; see JWC to TC, [11 June]. but my habitual feeling is, “we have so very small a stock of strength to depend upon!“—and I am too much given to prophesy not in the flattering strain to myself just now. This morning, a Note from Miss Davenpt Bromley, handed in by a groom, gave me great comfort: “a comfortable account from Paris has much relieved me this morning“;—“this morning” she said, and the groom and Note (intended for my Wife, and to be answered directly) were, sure enough, of Thursday morning, 9½ a.m.; but then, again, the Note itself was dated “Wednesday,“—I have hoped all day, only by mistake;—tho’ I could not yet learn for certain. Let us hope, let us hope! It is a bad element to me, also, that you spoke of writing “tomorrow,” and there has nothing come: but I study to interpret that my own way, as weaker than the Bromley document, as perhaps not meaning much. Why shd I trouble you with these my calculatings & forecastings, that go on as an undercurrent, among the sordid botherations and wearisome toils I am always plunged in? Your own troubles are of quite another magnitude and pungency all this while. Ah me, ah me!—

The Wife is not coming home till Saturday, as probably she has herself told you. Except for her, and my little Horse, I have absolutely no company in these times; often I do not speak to a single creature in the course of my day. Ruskin I shd have seen this afternoon; but had not the heart. He staid only an hour in Paris;Ruskin wrote to Lady Trevelyan, 17 June, explaining why he had not called on her and the Ashburtons in Paris on his way home, 30 May: “I could’nt call at Paris at 5 in the morning, I got there … about that time … breakfasted in a café … and got to Boulogne at one oclock” (Surtees, Reflections 213). and of course had no news to tell us of you, the night he was here.

You may well call my Horse a success! He is the finest little fellow in the world; full of taking ways, now that he is getting familiar with me. A very great and visible improvet he produces in my affairs; if it be a luxury to do a fellow fellowTC repeated “fellow” at turn of page.-creature good, as I think it is, a certain heart may fairly enjoy it amid its many pains & cares. God send us good news!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 June. MS: NLS 616.576. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: There is nothing whatever to be said; all in status quo as near as necessary; but it seems to me you shd have once, by a good chance favouring you, a kind of Note on regular paper at least, before ending yr lucky Tour of 5 days: lucky if I saw you agn on the 6th day, improved as you describe yrself—or indeed if I saw you once, on any terms. The rain is battering down in deluges; nothing audible but it, and an Italian Grinder-Demon,Street organ grinder; see 37:203TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1861. faint and far-off, but too distinct; whom not even the wet that his wretched yellow skin is getting can rightly inspire me with any pity for the evidt Missionary of the Pit.Missionary from hell or the bottomless pit; cf. Rev. 9:1, 11.
Latterly, after something of writing, I have been vigorously annihilating rubbish; that done, there are still a few moments for Notes,—for one to you first of all.

Last night I got extensively into work; and then, being filled with remorse for my day (and having a pill in me to boot), I decided to write Lady A. a Note (not the least word from her, or anybody,—unless that enigmatic Notice by Miss Bromley may be taken as later good news?)— But before I got done with all this, to my amazet the clock struck one; and more, on looking out I found plunges of rain: so did not try to go out; but hurried my milk, and was in bed not very long after 2. Resolutely quiet; and sleep nothing like so bad as you wd have prophesied. Today I expect to be cured by brown-soup whh you sneer at.— — I found in the Park yesternight my recognising Young Gentn with the Child on a pony led by strap: he ventured to join me; began talking feebly, wearisomely,—abt Bp of NatalBishop John William Colenso; see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March]. before long; when, what was my
astonisht to learn that he was the Brother-in-law who had been hereProbably Charles Bunyon (b. ca. 1822), Colenso’s wife’s brother; possibly he also attended the tea mentioned in JWC to JAF, [ca. 2 March]. (and cd not be pleased to be so forgotten)! Not a yg gentn at [all]Omitted by TC. tho a weak one; wrinkles visible on his face when you looked near, and a matter of 45 years on his poor head. Before long happily he rode “for home,” time being come. We shall know him again.

Nothing came for you since yesterday; nor for me except that Dud whh I inclose,—from a weak Brother,Unidentified. who wd lose his wits if I took the advice he gives. I did write my name at the bottom of his old grey blockhead of a Carte de visite; and sent him on his farther way.

Perhaps you will have felt it a duty (tho’ you don’t promise) to tell us by what train you are coming; and what kind of victual wd be properest for a delicate individuality in these circs. Oh my Dear, good b’ye: here is the “Dinner quite ready Sir,” & not the least scrap of “Note” to anybody but yrself. Thank the kind Dr & Mrs B. from me for what they have done. God bless you always, poor Coagitur.“Coadjutor“: one who works together with another; one of TC’s occasional names for JWC; cf. “Coadgitor,” (5:420TC to JWC, 11 Sept. 1831. T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 June]. MS: NLS 608.616B. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote “(3)” at top and bottom of letter, and on reverse: “Jane from St Leonards / 1863 (not ’4 as now: ah me!)“; This was JWC’s fourth letter from St. Leonards.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: It is quite superfluous to write, Dear, when I am coming myself in a few hours. But I know you are quite capable of worritting if the Postman passes, in the morning

We (that is Mr FrederickUnidentified. and I) leave here by the twelve oclock train and he says I will arrive at my own House about three oclock. Perhaps I shall get a glimpse of you before your ride—if not—you will find me all settled on your return—

I wish to Heaven I could carry this sea air home with me! it has done me so much good! it, and constant driving in the open air. But I fancy the benefit I have derived is hardly of a carry-away-able sort! Anyhow it is a comfort to know that one can be benefited by a change and to have felt almost well for three days!
They have been as kind as possible to me—and without any fuss or nonsense
But ‘all about it’ when I come
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Tell MargaretProbably in error for Mary, rather than an unidentified servant Margaret; the most recent Margaret (Sullivan) left June 1862. to have some dinner ready for me at about half after three

div3.sourceNote: TC-[PB], 14 June. MS: Emmanuel Coll. Lib., Cambridge. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [PEYTON BLAKISTON]

docBody.p: A very fine miniature. It recals to me, about the brow & eyes, something of my poor [Badams];The word has been blotted out, but is presumably “Badams“; John Badams, whom Bessy Blakiston knew from childhood and whom TC first met 1824; the miniature was probably painted when Badams was about 18; it is still in Carlyle’s House, Cheyne Row; see above. but he was ten years older, and much changed in complexion, in vivacity and kindly impetuosity of expression, when I first saw him.
An excellent Gift to send me! Thank Mrs Blackiston very specially for that among her other kindnesses.
docBody.name: T.C. (Chelsea 14 june 1863)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 14 June. MS: NLS 517.52. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I was very sorry to hear from you, yesterday afternoon, about poor James’s accidt; Jean’s son James Aitken had broken his collarbone; see TC to JAC, 9 July. of whh no whisper had reached me till then. He has been more than usually a stranger for some good while back,—only here once I know not how many weeks ago, and seemed to impute it to embarrassment and hurries of his own; changing Lodgings,James changed lodgings in spring 1861 (see 37:161TC to JCA, 1 May 1861), but had recently moved again, presumably to a suburb in S London. pressure of Office business &c &c:—ever since I got mounted again, I had been determining on a ride out to his new Quarters; but discovered that I had lost the written Address, and shd have to apply at Finsbury CircusPresumably the address of the mercantile house where James worked. for a new direction to my course,—and this, in the perpetual bother I am kept in, I had missed doing for the last 3 fridays (friday the last post day of the week, to whh date it had always been put off). In this fine state of darkness yr note found me yesterday; and to complete the busss, just as I was about flinging you a word to send me the Address from Dumfries, as the now shortest route, an interloping person came in, and detained me till after post! So goes the course of arrangts with me here at this time.

Well, not to preface any further, I set off at a venture, this Evg, with such vague light of dim recollections as I cd scrape together, I confess witht much hope of finding the place;—but I did, by good spiering and guessing, actually find it; & ended, in about an hour and half, all my uncertainties by seeing James in person, sitting at his own open window; rosy-faced, cheerful, and, except his arm in a sling, all going perfectly well with him. You need not disturb yr mind abt the poor fellow any farther: I sat abt ¾ of an hour with him; smoked two pipes, in one of which he joined; he gave me an acct of the accidt & his other affairs; and all was as satisfactory as, in the case, I could have wished. The bone had been wrong bandaged (apothecary in a hurry) when it first miscarried (some “rut” in the road he said); & the first night he had got no sleep, but been obliged to take off the wrappages himself, whh were stopping the circulatn of the arm (left arm it is); and send for a proper
Dr on the morrow; who immediately; and since that, Jas has had no trouble with it farther, except keeping himself in a quiet posture in a good stuffed chair, at a quiet window with outlook into the silent country and fine summer skies; and entertaining himself with diligent reading of a Certain Person’s Works,TC’s works.—a volume of whh he had in his right hand at the time of our interview. His Hosts seem clean good people; his little sitting room was prettyand in fair order, his bedroom up stairs is “bigger,” he told me, “by the breadth of the lobby,” and must be big enough,—out from it, opposite & southward is just one new House (a very decent young Dairyman’s, whose own property “freehold” it is): the whole street, of whh Jas is about the middle, has hardly fifteen houses in it; and between him and the British Channel is nothing,TC means that there were no towns between James’s suburb and the English (British) Channel, rather than that James could see the Channel. except that one freehold “Dairy,” but clear green hills and vallies, the beautifullest in the world, except that “advancing prosperity” has thrown them all into the mortar-tub; and there is such a higgledy-piggledy of trenchings, railway, build-buildings and dig-diggings, as in all Nature, I believe, the like of does not exist! I had not been in the region at all for perhaps 7 years; and nothing cd exceed my poor sense of disgust at the defacement made in it.

James is not coming home (on other accts as well) till beging of July. He spoke of resuming his work abt Wednesday; whh I earnestly charged him not to think of doing (for they are in no hurry abt him; his work at a slack any way),—but to go out and walk first for a couple of days &c &c, whh he faithfully promised. I hope you will get this, tomorrow night; and be easier in yr mind on that score. All is doing right. Yours ever
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AGAGIL, 15 June. MS: Univ. of Iowa. Pbd: Gilchrist 139–41.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p:
It is indeed long since we exchanged words, we two!There is no recorded correspondence since Anne Gilchrist left London in March 1862. So long that when I received your letter“As soon as the ‘Life of Blake’ was finished Anne Gilchrist wrote to [JWC] … placing Brookbank at Carlyle’s disposal” (Gilchrist 139). this morning I did not recognise the handwriting; but had to look for the signature; and when I found your name I was struck with
astonishment, thinking the letter was from a Catherine GilchristCatherine Gilchrist, sister of Dugald Gilchrist (Jane Baillie Welsh’s youthful suitor); she lived with JBW and Grace Welsh during the winter of 1824–25, when JBW tutored her; see vol. 3 and passim. whom I used to correspond with 45 years ago!! And yet I have often thought of you and often talked of you in the past year—and have not thought of Catherine Gilchrist the least in the world! What a thorough belief in your total forgetfulness of me did this little fact indicate, that my mind should have leapt back forty five years for the writer of that letter! I answer it in a hurry, having to go up to town for groceries &c—before dinner time, which is now half past three with us!

I should like much to go and see you in your country homeFor her previous invitation in 1862 for the Carlyles to go “next year,” see 38:189TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1862. George Eliot and G. H. Lewes rented Brookbank, Gilchrist’s house in Shottermill, Surrey, May to Aug. 1871, when Eliot wrote part of Middlemarch.—not with any view to our own convenience—but just to see you and talk with you—and refresh our friendship which seemed in the way of fading out like a photograph!—

But I cannot go just at present— I have been to St Leonards on a visit for a week—am just come home, and have a great many things to see after, before I could leave Mr C again— I was to have gone with a Lady to Folkestone on Wednesday,Caroline Davenport Bromley wrote, [10 June]: “If the weather is not too rainy, would you go with me to Folkestone on Friday or Saturday for a few days?” JWC was in St. Leonards at the time, returning Sat. 13 June, but perhaps hoped to arrange the trip for a few days later. for a few days, and broke off my engagement, on account of Mr C not liking that I should go away again just when I had come home. So I could not go in another direction on Wednesday. Tell me when you return from Essex,Gilchrist’s mother, Henrietta Burrows, lived in Earls Colne, Essex; see 38:189TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1862; it is mistakenly placed in Kent at 38:20 and 280. and there is a little time to choose a day out of, and I shall be only too glad to go!Shottermill was about 44 mi. (71 km.) SW of Chelsea.

Mr C is getting on very peaceably with his work, suffering nothing from heat as yet—and it would be most imprudent, while that is the case, to not let well alone. Shifting his quarters for more than a day or two, is always for him A most dangerous measure!— I want him to go to the sea for a few days—and I think he will—there being a dear old friend at St Leonards who would receive him at any time and keep him all right. But even that he will not do till he is burnt out— A thousand thanks to you all the same—
I will write at more leisure—but I would not keep you in suspense about the house
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BC, [16 June]. Addr: 21 Campden Hill Road / W. PM: 17 June 1863. MS: Women’s Lib., London Metropolitan Univ. Blanche Mary Shore Clough, b. Smith (1828–1904); she m., 1854, Arthur Hugh Clough (1819–61; ODNB), poet, known to TC since the mid-1840s. After his death she wrote asking if TC could find any old letters from her husband; see TC to BC, 9 March 1862.
div3.head: JWC TO BLANCHE CLOUGH

docBody.p: I hope to see you here on Sunday evening.
Don’t take the trouble to write, unless you would like another evening better.
I came in, well wetted, just after you called today.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [18 June]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Colenso’s visit; see TC to JAC, 19 June; also by JWC’s illness; see JWC to MCA, [28 June].
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Alas, dear Forster, there is nothing possible,—nor even half-possible! The poor Wife (for her sins, or at least for mine) had invited the Colensos,John William Colenso, bishop of Natal, and presumably his wife, Sarah; see JWC to GWGWE, [2 March]. with their heterodox aprons, for Friday Evg: and tonight you will find she is in bed, unable to see anybody (better a little; and a slight thing, of temporary misery, the Doctor says, “owing to electric weather,“—has been miserable enough; 52 hours now of total abstinence from food or drink, with want of sleep, with &c &c),—so that what is to become of Natal itself “on Friday” is at this moment a problem. Give my respects to Elwin.Elwin Whitwell (1816–1900; ODNB), rector of Booton, Norfolk 1849–1900; ed. of the Quarterly Review 1853–60. In a month’s time I shall hope to be out of the 7-years war (God send it!); in front of my last abominable stage of quagmire; and ready for a gladder meeting.
John Forster, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
Eliza Forster, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Today all is so awry! My days work shrunk into an hour’s work (such the preliminary fuglings“Fugling,” signaling, or “fugle,” motion (both used by TC in French Revolution, Carlyle, Works 4:225 and 243), apparently from the German Flügelmann, soldier acting as a model to follow, standing at the front during drill. I have had);—and to crown the matter, a yellow Demon
has begun grinding his Organ, to the tune of “Can you work, my lad?“— The Lord pity us all.
Yours ever/ T. Carlyle (Chelsea, Thursday 2 p.m.)For photographs of John and Eliza Forster, possibly taken around this time, see aboveand opp.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 June. MS: NLS 517.53. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I remember that this is Friday; and push away my dreary business shut, to fling you half a word before the week close.

I am well enough, nothing special to complain of that way except “some of the effecks of heat“:Possibly coterie speech; see 30:10TC to SGS, 27 July 18[5]5; source untraced. Jane too returned much improved by her week of Sea-air, tho’ alas it will not be very permanent I doubt,—tho’ it does still hold out to a visible degree. My Horse is doing his duty as before, no fear of him I shd think,—useful to me very, tho’ wearisome & lonesome very. My work creeping on, at say the 10th part of a reasonable velocity: but faster I cannot drive it than it will go! Undoubtedly a most ungainly thing: requiring infinite trouble in every particr, yielding infinite indifference of result (even to myself), but insisting to be honestly done: thank God, it will not endure quite forever! This is really all the news I have, at least that you don’t already know.

Craik’s correctns I spent (not very profitably) a half day in examining. They are exactly what you define them: 7, or so many, errors of the press (whh I corrected); the others one and all definable as errors of the Craik,—impossible to do his will in any one of them, tho’ of course I see he has been readg accurately, and am pleased with his zeal to help.John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 June: “On Saturday I did go out … to meet Craik & his two daughters. He was very talkative, & our evening passed away pleasantly. At parting he gave me that list of inaccuracies in your Vol. III. & he called here yesterday. I defended ‘Heir apparent,’ & ‘Pipin of Heristal’ (though a ‘Pipin of Heristal’ undoubtedly was the Grandfather of King Pipin). The ‘Titular of Lorraine’ also seemed right, so far as I knew; & the ‘sometimes (not once only) disagreed’ I proved by Köhler. The 370 ‘both Honourable Houses,’ I said was the only rational phrase in such a case, tho’ House of Lords may be right honble. I shewed that 346 lets any one doubt that chooses. And I could not concede that there were any other errors than those which I had marked with a stroke before the page—seven in all of printer’s errors. The list may amuse you & so I send it, though you have little use for such things at present.” TC noted on the envelope: “3 june 1863 / Contns … Craik: i.e. Nichts” (MS: NLS 1768.54). For Craik’s references, see Carlyle, Works 14:326, 359, 391, 393, and 15:175. Craik’s two surviving das. were Mary and Georgiana.

Ruskin &c are coming here tonight (Bp Colenso too! a thin harmless creature, decidedly rather wearisome to me): Rn’s Lecture was not much;—& I got a decided mischief by the villainous gas-atmosphere &c &c

Bessy Barnet was abt 25 years servant & factotum to Dr Blakiston, who had a sick Wife, children &c &c and is himself a kind of nervous excitable mortal. His Wife being dead, and By, his indispensable factotum being now liable to
tongues, he married her. Very fond of one another thinks Jane; and doing well. This is all. Dinner announced & Jane waiting 5 minutes ago. Adieu dr Br
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [28 June]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:169–72 inc, dated [5 July]; dated closer to JWC’s illness mid-June; see TC to JF, [18 June].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Every day since I got your letter; I have put off answering it, till the morrow; in hope always that the morrow would find me more up to writing an answer both long and pleasant! But alas! I had best not wait any longer for “a more convenient season“Cf. Acts 24:25. —but just write a stupid little note, according to my present disability; as a time when my head will be clearer, and my heart lighter, and my stomach less sick, is not to be calculated on!

I went some three weeks ago to St Leonards the pleasantest sea-side place I know, and staid from Monday to Saturday, in circumstances the most favourable to health that could be desired! the finest sea-air in the world—a large airy quiet house close on the shore—a carriage to drive out in twice a day—a clever Physician for host who dieted me on champaign and the most nourishing delicacies, and for hostess, a gentle graceful, loving woman who besides being full of interest for me as a heroine of Romance has the more personal interest for me of having been my—servant! about thirty years ago! and of having been sincerely mourned by me as—dead!
Did you ever hear of Bessey Barnet?— It will be a fine story to tell you when we meet—if you never did—but it is too long for writing.

Well! I returned from that visit quite set up—and the improvement lasted some two or three days— Then I turned as sick as a dog one evening, and had to take to bed—and the sickness not abating after two days, during which time to Mr C’s great dismay, I could eat nothing at all (nothing in the shape of illness ever alarms Mr C but that—not eating ones regular meals!) Mr Barnes was sent for—who ordered mustard blisters to my stomach, and unlimited Soda-water, “with a little brandy in it“— In about a week I was on foot again—but weak as a dish clout! And that is my condition to the present hour! I dont see much chance of bettering it, here— And Mr C seems determined to stick to his “work” all this summer and autumn as he did the last.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, [late June]: “Mrs Carlyle people tell me is lowly wretchedly ill—Carlyle has broken the knees of his old beautiful horse & got another—one other vol of Fred G is ready waiting for its fellow” (Mantell). It is very bad for him—and even bad for the work! He would get on twice as fast, if he
would give himself a holyday— But there is no persuading him as you know—“vara obstinate in his own wai“!“Cumberland man’s account of the Scotch” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:170).
And as I was away last autumn a whole month, by myself, I cannot have the face to leave him again this year—unless for a few days at a time—when I am hardly missed, till I am back again.

Besides; the present Servants are not adapted for being left to their own devices. They do very well, with overlooking and direction: and the week I was at St Leonards, nothing went wrong. But for that long, they could have their orders for every day—and as I did not tell them for certain what day I should be back there was a constant wholesome expectation of my return.

Mr C has got his tent up in the back area,For a photograph of TC under his awning in 1857, see 32:176TC to JWC, 9 July 1857. and writes away there, without much inconvenience as yet from the heat. He has changed his dinner hour to half past three, instead of seven; then he sleeps for an hour and then goes for his ride in the cool of the evening The horse Lady Ashburton sent him is a pretty, swift little creature, and very sure-footed, which is the first quality for a horse, whose rider always goes at a gallop! But Mr C draws many plaintive comparisons between this horse and poor old “Friz,” as to moral qualities. This one “shows no desire to please him whatever!—only goes at its best pace when its head is turned towards its own stable! Friz was always endeavouring to ascertain his wishes and to gain his approbation! it was a horse of very superior sense and sensibility! and had a profound regard for him“!—

I was interrupted by my Cousin James Baillie.For James Baillie’s reappearance, see JWC to BB, 22 May. TC later wrote on the MS in blue pencil: “(1856? or 7?) fragt Jas Baillie.“ the celebrated Dandy of forty years ago—and still as much a Dandy as ever only minus the fortune to spend on his clothes! However he still contrives to look very handsome and gentlemanly, and like nobody else!— He lives at Dover with a Lady whom he calls “Mrs Baillie“—but nobody but themselves know how that stands! andhe comes to town frequently to see after a chancery suit which has been going on for fi[f]tyJWC omitted “f.“ years by the settlement of which he expects seven thousand pounds. “Don’t he wish he may get it“?Coterie speech; see 29:307TC to JCA, 11 May 1855. kindest love to you all— / Your ever affectionate/ Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [30 June]. MS: NLS 553.286. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by the siege of Vicksburg, 25 May–4 July; news of its surrender reached London, 20 July, so also possibly dated 7 or 14 July.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg. Thanks for yr Nicolai Excerpts:Christoph Friedrich Nicolai, Freymüthige Anmerkungen über des Ritters von Zimmermann Fragmente über Friedrich den Grossen, von einigen brandenburgischen Patrioten (Berlin, 1791–92); see 27:129TC to JN, 31 May 1852, and Carlyle, Works 18:183. TC’s copy: HCC. he is wrong in Excerpt 2d about the Revolutionary,Nicolas de Bonneville (1760–1828), French revolutionary and writer. who was hardly come into the world when Matinées,Les Matinées du Roi de Prusse; see TC to JN, 21 Jan. at least when IdéeIdée de la personne, de la manière de vivre, et de la cour du Roi de Prusse (1752); see Carlyle, Works 16:338–40. TC previously denied the claim made by Nicolai and others that Nicolas de Bonneville wrote Matinées du Roi de Prusse (see Carlyle, Works 12:170); new evidence convinced him that the older Zacharie Pazzi de Bonneville (possibly the uncle of Nicolas de Bonneville) was the probable author, and also the author of Idée de la Personne; see Carlyle, Works 18:182–84. &c, made its appearance.

I have drawn up what I had to say (modified in part by what you sent me): and if you wd now take the trouble to copy it, and put in the references (Brunet,Jacques Charles Brunet (1780–1867), bibliographer, author of Manuel du librairie et de l’amateur de livres, 3 vols. (Paris 1810). Nicolai, &c), and to rectify anything you find wrong,—I shd have quite done with it, and be thankful on Sunday Evg.— I want still to know for certain what share ChoiseulJacques Philippe de Choiseul, comte de Stainville (1727–89), French minister of foreign affairs from 1759; see Carlyle, Works 18:3. had in the Pirate Enterprise of 1760:Frederick had privately printed 12 copies of his poems entitled Oeuvre de philosophe de Sans-Souci (Potsdam, 1749–52; see Carlyle, Works 16:241–42), containing Frederick’s private thoughts on other European monarchs; TC believed Choiseul encouraged de Bonneville to steal a copy and publish it widely in 1760; see Carlyle, Works 18:179–80. there are two Letters of his printed in the ‘ConstitlLe Constitutionnel was a French political newspaper, 1815–1914, which pbd. Choiseul’s note of 10 Dec. 1759; see Carlyle, Works 18:183. 2 decr 1850’ (see Oeuvres de Fredc 19o, 137n, and ask if the Museum people file that Paper); failing whh Preuss somewhere refers to Causeries de Lundi;“Causeries du Lundi” was a series of topical columns by Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve (1804–69), pbd. in Le Constitutionnel from 1849.—or perhaps our GothaKarl Friedrich Lucian Samwer (1819–82), lawyer, who discovered an edn. of Matinées in the Gotha archives, and pbd. the evidence in “Über Unechtheit und Ursprung der Matinées royales,” Die Grenzboten: Zeitschrift für Politik und Kultur 22 (1863): 473–84, 500–519; see Carlyle, Works 18:183–84. Friend already tells?— Mark somewhere or other (you who know) how many editns
of Matinées;TC wrote that seven or eight edns. of Matinées were pbd. after the first one; see Carlyle, Works 18:184. & any point worth putting on record with the supreme of brevity & so leaving forever.

I am considerably relieved to hear that Vicksburg (for whh the Yankee Editors were hallelujahing afflictively loud on Saturday) is still untaken!The Confederate fortress of Vicksburg, a key defensive position on the Mississippi River, was attacked by the Union army led by Gen. Ulysses S. Grant (1822–85) 19 and 22 May, then besieged from 25 May; the garrison’s surrender, 4 July, led to Union control of the Mississippi River.— In haste,—till Sunday Evg / Yours/ T.C. (Tuesday 1 p.m. Chelsea)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 July. MS: NLS 526.6. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I must not let the week close again witht some little word from me, as it tends to do. We are struggling along pretty much on the old terms; so you need not be uneasy. Poor Jane is rather below par, since the weather grew so hot; but she is better than she was a week ago, and fights a vigorous battle; goes out driving, &c, and does not yield to her many impediments. Perhaps a turn of Country or even sea-side may occur again, whh aways improves matters. I am now quite under canvas; that is, down in the flagged area, under the shadow of the House, and with an awning overhead: it embarrasses my working concerns; but it is much wholesomer; and indeed there was no alternative, the top story having become plainly uninhabitable. I have a great fight, not always successful to get even a small day’s work done. But I do advance: about the end of this month, I hope to have the Seven-Years War all on paper,—the last Battle (Torgau) comes on tomorrow; but there are two more Campaigns;Frederick’s sixth campaign, 1761 (see Carlyle, Works 18:361–407), and seventh campaign, 1762 (see Carlyle, Works 18:448–81). with whh I mean to be brief. Brevity, brevity, after that; on all accts! I ought to be printing again, surely, some time in September? There will be a sore struggle to close so wide a stocking in any feasible way: but it must, it surely can and shall be done.

Sometimes I judge (indeed generally of late) that we actually ought to have a pause in August, say two whole weeks, in the silent country somewhere, by
the sea-shore if that wd offer itself as feasible. There are plenty of chances; in fact rather too many, but none yet quite certainly eligible: Froude wants us in Devonshire (some old Schloss am Meer [castle by the sea],Froude was renting Ringrone House, built 1830s, on the edge of Salcombe, S Devon coast (Herbert Paul, Life of Froude [1905] 127). —but it is 200 miles off!)—that has some likelihood, as other offers have; but the first thing to be attended to, and followed so far as possible, is the return of the Ashburtons,—Lord A. actually to be here at Bath House on Thursday night next; so his Doctor, one Quain, stopped me yesterday on the street to say: almost a miracle; and far beyond our hope at one time. We shall see what that produces. In the mean time, let me be busy, busy.

You ought to get away into the Country without delay.John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 June, from Linlathen, where he was visiting Thomas Erskine, 24–ca. 30 June: “Linlathen is looking very beautiful this year, the foliage being richer than usual, & the weather most favourable for everything. Mrs Stirling is considerably stronger than she was before leaving Edinburgh. She cannot yet walk very much, but gets out for a long drive every good day. Erskine too is also looking better than usual. Both desire me to send their kindest remembrance to you & also to Jane. … First night I slept very badly, but slept well last night for a reasonable number of hours, & feel refreshed today. Perhaps I have been poring too much over my Danish, Islandic &c. & shall be better for a little rest.“ Yes, surely!— I am sorry to toWord repeated at turn of page. hear of J. Aitken’s collar-bone still troubling him, poor fellow. I write this night to him for some specific news. I will add one word to you tomorrow.

Very well; and thanks! The “berry” “loot“Unexplained; probably not plant or food specimens from Linlathen. &c are curious: I will read Laing’s BookPossibly The Diary of Alexander Brodie of Brodie, MDCLII—MDCLXXX, and of his son, James Brodie of Brodie, MDCLXXX—MDCLXXXV, ed. David Laing (Aberdeen 1863); otherwise unidentified. one day if I live; but cannot at prest.— Aim rather to avoid Augt in London; but indeed there too, there may be chance of us, and houseroom &c is always certain.
docBody.name: Yrs ever

ps.p: Send me Otthenin news;—and unless 3. Nelson Strt Drd SqreThe Otthenins lived at 33 Northumberland St. in Dec. 1862; they may have moved to Nelson St.; it crosses the end of Northumberland St., which continues as Drummond Pl. (not Sq.). be the address, a new Copy of that. My Compts &c there, and to Erskine. “Dinner, Sir!” (and I retire from under my awning).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 9 July. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 10 July 1863. MS: NLS 608.616C. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:289–92 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I had been fancying it was your turn to write, and so, not feeling any qualms of conscience at my own silence; but your letter comes with such an air of having nothing to be ashamed or apologetic for, that I begin to fear I had made a mistake and was myself the indebted Party!

At all events it would seem you have not heard from me since I went to St Leonards. I stayed there from Monday till Saturday, and liked my visit much. It is a beautiful place and Dr Blakiston’s house is situated within a stonecast of the Sea—and is a fine airy lofty House—handsomely but plainly furnished and Bessey looked very natural gliding about as mistress of it! Dr Blakiston is a clever, energetic, kind hearted man—very vain, rather egotistic and as excitable and impatient as my grandfather Walter!Walter Welsh (1752–1832), JWC’s maternal grandfather (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 122–30). But Bessey understands him entirely, seems to admire his faults as much as his virtues, and has the completest silken dominion over him! They live the quietest life, except for his practice— She will visit nowhere—“does not choose to be patronized“— She is always occupied about her house and his comforts. His practice is not very laborious (being a Physician) considering how lucrative it is!— He told me he made about two thousand a year

They were both as kind as kind could be— Bessey would not be hindered from bringing up my hot water and waiting on me as a Ladys maid— And she was never so pleased as when we talked of the things that happened when she was my servant— Dr Blackiston too talked of all that so frankly that there was no awkwardness in my changed position towards her. I seemed to improve every day. Dr B gave me—pepsine—which agreed wonderfully with me—and Bessey was always “nourishing” me with jellies champagne &c and always making of me, and that divine sea air! and I did not fatigue myself with walking, but had two drives in the carriage every day. never woman had a better chance at getting well! And I did come home a different creature from what I went away. And the difference lasted two or three days—but only two or three days tho’ I did continue the pepsine—gradually I ceased to eat again, and got sicker and sicker till I had to take to bed and lie there several days, unable to hold up my head for nausea!

Mr Barnes whom Mr C sent for; (Mr C never being alarmed at any form of
illness but the incapacity of taking one’s regular meals!) put mustard blisters to my stomach and dieted me on Soda water “with a little brandy in it“—and said “the heat had upset me“— I have not been feeling the heat at all disagreeable—but of course Drs know best! After a week I was ‘about’ again after a sort

But very thankful should I be to get away from this noisy, dusty place—into some quiet green place for a while and if I had my choice, independent of all other considerations, it is to Holme Hill I should like best to go. But I cannot run away this year again, as I did the last, and leave Mr C to his own devices, especially as he is likely to take a short Holyday himself after all, provided I keep him up to it, and go with him. The Ashburtons are at last coming home—this day week. Dr Quain is going to Paris in a few days to superintend the journey and hopes that when he (Lord A) gets home to The Grange he will make more rapid progress in gaining strength than he has done hit[h]erto. They are sure to want us at the Grange and Mr C will not refuse him, in his present circumstances. Then there was a promise when Mr C refused Lord Lothian’s invitation last summerThe Lothians invited the Carlyles to visit the previous summer; see 38:121, 122JWC to LLO, [July 1862]. that we would go the next year—when The Book was to be done! The Book alas is not done!—nor within six months of being done! But Lord Lothian asks us again, and I think Mr C will hardly find in his heart to refuse. That poor young man is so fond of him! and has such a sad life! Miss Baring wants me to go to her in HampshireLouisa Baring (1804–88), Lord Ashburton’s sister, lived at 23 Princes Gate, London, and had a house at Alverstoke, Hampshire, which JWC visited Aug. 1858. on the 22d— And I could do that, which is a short journey, and would not require me to be long away But Mr C said today I had to keep in mind, that I might have to go to the Grange and afterwards to BlickinghamBlickling Park, 15 mi. (24 km.) N of Norwich. (the Lothians’ place in Norfolk)—so I must postpone my own will to his ‘mights.’During July JWC visited Geraldine Jewsbury; Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 24 July: “Mrs Carlyle came to see me one day & I go there again—she looks terribly ill & weak. He is always in the depths of Frederick” (Mantell).

It isnt a very comfortable idea to me our both leaving the House with these two young maids in it— The one aged six and twenty is just as young in sense as the one at eighteen. They do very well with looking after and constant direction; but left to themselves I forsee they will make acquaintance with all the idle people round about. and that when we take them up again I shall probably find them spoiled: not to say that they may have people in the house who are not safe. These apprehensions are excited in me by what I have observed of their readiness to strike up conversation with all the lounging passers by over the area railing! Since the weather was hot they keep the kitchen windows open and sit in them and sometimes go out altogether into
the area—and attract the notice of men women and children who address them, and then they answer— I have two or three times forebidden this; but still it goes on—when they think me out of hearing. They are not lightheaded girls at all, only indiscreet and underbred—and it is very difficult to repress a habit which you cannot make them see the impropriety of. I am very glad your cook is answering.— Is little MaryOne of Mary Russell’s servants. as good as ever? give her my kind remembrance.
Kindest regards to the Dr Don’t be long of writing Your ever loving
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-H & Co. [HAC], 20 July. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.

docBody.p: Will you be so good as send me, in the usual way:For recent orders, see 35:126TC to HAC, [27 June 1859], 36:269TC to [JC], 24 May 1859, and 37:126TC to HAC, 23 Feb. 1861.

1°. Two Dozen Port, the same kind we last had.
2°. Three Dozen Sherry, same kind as last;—and also
3°. Two Dozen Sherry of the Manzannello kind, that is of “light, dry, bitter” kind, & of approved quality (be particular in that!)
In sum, therefore: 2 doz. Port; 5 doz. Sherry, of the two kinds specified;—distinguishing the Bottles, of course, by some recognisable outer mark.
Payment by return of post.TC noted: “8 Augt 1863 / to Hutchn & Co (wine) / £16..11..6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 31 July. MS: NLS 526.7. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—I have scarcely a minute left; but half a word will be better than none. I like well to think of you at Scotsbrig agn, after the long
absence;—wish I were there myself, for that matter;—and send all manner of kindly remembrances and affectionate wishes to Jamie and his Family. Oh me, oh me!—

The AshburtonThus in MS. came across in the end of last week. I saw them three or four times,—him extremely thin and frail, but looking cheery quiet, and as if he wd daily gather more strength now in the improved positn. They went to The Grange, day before yesterday; were recd by the Tenantry (I hear) all out in solemn gala &c; find everything looking beautiful &c:—Ld A. himself writes to me this morning, in a fine firm hand, very legible tho’ in pencil (there being no ink near). It seems to be getting settled that we are very shortly go to out thither; and try to stay some time, I “working” the while (whh really might be possible?) Any way it is like to do us both good.— I am now near the end of 7-jahrig-Krieg [7 Years’ War] (first rude draft of it); yesterday I caught cold (under my awning in the east wind), and sniftered the whole day; but today it is off again, & I up stairs with warmer clothing. Christison’s functn is ended;Dr. David Christison, one of Lord Ashburton’s physicians, had accompanied him to Paris. he returns to Edinr—“Dinner Sir!” Forgive me: all of you!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-ET [ETWI], 31 July. MS: Harvard. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD T. B. TWISLETON

docBody.p: For Keith’s sake (not for my own, having entirely done with him), I shd like to glance over that Supplement,TC sent Twisleton memoranda on the Keiths 28 March; see TC:TC’s Memoranda, 2728 March, and TC to ETETWI, 28 March; perhaps Twisleton had found some supplementary information; otherwise unidentified. if you cd leave it with me when you come tomorrow night. In haste,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 2 [1] Aug. Addr: The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: 1 Aug. 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Letter dated by postmark; TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: The minutes I had set apart for you, this day, were stolen by an accidental Yankee from N. York,The New Yorker is unidentified. —worse luck to him!—& tomorrow there will be no post.

I can only say therefore that you have, in effect, put on my unworthy back one of the most magnificent Dressing-gowns ever made by man or tailor;—and that I am reduced to silence by this and other gifts, and miraculous remembrances of me, at such a time! The wife is enchanted; and declares this new garment actually makes me “look well.” It has an admirable simplicity fit for the modest mind (she says); & an opulence & grace, of Colour, material and design, whh render it quasi-royal quasi-pontifical, &c &c. My own notion is that, if I be ever (what is not likely) waited on by a Deputatn of Mankind announcing that I am appointed, say “King of the Romans” (with a view to being “Kaiser of the Future“), & find myself, as is likely, ill dressed at the time,—I need only fling on this vesture, and (if I have a clean shirt) stride downstairs, in a majestically appropriate manner.— — Really, really, in sober sadness, I am ashamed; and very grateful to my Lady and you.

Christison came last night with the Parcel;Christison wrote to Lady Ashburton, 1 Aug.: “I spent yesterday evening with the Carlyles and took the dressing gown with me. First Mrs Carlyle put it on to show it off to Mr Carlyle, and then he put it on to show it to her. It was unanimously voted the ne plus ultra of dressing gowns, and she said that he had never looked so well in anything else before. Miss Bromley & a Miss Dewsbury [Jewsbury] were there. I was more charmed than ever with Mr Carlyle & spent a very pleasant evening. She gave me carte de visite likenesses of Mr C. & herself which have been done recently” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). The cartes de visite of TC and JWC were presumably from William Jeffrey’s photographs, Sept. 1862; see 38:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 38, 225JWC to JCA, [30 Sept. 1862], and JWC to JRDRJR, 6 Jan. yr Letter in the morning was itself a prize—such cheerful news, loyal tenantry (who were discreet enough to vanish too, before they had done mischief);—and the whole in a hand as firm as it was 50 years ago! Let us be thankful.

My New Yorker (who in fact is a solid Scotchman, of 25 years standing there, Professor, Dr &c &c) has quite the orthodox (i.e. the my-dox)I.e., TC’s views.) views upon the late riots,Following President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation, which took effect 1 Jan. 1863, tensions increased in New York between proslavery Democrats and abolitionist Unionists. A Conscription Act, passed 3 March and enforced in New York from 11 July, was particularly resented by the poor because any person paying a $300 commutation fee could escape the draft. The Democratic governor of New York condemned the act as unconstitutional. Five days of rioting began 13 July. As well as attacking draft offices, the rioters attacked African Americans, seen as competition for scarce jobs and the reason why the Civil War was being fought. Many were lynched, and a black orphanage burnt. The Examiner reported, 25 July: “A mob of several thousand persons surrounded the buildings where the lots were drawn, destroyed the enrolment papers, and assaulted the officers and police, several of whom are reported to have been either killed or seriously injured.” Estimates of the dead and injured vary widely, but it is probable several hundred were killed. It took several days for the police to regain control of the city, because the New York Militia was away reinforcing the Union armies at the Battle of Gettysburg, 1–3 July. Once the armiesmilitia began to return to New York, along with additional units from the army sent from the battlefield, order was restored. The Examiner commented, 1 Aug.: “It is now not only North against South, but Federal Northern against Northern State Citizen, white against black. What a complication of the fiercest strife!“ the Nigger questn, and all other points of that Yankee
farce-tragedy. “Saw it coming, ten years ago” &c &c.— — Alas, I ought to be asleep, preparatory for my little horse; instead of talking farther. Adieu; and may never worse be among us!Proverbial; see 15:178TC to AC, 13 Nov. 1842.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 8 Aug. MS: NLS 517.54. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I find you are gone to Scotsbrig today: I had sent Jean a Fraser, in the notion that it might perhaps find you at Dumfries and be a sign from me; this having failed I will write you a few words. After a toilsome enough and rather futile day, I escape up to my garret here, after tea, for that object;—one small duty I may still accomplish tho’ my poor day’s work was rather a failure, and my ride a labour rather than a pleasure to me in the solitary evening. A beautiful evg too, and indeed a beautiful bright day, under one’s Awning (had the work gone right, as it did not): but both day and evg solitary oherwise, and not only so but noisy as well, whh is an ill combinatn. I had to take a blue-pill too last week; you know what that means with me! Were my nerves clear, and my spirits good, I cd now dash off my work and finish at a good rate: but that is a conditn as impossible as growing young again; I must finish without that,—namely by sheer compulsion, and at such rate as I can!

I cannot tell you yet anything about our motions. It seemed to be settled, when the Ashburtons went away, that we were to follow almost directly; “in a week or ten days,” was what I agreed to, and we expected to have heard before now some farther news abt it: but none comes, and we begin to think there may have obstacles arisen (poor Lord A. too weak to be troubled with
any guest, even the most familiar; poor Lady A. got into a burble, as she is apt to do, with her enthusiastic plans &c &c); and that the thing is shoved away into the vague more or less. There was another pressing invitatn too, “for Augt sometime,” to a place called Blickling (very ancient Anne-Boleyn Mansion,Blickling Hall, once lived in by Thomas Boleyn (1476 or 1477–1539; ODNB) and his wife Elizabeth (d. 1538); their da. Anne Boleyn (ca. 1500–1536; ODNB), queen of England 1533–36, may have been born there. For the invitation, see JWC to MR, 9 July. nr Norwich), where the Marquis of Lothian lives, an amiable valetudinary yg man, who has been very pressing on the matter: this, tho’ Jane is rather eager for it, I have pretty much decided to stave off, this year, as we did last; but of this too we yet hear nothing. And so are quite at sea in regard to all that. Proverbially “at sea“;—if it were only literally, nothing cd be better; for a week of sea-bathing is what I shd covet more than anything, and will yet try for: as to the rest, really London, in its empty state, with one’s own bed and home, is to me abt as good as any other place whatever. Jane does get very weakly in the heat here; her I must send away into some country recreation (Scotland perhaps still?); but for myself I can do very well without. My Paper is done;—and I have a Note to write to Irma,Irma Otthenin; for her photograph, see opp.above; it may have been taken at the same time as her mother’s (see 115TC to JAC, 29 April). as you see by the inclosed!

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Adieu for this night. I will add a word on Monday before posting.TC added nothing.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 13 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
In receiving a letter in Dr Christison’s handwriting this morning, I was not so surprised, as frightened; for I had some notion of his being at the Grange; tho’ in taking leave of me he had asked my “messages for Edinr.” But I had gone up to Bath House some three days ago, to ask HanahHannah Hall; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [ca. 10 May]. if she knew how Lord Ashburton was; and she had told me, along with the most favourable accounts of “my Lord,” that “it was a good thing in her opinion Dr Christison was gone back to him; for he was a discreet well disposed Gentleman, Dr Christison, not like some that had been there.” So I supposed he was at the Grange; but as he had latterly only written when there was some hitch in Lord A’s progress, it was like my foolishness to open the letter in fear and trembling! But it was a nice comfortable letter. I think I will inclose it to you,
that you may read the pretty things he says of Baby!Mary Baring. Pretty things said of oneself or one’s Baby give more pleasure when said ‘behind one’s back’!— I am not benevolent enough to get excited, in a general way, over the happiness of “others“! When told of any one being very “happy“; the response of my secret heart is apt to be, just; “Very Good, It is more than I am!” Happiness can do very well without sympathy; and having only a limited amount of sympathy in me, I keep it, generally speaking for the miserable. But either, because you have come thro’ so much misery before reaching the present happiness; or because I love you in a quite exceptional way; or for both these reasons together; it is a fact that it makes my heart all warm to think of you in these bright days of peace and hope!
Oh yes! you must be very careful! must let nobody come,—must let nothing that human will can avert interfere with His progress!

I heard of the Linlathen people the other day, from Miss Dundas,Probably Miss Hamilton Dundas, 8 St. Bernard’s Crescent, Edinburgh; she might have been a relative of the Mr. Dundas present at a dinner in Edinburgh, 22 April, with John A. Carlyle; Thomas Erskine; Charles, Lord Neaves (1800–1876; ODNB), Scots law lord; and William Henry Fox Talbot (1800–77; ODNB), photography pioneer; and others. John wrote: “[W]e had rather pleasant talk and entertainment.“ who was staying there, and who wrote to me, under the absurd impression that I “was benevolent and active in doing good in my neighbourhood” (fancy!) to “find out the circumstances of a young womanUnidentified. from Scotland who had written to her that she and her children were actually starving“!—I found the woman, who did not look starved the least in the world! and her two children were the merriest, fattest infants I ever saw in my life! But there was sufficient evidence of poverty in the house to justify me in advising Miss Dundas to aid the Husband into the carreer of hawking vegetables in the streets! in which “a very good living could be made,” the woman said, “Many brought up large families comfortably in that way!!“— I wrote a long account of all the outs and ins of the case, so far as I could make them out by looking and questioning. But I have had no second letter and am afraid Miss Dundas is not pleased that the babies were not emaciated and wailing for bread!

It does not need this ideal enterprise of hawking vegetables to remind me of the astonishing supplies of fruit and flowers and vegetables I am receiving from Melchet Park!Melchet Court, country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire; purchased in 1861 by Lord Ashburton; see 38:8JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861].— I never saw such flowers! such fruit! and these beautiful things keep me in a sort of continual atmosphere of you! But two hampers in one week!The Carlyles also received a weekly hamper from Addiscombe Farm. as there came last week—is really too much! I really need no
longer try to thank you for your wonderful kindness! There are no words for it! and for actions! alas! I am afraid our relative positions make it impossible I should ever thank you in deeds! But who knows? The fable of the Lion and the mouse“The Lion and the Mouse,” Aesop’s Fables, illustrating that the least may help the greatest; see 38:267JWC to LLA, [22 Nov. 1862]. was meant to encourage people so situated
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [19 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:526–27; Hansons, NE 509–10 inc; Ashton 427–28 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: You have seen children building card-houses; as eagerly as if it were houses to live in? and you have seen, at some push against the table, the Houses become a shower of cards? With just such an absurd suddenness and completeness, did your letter yesterday morning sweep down the schemes of travel, which Mr C and his Doctor-Brother had been building up and hithering and thithering amongst, for the two preceding days—to say nothing of my own separate schemes (the fullest liberty to dispose of myself, in Mr C’s projected absence, having been accorded me, in the offer of “a draft to any amount you choose to specify“)!

We were sitting at breakfast, which, to judge from the look of the table, consisted mainly of pocket maps and Bradshaws,Bradshaw’s Monthly General Railway and Steam Navigation Guide. with a supply of which my Brother in law always surrounds himself; and for the twentieth time Dr C had just urged on Mr C that, “say what he liked, to sail to Jersey would be the most feasable thing, or to—Denmark!“John A. Carlyle had recently learned Danish; see TC to JAC, 29 April. and Mr C had just detailed the superior advantage of “taking a look at Orkney and Shetland” —or “perhaps better, after all, sail to Plymouth, and go on by land to Froude’s;Froude was renting a house near Salcombe on the S Devon coast; see TC to JAC, 9 July. tho’ it would be a nicer thing a cruise round—the Western Isles!!!” the only point of agreement between them being that they should start for somewhere tomorrow;—when your letter was brought in, which, when I had read it in silence, I handed to Mr C, who, having read the first page, said quite simply, “Oh! that is all right! we are going to the Grange Sir.” “And you won’t sail anywhere?” “Certainly not! I tell you we are going to The Grange“! I could
hardly help laughing, as the Dr swept together, in an indignant manner, his aids to locomotion!

“And will you afterwards go to Blickling on the 10th?” I asked. “Certainly not! how am I to leave my work again on the tenth?“— “Then what am I to say to Lady Lothian?—you promised, you know! and I must answer her letter today” “Say?—Oh!—just say every thing that is most courteous!! only making it perfectly clear that we are not coming“!!

A pretty difficult problem, that combination! And I had to tell, we were going to the Grange! And the Lady had politely written to me that if the tenth did not suit us we might choose our own time earlier!— I spent a whole hour in poising and wriggling over the note to her! and felt ashamed of it when written!

For the rest, the important rest; we will come on Monday, if we hear nothing to the contrary. And I am sure Mr C means to be very good, and not excite Lord Ashburton with too much or too loud talk, or in any other way! And if he do, in spite of his intentions; I will take him away on the instant; and I will take your orders in every particular.

Oh dear! how glad I am to be going to the Grange again after all! At one time I felt to hate the dear old place in spite of all the good days I had spent at it, and all the kindness I had received there! You know when that time was!JWC probably refers to Lord Ashburton’s recent illness at The Grange, rather than her earlier distress when TC was overly devoted to Harriet, the previous Lady Ashburton.
My fond remembrance to Baby. I wonder will she know us again?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Aug. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Alresford, 26 Aug. 1863. MS: NLS 526.8. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on “The Grange” headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: We got beautifully down hither on Monday; carriage all to ourselves, train steady and deliberate, punctual to its time,—conveyance waiting, and all else as we cd have wished it. I rode my little horseTC apparently took his horse, Noggs, with him; see TC to Lady ALLA, 20 Sept. pensively along, full of many thots; Jane, on wheels, was several miles ahead. Ld Ashburton and Lady were out in the woods; and did not appear for 2 hours after; the evg being so beautiful they had lingered out in the woods; whh was rather detrimental to him, and has kept him rather below par ever since.

There is nobody here at all, except a widow sister-in-law of the Lady’s;Mary Anstruther. last night Dr Quain, who comes weekly, was here, also Venables for one night: they both went this morning; and now we are solitude’s self again; I hardly ever in my life had so quiet a lodging as this room. The profound and perfect silence is infinitely pleasing to my poor nerves, for the time being; nothing can be hospitabler and sincerer than the treatment we get:—and, in effect, I am actually at something of the approximate nature of Work (poor “work,” it must be owned!) both today and yesterday; and practically think I shall be able to get on very tolerably, and realise benefit and a better rustication than cd have been hoped. It was settled, and began to be put in practice this morning, that I breakfast by myself at 9 precise, then to work and do not shew face till 2, or even ½ past 3 (if I decline lunchn):—in short, I have a fair chance; and all is going right. This I tell you as what will be a bit of good news to you; and thankful I am to think I have still some left in this world to whom it is worth while to tell it.

I wd have written yesterday, and intended to do so, “at 5 on getting home from my ride“: with that thot I went out, on a fine swift horse of Ld A’s, which carried me beautifully a good distance; but, alas, there came very soon to be showers; and then when I concluded all was over there came a terrible lengthy most noisy and furious storm of thunder, rain in torrents, hail in ditto, with raging explosions & a great deal of lightning; and—I rather, or the horse and I together, lost my road home; did not get to the stable till all was over; and in a word have not had such a ride for 7 years, and hardly ever such a wetting in my life! I stript instantly &c &c, and it did me no ill at all. Today I had a small snatch of walking abt breakfast time; intending another ride at 3. But at 1 the sky darkened again, and rain has been diligently going on ever since: I thot it wd fair abt 6; but it does not;—so I have my strong shoes ready; and intend to be out in a few minutes taliter qualiter [one way or another]. I have nothing more to do; my dinner too I have mainly eaten my dinner at 2 (and have even had “tea,” but shall have to make a fashion of dining agn towards 9,—that is a scheme I am trying); I can affor[d]Letter omitted. to have my trousers damped (changing whenever I come in), and with tobacco there is no danger of damp. Enough of me & my outlooks.

I hope you will still find Chelsea habitable for some time; and be able to turn the empty house to some advantage. I was very sorry to leave you that day, witht much hope of finding you at my return: but perhaps next year—who knows? Let us thank God for all his goodness to us, and still have hope.

Wenckstern’s PamphletProbably Otto von Wenckstern, Prussian Complications (1863); see TC to JAC, [30 Aug.]. wd be welcome here; will you set Jones on getting
it;John A. Carlyle sent the request to John Edward Jones at the London Lib., who replied, 27 Aug.: “Mr Farie, who is now in the country, gave me the name of Mann of Cornhill as the publishers of the pamphlet on Prussia—Mann says he knows of no other than the one called ‘Prussia and the Poles.’ Shall I send this to Mr T. Carlyle or not?” (MS: NLS 1775 B.259). John Carlyle wrote on the back of Jones’s letter, 28 Aug.: “This note has come from Jones with the Pamphlet ‘Prussia & the Poles’ tonight, which seems likely after all to be the one you want, for Mann told me also that it was the only one he had published about Prussia. … It belongs to the library and you can return it when you please.” Mann Nephews, publishers and booksellers, 39 Cornhill. the post for one penny will convey it when found. I have also exhausted my Bramah Pencil abt an hour ago; and have not another lead: “M“Presumably a “propelling pencil,” first patented in 1822 by Sampson Mordan (1790–1881), previously an apprentice of Joseph Bramah (1749–1814; ODNB); “M” for medium refers to the hardness of the lead. Mordan also produced a combination propelling or mechanical pencil with a Bramah pen nib at the other end. is the Letter.

Be sure you take care of yrself; and have all the MacmillanAlexander Macmillan (1818–96; ODNB), publisher, apparently discussed with John A. Carlyle the possibility of his editing a new edition of The Bruce (written by 1375) by John Barbour (ca. 1330–1395; ODNB), ecclesiastic and poet. Since the great success of F. T. Palgrave, Golden Treasury of the Best Songs and Lyrical Poems in the English Language (1861), Macmillan hoped to commission more anthologies in a Golden Treasury series. John wrote, 26 Aug.: “Yesterday I went to the London Library to see the different editions of Barbour. I found that The Bruce cannot be much modernised in text, or helped except by making the spelling uniform throughout, & placing accents here & there for the pronunciation. Barbour would then be fully easier to read than Chaucer, I think, if proper rules & glossary were given for reading it. Today I mean to see M’Millan, & tell him that I must have further time for consideration ere I can undertake the editorship even of Barbour alone. I shall also hear what plans he has for it & the other Scotch Poems he wishes to republish.” John wrote again, 27 Aug.: “Macmillan altogether vague about the series of Scotch Poems he intends to publish; & so the matter is to stand undecided till he gets more information on the subject.” Macmillan did not publish any collection of Scottish poems until Mary Carlyle Aitken’s Scottish Songs (1874). thing settled before going.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [30 Aug]. MS: NLS 517.55. Hitherto unpbd. Written on “The Grange” headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: The Grange / Alresford Sunday [30 August 1863] 6 p.m.
