docBody.p: I am just returned from a long walk, longer than my choice wd have been; and doubt I have hardly a minute of time now available for post!—

I got all your three Notes,—the first two together; the last unit this morning. Thanks for the pains you take:—I hope you still won’t go on Tuesday!John A. Carlyle replied, 31 Aug.: “Thanks for your kind note of last night. … I have gone too far to recede, & so I must start tomorrow morning, Let us hope that we may soon meet again, though there is no immediate prospect of meeting. I feel rather melancholy here in the solitude & with the new servants, & have nothing more to do in London.” He wrote again later in the day: “I start tomorrow at 11.20 a.m. & expect to get to Northwich a little before 5 p.m. … then go on to Bury to stay over Friday. I also have an invitation to York from a Lady … whom I knew long ago in Italy; but I have not decidedly accepted it, for I rather feel afraid of going into strange houses. So I may perhaps go on to Dumfries by some of the Saturday trains, & get done with moving for a time. Had I felt sure of your returning to Chelsea within any reasonable time I might have waited, as I have plenty to do with my Icelandic &c. But it is clearly necessary for you to get as much of the country air & quiet as possible after your long struggles; & there must be something to strengthen you in the very presence of such kind & good people as you are with.“— This Wen[c]kstern Pamphlet is still not the right one! The right one treats of the Kg of Pra’s quarrel with his Parliamt;Otto von Wenckstern’s Prussian Complications (1863) concerned the problems that William I (1797–1888), king of Prussia 1861–88, currently had with his parliament, and “the origin of the complication which has brought Prussia to a dead lock” (Wenckstern 4). and has nothing to do with Poles. It is indisputably to be had in London: but unless Jones will make a new attempt, determining to succeed, don’t you mind it farther.John A. Carlyle wrote, 31 Aug.: “I have seen Jones … & told him about the Pamphlet, but he has no hopes of getting it till he gets the title from Farie as well as the name of the Publisher. Pamphlets are generally published at expense of their authors, & so publishers care little for them unless there is a great sale.“

We are doing quite tolerably here: I remain strictly perdue [hidden] till 2 o’clock: abt 4 hours of what might be work, and alas, is not completely. At 3½ —5½ , I get (on weekdays) an excellt ride; dinner at 8 or 9 p.m. I try to convert into a very tolerable form of supper: I am in bed at midnight; and generally have a fair bit of sleep. We have a silence such as cannot be surpassed; and everybody is as good as gold!— I will write no more at present, for good reasons. There will come some kind of word or symbol on Tuesday morning; hoping still to find you, and not with a hackney Cab waiting.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: John also reported in his second 31 Aug. letter: “Tom Wilson called here last Friday evening [28 Aug.] & sat for an hour or two. He & his wife were to start for Weimar by the Sunday Steamer to Antwerp; & they expect to be back in about a fortnight. He had got the license he wanted from the Bishop of London, mainly he thought thro’ your note to Canon Stanley; but is uncertain whether he will remain in London or go back to Weimar to settle there.” Thomas Wilson and his wife; Archibald Campbell Tait (1811–82; ODNB), bishop of London, 1856–68; Canon Arthur Penryn Stanley (1815–81; ODNB); see 30:52TC to GCR, 20 Aug. 1855, and 35:20937:biographical notes.

ps.p: Here is steady rain begun; poor Miss Bromley and I got in with little damage from the beginnings of it.— — I found in my pencil itself a lead, whh has been a treasure to me!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JEJ, 31 Aug. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Written on “The Grange” headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO J. E. JONES

docBody.p: Will Mr Jones be so kind to me as look after the enclosed indication at Nutt’s; and send me the BookDavid Nutt (1810–63), bookseller specializing in foreign books, 270 Strand; see 17:197TC to KAVE, 4 Dec. 1843. Book unidentified. hither by Post. Perhaps the Ln Library ought to be proprietor of such a Book; but in the other case, I want to see it, & will gladly give the price for it.

Note farther, The Wenkstern Pamphlet sent me is well worth having; but is still not the one I wanted. That Letter treats, not of Prussia and the Poles, but of the King of Pra’s Quarrel with his Parliament, and I think is a more recent performance. It most certainly exists, published by somebody in London; for I read it within the last month: if Mr Jones could procure me a Copy, and send it with the other Book, it wd be very obliging. I expect to be home within a fortnight, and will settle accts.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: To Mr Jones, / London Library

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 8 Sept. MS: NLS 517.56. Hitherto unpbd. Written on “The Grange” headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Sister,—I will not disappoint myself this day again, but actually write you a little word of news from my rustication, instead of mere intending and ever anew intending to do it. Strange how one’s day is condemned even here; just as in Chelsea, always filled with one poor demand or another! Indeed you are to understand that I am “working” here (what is called working, tho’ alas too flatteringly); and that I do continue absolutely private till 2 p.m. every day; & by dint of great exertion and care continual, save to myself some 4 clear hours out of the 24,—tho’, alas, in the foreign element, the “work” got done is of course still more feckless than in my own garret, where it is bad enough for most part.

We are a very small party; no stranger here but one pleasant Lady of our
acquaintance,Presumably Caroline Davenport Bromley. and ourselves two: Lord A. keeps mainly in his own room; comes out for abt 2 hours in the evg (when I am set to read,—from vol IV of Friedrich, in late times): I generally go in and pay him a little visit between 2 and 3 in the afternoon before going out to ride. He is very weak, hardly able to walk at all, but is wonderfully cheerful, & seems to have some fund of vitality whh is really singular: the DoctorDr. Quain. who attends is confident of good results if care be taken. Jane has set them upon a scheme of her Father’s (a “spring-deal,” long plank upon whh the Patient is seated in a chair, and gently shaken for a couple of hours,See Carlyle, Reminiscences 120–21. Closing parenthesis omitted. when the weather does not permit out-of-doors driving.— To us everybody is extreme in kindness; not too little of it, but, if there be a fault, too much.

The best circumstance for me is that I get a beautiful and swift ride every afternoon; abt 2 hours of it or more, thro’ green lanes, green downs, in quiet pleasant places; a great contrast to the roaring jumble of London & its stony thoroughfares. I sleep rather well;—and I wish poor Jane did so too; but she does not seem to reap any profit in the health way, as I am pretty confidt I do.— We think of setting off for home next Monday: 3 weeks good; the very interruption to old ways for so long will have a tendency to benefit.

John staid in Chelsea only a week behind us. I was very sorry to leave him; sorry to hear that he was gone. He wrote from Cheshire or thereabts more than once; I did send a Newspaper; but he is now gone somewhere abt York, & I do not know the Address. He expected to be back with you very shortly; perhaps is there by this time? A word from him, or from you (if I had any right to ask such a thing) wd agn be welcome. To Chelsea, if after Saturday. God bless you, dear Sister. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 10 Sept. MS: NLS 553.252. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:527; Hansons, NE 509. Written on “The Grange” headed notepaper; “Hants.” added by TC.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
I hope you have got safe home agn; and that you feel improved by your Appenzell regimen. We too have been on a kind of regimen, or new regulation of life, tho’ not like that of Gais:Gais, town where Neuberg stayed in Canton Appenzell, Switzerland, attempting to improve his health; for the regime, see 37:214TC to JN, 17 Aug. 1861, and 37:11937:biographical notes. Neuberg’s letter of 10 Sept., announcing his safe return, crossed with TC’s.—we got out hither Monday gone a week
(nobody to be here but ourselves), and expect to return on Monday next, after 3 weeks of beautiful green solitude,—attended with a great deal of brisk riding, on my part, tho’ the weather has been rainy and at times even thundery. But there have always been bright intervals; and the silence itself has been something quasi-divine to me, after such a dose of uproars.

I have almost daily tried a little working, too; but cannot boast to have made much of that. What makes me write today is to give you warning that the Uncopied Ms. whh I wanted, and want earnestly to see soon copied, is lying all in a state for being started with in case I had heard of you before this: Copier’s Address,Mr. Bishop; see TC to JN, [20 Oct.] (both letters of that date); unidentified further. &c &c everything is lying wrapt in a Parcel to yr Address; but it is, of course, useless to stir in that or anything cognate till after Monday Evg at soonest.
I want several things, I mean the disinterment of sevl things, from the Catacombs of distracted Preuss;—e.g. these three:

1°. That story of the Parson admitted to break Frh’s rest when he was expecting news of some vital mility operatn in the distance.TC asked Neuberg previously to find this anecdote; see 36:62TC to JN, [7 Feb. 1860]; presumably untraced as it did not appear in Frederick.

2°. That of the Princess (of Brunsk, I think, or Ex-Princess Royal), who gave the Customhouse Intruder a box on the ear, instead of paymt for her silks.Frederick the Great’s niece Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Lüneburg (1746–1840) m., 1765, Frederick’s nephew Frederick William (1744–97), king of Prussia 1786–97; the marriage was unhappy and was dissolved 1769. For the anecdote, see Carlyle, Works 19:32–33.

3° The incidt of Frh’s ordering his Page, in a street crowd assembled to read some Placard agt him, “The thing is far too high; bring it down to a level with the people’s eyesight!“See Carlyle, Works 19:30. Not one of these can I extort from that chaotic blockhead, tho’ I have had them 3 or 4 times before now.

In fact, this last portion of my Task, with Larkin and everybody falling away, and my own poor strength on the edge of doing the like, is generally horrible and frightful to me;—and I very much need a shove from one who has never yet wearied of helping me. On Monday evg (not likely!)—or the sooner after it, the better. After Saty evg, no Letter hither!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JB [JBUL], [13 Sept.]. Addr: Letter Carrier for Cheyne Row / Chelsea / Brompton Post Office / London. PM: Alresford, 13 Sept. 1863. MS: NLS 1797.84. Hitherto unpbd. John Bullock (1815–90) from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier; he was the successor to John Piper (34:biographical notes) as the Carlyles’ postman about 1858; see JWC to CSO, [19 Aug. 1858].
div3.head: JWC TO MR. BULLOCK

docBody.p: Please Mr Bullock send no more letters for either Mr Carlyle or me to the above address.
We shall be at Cheyne Row tomorrow evening. J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Sept. MS: NLS 517.57. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have got yr Letter, this morning; two of Jean’s in succession; for whh, as for yours of this day and of former days, my thanks to the respective Authors. I followed you, with at least a newspaper, to the last distinct address on your progress northward; after that I had to wait till your anchorage at Dumfries, where I am glad to find you arrived, and hope you may rest yrself a while. The Notes you sent to The Grange were abundantly welcome; that written in pencil from the Euston-square Station was quite interesting: I read the “Think and Smoke Tobacco“John A. Carlyle wrote from Euston Station, [1 Sept.]: “I send you the ‘meditation’ as my memory gives it,” writing out verses 1–3 and 5 of the “Song on Tobacco“: “This Indian weed, now withered quite, / Though green at morn, and dour at night, / Shews thy decay: / All flesh is hay. / Thus think & smoke tobacco. // The pipe, so lily-like & weak, / Does thro’ thy mortal state bespeak; / Thou art even such, / Gone with a touch / Thus think & smoke tobacco. // And when the smoke ascends on high, / Then thou beholdest the vanity / Of earthly stuff / Gone with a puff / Thus think & smoke tobacco. // And next the ashes cast away / Then to thyself thou mayest say / That to the dust / Return thou must / Thus think & smoke tobacco.“ (as given there, with only one verse wanting, whh I happened to remember complete)Verse 4 was “And when the pipe grows foul within, / Think on thy soul defil’d with sin; / For then the fire / It does require. / Thus think, and smoke tobacco.“ to a select audiencePresumably JWC and Lord and Lady Ashburton. that night; who were well content with it. It is indeed a most gentle wise and genial old thing. You have now sent me a Pen-and-ink Copy, too; whh I intend to try if I can keep. Cd not you send it to Notes & QueriesThere was a substantial correspondence about “Song on Tobacco” in Notes and Queries in 1856 (Notes and Queries, 2d series, [9 Feb.] 6:115; [1 March] 9:182; [29 March] 13:258–60; [19 April] 16:320; [10 May] 19:378). Many varied theories were put forward as to its origins, and alternate wordings given. The version given by John Carlyle is closest to the one given by Ralph Erskine (1686–1752; ODNB), minister and poet, entitled “Smoking Spiritualized,” in Gospel Sonnets; or Spiritual Songs, 9th edn. (Glasgow 1760) xxii—xxiv, where he calls it “an old Meditation upon smoking Tobacco.” The poem’s first recorded appearance was in Thomas Jenner’s collection, The Soules Solace, or Thirtie and One Spirituall Emblems (1626); as each stanza ended “Thus thinke, then drinke Tobacco,” the poem was followed by a riposte: “answered by G.W. thus / Thus thinke, drink no Tobacco.” G.W. is presumed to be George Wither (1588–1667; ODNB), poet and satirist; some attributed the poem to Wither, although it is untraced in his published works. (or Chorley would, if I had time to tell him); and then learn who the Author was?—

We got home on Monday night; all right,—except that yr room was empty, and instead of “The Doctor” in my peculiar garret there was nothing but a very nice old pair of Surgeon’s Scissors said to be his:—tell me if I can send them by post or how. And, à propos of sending, please tell Jean to do as she says with the clart of cranberries; nothing else is feasible: and not to bother abt sending them unless a chance occur.

For the last 3 or 4 days I had quite given up “working” as I was pleased to call it; and employed myself in lounging abt the woody solitudes, and sauntering up and down on horseback or afoot, whh I supposed might be at least a not more imaginary investment of time than the other! I know not whether I am anything improved in health or not: but at least it is a break; and I suppose will prove to have been a rest, or the nearest we cd come to that. Lord A. is as weak as water for any muscular exertion; but he has a great deal of vitality in various other forms; perfectly alert in mind for one thing: his Doctors shd hope well of him. Christison, I rather think, will come back thro’ the winter. Jane (and the Farm carpenter) mounted up a beautiful “Spring Deal” (plank 20 feet long, resting on cylinders, with a chair fixed on it; has a motion soft as air,—and old contrivance of her father’s) for the sick man: we all trust The Grange may prove a far better lodging thro’ this winter than Paris, on failure of Nice, did last!The Ashburtons were on their way to Nice when Lord Ashburton fell ill, and they remained in Paris.—

I have been trying hard to begin in earnest agn: but am sweer; oh nobody can say how sweer, how utterly done out and lazy! I shall be happier & livelier, when I do get into the journey pace agn, & warm my old spavined bones! Good night, dear Brother: love to everybody yonder. Yours ever T. C.

bibl.person: MATILDA AND SARAH SUTHERLAND AND LIZZIE THOMAS

div3.sourceNote: TC-MS, SS, and LT [MSSLT], 16 Sept. MS: Fales Collection, Bobst Lib., New York Univ. Hitherto unpbd. Matilda Mary Sutherland (b. 1841, in London) and Sarah Sutherland (b. 1845, in Madras, E. India), 5 Grosvenor Pl., Bath, das. of Robert (b. 1801, in Scotland) and Maria (b. ca. 1816, in E. India); and their cousin Eliza (Lizzie) Thomas (b. 1842, in Madras), da. of William and Catherine Thomas; presumably children of friends or family connections of the Ashburtons; see JWC to LLA, 19 Sept.
div3.head: TC TO MATILDA SUTHERLAND, AND SARAH SUTHERLAND AND LIZZIE THOMAS

docBody.p: Oh you mischievous little gypsies (or cherubs),They asked TC to sign their books (probably autograph), either in a letter or through the Ashburtons, replying jointly to TC’s letter, 16 Sept.: “Can you understand Excitement? If so, you will understand how, when your letter appeared this morning, we mentally revolted against the purgatorial propriety of a breakfast table & wished the envelope wd be transformed to our eyes, at least. // And when we opened it or rather read your words, how shall we describe our feelings? Joy, gratitude and love filled our hearts, & we knew not whether to admire most the true kindliness of heart which dictated those words, or the indomitable Fun which blinked through them, telling us to what an extent you also patronize Mischief! … How to thank you enough, we know not, & what not to say, puzzles us equally, so where our plea fails, let yr imagination supply the deficiency (if you can!) We think it so very kind of you to humour us; & sincerely wish we could see you, if it were possible after the fashion of fairies & other invisibilities— // ‘Thank you’ is little to say, & to little minds means but little; but, simple as it is, to your great mind & great heart we know it will say what we wish.“—particularly you Miss Sally, who are ring-leader!Lizzie (who signed the letter second) admitted that she rather than Sarah was the “ring-leader“: “One thing truth induces us to say viz that your usual penetration has failed to discover the true ringleader which is Gypsy No. 2. Bold enough to dictate a letter, too shy to write it, she is at last forced, most reluctantly, to confession.“—

Send me your bits of Books, however; and I will write some word on them,TC wrote the verse “Simon Brodie Had a Cow” (see 26:174JWC to TC, [14 Sept. 1851]) in Lizzie’s book; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 19 Sept. now that I have returned home.

ps.p: Chelsea, 16 Septr 1863

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [16 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 17 Sept. 1863. MS: NLS 608.617. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:172–74 inc.; Simpsons 257–58 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row—Chelsea Wednesday night (16 Septr 1863)Date added by TC.
docBody.p:
How absurd of you, my dearest Mary, to make so many apologies about a trifling request like that! Why; if you had asked for twenty autographs; Mr C
could have written them in twenty minutes, and would have written them for you with pleasure. Certainly, my Dear, as I have often said before, faith is not your strong point!

Well, we have done our “outing” (as the people here call going into the country); and it is all the “outing” we are likely to do till next summer (if we live to see next summer) unless Lord Ashburton should be well enough, and myself well enough to make another expedition to The Grange during the Winter. I had some idea of going to Folkstone, where Miss Davenport Bromley has a house at present, and pressed me to come and take some tepid seawater baths—but my experience of the wretchedness of being from home, with this devilry in my arm, has decided me to remain stationary, for the present. In spite of the fine air and beauty of The Grange, and Lady Ashburtons superhuman kindness, I had no enjoyment of anything, all the three weeks we staid; being in constant pain, day and night; and not able to comb my own hair, or do anything in which a left arm is needed as well as a right one! I think I told you I had had pain more or less in my left arm for two months before I left London. It was trifling in the beginning; indeed nothing to speak of, when I did not move it backwards or upwards. I did not think it worth sending for Mr Barnes about at first, and latterly, he was away at the seaside for some weeks, having been ill himself. There was nobody else I liked to consult. Besides I always flatter myself that anything that ails me more than usual is sure to be removed by change of scene; so I bore on, in hope that so soon as I got to The Grange the arm would come all right. It did quite the reverse however, for it became worse and worse, and I was driven at last to consult Dr Quain, when he came down to see Lord A. He told me, before I had spoken a dozen words, that it wasn’t rheumatism I had got but neuralgia (if any good Christian would explain to me the difference between these two things I should feel edified and grateful!) It had been produced he said by extreme weakness; and that I must be stronger before any impression could be made on it. Could I take quinine? I didn’t know—I would try—so he sent me quinine pills from London to be taken twice a day if they gave me no headache, which they dont do—and an embrocation of opium, aconite, camphor, and chloroform (I tell you all this that you may ask your Dr if he thinks it right, or can suggest anything else) moreover, I was to take castor oil every two or three days. I have been following these directions for a fortnight; and there is certainly an improvement in my general health. I feel less cowardly and less fanciful, and feel less disgust at human food; but tho’ the embrocation relieves the pain while I am applying it and for a few minutes after, it is as stiff and painful as ever when left to itself. For the rest; Dr C tired of his solitude after ten days, and left my maids free to clean the house from top to bottom, which they have done very effectually. They seem to have conducted themselves well in every way. Their expenses after they were left alone were
so modest, that I presented them with five shillings each, in token of my approbation. That reminds me of Maria and the horrid mooncalve,Maria Chamberlayne and Elizabeth; see JWC to MR, [10 Dec. 1862]. who lived at rack and mangerProverbial; to live well at another’s expense. while I was away last year! Maria is still with her MotherAnn Chamberlayne, servant at The Grange; see 38:26JWC to ACH, [25 Dec. 1861]. some eight miles from the Grange, and, hearing I was there, She and her Mother came over to see me. A very different looking girl she was from what I last saw her. Modest and penitent and very thin! She could hardly get out a word all the time she stayed but cried and sobbed continuosly. The Mother asked if my present servants suited! and then; if I knew of a place for Maria? She would have liked to come back: but catch me ever undertaking to manage that temper again—even if I were not “suited“!

I have forgotten in two letters to tell you about Mary Milligan.Mary Milligan (1811–64) was a servant of JWC’s mother; she left when she m., 1841, Charles McKie (1801–47) of Newhall Farm, Keir, Dumfriesshire (see 13:307–8JWC to IC, 24 Nov. 1841); the last recorded mention of her was after her husband’s death (see 22:267JWC to MR, 7 March [1848]). TC noted later on MS: “Mary Millign, once her Mother’s old servt (suprà), even now widow of that ‘Farmer Charles.’“ I was greatly startled some two months ago to receive a letter from her; and greatly moved by it, for I took it as an indication that she was on the point of going mad again. She seems to fall to thinking about us when her mind is giving way. I answered her letter kindly, giving the promise she asked for, and I sent her a bad photograph which she says is liker you than me. I could not write without telling her that I had felt to hate her for the vexation she had caused my Mother, the photograph was to soften down that truth. She wrote again. I think I have the letters and will inclose them. But dont say anything about it in case of its coming to her ears, poor soul, that I had shown her letters to me. Tell me if she be again ill?
And now I am tired! and good night! and god bless you. Love to the Dr
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: I find the Marchioness of Lothians last note beside Mary Milligan’s. I send it too that you may see how goodnatured she is about our absurd behaviour! Poor soul she has a sad time between a paralysed young Husband on one hand and on the other an insane Mother (Lady Shrewsbury)Sarah Elizabeth, b. Beresford (1807–84), m., 1828, Henry John Chetwynd-Talbot (1803–68), 18th earl of Shrewsbury. whom she keeps almost constantly in the house with her—in a state of melancholy mania.TC noted later on MS: “Middle of July 1863, Ld Ashburton, almost a miracle to us, got home from Paris; ‘24 augt–14 Septr’ we were at The Grange, —surely not our last visit there; and yet when was the other (while I sat alone till 3 p.m. always; had huge maps of Poland &c and Her neuralgia was fatally beginning)? Sad mornings, when I went to her room the first thing, and found her so ill, lame of right arm, looking broken & dispirited as never before! Days sad altogethr and solitary, but quiet and busy. Ld A weak of body, but clear and good tho’ heavy-laden. Two out-of-door Photoghs still here belong to this time. Were there two visits or only one. Ld A died, ‘4 March 1864’ she gone to St. Leonard’s then ‘Dr C.’ my Brr whom we had left here. … 16 Septr 1863.” TC probably refers to the photographs taken at their previous visit to The Grange, Oct. 1862, by Robert Vernon Heath ca. (1819–95; ODNB); see 38:248–49JWC to EFO, 30 Oct. 1862.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 18 Sept. MS: NLS 526.9 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This Letter,Chorley wrote, 17 Sept.: “One word of a matter which nearly concerns me:—the release of my sister:—today, in the gentlest manner, after a seizure, like paralysis, of a few days only, without apparent pain. … For the mode of deliverance quite as much for the relief itself, I am, with reason, grateful.“ whh came last night, will affect youChorley asked TC to tell John A. Carlyle “that his sometime patient has been freed from a long burden at last.“ as it does me: poor Miss ChorleyMary Ann (Phoebe) (ca. 1801–63) had been paralyzed since about 1850; see 9:328TC to MAC, 9 Oct. 1837. She had lived with her brother at 76 Chester Sq. since 1845; see 19:135TC to JWC, [Aug. 1845]. She d. 17 Sept. (Times, 19 Sept.). now at last gone to her rest; a weary load of misery shaken off, and a kindly innocent fellow soul no more to be fellow pilgrim with us in this world!—

I am trying strenuously to force some real beginning from myself today, the want of [words missing]Words missing, here and elsewhere because the signature was cut away. miserable: but [words missing] nor small! [words missing] am like to have.— I went cantering yesterday over Wimbledon Common; day before by the Regent’s Park; my horse is lively, not disloyal, but has nothing of the friendship for me whh the otherFritz. evidently had. I have changed my ridingtime to 3 p.m., dinner at 6 or later: It is now near 12,—and nothing done but more interruptns staved aside! Judge if I shd not be bestirring myself.
With best regards to Jean and everybody; hoping to hear that you are at anchor in not bad c[ircumstances?]; [remainder of letter missing]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 19 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am so glad, dearest Lady, that you have told Mrs BadgerUnidentified further. to come down to you! Your own Instinct is the only safe thing to go by, in choosing a servant to be about your own person—especially in the present state of things with you! when to be loved, and cared for, and humanly waited on, is so much more important than to be “turned out” the pink of fashion and adornment! I defy any Ladysmaid to make you look other than well dressed! but any Lady’s maid, wanting in tact and human feelings may make you feel uncomfortable; —in these anxious times, when, even had your nature been less real than it is, the stern realities of your Life must have swallowed up vain shows!

Pray let me know your decision about her; as if she does not please you I would ask Elise.Mme. Elise Delepine, milliner and dressmaker. She apparently also ran an agency for “Lady’s maids“; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [21 Sept.].

I thank God for Lord A’s ammendment! Decidedly Quain is very clever—very prompt and dexterous! also—he writes remarkably pretty and ingenious notes! The one he sent me about the Books was as good as a Poem!— When I was calling for Lady William Russell yesterday, who is too poorly to move to Walmer CastleWalmer Castle, nr. Dover, Kent; originally built as a coastal fortification, it later became the official residence of the lord warden of the Cinque Ports; the post was occupied by Lord Palmerston 1861–66. as she had intended; she talked of Dr Quain as “the most rising” medical man in London.” She was always, she said, hearing of cases “where he had at once hit the nail on the head, when other Drs were puzzling to find it.“— It always does one good to visit Lady William! She has such an unsurpassable gift of flattery! However Cinderellaish may be my opinion of myself in entering her room; I always come away thinking myself “one and somewhat“!Coterie speech; see 6:81JWC to MWE, [27 Dec. 1831]; see also 29:x29:introduction. — Yesterday for example, I found a Colonel Percy—Probably Lord Henry Hugh Manvers Percy (1817–77; ODNB), col. in the Grenadier Guards, aide-de-camp to the queen 1855–65; otherwise unidentified. with her, whom she “begged to introduce to Mrs Carlyle—the wife of Mr Carlyle the distinguished Philosopher, and herself a very distinguished woman; altho’ she was not aware of it“! What more delicate compliment could be devised? the “although she was not aware of it” at once investing me with an admirable modesty to my own eyes! and anticipating any doubts I might naturally feel as to the fact! She must have made a first-rate ambassadress
in her time!Her husband, Lord George William Russell, held various diplomatic posts in the 1830s, including ambassador at Berlin. I saw an oil sketch of ArthurHer son Arthur, with whom she lived. just completed by the Mr LaytonProbably Frederic Leighton (1830–96; ODNB), artist; portrait untraced. who was to do the “wee Witch.“Lady Ashburton’s da., Mary; Leighton did a sketch of her but wrote to his mother shortly after Lord Ashburton’s death: “The child’s picture also goes to the wall, as she won’t be able to sit for some time, and would then be changed” (Mrs. Russell Barrington, The Life, Letters and Work of Frederic Leighton [1906] 2:123).— What came of his picture? Is itlike?— Arthur Russells is very good indeed at a distance; near, it looked to me quite distorted. Lady William asked me to tell “dear Lord Ashburton” that she had been very glad to hear of his recovery. That “sufferers like herself could best sympathize with others in suffering“— Poor Soul! She has a dreadful time! and endures so bravely!

I enclose three little letters that came this morning from the Bath “little Gipsies, or—Cherubs” (as he (Mr C) called them in his note,See TC to MS, SS, and LTMSSLT, 16 Sept. Matilda and Sarah Sutherland and Lizzie Thomas each wrote TC a letter of thanks, 18 Sept. Lizzie’s letter was the longest and most effusive: “So great is my detestation of ordinary Running-after-people, & writing Unrealities, that I scarcely trust myself to say what I do feel & mean, lest I should pain you by seeming to do both. I feel deeply sensible of the forbearance you have shewn to the wild fancy of a stranger. // Whether you intended the tale of poor Simon Brodies’s loss & over-anxiety consequent thereupon, as a friendly reproof to my impatient spirit, I know not; nevertheless such it is to me— Early sorrow has done much to restrain & train me; the Book of Books has done more; yet the longing after the never-failing ‘Charity which seeketh not her own’ that marked my childhood is only intensified in my girlhood, & when two, instead of one score of years are mine I could wish to be longing for it still. // Many are the painful Associations which a visit to Bath inevitably awakens in me, but pleasant & evergreen will be the recollection of the days when ‘we went gypsying’—the remembrance of fears raised only to be dispelled, of hopes indulged only to be fulfilled. & If there rests upon this lively peak of ours the shadow of aught unfeminine, let me ask you to cast it upon me, & not on my cousins— But why do I write thus, why trouble you so with myself? Forgive the weakness; but it is a temptation to linger where I know I am understood, & that yr kindness is no glittering icicle, which attracts only to chill— // Live on, O Man of endless Sympathy! May the sympathy of One greater than all men, be thine! & if, during thy walk through Life to Eternity, the brown dead leaves of the Path crackle mournfully under thy feet, may thine hand ever be able to pluck such flowers of the Present, while thy loving truthful Eye looks upward to the blue sky of the Future with confidence, & traces in the fair white clouds the outline of a fitter resting-place than Earth, even a ‘Temple not made with hands, eternal in the Heavens’!“ giving them leave to send “their bits of books“!) Ah! these young Enthusiasts are rather touching to me! They remind me of long long years ago when “One’s Youth was left behind, for someone else to find!“A favorite quotation of JWC’s; see 38:158–59JWC to TC, [22 Aug. 1862].

Mr C has not forgotten the Books—they will be sent by Railway on
Monday.See TC to Lady ALLA, 20 Sept. unless anybody is coming to Bath House on Monday who could take them— It will be time on Monday morning to know that.
Please tell me if the reading desk arrived safe, and is satisfactory? It not; he was to make another.
Who on Earth but your own self would have thought of bringing down Mrs Hamilton?Not further identified. You are good! And if anyone can help loving you dearly it is not I
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 20 Sept. Addr: The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: London, 21 Sept. 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Jane is about sending off tomorrow some tin case,—(whh has shed its bounties here, rusks I believe, thanked be the Giver!)—and in this there will come three little Books for his Lordship’s reading and yours: Two Highland-Rebellion Books,TC previously loaned Lady Ashburton a copy of Andrew Henderson, The History of the Rebellion, 1745 and 1746 (Edinburgh 1748); see 37:173TC to JAC, 7 June 1861. There were several other books he may have sent, including James Ray, A Compleat History of the Rebellion (York 1755); Robert Chambers, History of the Rebellion in Scotland in 1745, 1746, 2 vols. (Edinburgh 1827); Andrew Henderson, Life of William Augustus Duke of Cumberland (1766); and Historical Memoirs of … late Duke of Cumberland (1767); see 33:95TC to HL, [2 Oct.? 1857]. and Anson’s Voyage;George Anson, A Voyage to the South Seas (1745); TC recommended Anson’s book to the Ashburtons 1862, as a “Capital little Book“; see 28:257TC to JCA, 2 Sept. 1853. these are all I find here as yet; but many more are attainable. They are far from pretty to look upon, these three; but they are capable of being held in the hand;—and I hope the Highland part of them may help one another to be entertaining, if you can persist. Six more (perhaps six) of the same genus, all abt the Rebellion, Jenny Cameron,Jenny Cameron (ca. 1700—ca. 1772), supporter of Charles Edward Stuart (1720–88; 5145ODNB), the Young Pretender; TC may have sent Brief Account of the Life and Family of Miss Jenny Cameron (1746). Lords Kilmarnock-Balmerino,William Boyd (1705–46; OBNB), 4th earl of Kilmarnock, and Arthur Elphinstone (1688–1746; ODNB), 6th Lord Balmerino, Jacobite army officers; various editions of their Lives were pbd. 1746. Fraser of Lovat &c,Simon Fraser (ca. 1667–1747; ODNB), 11th Lord Lovat, Jacobite army officer; TC may have sent James Fraser, A Genuine Narrative of the Life, Behaviour, and Conduct of Simon Lord Fraser of Lovat from His Birth to His Execution (1747). are coming to you from a Northampton BooksellerUnidentified further. straightway;—of whh pray send me notice when
they come. The present three will probably arrive on Tuesday. I have to say of them, and of the Six, that they all from this hour belong to yr Ladyship (an unexpected homage to yr Highland character and merits),—and that there need at least be no trouble abt them, as to returning them &c &c, but a free enjoyment of any small use they may have.

My little Horse is still sensibly proud of having gallopped on Abbotston Down, and (I su[s]pectLetter omitted by TC.) of having lived in The Grange Stables: he is a curious little fellow; and amuses me considerably when we are both in spirits. It is not till today that I have fairly got into the old wheel-ruts again,—after all that carousing in your green woods and glades; under such environment of thots withal, from Past, from Present, Future! Very beautiful to me; very sad and strange.— I believe I shall be really better for this break in my Chelsea monotonies, whh was otherwise so interesting and gratifying to me.
Beware of the cold;—oh beware, and all will yet go right, if it please Heaven!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: The rusks are unsurpassable! I have eaten two, with hot milk; and deliberately give that verdict.— Past midnight; time to be in bed. / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [21 Sept.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have just twenty minutes to write in, between my coming in from a business drive, and the post going out! Judge if I must not condense—“hasten to the catastrophe“—or what you will!

On my way to a Frame-makerPossibly William Freston, picture frame maker, 54 Union St.; otherwise unidentified. beyond Oxford Street—to whom I was taking the three photographs you gave me (because his gilding wears better than any one else’s I know) I dropt the “empties” which I had brought from the Grange fulls, and the tin box which came on Sunday (!) filled with rusks (No day of the week, it would seem, but your bountifulness can pour itself into it! Such good rusks they are! break with crispness if one do but look at them! He began his suppers on rusks and milk last night) at Bath House. and ascertaining from Hanah that she was sending a parcel that would reach the Grange tomorrow morning, I left to her care two parcels I was meaning to
take to the Railway office, the one the books Mr C promised, with Fairey’s translation of Haxthausen,August von Haxthausen, The Russian Empire: Its People, Institutions and Resources, trans. Robert Farie, 2 vols. (1856); see 29:113TC to JAC, 6 June 1854. which is my own, and on which I have inscribed your name, as I think you should be kind enough to keep it as a creditable memorial of one of the sincerest if not the sanest of your admirers! Tied up with the Books is the bit of marble cornice from Livia’s lately excavated Villa;Livia Drusilla (58 bc–29 ad), wife of Caesar Augustus (63 bc–14 ad), emperor of Rome; excavations began summer 1863 on the villa at Prima Porta, 7 mi. (11 km.) N of Rome. for your Museum— It is perfectly authentic having been picked up on the spot (with permission) by the Lady who sent it to me.Possibly sent to JWC by Charlotte Cushman, who had a house in Rome. Also there is a little copy of Herrmann und Dorothea a lovely thing in itself, sent me by Goethe himselfJohann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749–1832), Hermann und Dorothea (1797). Goethe included this book in his parcel sent to the Carlyles, 15 Jan. 1828; see C. E. Norton, Correspondence between Goethe and Carlyle (1887) 59.—with a verse made on purpose for me (!) (it is printed with my name in his posthumous Works)JWC means a collection of Goethe’s works pbd. after his death, rather than Posthumous Works, 15 vols. (Stuttgart, 1832–34); edn. untraced. In her next sentence, JWC omitted the final “e” from Goethe. and written on the fly leaf in his own handwriting. As an autograph it is valuable Goeth[e] having written little with his own hand—merely appending his signature to what his SecretaryUnidentified; probably not Johann Peter Eckermann (1792–1854), Goethe’s friend and literary assistant; see 4:404TC to G, 25 Sept. 1828. wrote to his dictation. I wish the little Book to be kept for Baby.Mary Baring. and it is better to give it to her now, than bequeath it to her in my will!— There is still the old Spode teapot to send, but that I had no hay today to pack it with!

I called to speak to EliseMadame Elise’s business was at 170 Regent St. but she was not visible—one of her girls told me there were “no Ladys maids on the books” at present. But perhaps Madame Elise might have one “on her mind“— She would let me know— Those they often knew of were recommended by Ladies who wished to find a situation for them, that sounded well!
I “saw” a Ladys maid this morning and am to see her again tonight—till she come again there is no use entering into her particulars. Luckily! for I have not time for many more words.
We are so glad of the news of Lord Ashburton so glad!
God bless you all three! I miss that child more than I can tell! Mr C was giving such an account of her to Ballantyne!Thomas Ballantyne. last night!
there will perhaps be a letter from me about the new Lady’s maid at Alresford tomorrow afternoon—it will depend on the time of her coming tonight. I will see to the Housemaid—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: The second parcel I left at Bath house was the maps and documents about Darnleys explosion or rather blowing up for he didnt explode poor fellow!See TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1862, and TC to JAC, 26 March.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCH] , 23 [22] Sept. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. JWC misdated; letter clearly written before her fall, evening of 22 Sept.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARIA CHAMBERLAYNE

docBody.p: I will not delay answering your letter until I can “tell you that my arm is better.” For that may be a long time off—if ever! I sometimes think, this pained half-crippled arm, of now more than three months standing, is added to my Life-burden in permanency! If so; I pray God to make me patient and brave to bear it! That’s all!

I was glad of your letter—very glad, at this distance of Time and Space, as I used to be, when living in the same House together, you would, after quarrel with me, longer or shorter, valiantly shake “the Black Dog” off your Back, and “come to me and be good.”

When a Person, I have once loved and thought loved me, has turned against me in unkindness or seemed to do so; I cannot, as I see some wiser people do, just be done with that person and think no more about it! Years may pass, and still the old liking, the old disappointment and regret will turn up in my mind from time to time; with the same feeling of smart, and the same hurt to my faith in human nature! and so Maria, Dear, I am very glad that my latest remembrance of you is, that, after all, you “came to me and were good!”For the recent visit of Maria and Ann Chamberlayne to see JWC while she was staying at The Grange, see JWC to MR, [16 Sept.]. (as we say to Children!)

When you would like me to “see a Lady” for you (as the phrase is) or to answer a Lady’s letter about you; you may refer to me without apprehension. Should I hear, before yourself, of any situation likely to suit you, I shall not forget that you are wanting one. But at present, I have not in all London a single Lady of my acquaintance except Lady William Russell, too ill to go
away like all the rest and little Mrs DilberoglueFor a photograph of Sarah Dilberoglue, possibly taken around this time, see opp above . TC wrote underneath: “Mrs Dilberoglue (English, Sheffield)” (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 2, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). who is in a state [of] comfort and settledness with her servants.
Jane Welsh Carlyle to Maria Chamberlayne, 23 [22] September 1863 (detail)
Courtesy of Thomas Carlyle Papers, Duke University Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library
Sarah Dilberoglue, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
I will write again and tell you if my arm get better.
With compliments to your Mother, whom I was pleased to make acquaintance with, and best wishes for yourself and your Belongings,
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [22 Sept.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: When I wrote yesterday I was expecting a Lady’s maid who had called at ten in the morning, from the Coram Street Office,No Servants’ Registry listed in either Great Coram St. or Little Coram St.; the nearest was the Central Servants’ Home & Register Office, 51 Southampton Row, nr. Russell Sq. to return in the evening; as she had engaged to do, of her own accord. As she did not come, I infer she engaged herself elsewhere, and did not think it worth while to keep her word; tho she had insisted on coming back to tell me, whether she accepted another situation she was then going after or not.— She was not particularly prepossessing in appearance—still she was a feasable looking woman enough. and as she had been, at one time with Lady Charlotte Howard, the Sister of Lady Arabella BaringCharlotte Howard (1803–86); her sister, Arabella Georgina, b. Howard (1809–84), m., 1841, Lord Ashburton’s cousin Francis Thornhill Baring (1796–1866; ODNB), M.P. for Portsmouth 1826–65. you would have had a clue to her. But after keeping me inquiring into her for a quarter of an hour; she told me she had been recommended to a situation by a former Mistress, and was going from here to see about it; “only the Person at Coram Street had told her to come here first“! And then she volunteered to return, and tell me whether she had engaged herself or not. I told her a note by post would save her trouble; “Oh no!” she would come herself.” as she has neither come nor written, there is no use in going into her details.

Yesterday afternoon came an Upper-Housemaid from Bond Street.Household Servants’ Institution and Select Registry, 44 New Bond St. There could be no objections to this one on the score of want of weight—physical at least! I have not seen a larger woman for a long time! tall and expansive, rather hay-stackish in fact! But she had a good face,—kindly, rather sad, —
and innocent—so far as an upper Housemaid, 39 years of age, could be imagined innocent! Moreover, she is Scotch—Mary GalbraithPossibly Mary Galbraith (ca. 1824–99), b. Bervie (nr. Stonehaven), Kincardineshire; d. unm. Stonehaven. her name. She had been only six months in her last place. Gave warning because, having been used to large establis[h]ments, with a great deal of work, she did not like being with two old Ladies, who kept no company, and had so little todo— This is her account of her staying so short a time. The Ladies were two Missess Talbot of / Templeguiton / near Winchcombe / Cheltenham /Isabella Talbot (1793–1869) and her sister Jane Elizabeth Talbot (1795–1880), of Temple Guiting, Gloucestershire. JWC set out the addresses under each name. Before going to these old Ladies, she was two years with Mrs Bevan /Isabella Judith Maria, b. Loraine-Smith (ca. 1821–85), m., 1840, Richard Lee Bevan (1811–1900), member of the banking firm, Barclay, Bevan & Co.; of Brixworth Hall, Northamptonshire. of Brixworth Hall / Northamptonshire / Before that; with Mrs Saville (Mr Saville son of Lord—somebody) / Henry Savile Lumley-Savile (1820–81), illegitimate son of John Lumley-Savile (1788–1856), 8th earl of Scarborough, from whom he inherited the Rufford Abbey estates. His wife, not further identified. Rufford Abbey / Nottinghamshire / Her last place in London was with Lord Sandys /Arthur Marcus Cecil Sandys (1798–1863), 3d Baron Sandys, m. Louisa, b. Blake ca. (1822–86); they lived at 2 Chesham St., nr. Belgrave Sq. Grosvenor Square / And she was brought from Edinr to London by the Honble Mrs Broderick (or Broadrip!) “one of the Dundas family“)—Lowndes Square.Possibly Hon. Augusta Mary, b. Fremantle (1828–1903), m., 1853, William Brodrick (1830–1907); they lived at 65 Eaton Pl. (which intersects with Lowndes Pl.). Possibly a relative of Miss and Mr. Dundas, friends of Thomas Erskine; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 13 Aug.— She speaks like a sensible kindly Scotchwoman. Was plainly dressed in deep mourning (for an Aunt)Unidentified further. Mary Galbraith’s two aunts were Sarah Napier (1790–1865) and Martha Napier (1791–1879), both of Stonehaven; both d. unm. and wears no Crinoline (to be sure, few women could have less merit in abstaining from Crinoline!!). But she dislikes it on principle, “cant bear to see the young girls sweeping about amongst valuable furniture in Crinolines” I forgot to say, with reference to Mrs Bevan; that the reason she gave for leaving her was that Mrs Bevan required all the House work to be done by one o’clock; that the upper Housemaid might do needlework all the rest of the day. And was always finding fault with her, because she found this impossible, when the days were short.— She knew it was her business to keep the linen in order, but she thought the most of the needlework ought to be done during the summer, and in the evenings; and more time and daylight allowed for “dusting and such like.” Is it to be inferred from this that Mary Galbraith is slow? I asked her! but she “disowned the soft impeachment“Coterie speech; see 24:170JWC to MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849; cf. Sheridan, The Rivals 5.3. I said, I
thought her having been so short a time in her last place would be an objection, as you had a great dislike to servants with a turn for shifting about. To which she answered with great earnestness, “Well Mam i am not likely to “shift about” now if I could make the place do at all, and give satisfaction in it. And since you are Scotch Mam; I’ll just tell you why, and why I would dress plain; even if I liked fine clothes, which I don’t! My Parents died when I was a child, and two Aunts living at Stonehaven near Aberdeen (perhaps Lady Ashburton knows Stonehaven (!!)) fetched me away there, and brought me up. And the Eldest died a few weeks ago (it is for her I am wearing these blacks) and my uncleThe Napier sisters had three surviving brothers, Thomas (1793–1877), master miller; Robert (1788–1866), painter; and Walter (1797–1878), schoolmaster; a fourth brother, recently d., was Simon (1799–1862), grocer. came in to all her money; and the other sister, an old woman, is left with only fifty pounds a year. And I have settled in my own mind, to put ten pounds a year of my wages in the Bank, and dress myself out of the rest; that it may be ready for her in case of illness, or to pay for her funeral! For an own Mother couldn’t have been kinder to me than that Aunt has been!” The large woman had been gradually rising into the region of song—becoming quite Lyrical, and when she came to “in case of illness” her mouth went all quivering and tears ran down her cheeks!

“Highly impractical all this my Dear;” Mr Carlyle would say if I read the last page to him. and to be sure it proves nothing for her qualifications as Upper Housemaid—only for her likeableness as a great big scotch Mary Galbraith!— I can form no prediction as to her competency for the situation. only if she could do her work well; I think you would like the woman. 39 years old—unusually large—six months in her last place—all that is questionable!If she was Mary Galbraith from Bervie, she was apparently lying. At all events the Miss Talbots would need to give her a good character. Do you know the Mrs Brodrick (“one of the Dundas family“)? Her wages from the Miss Talbots had been sixteen pounds and everything found. From the former Mistress eighteen pounds and everything found.

IThe top 1½ ins. of the page are blank and have two small holes in them, suggesting something had been pinned to the page. see my mistake now, but not being able to make out “Fred“:In Lady Ashburton’s letter; JWC possibly refers to the husband of the Mrs. Hamilton mentioned at the end of JWC to Lady ALLA, 19 Sept.; probably not a reference to TC’s Frederick. you will see what put that absurd idea in my head! I thought you had found out, the man had a wife; and with your usual superhuman kindness had felt sorry that she had been cut out of the Holyday they might have had together and given him leave to have her there for his private delectation. Well! the mistake has given me a good laugh anyhow, which is a blessing in these Neuralgia times!

Miss Bromley sent me yesterday morning the photograph of—Spark!For Spark’s photograph, see oppabove. I cannot say that I think him a fascinating dog; nor did he shine in society on his late visit at the Grange; but as her dog I am glad to see him—on paper!
Caroline Davenport Bromley’s dog, Spark, 1863
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Mary Galbraith’s present address is / Mrs Turner’s / 3 Robert Street / Grosvenor Square. / in case you think it worth while to ask her anything. She was very anxious to know her fate soon; “living in Lodgings being such an expense.” (So they all say, but dont think of that when the whim takes them to change) I promised to write direct to herself when I had your answer I shall keep this letter open till post time, in case any Lady’s-maid appear.
afternoon
A letter from the misgiven Lady’s-Maid of yesterday. which would disgrace a third house-maid! Best that the writer of that note “engaged” elsewhere without giving more bother!

There has just been here, bringing your note to her, a Swiss Lady’s-Maid, called Mary Guignard.Possibly Marie Julie Guignard (b. 1818), Marie Louise Guignard (b. 1824), or Marie Zelie Guignard (b. 1830). She has been in England ten or eleven years, speaks good English, is six feet high! has good written characters to show from several Ladies she has lived with—two years—three years—eighteen months. — her last situation she left in six-months, “it was impossible, tho’ they gave higher wages than she had ever had, to stay in such a House! such quarrelling day and night, and drinking!” It was with Mr Bingham who was a nice gentleman himself, but had married strangely.“Both unidentified further. If you don’t mind being towered over by a Giantess, you had better see this woman. She much wishes for a personal interview. Her recommendations are very high—if authentic (one never feels to trust implicitely in written characters). Tho’ so large she is not unpleasant looking. It is a strong, shrewd, essentially goodnatured face, tho’ with a superficial hardness in it. At least that is how she strikes me! She was wearing some Lady’s cast off dress which tho black was not in the best taste—for the streets! But, on the whole, I doubt if you will find, except thro’ private recommendation, a person more promising than this Swiss Giantess!— Lord A saw her (“two years ago“; I think she said two or three was it?). She was “looked at by him at Bath House and asked a great many questions,” and he told her to come back the following week when you would be there; (so he must have considered her not impossible) but before next week she had accepted another situation— Does he remember a tall swiss woman? What a pity but you could come up, and see both the large women, and any others
recommended all at once! They could come here to you. and I could give you some dinner—out of the chill, and muddle at Bath House, which is “all upset” Hanah said yesterday, by the Photographers “and, worst of all Mr Hal?“Unidentified further. (some name I forget.“)—when the gate was opened a little, I saw a photograph Apparatus and a Statue! and a good deal of what Hanah calls “mess“

The Swiss said she had been recommended to you at first, by Mr Dewsbury;Presumably Thomas Dousbery (b. 1805), sec. of the New Bond St. Servants’ Office. and that you took no notice for ten days; and meanwhile she was living at a French Lodging House in Knightsbridge, at considerable expence; and she could not keep herself disengaged beyond a few days—if an opportunity of a situation offered.

Do you know anything of Mrs Watson Taylor?Possibly Hannah Charlotte, b. Hay (d. 1887), m., 1843, Simon Watson-Taylor (d. 1902), of Erlestoke Park, Wiltshire. There is a highly appreciative letter from her in the Woman’s budgetI.e., the woman’s collection of references in her bag.—she has with her three years. The wages she has been used to are twenty four pounds—with washing, tea beer &c or the money for all that. Then she would expect the Lady’s left off things which I told her was an arrangement that I (as an individual) would much dislike. That it would give me the feeling of having an Heir always at my elbow, waiting eagerly for my diseace! She smiled a rugged smile, and said “she was not so greedy as some Lady’s Maids were, always telling their Lady, it was time this and the other piece of dress should be left off!“
You will get this letter tomorrow morning. Could you answer by return of Post? either to me or to the Giantess herself. you have her address? / Mme Guignard / 6 Park Row / Knightsbridge
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], [23 Sept.]. Pbd. Wilson, Carlyle 5:529. Wilson wrote: “Date-able by the post-marks that day, 23.9.1863, there is a shop-keeper’s note about books that had been ordered [see TC to LLA, 20 Sept.], to say that those not sent had been ‘all sold.’ Carlyle wrote below, in sending on the letter ‘For the Lady Ashburton to know,’ that what they were sending would be ‘the worst of the “six,” most likely; tho’ I know not what the name of it is!’ Then he ran on.—“
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
My poor wife had an ugly accident yesterdayTC began his long note about JWC’s accident (Froude, LM 3:174–81), with a summary of JWC’s previous suffering and his struggles with Frederick: “Of all these dreary sufferings and miseries, which had been steadily increasing for years past, I perceive now, with pain and remorse, I had never had the least of a clear notion; such her invincible spirit in bearing them, such her constant effort to hide them from me altogether. My own poor existence, as she also well knew, was laden to the utmost pitch of strength, and sunk in perpetual muddy darkness, by a task too heavy for me—task which seemed impossible, and as if it would end me instead of I it. I saw no company, had no companion but my horse (fourteen miles a day, winter time, mainly in the dark), rode in all, as I have sometimes counted, above 30,000 miles for health’s sake, while writing that unutterable book. The one bright point in my day was from half an hour to twenty minutes’ talking with her, after my return from those thrice dismal rides, while I sat smoking (on the hearthrug, with my back to the jamb, puffing firewards—a rare invention!) and sipping a spoonful of brandy in water, preparatory to the hour of sleep I had before dinner. She, too, the dear and noble soul, seemed to feel that this was the eye of her day, the flower of all her daily endeavour in the world. I found her oftenest stretched on the sofa (close at my right hand, I between her and the fire), her drawing-room and self all in the gracefullest and most perfect order, and waiting with such a welcome; ah, me! ah, me! She was weak, weak, far weaker than I understood; but to me was bright always as stars and diamonds; nay, I should say a kind of cheery sunshine in those otherwise Egyptian days. She had always something cheerful to tell me of (especially if she had been out, or had had visitors): generally something quite pretty to report (in her sprightly, quiet, and ever-genial way). At lowest, nothing of unpleasant was ever heard from her; all that was gloomy she was silent upon, and had strictly hidden away. Once, I remember, years before this, while she suffered under one of her bad influenzas (little known to me how bad), I came in for three successive evenings, full of the ‘Battle of Molwitz’ (which I had at last got to understand, much to my inward triumph), and talked to her all my half-hour about nothing else. She answered little (‘speaking not good for me,’ perhaps); but gave no sign of want of interest—nay, perhaps did not quite want it, and yet confessed to me, several years afterwards, her principal thought was, ‘Alas, I shall never see this come to print; I am hastening towards death instead!’ These were, indeed, dark days for us both, and still darker unknown to us were at hand” (Froude, LM 3:174–75). The remainder of TC’s long note has been divided between relevant letters; see TC to JCA, 27 Sept., TC to JCA, 3 Oct., JWC to Lady ALLA, 2 Nov., TC to JAC, 6 Dec., TC to Lady ALLA, 21 Dec., and TC to JAC, 30 Dec. in some crowded place, while getting into a street vehicle too rapidly, fell on the curb-stone; hurt her
left leg and side, and was brought home to me quite lame. No bones broken, hip-joint not injured (as I feared); but very great misery of pain ever since;—and in short a bad job for us, whh. we had no need of as things were. In a day or two (the Dr. promises) it will be easier to bear.
Hoping there is nothing wrong at the Grange!
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], [26 Sept.]. Addr: The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: London, 26 Sept. 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.dateline: Chelsea Saty (Horse at the door) [26 September 1863].
docBody.p: Many thanks for yr good news. The poor Wife is visibly a good deal better today; “limb nearly painless when let altogether alone“;—and I do flatter myself the worst is past, and that we shall see her limping about, in vertical attitude again before long.

Last night, literally at the 11th hour, I gave MonroeProbably an Ashburton servant rather than Alexander Munro (1825–72; ODNB), sculptor (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855). a BookUnidentified. for The Grange.— Book promised but forgotten.

Poor Ellice,Edward “Bear” Ellice d., 17 Sept., of heart disease, at Ardochy, Inverness-shire. The Times reported, 21 Sept.: “[T]he sudden death of this venerable and world-known public man will be universally felt; and we feel assured that his loss will be lamented by men of all political parties without exception“; the Examiner obituary was more personal: “[W]ith a strong and large capacity for friendship, he could do a thousand good offices with a stately cordiality and a warmth of sympathy that to the last bespoke the living force of the old generous nature” (26 Sept.). poor old Bear; we shall hear his sonsy voice among us no more!

I have been interrupted by Henry Taylor (first sight for almost a twelvemonth; considerably mended;Henry Taylor suffered from asthma; see 37:49TC to HT, 28 Nov. 1860. making many kind enquiries for you);—I never was, hardly, in greater hurry. Yours ever/ T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 Sept. MS: NLS 517.58 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
We have been in trouble here; and still rather are, tho’ happily it is much abated now. On Tuesday Evg last, poor Jane, who had been ill-plagued for two months past with a violent pain (whh they call neuralgia) in her left arm, was just beginning to feel something of improvet there, determined heroically to go out and make a visit to a Cousin she has in the City (one Mrs Godby,Mary Godby. at the big Post-Office Establisht here), & have at least a ride to and
from. The ride to, and the visit, went all well; but on getting into the omnibus for home agn, the place being crowded, tumultuous with open excavations &c, and the maid sent with her being very stupid, Jane had a spring to make out of the way of some cab; the curbstone was slippery;—and in short she fell on the flags, full length, on the lame arm too; and got herself terribly flurried, as well as altogether lamed for the time being.TC wrote later: “One evening … on my return from riding, I learned rather with satisfaction for her sake that she had ventured on a drive to the General Post Office to see her cousin, Mrs. Godby, ‘matron’ of that establishment; and would take tea there. After sleep and dinner, I was still without her; ‘Well, well, I thought, what a nice little story will she have to tell me soon!’ and lay quietly down on the sofa, and comfortably waited—still comfortably, though the time (an hour or more) was longer than I had expected. At length came the welcome sound of her wheels; I started up—she rather lingered in appearing,—I rang, got no clear answer, rushed down, and, oh, what a sight awaited me! She was still in the cab, Larkin speaking to her (Larkin lived next door, and for him she had sent, carefully saving me!) Oh, Heavens! and, alas! Both Larkin and I were needed. She had had a frightful street-accident in St. Martin’s, and was now lamed and in agony! This was the account I got by degrees. // Mrs. Godby sent a maid-servant out with her to catch an omnibus; maid was stupid, unhelpful, and there happened to be some excavation on the street which did not permit the omnibus to come close. Just as my poor little darling was stepping from the kerbstone to run over (maid merely looking on), a furious cab rushed through the interval; she had to stop spasmodically, then still more spasmodically try to keep from falling flat on the other side, and ruining her poor neuralgic arm. In vain, this latter effort; she did fall, lame arm useless for help, and in the desperate effort she had torn the sinews of the thigh-bone, and was powerless to move or stand, and in pain unspeakable. Larkin and I lifted her into a chair, carried her with all our steadiness (for every shake was misery) up to her bed, where, in a few minutes, the good Barnes, luckily found at home, made appearance with what help there was” (Froude, LM 3:175–77). See also Carlyle, Reminiscences 164–67. I have never seen her so beaten as she was for two days following; the pain altogether horrible, not the least movement possible, no sleep, & all the sad concomitants!Larkin also gave a detailed description of the episode: “On the evening in question, I was sitting quietly at home, when I heard a gentle rap at the door; and was informed that Mrs. Carlyle’s servant wished to speak to me. She told me that Mrs. Carlyle had just been brought home in a cab, seriously hurt by a fall, and begged I would come in at once. I went instantly, and found her on a chair in the back room of the ground floor, evidently in great pain. As soon as she saw me, she said, ‘Oh, Mr. Larkin, do get me up into my own room before Mr. Carlyle knows anything about it. He’ll drive me mad if he comes in now!’ We at once consulted as to how we could best carry her up; when, just as we were about to do it, he entered … looking terribly shocked and even angry. I saw he was annoyed at my being there, instead of him; so I said as little as possible, helped him to carry her upstairs, and then left. On the following morning I called to inquire how she was, and found she had given word that I was to be asked to go up and see her. She was full of thanks, and told me it would be a great comfort to her if I would come up every morning for five minutes, as she knew she should often be wanting some little thing done; and pleasantly added, ‘It will be something to look forward to’” (BQR 76–77). Happily there seems to be no bone broken, nothing wrong to the hip-joint (whh I was
much afraid of): she is now abt altogether free from pain (in the newly hurt limb, not at all in the old arm whh is worse than before); and, on condition of lying absolutely still, has the prospect (her Doctor seems to say) of soon being about again,—perhaps in a hitching way for some time longer. She is very content with the immense relief there already is (from unendurable pain); and we flatter ourselves things will come round to the old pass in a little while, and a great fright and hurly-burly be over.— Perhaps JamesHer son James. told you abt this; he was here the other night: you have now, at any rate, the correct particulars.

Tell the Dr I got his Note. He will understand I have not been making brillt progress, in this sad interim! In fact I am terribly bested for “getting forward” here, what with one thing, what with another. Say however that I am getting really under way; and theMS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 27 Sept. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 28 Sept. 1863. MS: NLS 553.253. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I fear you are still unwell; I was on the road to you today, but cd not make it out; such my hurry.

Poor Mrs C. had an ugly accident, Tuesday evg last; fell on the curbstone, getting into some street-vehicle in a crowded place; and hurt herself very much. Happily no bones broken, nor any joint injured; but the miserablest agony of pain for two days after,—whh is much abated now; tho’ she is still prostrate in bed; and totally lame, the Dr does not predict for how long. My own “progress” under these circs,—you may fancy it! Patience; push along, push steadily!—

On the back of this I have marked 3 Books from Heberle,J. M. Héberlé, Cologne booksellers. whh I wish you to send for with all speed! Two of them are by Preuss, and I had not heard of them before.— This CopyistMr. Bishop; see TC to JN, 10 Sept. seems a docile lad; I doubt not you will make him succeed. I know the Preuss Note abt Cunningham’s Print:Edward (sometimes Edmund) Francis Cunningham (ca. 1742–95; ODNB), Scottish portrait painter, painted various portraits of Frederick, but TC presumably refers here to Friedrich’s Last Review; see Carlyle, Works 19:285–86, andCL 28:82TC to JN, 16 March 1853, and 228TC to JN, 28 July 1853. I wd give a great deal for the Key to it,—pray urge Hebe to try with all his might for that too!
Heberle’s Catalogue (pp. 90, 91)

Nos 1808, 1809 (Preuss, Frh im 7-jährn Krieg;Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse im siebenjährigen Kriege und in seinen späteren Regentensorgen. Eine historische Portrait-Skizze (Berlin 1858).—and über die “Instruction Secrète“The “Secret Letter of Instruction,” from Frederick to his cabinet minister Karl Wilhelm Finck von Finckenstein (1714–1800), 10 Jan. 1757, was kept secret until 1854, when it was “lithographed at Berlin, and distributed to a select public” (Carlyle, Works 17:99); also pbd. in vol. 25 of Preuss’s edn. of Oeuvres de Frédéric le Grand, 31 vols. (Berlin, 1846–57); see Carlyle, Works 17:99–102.

No 1817 (Selle, Krankheitsgesche Fr’s)Christian Gottlieb Selle (1748–1800), Frederick’s personal physician 1785–86; he wrote an account of Frederick’s final illness, Krankheitsgeschichte des Höchsteeligen Königs von Preussen Friedrichs des Zweyten Majestät (Berlin 1786), described by TC as “a very small Pamphlet, now very rare;—giving in the most distinct, intelligent, modest and conclusive way, an account of everything pertinent, and rigorously of nothing else“; see Carlyle, Works 19:286; TC’s copy: HCC.

I want these 3 books very specially.—Suhm, Letzte Stunden &c Frh’s,[Johann Gottfried Kletschke], Letzte Stunden und Leichenbegängniss Friedrichs des Zweiten, König von Preussen (Potsdam 1786); see Carlyle, Works 19:297; TC’s copy: HCC. Apparently TC gave the author as Suhm in error. I have got; but it is worth nothing.
I have taken such a bit of Paper; and am in such a tempest of small bothers—!—

p.name: T.C.
p.note: TC wrote the list of books first (in pencil), then wrote the letter on the other side; this last sentence and signature were written in the book list margin.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 30 [29] Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; see TC to LOA, 1 Oct.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dear Lady Ashburton,—My Bulletin today again is favourable; things going on well, as well as we cd expect. There is nothing of contusion, nothing of breakage or dislocation, wholly a strain of the muscles, or sinews (I suppose) in making the violent effort to avoid falling. Will take time, the Dr says, will take patience;—too likely! She has nothing of pain in the limb; and can even lift it with her two hands without the least pain; but let her try to make it lift itself—!—She gets daily to the sofa a little while,—the great difficulty is in getting in again. The neuralgia even was worse for some days; is now abt the old rate; and suffers & causes much trouble. She eats abt as well or better
than you saw her do; sleep has never yet reached 4 hours, oftenest abt 3,—all broken into patches. She is very quiet, clear of head, as “patient” as the Doctor cd prescribe:Froude reported an incident from the first days after the accident, apparently told him by JWC: “Carlyle was not allowed to know how seriously she had been injured. The doctor and she both agreed to conceal it from him, and during those first days a small incident happened, which she herself described to me, showing the distracting want of perception which sometimes characterized him—a want of perception, not a want of feeling, for no one could have felt more tenderly. The nerves and muscles were completely disabled on the side on which she had fallen, and one effect was that the under jaw had dropped, and that she could not close it. Carlyle always disliked an open mouth; he thought it a sign of foolishness. One morning, when the pain was at its worst, he came into her room, and stood looking at her, leaning on the mantel-piece. ‘Jane,’ he said presently, ‘ye had better shut your mouth.’ She tried to tell him that she could not. ‘Jane,’ he began again, ‘ye’ll find yourself in a more compact and pious frame of mind, if ye shut your mouth.’ In old-fashioned and, in him, perfectly sincere phraseology he told her that she ought to be thankful that the accident was no worse. Mrs. Carlyle hated cant as heartily as he, and to her, in her sore state of mind and body, such words had a flavour of cant in them. True herself as steel, she would not bear it. ‘Thankful!’ she said to him; ‘thankful for what? for having been thrown down in the street when I had gone on an errand of charity? for being disabled, crushed, made to suffer in this way? I am not thankful, and I will not say that I am.’ He left her, saying he was sorry to see her so rebellious” (Froude, Carlyle 4:271–73). she bids me tell you “she is going on slowly, and“— Nothing more came from her at that moment!
I supposed, when I wrote last, you were out of bed, and yr sore-throat quite conquered. Tell us soon that it is so;—and that your patientLord Ashburton. too is doing well
Twisleton is waiting for me; Neuberg has interrupted me for five minutes: I am in paper-clippings and confusions to the chin. Ever yr Ladyship’s/ T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 1 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 513.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: There went nothing yesterday in answer to your kind Note;—the little thing My Lady got was indeed dated ‘Septr 30’; but by mistake: it belonged to the day before; and owing to the Twisleton Walking-Dialogue, and previous and subsequent confusions, was forgotten in my pocket till too late for post.According to JWC to MR, [5 Nov.], the post time was 4:30 p.m. although the post office directory stated that letters could be posted locally up to 9:00 p.m., at either pillar boxes or receiving houses, for delivery the next day. This day again I have failed to write in time for post;—but am busy now, towards the stroke of midnight, not to fail tomorrow.

Relieve your conscience upon one score! It is absolutely certain my Wife got hurt not on your or My Lady’s busss in any sense, but altogether on her own; she was visiting a Lady-Friend,Mary Godby.—intending, poor soul, to stir herself up a little, I suppose, and have the benefit of a ride to and from. She would have had various “things to tell me,” too, on returning, after I had come home and dined! It was beautifully meant, and deserved applauses, tho’ it ended in this sad way.

The first pain, as I said, is quite gone; but the Dr seems to intimate that the one remedy is time and rest; and that it will take time. If she were able to move at all, even to get freely out of bed and in, it wd be a great relief:—out of bed she manages to get, without much difficulty, by means of the sound leg and arm; but the getting in is always something of a problem. But she is the shiftiest creature in the world; full of contrivances, ingenious adjustments; has her wits thoroughly awake, her temper patient as agt the inexorable and unalterable;—and shews really a wonderful gift, already in this new case as in others, of “doing all things decently and in order.“— I am sor[r]iestTC omitted “r.“ for her want of sleep; she never yet gets beyond the stinted “3 hours, all in fractions“; and at prest she cannot read, or rise to mend her fire,—and will not have anybody sit with her, absolutely not. On the whole she certainly improves, tho’ slowly; and we must wait.

It was glorious news that, in spite of the bad weather, you go on prosperously. The change of season, I suppose, must be the ticklish point; were that once done— Be careful, oh be careful!— — I have a Patten’s Rebellion of 1715Rev. Robert Patten, The History of the Late Rebellion (1717). for my Lady by the first chance. Good night; 12 has now struck, & all creatures are gone silent.—
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA] , [2 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated early Oct. by Lady Ashburton’s own illness; see TC to LLA, 30 [29] Sept. The letter was written in ink.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
My good beautiful Darling your pencilled words this morning were like a drop of comfort out of Heaven! God bless you for them! I was not surpri[s]ed to hear you were ill What else was to be expected after all those miserable days before we left you? I am in great pain—“torn sinews” the Dr says— I cant move except my right hand— I shall be able to move in a few days the Dr
says— I get hardly any sleep for the pain and your grapes are so cooling thro’ the long nights. My accident had nothing whatever to do with you— I almost wish it had had that pleasant association! as it is, it was one great stupid going to meet trouble

I sent for a LadyUnidentified; possibly Mary Godby or Geraldine Jewsbury, who visited often after JWC’s accident. to write the rest of my dictation but she cant come for two hours which will be too late So put up with torn sinews JWC’s handwriting was particularly bad in this letter; she wrote subsequent letters of this period in blue pencil. I was afraid my accident would cut short my search after servants—and so I was glad when you said—the three were coming down— Now I hope you haven’t concluded with the Swiss GiantessMary Guignard; see JWC to Lady A LLA , [22 Sept.]. for I have seen this morning the nicest Ladys maidof the whole lot. She came here accidentally Had gone to Bathhouse after the situation and Hannah not knowing what to do with her bade her come and tell Mrs Car-lyleJWC writes the name thus, indicating pronunciation; for a different emphasis, see JWC to Lady A LLA , [ca. 10] May . about it!
