I had her up to my bedside and warmed to her directly, she looked so gentle and sympathetic I could have taken her to myself for nurse without further investigation She is no Giantess—is slight rather—nicely dressed—so modest and gentle—and ten years in one placed— I should expect much more from her in every way than from the Swiss— She looks about eight and thirty

Thanks to Miss AnstrutherPresumably Annie Nairn Anstruther. The woman would much like to see you if you are not engaged / Yours entirely /
Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 3 Oct. MS: NLS 517.59. Hitherto unpbd. Sat. was 3 Oct.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—I got yr Note, and have had a little word, from the DrJohn A. Carlyle. yesterday. Thanks for your promptitude. I had to direct farther: “3 pairs of the best knit drawers “for Jane,” got where and how you got the last 3, whh were very good“:Probably Marion Dinwiddie (1819–95), hosier, of 131 High St., Dumfries, who made drawers for JWC in 1860; see 37:16JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1860]. pray attend to that also, and do yr best to get a good article, to come with the masculine lot. My poor Woman here, tho’ totally lame at prest, hopes
to be up agn, and wear those pieces of clothing;—Heaven grant, it were soon! She is evidently better; can now move the toes freely; but has such a work to get stirred at all, otherwise,—to get out & in of her bed even! She is very quiet; tho’ only on “3 hours” bad TC’s line over “bad,” presumably for emphasis. broken sleep nightly; and continually tormented with the neuralgic arm, whh itself seems to have got hurt in the busss. She has trained one of her maidsMary. (formerly rather useless) to act Nurse very well; and has her bit of a bedroom so sorted, trimmed, and furnished with conveniences and neat contrivances, as you have seldom seen!TC wrote later: “The torment of those first three days was naturally horrible; but it was right bravely borne, and directly thereupon all things looked up, she herself, bright centre of them, throwing light into all things. It was wonderful to see how in a few days she seemed to be almost happy, contented with immunity from pain, and proud to have made (as she soon did) her little bedroom into a boudoir, all in her own likeness, She sent for the carpenter, directed him in everything, had cords and appliances put up for grasping with and getting good of her hand, the one useful limb now left. It was wonderful what she had made of that room, by carpenter and housemaid, in a few hours—all done in her own image, as I said. On a little table at her right hand, among books and other useful furniture, she gaily pointed out to me a dainty little bottle of champagne, from which, by some leaden article screwed through the cork, and needing only a touch, she could take a spoonful or teaspoonful at any time, without injuring the rest: ‘Is not that pretty? Excellent champagne (Miss Bromley’s kind gift), and does me good, I can tell you.’ I remember this scene well, and that, in the love of gentle and assiduous friends, and their kind little interviews and ministrations, added to the hope she had, her sick room had comparatively an almost happy air, so elegant and beautiful it all was, and her own behaviour in it always was” (Froude, LM 3:177). “Longs for the first blink of daylight“—ah me! We must wait patiently.

I know not whether you will get this tomorrow; but I send it on chance. I for my own poor part am as well as usual in health; but as for the work part,—that is itself like to drive me mad (so cramp, perverse, confused, and hideously disgusting as is it), had I nothing else on me.— JamesJames Aitken. is coming tomorrow to dinner. Good be with you all.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 8 Oct. Addr: Mayfair. PM: London, 8 Oct. 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Boston Evening Transcript, 11 May 1915 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: Thanks for these pleasant fruits of the Earth; whh are doubly and trebly valuable as proof of yr friendly remembrance, kind and unabating tho’ silent.

Be not too angry with the blockheadism of the world: it is very bad,—and looks even worse than it is, when the chiefly vocal parties are the foolish, and the wise are mainly those that keep silence:—but on the whole it does not make or unmake a man; the man (in all times & places) has to do that feat for himself.

I forget if you know German; or have made any real face-to-face acquaintance with Goethe? If not, I cd seriously recommend you to learn German, for that object, were there no other. Among European Writers or Speakers for the last 200 years, you will find this one, in several importt respects, to be unique.

closer.salute: Believe me, / Yours with thanks & good wishes

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Oct. MS: NLS 517.60. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This shall salute you on yr first Saturday morning of the new Edinr Winter, —whh I only heard of from yrself yesterday morng, Jean not having written. It made me somehow sad: that you too had done with your visitings and bit of rusticatn and recreatn, and home agn, to such home as there was.John A. Carlyle had returned to his lodgings at 67 Hanover St., Edinburgh, for the winter. Well, well; it is intrinsically the way with all living men: not opulence of felicity, but poverty,—a poor acct of empty (Pandora) Boxes, and only work lying solid at the bottom!— I am sorry to hear of Jamie’s disappointt and bafflings with the elements.Presumably their brother James was having difficulties with the harvest because of weather conditions. The Dumfries Courier reported, 29 Sept.: “[M]uch of the cut grain has been damaged by long exposure; this was evident on Saturday last, and what was not when Sunday’s rain came must have suffered severely. Few stooks could stand such a wind, and the sheaves must have been thoroughly redrenched.“ I suppose he does not need our help: otherwise—?

Jane’s hurt here is clearly getting better. The injury was not to bone or to joint; “lacerated sinews,” the people call it; and can do nothing for it but leave it absolutely in peace till its own time. The pain is quite gone if you let it lie; nor is the pain anything like so bad as once on its getting stirred:—I cd not well think how “sinews” had got “torn” by the kind of fall it was, but Jane remembers making an “awful effort to save her sore arm“; effort whh failed, and has done most of the mischief. She can now get into bed as well as out, by herself with her maids, whh is a considerable relief: all day she sits on the sofa in her bedroom (often enough “receiving” there,—you never saw such a neat
place of the size);—she has not seen the drawingroom since “Tuesday gone a fortnight“; nor can I yet guess when she will, I wish we cd!

I am at last, in some sort, got into this Book 19th“Friedrich Like to be Overwhelmed in the Seven-Years War. 1759–1760“; see Carlyle, Works 18:1–215. (sorrow on it); and am struggling forward, at a frightful rate of slowness, under so many impedts from withtBottom third of page cut away, presumably for the signature on the other side.
-specially so much a friend of mine. I am really sad of heart to think of that faithful old Fritz,TC’s previous horse. and the stormy plunges we have had together!—
Be good to the not too happy Otthenins; patient, what you can: if they are not wise, the more are you bound to be wise for two! My kind regards at any rate; that is always a standing fact.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GW [GWE], [13 Oct.]. MS: NLS 608.618A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:181–84 inc. Letter dated “exactly three weeks ” after JWC’s fall, Tues., 22 Sept. The letter, written in red pencil, was enclosed in a folded sheet of paper on which TC wrote ” 20? Octr 1863 to Aunt Grace: (in red pencil, after the fall; before the sad sequel!)—.“
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE WELSH

docBody.p: Thank you a thousand times dearest Grace for your long most moving letter.For details from Grace Welsh’s letter, see JWC to MR, [19 Oct.]. It is not because of it, that I write today, for I was meaning to write today at any rate; indeed it rather makes writing more difficult to me; I have cried so over it, that I have given myself a bad headach in addition to my other lamings— But a little letter I will write by todays post and a bigger one when I am more able—

I wrote a few lines to Mrs CravenJWC’s cousin Mary May Craven, da. of her paternal uncle Robert. in answer to her announcement of that dear girls angel deathMary May’s sister Grace Dobie; she d. 2 Oct. of phthisis (pulmonary tuberculosis).— I told her of my accident, and was trusting to her telling you: but as I told her I had kept you in ignorance of it in the beginning lest Elizabeth and you and Ann with your terrible experience of such an accident“Poor Elizabeth had slipped and fallen on the street [in 1854]; dislocated her thigh-bone; got it wrong set; then, after long months of misery, undergone a setting of it ‘right’—but is lame to this day” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:181); see 29:69JWC to JAC, [18 April 1854]. might be alarmed and distressed for me more than (I hoped) there would prove cause for—she thought perhaps I wished you to remain unaware of it, even when I reported myself progressing more favourably than could
have been predicted. I need not go into the how of the fall. I will tell you all “particulars” when I gain more facility in writing—enough to say that exactly this day three weeks, I was plashed down on the pavement of St Martin le Grand (five miles from home) on my left side (the arm of which couldnt break the fall)—and hurt all down from the hip joint so fearfully and on the already lamed shoulder besides—that I couldnt stir, but had to be lifted up by people who gathered round me (a Policeman among them) and put into a cab— Elizabeth can fancy my drive home—five miles—and the getting of me out of the cab and upstairs to bed! Wasn’t I often thinking of her all the time? “My” Dr came immediately; and found neither breakage of the leg nor dislocation—but the agony of pain he said would have been less had the bone broken— I thought of Elizabeth, and doubted that! Still for three days and three sleepless nights it was such agony as I had never known before— After that the pain went gradually out of the leg unless when I moved it—when the bedpan was pushed under me &c &c! But the arm with its complication of sprain and neuralgia has given me a sad time—till these last two days that it has returned almost to the state it was in before the fall. a week ago Mr Barnes made me get out of bed for fear of “a bad back” and sit on end on a sofa in my bedroom. like Miss Biffin—(the little egg-shaped woman that used to be shown)Sarah Biffin or Beffin (1784–1850; ODNB), painter of miniatures; born without limbs, she painted with her mouth; she was “shown” as part of a traveling circus; see 33:72–74JWC to TC, [6 Sept. 1857].—and two days ago he compelled me to walk a few steps, supported with his arms—and to do the same thing at least twice a day It has been a case of what they call “lacerated sinews,” and he said the tendency of the muscles was to contract themselves after such a thing, and if I did not force myself to put down my foot now and then, I should never be able to walk at all! Such a threat and his determined manner enables me to make the effort which costs! I can tell you But at whatever cost of pain and nervousness, I have today passed thro’ the door of my bedroom (which opens into the Drawing room luckily), using one of the maids as a crutch. So you see I am already a good way towards recovery—for which I feel every moment deep thankfulness to God— To have experienced such agony and to be delivered from it comparatively—makes one feel one’s dependence as nothing else does!

For the rest as dear BettyBetty Braid. is always saying “I have mony mercies“— My Servants have been most kind and unwearied in their attentions—my Friends more like Sisters or Mothers than commonplace friends— Oh I shall have such wonderful kindnesses to tell you of when I can write freely—my third cousin Mrs Godby and several others wished to stay with me—but the “nursing” I needed was of quite a menial sort— I should still have sought it from my servants, and a Lady nurse would only have given them more to do, and been
dreadfully in the way of Mr C—my great object, after getting what waiting on I absolutely needed has been that the usual quiet routine of the house should not be disturbed around Mr C—who thinks, I am sure, that he has been victimised enough in having to answer occasional letters of enquiry about me!! And now I must conclude—for the present
I am so sorry for poor Robert’sUnidentified further; possibly a servant rather than a relative; Mary May Craven’s father and husband were both named Robert. fingers—

A hearty kiss to each of you— Be sure to send me the copy of Graces words to her Mother“The poor niece’s” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:184); Grace Dobie’s mother was Mary Welsh.— Oh poor Souls! What woe and what mercy!
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], [15 Oct.]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Pbd: Blunt, CLC 416–17.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: Dear little Woman— The Persians have a proverb; “Believe that a Mountain can change its place; but never that a man (human being) can change his nature“Cf. “If ye hear that a mountain has changed its place, believe it: but if ye hear that a man has changed his disposition, believe it not“: Fakir Jany Muhammad Asäad, Practical Philosophy of the Muhammadan People (1839) 35. Also referred to by Emerson in “Eloquence,” Atlantic Monthly (2 Sept. 1858); see Emerson’s Complete Works (Boston 1904) 7:64. and it is the truest of sayings!— So, when I didn’t answer your letter, but seemed to have forgotten to care for you; you would conclude, being a girl with some natural logic, that something else than forgetfulness or indifference was the reason—that I was in some way unable to write you a letter. and so it has been. I have been disabled to an extent that you never saw me!

It is three weeks past last Tuesday since I met with a horrid accident. I had been calling for Mrs Godby at the General Post office, and on leaving her house to take the Omnibus, I had to cross the most dangerous thoroughfare in all LondonSt. Martin’s le Grand; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 2 Nov.— I had just crossed in safety, but flurried by the danger of being run over, when I struck the side of my foot against the curb stone and was plashed down on the pavement on my left side, and was so hurt that I lay there unable to stir. People gathered round me, a Policeman among them, and I was hauled up in agony, and placed in a cab, to get home all the way (five miles) alone as I could!

I shall never forget the agony of that drive—or of my being carried into the house by Mr Larkin, and up stairs, in an arm chair, by Mr C and him—and then I was laid on my bed, and MrsThus in MS, for Mr. Barnes. Barnes came, and found no broken bones only “lacerated sinews,” which so far as pain goes, is they say, much worse to bear—

For days and nights I lay unable to move, in dreadful agony, and without a wink of sleep— After the first week the pain in my leg was bad only when moved—but my arm which had been stiff with neuralgia for two months before continued and continues to give me great suffering—after a fortnight I could be set on end on a sofa—and now after three weeks I have walked thro my bedroom door into the drawing room sofa—half carried by one of the Girls— But Mr Barnes said I must put my foot to the ground occasionally—at whatever cost of pain, or IThus in MS. the muscles would contract and I should never be able to walk at all—
I may be thankful to God that I have got this length so soon!
My maids have been most kind and attentive to me—grudging no trouble and they have had plenty of that! And my Friends have been so dear and good that it makes me like to cry to think of it all!—

So you see why I have not answered your letter sooner— Dont be vexed about me Dear— I am doing better than could have been hoped—and I will write and tell you when I can walk alone— Yours always kindly Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 18 Oct. MS: NLS 531.3. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,— It is positively a shame (and yet I really cd not help it) that I found no moment on Thursday Night, or Friday, or even Saturday (whh wd have been still a chance for better despatch than this), to send a single word of announcet, “Arrived, all right.” Well, on Thursday night, duly, that was the agreeable fact: a Capital Dressing-gown, fits completely, and is very feel, and admitted to be bonny by a severe judge here. Her own Drawers were perfectly right; mine do (so far as eye and hand and anticipative judgt go): in short you have managed, nobody cd better; and I am much thankful;—and request you to send me the people’s acct; TC noted: “29 Octr 1863 / To Sister Jean (for Dressing gown &c &c) / é4..8..8” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh will bring the stocking handsomely to the toe; and let the needles rest till a new one be needed.

Jane goes on steadily progressing at a slow rate: for four or five days past,
she has been putting her foot to the ground more and always rather more; walks some steps, leaning on one of her maids; and passes her day, more cheerfully, sitting in the drawing-room (whh is on the same floor with her bedroom); not able to do much, not even to read much, but very alert in eye and mind.

I am myself queasy and stupid; boring with great obstinacy agt the sullen mass of rubbish whh is to be top story of my Book; very slow; sick of heart, indeed utterly weary, as I seldom was of anything whatever,—but much determined to “gar myself do it.” How often does that phrase of my brave Father’s come into my mind!Coterie speech; see 2:430 TC to JAC, 17 Sept. 1823
, and 17:292 TC to AC, 3 March 1844
. He had too hadThus in MS. sore jobs to do; we all have. But they that do them, rest well.

The weather alternates between wet and bright-dry; not at all bad weather, tho’ of the kind you call clashy I was out today towards Richmond (a ride of 6 miles, free from jumble on the sunday); everything was green down below & mournfully party-coloured higher up,—the red leaves, the yellow & the still green copiously continuing on the trees; sky windy with many dry clouds:—another Year pensively about to die.— My errand was, to call on Henry Taylor, one of the few “old friends” still left me; who is a good man,—if I now cared much about men.—— I have seen nothing more of James; tho’ he was at the door one day (in my absence), inquiring for his Aunt.

Goodnight, dear Sister; I have still some scribblings to do,—and it is wearing late: near 11 p.m. in my elevated wor[k]shop,TC omitted “k.” silent except for the piping of the winds. God bless you all always.—
T. Carlyle

ps.p: Tell me, Do you get this on Monday Night?TC wrote on Sunday, with no post collections in London. But letters collected first thing Monday morning could arrive that evening.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 18 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Correspondent identified as Ward by their recent contact (see TC to CAW, 8 Oct.) and TC’s suggestion of riding together in 1860. Ward lived at 12 Chapel St., Mayfair, nr. Hyde Park.
div3.head: TC TO C. A. WARD

docBody.p: I regret to have unwittingly spilt yr pleasant intention.Unexplained. I did not know you mean anything specific or immediate; I have seldom time to write the smallest Note,—and practically for years back, never do, except upon evidt compulsion.

Long ago I said something of a ride together:TC suggested a ride together in 1860; see 36:264TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860. that is actually the one good method of getting any talk with me (till this monstrous Prussn Slavery is over);—and I still stand to what was then said (“any day, at this door, on the stroke of 3“); tho’ I think you rejected that scheme.
My Slavery, if I hold out, will end before very long now; and I continue persuaded that your charitable project is not lost but only deferred.
With many sincere good wishes
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [18 Oct.]. Addr: Rosslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 20 Oct. 1863. MS: NLS 553.254. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Thanks for the Sulzer;Johann Georg Sulzer (1720–79), German philosopher; for his conversation about human nature with Frederick the Great, see Carlyle, Works 16:337–38; this was a favorite exchange of TC’s; see 33:233–34TC to RWE, 2 June 1858. whh is all I cd require.

Think you there is no chance still of those Letters of Montcalm,Lettres de Monsieur le marquis de Montcalm, gouverneur-general en Canada: à Messieurs de Berryer & de La Molé, ecrites dans les années 1757; 1758, & 1759: avec une version angloise (1777), pamphlet containing three letters. Louis Joseph, marquis de Montcalm (1712–59), French general, whose forces were defeated by the British at the Battle of Québec, 13 Sept. 1759. under any title,—perhaps? Did you ask WattsThomas Watts (1811–69; ODNB), librarian, British Museum, responsible for purchase of current foreign literature. Neuberg did not find the pamphlet in the British Museum, and TC was able to find only extracts from the letters in R. S. Beatson, The Plains of Abraham; Notes Original and Selected (Gibraltar 1858). He later found a copy of the pamphlet in the Temple Library in London and then declared the letters to be forgeries; but he allowed the one quoted to remain in future editions of Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 18:144–47. abt them;—he ought at least to get them (for his own sake), and blush more or less! The Printer is getting to work agn: “Heave oh!“— —

Tomorrow afternoon I shall be absolutely on the heels of that ingenuous but sparse-writing young man.Mr. Bishop; see TC to JN, [20 Oct.], TC to Mr. BMRBI, [20 Oct.], and TC to JN, [20 Oct.]. His wide mode of penmanship is intrinsically no great matter; but it shocks not a little my poor sick imaginn,—and is really bad. Tell him to bring me at once what he has got (after you & he have settled how many “pages of 375 words” there are); the whole lot, surely, cannot now take him very long.
I recommend myself to your sympathy; I seldom in my life felt nearer my last card. / Yours always/ T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [19 Oct.]. MS: NLS 608.618B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:184–87 inc., where dated 26 Oct., following TC’s “26 Octr 1863” on the MS; TC also noted “some intermediate Letter lost, evidtly.” Now dated nearer to receipt of Grace Welsh’s letter; see JWC to GWE, [13 Oct.]. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Tho’ I still write to you in pencil, I have progressed out of my Bedroom into the Drawing room for most part of the day. A door opens from the one room into the other,—luckily for my present disabilities,—and as Mr Barnes told me, I must walk a few steps every day whether painful or not; otherwise the muscles of my leg would contract and I should never walk at all; I walk daily from my bedroom into the Drawing room Sofa—after a fashion! my sound arm round Marys neck, and her arm round my waist. I think there is more nervousness than pain in the difficulty with which I make this little journey! For the rest I dont lie much on my sofa—but sit—on end— I cannot however sit up at a table to write with pen and ink—I must write with cushions at my back, and with the paper on my knees—in which circumstances a pencil is less fatiguing than pen and ink, as well as less destructive to my clothes!

The unlucky leg will in a week or two, I hope, be all right— I have no pain whatever in it now, except when I try to use it; and then the pain is not great, and gets daily a trifle less. But my arm is still a bad business; especially at night, I suffer much from it. It spoils my sleep, and that again reacts upon it, and makes it worse, I cannot satisfy myself how much of the pain I am now suffering is the effect of the fall, how much [that of]TC’s addition. the old neuralgia—and Mr Barnes can throw no light on that for me, or suggest any remedy—at least he doesn’t!— It seems to me he regards my leg as his patient, and my arm as Dr Quain’s patient, which He has nothing to do with! and is rather glad to be irresponsible for; seeing nothing to be done! He did once say in a careless way, that plain bark and sodaCinchona bark, often called Peruvian bark, from which quinine is made, but taken in powdered form with soda water, rather than the purified quinine JWC was already taking. Peruvian bark contains other active substances as well as quinine. “one of the most nauseous mixtures he knew of in this world” was better than “my quinine“—but when I asked would it have as good an effect on my spirits as the quinine had had, he said “Oh I cant
promise you that!—it would probably make you sick and low—better keep to your ladylike quinine!!“
Ask the DrMary’s husband, Dr. James Russell. if he sees any superiority in plain bark and soda? I dont care how nauseous a medicine is, if it do me good—

Another of my uncle Robert’s daughters has died—of consumption.Grace Dobie; see JWC to GWGWE, [13 Oct.]. Grace (my Aunt) has written me a long minute account of her deathbed—one of the saddest things I ever read in my life! It quite crushed down the heart in me for days!

The poor young creatures sufferings and the deaf mother’s, and—oh such a heap of misery—is all set before one so vividly—and then the consolation! It is a comfort to know that the dying girl was supported thro her terrible trial by her religious faith and hope—a comfort, and the only comfort possible, conceivable—if it had stopped there—but—you know my feelings about religious excitement—ecstatics— I cannot regard that as a genuine element of religion— Was not Christ himself, on the Cross, calm—simple—? Did he not even pray that if it were possible the cup might pass from him? Was there ever in the whole history of his life a trace of excitement?— The fuss and excitement that seems to have gone on about this poor young deathbed, then, jars on my mind—the working up of the sufferer herself, and the working up of themselves (the onlookers) into a sort of hysterical ecstasy is almost as painful to me as the rest of the sad business—I feel it to be a getting up of a deathbed scene to be put into a tract!—and in the heart of it all such an amount of real terrible anguish—and the grand solemn faith that could bear all, and triumph over all, harrassed by earthly interference and excitations—

I will send the letter—perhaps you will find all this wrong in me, we could never agree about the “revivals“A religious revivalism movement took place in Britain 1859–61; see 37:196TC to JCA, 3 Aug. 1861.—never mind! we love one another all the same—
My kindest regards to the Doctor—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Send back Grace’s letter

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [20 Oct.]. MS: NLS 553.255. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Bishop has been here, with a Sheaf of sparse Ms. (poor fellow, a very nice lad, pray pay him handsomely when he has done—i.e. tell me what to pay him; I really like him well):— But, Good Heaven! I find a Sheet (the Larkin sheet, whh you took as specimen) completely wanting; and cannot stir at all till I get it!
For God’s sake, get it sent at once; I cannot afford to lose another day. And pardon all the botheration I give you; for really es wird zu arg [it will be bad]—for both of us.
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: P.S. Thank God I have got the original at least;—we need not be in such a toss!— Send a Note to the poor Lad, to leave the missing Larkin here; that will do

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mr. B [MRBI], [20 Oct.]. MS: NLS 553.257. Hitherto unpbd. Letter enclosed with the second TC to JN, [20 Oct.]; the substance of the letter’s instructions was apparently rewritten for Bishop more kindly, and Neuberg kept TC’s letter to Bishop.
div3.head: TC TO MR. BISHOP

docBody.p: Mr Bishop is to make no attempt, for the future, at writing anything whh he himself does not see to be sense. The “1/ 2/” &c in the Mss. were for his direction; to copy them is useless, and worse.

Standing rule is henceforth: When Mr B. comes to a passage which he cannot make sense of, he is to omit it altogether,—clearly indicating where, in the Original, it is to be found: e.g. “top of of p.19” (“p. 19½” will do as indicatn of the 2d page in a sheet).
Item, To send me the Specimen sheet (whh immediately precedes the first of his, & the want of whh keeps me idle) by Post, witht delay.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, Tuesday Night

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [20 Oct.]. MS: NLS 553.256. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 21 Oct. 1863. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:531.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I am sorry to bother you again: but I have been in that “Copy“; and—Ach Gott!

Don’t affront the poor young man; but let us have done with him so soon as possible! And witht attempt at Copying what he knows he cannot read!— I wantthe Larkin sheet; and I want no more such “Copyings” of the unintelligible.
Had I known the good Youth’s Address, I wd not have troubled you this second time.

I have written a kind of direction to him,—do you smooth it to him, what you can;For TC’s abrupt instructions, see TC to Mr. BMRBI, [20 Oct.]. compute liberally what he can expect of pay (the worth of him to me is not the question), and he shall have a Draught for it so soon as his Copy is completed.TC noted in his checkbook: “3 Novr 1863 / to Bishop (Copying!) / £2..11..11” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
God grant us all a degree of patience adequate or approximately so.
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Mr Moncure Conway (the Virginn New-Englander whom Emerson sent)See TC to JAC, 29 April. is going to call on you; for advice about an eligible little German Town to pass the winter in,Conway’s wife and children had arrived in England; they spent the winter in rooms at 16 Lansdowne Ter., Regent’s Park, then went to Germany Aug. 1864. with a half-eye to “literary pursuits.” He is a pleasant enough and perfectly honest man;—will present his Card with my name on it, one of these days.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MC [MCON], 21 Oct. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MONCURE D. CONWAY

docBody.p: “Rosslyn Park“Roslyn Park, where Neuberg lived; see the second TC to JN, [20 Oct.]. is an expanse of ground, at the southern end of Hampstead, where a good many new Houses are built,—Mr Neuberg’s one of them, almost the first after you enter the place, and very discoverable on inquiry from any Postman or the like.

Mounting Haverstock Hill (by the old Hampstead Road whh passes near
the N.E. corner of the Regent’s Park), you find, after getting to the top of the Hill, an old-fashioned Public House,Probably the Load of Hay Inn, about ½ mi. (1 km.) SE of the entry to Roslyn Park. still in good repair, on yr right hand; go still forward abt two gunshots; just when the ground is agn abt to rise, and the steep main Street of Hampstd to begin, you find on yr left an opening or road (perhaps the third you have come to since the Public House); go into that,—right ahead of you is N.’s gable (among neighbours not many), enter the gate on yr left hand, and [word or words indecipherable] him. I have warned him that you are coming / T.C.
Chelsea, 21 octr 1863
to M. D. Conway Esq

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lord A [LOA], [22 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:381, where dated ca. 1860. Dated by the publication of Wasson’s letter; see TC to JAC, 23 Oct. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: In the first place; thanks from the heart, for the kind little letter you wrote about me to Mr C!— The Sympathy shown me on this “melancholy occasion” has been of much the same benefit to me, as the Quinine Dr Quain advised for my neuralgia;—it has not lessened the positive pain; but it has made me stronger to bear it!

I am—we are—sincerely glad to hear the capital account of you, given in Miss AnstruthersAnnie Nairn Anstruther. letter of this morning. I have news of BabyMary Baring. too this morning, from Mrs Mackenzie,Mary Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie, Lady Ashburton’s sister-in-law. which removes one’s anxieties on her dear little account!
So I am in good spirits this morning; having nobody to feel anxious about! and my own pains being rather bearable!

In proof thereof I send you a printed document which arrived for Mr C last evening.“A Letter to Thomas Carlyle” by David Atwood Wasson (1823–87), Transcendentalist minister, poet, and abolitionist (Atlantic Monthly, Oct. 1863, 497–504; quotations from this article are cited by page no. below). It was a response to TC’s parable: “ILIAS (Americana) IN NUCE [“American Iliad in a Nutshell“] / Peter of the North (to Paul of the South). ‘Paul, you unaccountable scoundrel, I find you hire servants for life, not by the month or year as I do! You are going straight to hell, you —!’ Paul. / ‘Good words, Peter! The risk is my own; I am willing to take the risk. Hire you your servants by the month or the day, and get straight to Heaven; leave me to my own method.’ / Peter. ‘No, I won’t. I will beat your brains out first!’ (And is trying dreadfully ever since, but cannot yet manage it.) / May 1863. T. C.” (Macmillan’s Magazine, Aug. 1863, 301). TC’s reduction of the causes of the American Civil War to a difference of opinion as to whether labor should be hired by the month, year, or for life, infuriated Wasson, who described himself as a former disciple of TC: “‘Sartor Resartus’ I read twenty years ago afoot and on horseback, sleeping with it under my pillow and wearing it in my pocket till pocket and it were worn out” (502) Wasson angrily condemned TC for his flippant attitudes to slavery: “[B]e assured that this is the American Iliad in no other nutshell than your private one,—in those too contracted cerebral quarters to which … your powerful intelligence, under such prolonged and pitiless extremes of dogmatic compression, has at last got reduced (497) … . The whole wide heaven was not too wide for you … but now you can be jolly in your ‘nutshell’” (502). TC also received a letter from Horace Howard Furness (1833–1912), Philadelphia, 29 Aug.: “Sir, Pray observe an instance of hiring for life.’ God forgive you for your cruel jest, and blindness!” enclosing a small card with a picture of a slave with his back covered in whip scars (MS:NLS Acc. 11388/30.31; see opp.above ), with “The Scourged Back” printed on the reverse. TC forwarded the letter and card to the Ashburtons. H. H. Furness was a son of William Henry Furness (1802–96), unitarian clergyman of Philadelphia, abolitionist, close friend of Emerson; he negotiated TC’s U.S. publishing arrangements with Carey & Hart; see 20:93TC to RWE, 3 Jan. 1846. Charlotte Taylor of Washington, who had two brothers in the Union army and about 20 cousins in the Confederate army, previously a great admirer of TC, wrote a long letter, 27 Aug., expressing her bitter disappointment: “You have pained, wounded and offended, a whole Nation by your careless scoff at our present bitter struggle, our awful trial and striving for life.” She continued that it did not matter much what most people say: “But, when you speak—oh, Sir, believe me, we all listen when Carlyle speaks, and your cruel sneer pains us deeply.” She recommended he listen to Moncure Conway. For further reactions to TC’s piece, see Introduction. And if it only amuse you half as much as it seemed to amuse him—!
Especially the writers solemn prayer for Mr C’s deathWasson wrote: “Ill it is when they that do deepest homage to a great spirit can no longer pray for the increase of his days; … when the utmost bravery of their affection must breathe, not Serus, but CITO in caelum redeas [Not slowly but quickly may you return to the heavens]!” (503); cf. Horace, Odes 2.45. gave him (Mr C) the highest gratification!— The Thing is rather too inflated for my taste, but Mr C declares “no—there is a great deal of a very high sort of Talent in it—and a profound sincerity“!— It is to be hoped, not of a practical sort! for if that “profound sincerity” felt a need of putting itself into action Mr C’s assassination would be inevitable!
“The Scourged Back“
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland
My kind regards, and thanks, and good intentions to Miss Anstruther! please—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Oct. MS: NLS 517.61. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother, We are doing well enough;—but I have not half a moment of time. Neuberg (bad luck to him, and to me that applied to him “to hire and superintend a Copyist in defect of Larkin“!)Mr. Bishop. has sent me an Armful of such “Copy” as I never saw in the world before. Like to drive me delirs if I did not plug myself down!— Plunge, and tear yrself thro’ it; there is no other remedy or rule.

Jane walks, pushing a chair, from bedroom to drawing room; no trouble from her leg, but only from the neuralgic arm. Wonderfully cheerful, and I think in as good health as when she was daily out of doors, and tiring herself for exercise.

FoxtonFrederick Joseph Foxton (ca. 1807–70), lapsed Church of Wales clergyman, traveled with TC in Germany 1858; see 35:61TC to UCWAN, [2 April 1859]. He wrote to TC from Rhayader, Wales, 23 Feb.: “You are to me still, & I believe ever will be, the most interesting person in the world.“ is here; went riding with me yesterday,—a great “treat” in my absolute famine of company on such occasions. He is of stickish type; but greatly attached to me, and a first-rate rider. TaitRobert Scott Tait (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; friend of the Carlyles since 1853; living at 14 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq.; m., 1859, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832); they had a da., Mildred (1860–1950). He painted TC’s portrait (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856), and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]), taking photographs of the Carlyles and their house as preparation for the painting; he also took photographs for TC’s use in Frederick. has been (for the first time in his life, and almost to the comfort of valetudn friends) really ill,—of something called “The Shingles,” or St Anthy’s Fire!St. Anthony’s Fire was a name given to various diseases causing severe skin blistering, named for St. Anthony of Egypt (ca. 250–356); his followers set up a hospital in Grenoble, France, ca. 1100, which became a center of pilgrimage for sufferers. Now getting better.

I had a curious American Letter [c]utTC omitted “c.“ out for me from the Atlantic Monthly or some Yankee magne by the Author) on that “Ilias in Nuce” (clever man, but nearly gone insane on the Nigger Question):David A. Wasson; see JWC to Lord ALOA, [22 Oct.]. this I meant to send you, but Jane has pushed it off for Ld Ashbn. Be content with the Shadow of “Andrew Carruthers,“Perhaps related to Andrew Carruthers (d. 1837), mason; see 29:307TC to JCA, 11 May 1855; otherwise unidentified.—poor Aw, become a Poet!—Tell Miss Irma to call, or give us notice, when she arrives hereabts.Irma Otthenin. John A. Carlyle replied, 30 Oct.: “Miss Irma … talks of going to London perhaps next week, & will call whenever she gets there.“ Yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MW, [27 Oct.] Addr: care of A. Welsh Esqr / Sandown Park / Wavertree Liverpool. PM: London, 28 Oct. 1863. MS: NLS 608.618C. Hitherto unpbd. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p: I entreat you write me one line or two? I am so anxious about that dear little Boy!John (Jackie) Welsh, son of Alexander and Sophy. From what Mrs Godby had heard from Sophy I was led to believe all danger over. But WaltersRev. Walter Welsh of Auchtertool, Alexander and Maggie’s brother. letter telling me you had been sent for has made me full of dread.

The sufferings of a child are always more painful for me to think of than a grown person’s—and “rheumatic fever” must be terrible suffering. I know by what I have felt of the same illness in a less degree! My heart is sore for Alec and Sophy! Dear, affectionate Alec! so proud as he looked of that Boy! when they were here togetherThey visited Cheyne Row Aug. 1862; see 38:131TC to JWC, [11 Aug. 1862], and 146TC to JAC, 17 Aug. 1862.— The apple of his eye he seemed—
But please God he will be recoverThus in MS.—as he did before when he was, I suppose as ill as now!— But write to me Dear! You neednt spend ten minutes on it!

I will tell you all about myself when your mind is relieved from this more pressing anxiety—and when my own mind is relieved from it. Enough to say for the moment, that I am going on as well could be expected
Love to you all, and the sincerest sympathy—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG [AGIL], 31 Oct. Pbd: Gilchrist 141–42.
div3.head: TC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p:
Dear Mrs. Gilchrist: I receive with many feelings the BookAlexander Gilchrist, Life of William Blake, 2 vols. (1863), completed by Anne Gilchrist after her husband’s death in 1861, with the assistance of Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828–82; ODNB) and his brother William Rossetti (1829–1919; ODNB). you send me, after these long delays. Thankfulness is one clear feeling;—not only to you from myself, but to you for the same of Another who is not now here. Sorrowful remembrance, I need not say, is a background to the whole:—very
curious to me as I read on. For the better the Book is, the shadier grow those dark tints of memory; the shadier, but also the more beautiful, and in a sort, the less painful!—

I have been upon the book these three evenings, with all the leisure I could amass for it; and find everywhere that it is right well done,—minute knowledge well arranged, lively utterance, brevity, cheerful lucidity;—and, in fact, that it is a Book likely to prove extensively acceptable, and have the many fine merits that are in it recognised by the Public. Your own little PrefaceAnne Gilchrist wrote in the preface: “One short word of sorrowful significance which has had to be inserted in the title-page [i.e., ‘late’], while it acquaints the reader with the peculiar circumstances under which this Biography comes before him, seems also to require a few words about its final preparation for the press; the more so as the time which has elapsed since the Life of Blake was first announced might otherwise lead to a wrong inference respecting the state in which it was left by the beloved author when he was seized, in the full tide of health and work and happy life, with the fever which, in five days, carried him hence. The Life was substantially complete; and the first eight chapters were already printed” (Life of William Blake [v]). Anne Gilchrist then thanked the Rossetti brothers for their help in completing the book. is all that is proper:Gilchrist sent TC’s letter to a friend: “You must bear in mind in reading it, that he is a man very sparing of praise, stern in his requirements, inflexibly sincere, both in forming and in expressing his judgment. To me its effect was almost overpowering—knowing the man as I do. Knowing the depth of meaning and feeling conveyed in those brief words” (Gilchrist 141).—could but the Queen of these realms have been as Queen-like in her widowhood!Queen Victoria, whose husband Prince Albert also died in 1861, went into deep mourning and withdrew from public life.—

I send you many thanks and regards, dear Mrs. Gilchrist; and shall wish you and yours always well.Anne Gilchrist visited Cheyne Row 9 Nov.; she wrote to a relative: “Poor Mrs. Carlyle I did not see; and received the saddest news of her, but I spent a delightful two hours with Carlyle himself on Monday evening. He again spoke most warmly of the Blake; called it a ‘beautiful delineation of character;’ spoke of the ‘acuteness and thoroughness with which the slightest clues had been followed out in gathering the materials, and with all this toil and minute accuracy on the writer’s part, nothing but pleasure for the reader—no tediousness;’ and many more things had I but time to write them” (Gilchrist 142).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS [JSI], 1 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, CR 163–64; Blunt, Forum 47. Quot: Townsend Scudder, Jane Welsh Carlyle (New York 1939) 365. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN SIMMONDS

docBody.p: Many thanks, dear Mr Simmonds, for sending me the good news so quickly!The birth of Isabella and John Simmonds’s da., 1 Nov.— Having lots of Time at present for making myself miserable, and a born genius for that sort of thing, and considering what happened before,Isabella Simmonds possiblymay have suffered a miscarriage previously. I had been more anxious how your dear little Wife should get thro’ this business than she had the smallest idea! But she has got thro’ it well thank God—as she gets thro’ most things.
I am only sorry that I shan’t be up to going to see Her and It for some time. Give her my love and compliments on her cleverness—and It a kiss for me and congratulations on having got itself born!
I suppose it is very red?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], 2 Nov. MS: NLS 20767. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 294–95 inc. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p:
Your letter was bit of very real gladness for me; tho’ at the same time there was something curiously faraway about it; like a letter one gets in a dream—(if you have any experience of dream-letters)!— Here, you see, was a woman whom I dearly care for (Lady—if you prefer it!) and who, I try to believe (with a certain success latterly,) cares for me; writing to me from only the other end of the same kingdom, in utter ignorance that there had been any solution of continuity in my Life between the present time and the time when we had the Cab-meeting in Piccadilly!—in utter ignorance of my “accident“!—whereas all the letters I had received for the last six weeks (except one the other day, from your Sister, Miss Stanley)Presumably Maude Stanley. had been full of my “accident,” questions about it, condolences about it, fears and hopes about it!—so that I
have “lived and moved (no! there has been no moving!) and had my being“Cf. Acts 17:28. in my accident whether I would or no!

Well! and what was it, the accident? you would like to know. I feel the less reluctance to “renew grief“Coterie speech; see 38:3JWC to LAI, [1 Nov. 1862]. in telling you; as I am now so far recovered that I am past needing to be condoled with, and the knowledge will entail on you none of that bother!

Just two or three days after I had that lucky glimpse of you in Piccadilly. I had occasion to be at the General Post Office “There is no such dangerous thoroughfare as St Martin le Grand in all London,” my Dr says; so I may be excused for having been flurried in crossing, to get to a Cab; and in such a hurry to find myself safe on the Pavement, that I struck the side of my foot violently against the curb-stone, and was plashed down on my left side on the pavement. I tried to gather myself up, but the agony I was in wouldnt let me. So I had to resign myself to become the Centre of Attraction to a small crowd and to be lifted by two Roughs and a Policeman, and put into a cab. Then there was five miles of jolting over the stones. not knowing whether my leg and arm were broken, or what I had done to myself; only that I was in such agony as I had never known before! Then there was the getting me into the House, and up to my bed, which was accomplished by the ingenuity of the Gentleman next door,Henry Larkin. impeded rather than assisted by Mr C, who was too nervous for anything! Then there was the Doctor—who found no bones broken—considered it a case of “lacerated sinews.” Then there were days and nights when I couldnt move so much as an inch on my bed, and couldnt sleep a wink for the terrible pain! and was decidedly very ill off indeed!

After a fortnight I was lifted out of bed and set on end on a sofa in my bedroom, reminding myself of Miss Biffin!Sarah Biffin; see JWC to GWGWE, [13 Oct.]. After another fortnight I was half-carried half-walked into the Drawing-room. And now, at the end of six weeks since the “Accident,” I can walk accross the floor, by myself, with a stick.TC wrote later: “I was sitting solitary over my dreary Prussian books, as usual, in the drawing-room, perhaps about 10 p.m., room perhaps (without my knowledge) made trimmer than usual, when suddenly, without warning given, the double door from her bedroom went wide open, and my little darling, all radiant in graceful evening dress, followed by a maid with new lights, came gliding in to me, gently stooping, leaning on a fine Malacca cane, saying silently but so eloquently, ‘Here am I come back to you, dear!’ It was among the bright moments of my life—the picture of it still vivid with me, and will always be. Till now I had not seen her in the drawing-room, had only heard of those tentative pilgrimings thither with her maid for support. But now I considered the victory as good as won, and everything fallen into its old course again or a better. Blind that we were! This was but a gleam of sunlight, and ended swiftly in a far blacker storm of miseries than ever before” (Froude, LM 3:177–78).

But I cannot sit up at a table to write with pen and ink. I write with the paper on my knees, and cushions at my back—ergo—in pencil. For while the leg has been gradually mending—faster than could have been hoped; the sprained arm has been tormented by rheumatism (neuralgia Dr Quain called it. but no Doctor nor “plain human cretur“Coterie speech; see 26:278–79JWC to KS, [22 Dec. 1851]. Closing parenthesis omitted. ever explained yet to my satisfaction the difference between Rheumatism and Neuralgia. That is now my worst grievance But I have got a new prescription for it, which I really think is doing it good.
Have you gone to sleep yet over this long story? Don’t please till I have told you further that nothing could exceed the kindness of my friends! My servants too have been most kind and attentive.

You once said to me of Miss Davenport Bromley you couldnt understand my liking for her. I will tell you one thing to show you what sort of a Friend she can be. Shortly before my accident I had had a letter from her pressing me to come to her at Folkestone where she had a house for two months. This letter being still unanswered I begged Mr C to write and tell her what had befallen me. This was some five days after I had been put to bed.

The day after his letter, she appeared at my bedside! looking so agitated and so kind! I shall never forget her look: she “couldnt sleep after getting the letter, she said, for thinking about me; and just came up by the first Train in the morning! When I said; “came all that way on purpose to see me?” she answered with tears in her eyes; “Oh! if it had been twice the distance, dear Mrs Carlyle, I should have come all the same; I was so unhappy about you!” She hadn’t even her own house in TownThe Davenport Bromleys’ London house was 32 Grosvenor St.; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 1 May. to go to, It was all being painted. So she had bespoken a bed at Mrs Vivian’sPossibly Mrs. Vivian, 14 Devonshire Ter., Bayswater, or Mrs. Sarah Vivian, 7 Belgrave Sq. on her way here. Next morning she was here again soon after ten, and staid till just time to return by the one o’clock train to Folkestone, where she had left visitors in her House! Will you ever ask me again why I like Her? And Lady William Russell—such adorably kind little letters she has written me—and sent Arthur or OdoLady William Russell’s two younger sons, Arthur John Edward and Odo Leopold William Russell. every two or three days to ask about me— And Lady Ashburton! such endless flowers and grapes and things she has showe[r]ed about me! And she too offered “to
come up” if it would be any comfort to have her beside me“! and E[v]erybody!JWC omitted “r” in “showe[r]ed” and “v” in “E[v]erybody.“— I declare it makes me like to cry to think over it all.
There! I never wrote you such an egoistic letter before. and I wont do it again.

What on earth is the meaning of this absurd scandal about Lord Palmerston? Surely it must be either a political conspiracy or an attempt to extort money!Lord Palmerston was named, 19 Oct. 1863, as corespondent in a divorce case brought by Timothy Joseph O’Kane (1820–90), an Irish radical journalist. He sought damages of £20,000 in compensation for adultery with his alleged wife, Margaret Matilda Augusta Morris O’Kane. The case was dismissed, Feb. 1864, because O’Kane could not prove the marriage. O’Kane subsequently changed his name to Thadeus and emigrated to Australia, where he became a newspaper editor in Queensland. I have heard of nothing like it, since the old Lord Buchan insisted on appearing before the Kirksession and being “rebuked” for a child that some young woman had laid to him!Anecdote untraced, but possibly refers to David Steuart Erskine (1742–1829; ODNB), 11th earl of Buchan, antiquary and political reformer. He m., 1771, Margaret, b. Fraser (d. 1819), with whom he had no children; but he had a natural son, David Erskine (1772–1837; ODNB), raised in his household, to whom he left his unentailed estates.

Will you tell your Sister my lamed condition— I cannot be writing about that to her too!— When I get back into the regions of pen and ink I will reply to her letter, which I thank her for. But pencil writing is only for those one is on terms of ease and confidence with—like presenting oneself in a loose wrapper, without one’s stays! I don’t mind coming to you in—anything!

I have not heard of Lady Stanley’s deathMaria Josepha, b. Holroyd (1771–1863), Dowager Lady Stanley of Alderley, Lady Airlie’s grandmother. She d. 1 Nov.—so I suppose you are still in expectation of it—a very sad state such waiting is—
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MW, [2 Nov.]. Addr: Sandown Park / Wavertree / Liverpool. PM: London, 2 Nov. 1863. MS: NLS 608.619A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:187–89. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p: The very sight of your letter was a relief to me; for I knew that unless dear JackieJohn (Jackie) Welsh; see JWC to MW, [27 Oct.]. had been a little better you couldn’t have written as much!
Next time do write a mere bulletin, or I cant press you to “be quick“!

From the account you give, I draw far better hope about him than I dare
say you meant to give in writing it. But there seems to be so much vitality in the poor little fellow—his caring to be read to—his little speech—all that sounds as if there were a good basis of Life at the bottom of all this illness. God grant he may soon be pronounced convalescent! I am very convalescent! I can move about the room, with a stick—and the pain in my arm has been considerably less for the past few days—when I make no attempt to move it more than it likes. I attribute the improvement to a new medecine recommended to me by C’s friend Mr Foxton,Frederick J. Foxton. who had been cured by it. Before taking it I asked the advice of Dr Blakiston at St Leonards (Bessey’s Husband—a man of real ability) and he sent me a proper prescription and directions about using it. It is called Iodite of Potash and is taken with quantities of fluid—and along with it have to be taken pills of Valeriate of Quinine If it cures me, and you ever need curing you shall have the prescription

In the beginning of this arm-business—some four months ago now, I fancied I had given my arm an unconscious sprain; as the pain in attempting to move it preceded any aching or shooting, independent of attempting to move it— The Doctor persuaded me “it was all neuralgia“— Since my accident that sprained feeling has been dreadful, till within the last few days—and tho Mr Barnes always declared “it was all rheumatism,” it has been impossible to persuade me, that the same blow received on my shoulder and hipjoint at the same time, and damaging the sinews in my thigh would not damage the sinews in my arm also—“That stands to reason” (as old HelenHelen Mitchell, the Carlyles’ maid 1837–46 and 1848–49. used to say) Of course if rheumatism is about in one it will gather to any strained part—and so there has been plenty of rheumatic pain besides the pain from the hurt— But I am certain it is more than Rheumatism that hinders me from lifting my arm—and having a faculty of remembering things long after date—I remembered the other day that I took to using the dumbbells for two or three days, to make myself stronger par vive force [by main force], when I was feeling so weak and ill early in summer (It must have been just before I noticed the stiffness of my arm)—and that I left them off because my arms felt too weak to use them and ached after— It would be a comfort to my weak mind to be assured that I there and then sprained some sinew in my arm—and all the rest would then have followed in the course of nature—and I might give up vague terrors about angina pectoris paralysis disease of the spine &c &c &c!!!JWC omitted commas between “angina pectoris,” “paralysis,” and “disease of the spine, &c.“ Best stop Yours affectionately
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IS [IEB], 3 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:189–91; Ireland, JWC 279–80; Blunt, CR 164–65; Blunt, Forum 47–48 inc; Bliss, JWC 309–10; Fielding and Sorensen 295–96 inc. The letter is written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA BARNES SIMMONDS

docBody.p: I am so thankful that you are all right! And to think of you writing on the third day after your confinement the most legible—indeed the only legible note I ever had from you in my life!!

Now, about this compliment offered me, which you are pleased to call a ‘favour’ (to you)— I don’t know what to say! I wish I could go and talk it over, but even if [I]Omitted by JWC. could go in a cab one of these next dry days I couldnt drive up your stairs in a cab!—

I should be greatly pleased that your baby bore a name of mineThe Simmondses wanted to call their da. Jane; she was named Ethel Jane Carlyle Simmonds.—But the ‘godmother’hood?? There seems to me one objection to that, which is a fatal one—I dont belong to the English Church and the Scotch Church which I do belong to recognises no Godfathers and Godmothers! The Father takes all the obligations on himself—(serves him right!) I was present at a Church of England Christening for the first time when the Blunts took me to see their Baby christenedGerald and Frances Blunt and Elaine Mary Blunt, b. 7 April 1862.—and it looked to me a very solemn piece of work!—and that Mr MauriceRev. Frederick D. Maurice, Church of England clergyman and Christian socialist. and Julia BluntJulia Sophia Blunt, Gerald’s sister; according to Frances Blunt’s diary, the godmother was Lady Mary Feilding (1823–1896; ODNB), founder of the Working Ladies’ Guild (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt of Chelsea [1911] 82). (the God Father and God Mother) had to take upon themselves, before God and man, very solemn engagements—which it was to be hoped they meant to fulfil! I should not have liked to bow and murmur and undertake all they did, without meaning to fulfil it according to my best ability!— Now my Darling how could I dream of binding myself to look after the spiritual welfare of any earthly Baby. I who have no confidence in my own spiritual welfare? I am not wanted TO! it may perhaps be answered—you mean to look after that yourself—without interference!— What are these spoken engagements then? A mere form? that is, a piece of humbug!— How could I in cold blood go thro with a ceremony, in a Church, to which neither the others nor myself attach a grain of veracity? If you can say anything to the purpose, I am very willing to be proved mistaken—and in that case very willing to stand Godmother to a Baby that on the third day is not at all red!!!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [5 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated during JWC’s slow recovery, when she could walk with a stick. Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: As all I am up to yet, in the way of locomotion, is limping thro’ my bedroom door into the Drawingroom, with help of a stick; I cannot run away from any troubles or anxieties I may happen to have, or walk them down as I used to do— So in these last days my anxieties about yourself and Baby have tormented me not a little: the more, that I didn’t even know where to address to you or Mrs Mackenzie a request for news. Thanks to Dr Christisons prompt answer to all my questions, and some more, I now know that you are all safe at the Grange again, and that altho neither you nor Baby have derived the benifit from your change of air which one had hoped for you; neither of you are absolutely laid up; and that Lord Ashburton is wonderfully improved. God be thanked for that anyhow! I am so glad Mrs Mackenzie is with you again; she looks as if she would be such a kind and energetic Helper under trouble. And that she has capital sense about Babies—at least about a Baby whom she has at heart, is proved by the condition in which she brought your Darling back to you from Nice.See JWC to Lady ALLA, 23 March.

Charlotte WynnCharlotte Williams Wynn (1807–69; ODNB; see 19:102TC to JAC, 17 July 1845), diarist. was here the other day, on her way thro’ London to Genoa, and was speaking of the “sensation” that “Lady Ashburtons child had produced at Nice“—“Such an extraordinary child,” she had been told, “It had two Drs to see it every day, and insisted on giving them their fees itself! and all its proceedings and equipments were so royal; that people could talk of nothing but this little English Princess that had come among them.” In reply to all which I showed her the “little English Princess’s” Photograph,Possibly the photograph of Mary Baring standing on an ottoman footstool; see 236above. For another, presumably taken on the same day, under which TC wrote “Hon. Mary Baring (Ld An’s one child),” see 237above. with which she was greatly delighted.
“Little Mary Baring,” n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
“Hon. Mary Baring,” n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

My recollection of that time of looking at Servants, from which I was so suddenly and painfully cut off, haunts me now in my seclusion with unabated curiosity like the first numbers of a “serial” Tale to which I cannot get the conclusion! Bid Mrs Mackenzie tell me the conclusion, please! Did the hay-stacky Housemaid’s character suit?Mary Galbraith; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [22 Sept.]. and is she installed at the Grange? and does she please you? Have you got a satisfactory Footman? and what of a
Lady’s-maid?— Among your other vexations at Brighton, you “had no nurse” Mrs Mackenzie said, and “Jeanie was ill.” Is she better? and what did “no nurse” mean? What had happened to Mrs Corbet?Jeannie Bean (b. ca. 1845), nursery maid, and Mrs. Corbett, nurse; see 38:256JWC to MR, [3 Nov. 1862], and Surtees, Ludovisi 91. So much of ones comfort depends on one’s servants (the more’s the pity!) that if I followed the dictates of Nature, my next question to anyone dear to me, after asking, “how are you?” would be what sort of servants have you got“?

I inclose a letter which came to me soon after my “accident,” when I was too bad to think of forwarding it: that you may see what a surprising Gardener you possess at Melchet!The gardener (unidentified further) presumably sent a note together with the weekly delivery of fruit from Melchet Court.—

Oh such a consolation these grapes have been to me! In the long nights when I couldn’t sleep, or was always waking up with the pain, and finding my tongue sticking to the roof of my mouth, then I put out my hand to the little table at my bedside and took a grape or two, and was relieved.
If kindness and help to others could keep any one healthy and happy in this world, you would never have a pain or a sorrow! But the fact is very different from that!

closer.salute: God keep you and all dear to you! is the constant prayer of your grateful and affectionate

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [5 Nov.]. MS: NLS 608.619B. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the same day as JWC to LLA, [5 Nov.], and finished on Sat., 7, or Sun., 8 Nov. Letter written in ink.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh yes, there it is! I knew it instantly; tho I did not recognise the handwriting of the direction! Thanks Darling! You have given me a pleasant surprise, and a welcome present! tho’ I cant say I am contented with the photograph as a photograph; or I should say rather as a picture.For JWC’s request for a photograph of Holmhill, and a later photograph of Holmhill, see 37:109–10JWC to MR, [Feb. 1861]. The little water-coloured sketch, that is framed and hung up opposite my bed, is much the better picture, but this having the alterations and more details, and more life-likeness in some of them; as for example the windows, which one almost expects to see your face or the Drs, looking out of; makes an agreeable supplement to the Sketch. The fault of it is, that it has been taken from a bad point of view,—from the under side of the sunk fence and right opposite; which shows the garden or shrubbery as a mere stripe, and almost bare of flowers, and throws a full glare on the white walls that makes them look like paste-board. I wish I had been at the doing of it! When I come—if I am spared to come again—we must have another view taken! with the Dr and you in the garden.

They sent me such a wonderful Photograph of Auchtertool ManseFor the photograph of Auchtertool Manse, see 39:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 39.—exactly like a wood engraving—and Walter is leaning back in a garden-chair and Maggie and Mary standing near the outer door—the one bare-headed, the other with a hat and feather.See oppabove. (That’s Mary of course!).Mary Welsh, on the left in the photograph, was known for her love of finery; see 38:99JWC to MR, [5 June 1862]. the figures are scarcely more than half an inch and yet to be recognised at a glance!
Mary, Maggie, and Walter Welsh, Auchtertool Manse (detail)
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

— Poor little Jackie in Liverpool has been again at Deaths door from Rheumatic fever. He returned from Fife so well seemingly and in a week or two was taken with this malady for the second time. From the accounts I receive from Maggie who was sent for to Liverpool to help nurse him, I have no fear but he will get round this time. but he appears to be a very delicate boy, and his Parents who idolize him as their only Boy have much anxiety before them!

Mary Welsh was prospering at the Manse, as Mistress— She always becomes a new creature in point of activity and good humour when Maggie is from home!See 38:197JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1862]. Pity one of them hadn’t been married, and set up in a house of her own!

I began this letter on Thursday—as you may see at the top of the sheet— But I have only a short time when writing is manageable—between my getting settled down on the Drawing-room Sofa and my two o’clock dinner. It is between eleven and twelve, before I have had my breakfast (in bed still) and got myself combed and dressed— What I used to do in a quarter of an hour when I had the free use of my two arms and two legs, takes me, now that I have to be assisted, nearer an hour and half!! So the morning slips away. Till two o’clock, after I have come into the Drawingroom I may write for most part without interruption. But by the time I have finished dinner or before I have finished people come to call—and there is no more peace till long after the general Post hour (half past four)—on Thursday I was interrupted by a note from Miss Anstruther begging me in her Mothers nameMary Frances Anstruther, and her da. Annie Nairn Anstruther. to take the use of their Brougham instead of driving out in a “Fly” as I had spoken of doing. The answer was waited for and was bothering to compose. How to express myself sufficiently grateful for the offer, and at the same time sufficiently decided to have nothing to do with their or anybody’s Brougham, so long as a Fly could be hired with my own money?— By the time I had satisfied myself with an answer; a Lady who has been very good to me all thro my “accident”
came,Possibly Mary Godby; see JWC to GWGWE, [13 Oct.]. and that was the end of my writing for that day!— Next day (Friday) I had a headache—not a usual form of illness with me now—and on Saturday it flashed on me to my dismay that thanks to the outrageous piety of Thornhill, no letters were allowed to enter there on Sunday—and none leaving London on Sunday—my thanks must necessarily be delayed till Tuesday morning—
Oh my Heavens I have been interrupted again. A LadyUnidentified. is here!
I will write soon again
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJGW, 10 Nov. Pbd: Clement J. Wilkinson, J. J. G. Wilkinson: A Memoir (1911) 37–38. John James Garth Wilkinson (1812–99; ODNB), Swedenborgian writer and homeopathic d 1838octor; known to TC since 1838; see TC to JJGW, 2 Aug. 1838, and TC to JAC, 26 March 1858.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES GARTH WILKINSON

docBody.p:
Dear Wilkinson,—The Photograph is excellt—very like;Wilkinson wrote, 4 Nov.: “Sometime ago you very kindly sent me an Autograph of yourself on a Photographic Portrait, to endow our Book of Images, if not Likenesses, of those we most value: May I now present to you a good shadow, if not the light, of my Countenance?” TC presumably sent Wilkinson a Jeffrey photograph, taken Sept. 1862 (see 38:217TC to JAC, 19 Sept. 1862, and 38:220JWC to MR, [21 Sept. 1862]), made into a carte de visite; see 38:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 38. Wilkinson’s photograph was by John Watkins, photographer, of 34 Parliament St.; see oppabove. and I am greatly obliged to you for it. We have put it into the brother compartment in the generalGalaxy of friendly Faces;Wilkinson’s photograph was pasted into the Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 4, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ. and from time to time it will turn up as a memento, or be sought for as such, bringing nothing but pleasant thoughts with it.
John James Garth Wilkinson, 1863
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

As to the Chelsea Photographs you speak of, I am far too busy to spare even an hour for such operations at prest: but surely in not many months now my doleful Prussian (ultra-Babylonish) CaptivityCf. Jer. 20:4 and 28:4. will end; after whh, if permitted, how happy shall I be to remember yr flattering suggestion.Wilkinson wrote: “If I had none but a personal motive for intruding my face, nothing would have induced me so to intrude it: but there is a better motive in the back-ground. // Two persons, representing, though not elected by, thousands & thousands,—yea! thousands of thousands,—urgently desire to have your, & Mrs Carlyle’s Portraits, by … [John Watkins]. The two individuals, unelected, representative (by Divine Right of), and … Autocratic over, the above-named vast Constituencies, are—John Watkins, & myself.“
Wish, for my sake, it may be soon.—Yours always truly.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 12 Nov. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 13 Nov. 1863. MS: NLS 553.258. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:531 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I have at length got thro’ that frightful mass of “Copy“;—and feel as if re-emerged into the upper air. Yr hand was very visible throughout the latter part of the thing,—and the poor LadMr. Bishop. too had done his best:—on the whole, he teaches me what use I had of old in your “Copying” services, (whh were a partial editing withal), and how unreplaceable these are are.Thus in MS. Whh, I think, will lead me to avoid Copying altogether for the future!—

I begin to have a frightful suspicion, almost convictn, that the 7-years Wr being done, there will be a Volume VI needed, instead of a Book 20.The first edn. was in six vols., comprising 21 bks. Horrible is the thot to me. But I fear there is no help.— — Come on Sunday night, at any rate; now that we are got into the upper air agn!—

I wish you to call at the Museum, and make some inquiry abt the Frau Karsch (Poetess Kärschims or Karshn to whom Frh gave the 7/6,Anna Luise Karschin (1722–91), German poet, met Frederick in 1763, when TC says he gave her £10; see Carlyle, Works 19:224.—whether there is any Biography of her, or any Fraction of her Poetries, accessible in the Museum Library or otherwise. Ask Mr Watt, he can shew you (for he did to me) a Print by Chodowiecki, representg the Interview of Frh and Karschin:Daniel Nikolaus Chodowiecki (1726–1801), German artist, whose work TC much admired; see 27:326TC to LOA, 7 Oct. 1852; the print of Karschin’s meeting with Frederick is untraced. Line over n to indicate doubled letter. it was in some Museum-Almanach or Magazine of the time;—surely there will be in it something or other to guide you in farther researches.
Sunday Evg come, any way.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Nov. MS: NLS 526.11. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
You are very good to write to me when I cannot ansr. The oftener you have charity to do that, the gladder & thankfuller I shall be! I hoped to have written today with more deliberatn,—for I am at last out of the horrible pluister of that poor blubber of a young man’s “Copy” so-called, whh he made
under the eye of (perfidious) Neuberg! Ng keeps out of my way ever since: but I have asked him for Sunday Evg agn; a poor faithful dog, and capable of infinite service with the wild Hill-sheep; tho’ occasionally napping; his “brain” threatg “to soften” (shocking to consider!):—and indeed he is quite preoccupied with his “new House“Neuberg had recently moved to Roslyn Park in Hampstead. at prest, & the shrubberies & the &c’s there!— By degrees, one will be independt of such Officials, Oh Heaven—and blind unwilling Horses to be driven over Bridges witht parapet!—

We are in tolerable health here; Jane, who has now been prisr 7 weeks, actually seems to thrive better than when she was forcing herself out every day: “Returned so utterly done out; joints like to fall in pieces, &c &c; and meat or drink a mere disgust“—she actually sleeps better, eats better, & is cheerfuller than formerly. For perhaps 3 weeks past she has been hitching abt;—walks with your Nithsdale nibbie (whh I had become fond of, and taken to, but gave up to her pro tempe [protempore: for the time being]), she can walk too, but slowly, witht stick: in short, she is doing well enough. As indeed am I;—and have need to be, as you shall now hear!

For months back I have been revolving the Questn; but within the last few days (while winding up that “Copy“), it has become frightfully probable that in “vol V” (witht making it a monster) there actually will not be any room for my “Book 21°,” sumingLine over m indicating doubled letter. up 23 years of Frk’s Life!— So I believe it will at last turn out. Robson is counting all that I have of any available kind: I will let it swell out as it likes;—I believe it will move easily heavier to the size of a Vol. than be squeezed down to that of “a Book.” Ay de mi;Coterie speech. but Courage!

You will like these Annandale Rhymes: do you know anythg of the “Craig Gibson“?“Popular Rhymes and Proverbs Connected with Localities,” a lecture on Annandale rhymes, delivered by the folklorist and surgeon Alexander Craig Gibson (1813–74; ODNB) to the Historic Society of Lancashire and Cheshire, 12 March 1863, was pbd. in their Transactions … Session 1862–63 (Liverpool 1863) 159–78; Gibson probably sent TC a printed copy of the lecture. Gibson’s mother, Mary Stuart Craig, was from Dumfriesshire where he spent part of his childhood. Brought up in Cumberland, he studied medicine at Edinburgh, then practiced in W Cumberland. He practiced in Bebington, Cheshire, from 1857.— If Mad. Otthenin like to keep the Book (for you will likely read her those Johnstone things)The lecture included information about the Johnstone clan, of which Jean Otthenin was a member; Gibson noted: “The Johnstones were distinguished along the Border as ‘The gentle Johnstones’; and their vaunted antiquity, their numbers and prosperity have given rise to the following quatrain:—/ ‘Within the bounds of Annandale / The gentle Johnstones ride; / A thousand years they have been there, / And a thousand years they’ll bide’” (166). leave it with her:John A. Carlyle wrote, 30 Oct.: “I was at Made Otthenin’s on Wednesday evening, & found all that I had told you confirmed, in regard to her additional comfort in the new house. She has everything very tidy, her eldest daughter [Margaret] continues to get out of bed for a few hours daily under the new doctor, so there is some little hope of her making progress towards recovery & getting back to her own country; but I have never seen her & therefore cannot judge accurately of her condition.“—but in case a reading (or a
being-read-to) seems to you enough: let JeanTheir sister, Jean Aitken. have them, please. The BradshawThe Bradshaw railway timetable. is worth hardly anythg even to you. Adieu dear Brr. Affecte regards to Erskine.John A. Carlyle wrote, 30 Oct.: “I had a letter from Erskine two days ago. Mrs Stirling & he expect to be in Edinr in about a fortnight. He desires me to send kindest regards to Jane & you.“ Yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 Nov. MS: NLS 517.62. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I forgot these two dudsPresumably the Bradshaw and lecture that TC said he was sending 13 Nov.; see TC to JAC, 13 Nov. on Friday; they are worth nothing; but turning up while I sort my rubbish, they may go,—with my affecte salutatns.

Yesterday I brot down my little Horse, broke slightly both his knees,—or rather he himself did it, the little villain; a rather provoking little Horse of late; and not so suitable for street hacking, as he might have been for ornamental palfreying in some nobleman’s Park. I had just got him clipped;—I design to ride him still; but withal to walk whenr I like it better. The creature is not the least dangerous (very good tempered); can go sure & swift at the jog-trot, or on soft ground at the gallop (mostly of blood genealogy the little wretch); most rapid excellt walker (when he likes!)—bad only and shambly at the high-trot: he was engaged that way yesterday, in a perfectly good part of Hyde Park, when he fell;—but nimbly sprang up, doing me no hurt whatever, nor even deranging my seat. Basta [enough].

Do you know any Annandale “Craig Gibson“—truly I don’t much mind! Or who the “revd Percival is at Carlisle?Unidentified. (ConectedLine over n indicating doubled letter. with the Assassinated Chancellor?Spencer Perceval (1762–1812; ODNB), chancellor of the exchequer 1807–9, prime minister 1809–12, assassinated in the House of Commons lobby 11 May 1812. Some of them are of “excitable” or cracky turn). Jean sent me
the ClippingUntraced. not he.For Alexander Craig Gibson, see TC to JAC, 13 Nov. There cannot be anything more enthusiastic.— — I shudder & scunner at “Vol VI“: but we shall see! God bless you T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mrs. W [MRSW], 17 Nov. MS: Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection, New York Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Mrs. Wilson, presumably the German wife of Thomas Wilson.
