div3.head: TC TO MRS. WILSON

docBody.p: I am sorry to bother you about Kaiser Joseph:Kaiser Joseph II (1741–90), Holy Roman emperor 1765–90. Citing Joseph Hormayr’s Oesterreichischer Plutarch (Vienna, 1807–14) 4:125–223, TC refers to “five or six recent Lives of Joseph, none of which, that I have seen, was worth reading, in comparison” (Carlyle, Works 19:282). but I think our easiest way of getting out of the affair will be, that you give me at once (if from yr memory you can) the title of any Book or Books you read abt him (according to what recollectn you at present have); that I may send to Germany for them, and see for myself.— — If you cannot recollect any Book-Title even approximately, pray don’t mind farther: I will send to any Teutsch Antiquar [German antiquarian bookseller] on chance; or do without,—whh also is possible.

I am in a mighty Wirrwarr [state of chaotic disorder] here; endeavoring to get my brick-clay gathered fairly into a heap here,—if without any straw or stubble, or indeed almost any patience left, to bake it into passable bricks;Cf. Exod. 5. and take leave of it to all eternity.
With kind regards to the Goodman,Thomas Wilson.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [18 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by reference to JWC’s accident “two months past yesterday.” TC wrote on reverse of MS, “fragt (1863—’4) after ‘recovery’ / from the first of the accidtl fall.” Letter written in blue pencil.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
I have no time to write you a nice long letter today—neither time nor composure of mind (you shall hear why)—yet it is better not to wait till tomorrow to set your mind at rest as to the safety of your “tub.” I was very much puzzled to
guess what it could mean, when Mary rushed up with a look of importance to say “if you please mam there’s a tub!!” It was a very welcome solution to find the ‘tub’ was not an empty one but contained both butter and fowls— Thank you heartily dear little Woman! It is no novelty to receive a kindness from you; but no amount of use and wont makes the kindness less thought of!

Mr C said when I told him, “are there any eggs?“— “Would you have had anybody in their senses pack eggs with a can of butter, and fowls“? I asked,—“Ah! well! butter and fowls are excellent things in their way! but it is a devil of a pity that in all London a man can’t command a fresh egg at any price!“— Ill used individual! He has not been without a new-laid egg to his breakfast for the last eight months!—only a week ago the last laying hen in the neighbourhood struck work—and he prefered going upon bacon to risking the shop eggs!— I said I would ask you to send some—tho’ upon my life I am ashamed to look so greedy!— But I am not able in my present lamed condition to make a crusade after fresh eggs in my own person—and servants never can find anything!—

And now I come to the reason why I am hurried and flurried today— You would hear all about my “accident” of course—but possible you may not know that I never since have got beyond my bedroom and the Drawingroom which it opens into. Two months past yesterday has this imprisonment lasted! I have not felt it grievous, I was so thankful when the terrible agony I was in at the begin[ning]JWC wrote “begin.“ subsided into bearable and fitful pain—and the weather being very cold latterly, when I could have gone out in a carriage, had there been anything to gain by it, besides an increase of rheumatism; I have made no exertion to go out, and none has been forced on me— But just now it is a summer temperature,The Times reported, 25 Nov., that during the previous week the “mean daily temperature was considerably above the average.“ and Mr C, with his life-long fixed idea about “out-of-doors exercise,” will leave me no rest till I have “taken a ride in a Fly” (a Fly being the name of a close hired carriage here)—and the Fly is coming in half an hour! and I am to get down the stairs! and the door-steps! and into it! I dont well know how! and I am so nervous! Oh so nervous as nobody that hasnt been smashed down on the pavement, and had their “sinews lacerated” can form a notion of!—
When I come back I shall have to lie down, I know—and as the post leaves at half after 4, there will be no chance of adding to my letter—so take this “small contribution” in good part—
My kind regards to Jamie and the “worl-like bairns, poor things“!!JWC may mean “warl-like,” i.e., healthily normal.
with a hearty kiss to yourself—and hearty thanks—ever affectionately
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [20 Nov.]. Longhand copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 297. Dated the Sat. after JWC to MCA, [18 Nov.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Speediest of dear little women! thanks thanks! The eggs are come and I have just unpacked them “with my own hands“;Coterie speech; a phrase of Edward Irving’s; see 1:301TC to AC, 2 Jan. [1821]. and there is not one broken! only three of the under layer, where the hay was thinner, had got a trifling bruise which wont prevent their being boiled. It will be such a deliverance sparing every day a tirade about having to eat bacon! (excellent bacon too, and excellently cooked!)—at a time when I can make no crusades myself in quest of new laid eggs! or in quest of anything! and no servant in my experience can find anything that has to be searched for. All the hens known to me have been “sold off” one lot after another, and tho Mr C evidently thinks I might lay at least one egg a-day for him myself, if I tried zealously enough; my “wishes” have not in this case as in many others, proved to be “presentiments of my powers“Coterie speech; “our wishes are presentiments of our powers” (see 29:36JWC to WA, [1 March 1854]) or “of our capabilities” (12:244TC to GEJ, 5 Sept. 1840), untraced phrase. as some sanguine people have held them to be! These people however never, I am confident, sat down on a nest, and tried to lay an egg, and did it!

I am poorly today, having had a horrid bad night, in consequence of having listened to the voice of wisdomTC. yesterday, and gone out with a stick, to try walking in the street! I did not stay above ten minutes, and the sun was shining; but I could not get along fast enough with my stick, to prevent me suffering from the change of temperature from my warm Drawingroom to the open air, and the fatigue of the thing was very great, and so all my pains were aggravated for the rest of the day—and thro’ the night I was in a fever. But when I do nothing to hurt myself, I am better than I had the least expectation of being, in the first days after my accident, in so short a period as two months! and the recollection of all the agony I suffered is still as vivid; that to have one leg and one arm still partially lamed seems a very small hardship indeed—and the quiet, shut up life that involves seems to be a thing to be thankful rather than otherwise. So you needn’t pity me unless you like!
docBody.name: J.W.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], [25 Nov.]. MS: NLS 20767. Hitherto unpbd. From this letter onward, JWC wrote in ink.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: Your letter took away my breath, and gave me a pain in my back! In spite of your kind consideration; prefacing the terrible narrative with assurance that nothing terrible had come of it! It is enough to make one believe in Predestination to mark the different results of falls! I too was once pitched out of a carriage, thro’ the air, right over the horse, and the whole mischief done to me, individually, was the breakage of a—bracelet-clasp!For accounts of JWC’s fall, 1847, see 22:41–42TC to RMM, 22 Aug. 1847, and 44TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1847. A year ago Mr C was “knocked down” in the street “by a Lady’s Crinoline (So he described the accident; the fact being I suppose, that his foot caught in the Crinoline) was plashed full length on the hard pavement—just as I was—and the result in his case was that he—`just got up again,’ and has abused Crinolines more outrageously ever since!TC’s fall not mentioned in any surviving letters; but TC referred to the crinoline at the end of bk. 20 (which he was shortly to work on) of Frederick: “Diseases, real or imaginary, await Nations like individuals … and [must be] got through the best you can. … Nay, fashions even; fashion of Crinoline, for instance … are you able to prevent even that? You have to be patient under it, and keep hoping!” (Carlyle, Works 18:491). not an ache to a little finger did that fall cause him!

But your accident has not been such a complete success as you lead me to suppose! I find from your Sister’sKate Stanley. letter just received, that your knee does not get well “though” you have had a blister and leech on it, and “the Dr fears a gathering” It is that sentence which is the cause of my writing today; otherwise, I should have waited for a brighter mood—my present one being of the dingiest and dullest—owing to three bad nights in sucession.

There is no use saying anything about the rashness of your travelling to Alderley and back again with a knee so badly bruised as yours, it seems, has been! It is done! and we have now only to speak of the consequences. My Darling! I am a Doctor’s daughter, and, in that way, have come by scraps of medical science, which, multifarious as is the training of young Ladies at the present day is not taught by “Masters.” And I know that a hurt on the knee is not a hurt to be trifled with,—to be experimented on!— There are many parts of the body where blistering and leeching, if they did no good, would at least do no harm, but the knee is a very kranky part, and much harm might ensue from any mistake in the treatment. What sort of Dr have you? is he a clever, experienced man? Have you perfect confidence in him? Unless you have; I
beseech you to send at once for Syme the Edinr Surgeon.James Syme (1799–1870; ODNB), surgeon; see 38:214JWC to MCA, [15 Sept. 1862]. From what I know of him, and have heard of him from clever men of his own profession I am sure he is the best Surgeon in Britain! and his advice now might save you from much pain and bother with your knee in the sequel. Don’t think me meddlesome and foolish! I love you dearly, and should be as sorry as any friend you have in the world to see any harm befal you! to have you for example laid up lame even as many months as I have been myself— It is nine weeks past yesterday since I had any free use of myself, And I cant predict how much longer it will be! But I have been out twice for a drive in “a neat Fly“! “The Beauties of Nature“Coterie speech; see 35:139JWC to JGCO, [9 July 1859]. (in—Hyde Park) sent me to—sleep! or rather the air and motion did and perhaps that was the best way of taking the thing!— I get so little sound sleep in my bed.

Lady de GreyHenrietta Anne Theodosia, b. Vyner (1833–1907), Lady de Grey; she m., 1851, George Frederick Samuel Robinson (1827–1909; ODNB), then Lord Goderich; earl of Ripon, Jan. 1859, and 3d Earl de Grey, Nov. 1859; radical politician, friend of TC since the early 1850s; see 32:25032:biographical notes. came the other day, and expressed much concern for your accident which she had not heard of till I told her— She looks so fat and well!—and is so much more self-possessed in manner than she used to be. She brought with her a Lady Rose or Rosa or Rosy somethingUnidentified further. with her (I couldnt catch the name) who was also very lively and pleasant, and it was as good as going into the country for change of air while the visit lasted! I mean as good for me.

What a charming photograph that of your Sister and the dogs!For the photograph of Kate Stanley and the dogs Reinecke and Argos, see 250TC to JAC, 26 Nov.; see also 36:214JWC to LST, [30–31 Aug. 1860], and 226JWC to KST, [5 Sept. 1860]. TC wrote later above the photograph: “Kate Stanley (Lady Amberley since)” (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 2, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). I will write to her when I have slept
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Nov. MS: NLS 517.63. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:216–17.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,— Thanks for your pleasant little Note; I do not deserve a long one. All this week and last I have been in quagmire up to the throat,—with that beautiful Book, as usual. Struggling as if for dear life:—thank Heaven, I did my foot on the hard again, this afternoon before the Horse came: I am not
yet quite out; alas, no; but I hope to be, tomorrow before Post goes: and you ought to be apprised of so agreeable a small fact. Every one of these plunges into mud, of whh there have been many, has seemed the last very bad one: but I begin now to doubt there will be more. It is on the whole an affair of stomach, of nervous vivacity, of being in what we call good spirits. Good spirits are, alas, very far from me usually, these many years back: it is some
little dexterity of hand, whh I find to have deserted me, that mainly creates those miserable stoppages of progress. I must endeavour to ride diligently, to “be very regular,” &c &c: in fine, I must endeavour to get done; that is pressingly necessary to me! They are abt publishing the 4th vol;Vol. 4 was pbd. April 1864. a Portrait of Wilhelmina Frederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58), margravine of Baireuth, Frederick’s sister; see Carlyle, Works 16:frontispiece. (whh I got from UsedomCount Karl Georg Guido Ludwig von Usedom (1805–84), Prussian diplomat, and Olympia (1811–87), his 2d wife, m. 1849; TC stayed with them during his visit to Germany 1858; see 34:159 TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858
, 36:237 JWC to TC, [9-10 Sept. 1860] , and 288 36:biographical notes .) is to be Frontispiece: Larkin takes all the charge. I stand out for finishing the 5th vol before Jany; the 6th before the end of June. I wish we saw it, as the blind man said!—

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Jane now ventures out occasionally: she is actually better in genl health than she was wont while not confined to the House. We have had generally very find weather; but last Saty there came on me suddenly such a deluge of rain and black storm (half way home from Hamersmith)Hammersmith, London suburb about 3 mi. (5 km.) W of Chelsea. as I never saw except in summer before. And has continued since: & tonight the wind has turned easterly.—I will add a word tomorrow. Good night dear Brother.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IS [IEB], [26 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, CR 165–66; Blunt, Forum 48. Dated the day before the christening, which took place in St. Luke’s Church, Chelsea, 27 Nov. Missing letters and words resulting from the torn corner of MS are in sq. br.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA SIMMONDS

p.note: Carina, one of JWC’s names for Isabella; see 37:140JWC to IEB, [3 April 1861], 154.

docBody.p: I am glad of the proposed addition to Its nameThe baby was christened Ethel Jane Carlyle Simmonds. —glad that the poor Dear will have a reasonable Christian name to fall back upon; when she has grown to having a judgement of her own, and to recognising the fatuity of a meaningless, lisping “Ethel“! out of a Thackeray Novel!Ethel Newcome in William Makepeace Thackeray, The Newcomes (1855).

I cannot engage to come tomorrow. I will try!—not to Luncheon however!According to Blunt, JWC went to the luncheon; see JWC to ISIEB, [27 Nov.]. that would complicate the nervousness of the thing for me. You have no idea how nervous I have been since my accident—sitting here, in the same Sofa-corner always, in the same dressing-gown, seeing the same two or three people!— To start out into a christening Company, before I can stand steadily
on my two legs—after such a nine weeks of seclusion!The accident was 22 Sept., so the nine-week mark had just passed, Tues., 24 Nov.— Dear have you thought what an effort that would take?—

I was very much the worse for my wild expedition that day to see my baby—I never closed my eyes all night after!— I felt so fatigued and excited by it!—and felt to have caught cold all over! The fatigue would be lessened by going in a cab—but on the other hand the excitement would be aggravated by the p[r]esen[ce of] company— You would [feel] very sorry if I were [laid] up for two or three days [in] consequence— But if it is a fine day tomorrow and I feel particularly brave, I will try to come for a few minutes.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IS [IEB], [27 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:191–92; Ireland, Life of JWC 280; Bliss 310. Quot: Blunt, Forum 48. Dated on MS in another hand, confirmed by the christening of Ethel Jane Simmonds, 27 Nov.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA SIMMONDS

docBody.p: Dear Pet! I am not the least well! and should just about as soon walk overhead into The Thames, as into a Roomful of People!JWC possibly changed her mind as Blunt noted that JWC “came to the house after the christening: and the silver mug she gave her small namesake is still in Mrs. Chambers’ [Ethel Simmonds’] possession” (Blunt, Forum 48); Blunt might have been misinformed or confused it with the christening of the Blunts’ da. in April 1862; see JWC to ISIEB, 3 Nov.— At the same time I wish to pay my respects to the Baby on this her next grand performance after getting herself born! and to place in her small hands a talisman worthy of the occasion, and suitable to a Baby born on “All Saints Day“The feast falls on 1 Nov.—(whatever sort of day that may be!)

As I shouldn’t at all recommend running a long pin into the creature; I advise you to wear the brooch in its present form till the Baby is significantly hardened from its present pulpy condition, to bear something tied round its throat, without fear of strangulation! And then you may remove the pin, and attach the talisman to a string, in form of locket. But what is it? “what does it do“? (as a servant of mine once asked me in respect of “a Lord“;)Coterie speech; Anne Cook’s question: “But what is a ‘Looart’ then? What diz’t duih?“; see 15:49JWC to TC, [25 Aug. 1842]. Cook, the Carlyles’ servant Nov. 1835 to June 1837, was dismissed for stealing; see 9:191TC to JAC, 23 April 1837, and 9:231TC to MAC, 11 June 1837. what it is my Dear, is an emblematic mosaic, made from bits of some tomb of the Early Xians—and representing an Early Xian device— The greek cross the palm leaves and all the rest of it!—worn by the like of me, I dare say it would have
no virtue to speak of—but worn by a Baby born on All Saints day—! it must be a potent charm against the Devil and all his works one would think!—for it is a perfectly authentic memorial of the Early Xians.
I hope you didn’t go and drop the “Jane” after all!— Bless you—and it
docBody.name: Jane Baillie Welsh Carlyle!

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 4 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Quot: Hansons, NE 516.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am to write you “A single word” in explanatn of my poor Wife’s silence;—and truly I have not means for many “words,” as it is striking 11 p.m., and they are about to turn me out of this room for sick-nurse purposes.

The poor Wife has been extremely ill for a fortnight past,—constant to bed, poor soul, since Monday gone a week.TC apparently overestimated the time JWC was confined to bed. She took a drive, 18 Nov., and a short walk, 19 Nov.; although she felt “poorly,” 20 Nov., she took another drive by 25 Nov. (see JWC to Lady ALLA, [25 Nov.]); TC also wrote to John A. Carlyle, 26 Nov., that JWC “ventures out occasionally.” She apparently went to the luncheon after Ethel Simmonds’s christening, 27 Nov., although “not the least well“; see JWC to ISIEB, [27 Nov.]. It is probable that, even if already unwell with influenza, she took to her bed by Mon., 30 Nov., rather than by TC’s “Monday gone a week,” i.e., 23 Nov. She seemed doing so nicely; able to walk abt with a staff; had been out driving once or twice:—but was taken with Influenza; and has since had the most miserable time. It is “only cold,” the Doctor says; “whh has kindled all the rheumatic neuralgia and other injuries and ailments into a violent state“:—I was really alarmed; and questioned the man today,—who reassured me in that manner, and in fact made light of it;—tho’, I find, he has since ordered morphine, in consideratn of the hideous pain. No sleep, no food; nothing but torture and agitatn: I do not recollect ever to have seen the poor soul so beaten before. A Cousin of hers, a good young “Maggie“Maggie Welsh. (from Fife and from Liverpool), whom she likes, has been written to: I do hope she is coming (tho’ there are obstacles);Maggie was in Liverpool, helping with the nursing of her nephew Jackie Welsh; see JWC to MW, [27 Oct.]. there will then be much better nursing; whh as the Doctor says, is all nearly that can be done.

This morning came Miss Anstruther’s Letter: News not quite good; Lord A. with some whiff of cold (whh had better have been spared);—Lady A., I
grieve to perceive, has had a great deal of suffering and botheratn: in fact, nobody but Baby seems to flourish as one ought.

My Book has suddenly (not quite unexpectedly) bulged out into a Sixth Volume upon me! Perhaps it will not be more difficult to do in that form. If I had the Fifth fairly done, I have a kind of eye upon The Grange for a week of entire holiday. Good be with you all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Dec. MS: NLS 526.12. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I must be almost as brief as yourself; but it is necessary I shd send you a word tonight.

Since you heard last poor Jane has fallen into a sad state of suffering,—indeed I believe it had secretly begun at the time I wrote; tho’ it did not develope itself for a day or two after. Monday night gone a week (gone a fortnight, where you read this), Froude & his WifeHenrietta Froude. were here: Jane sat talking to Mrs F. till that was done; then glided into her own bed, witht telling me how ill she was; & that is the last I have seen of her in this room. Great pain, restlessness, wretchedness,—feverish, sick, and all the muscular parts, head, back &c in continual suffering; next to no sleep, next to no food; &c &c. Barnes assures me it is nothing but “Influenza whh has stirred up all the other ailments into a state of violence“: at first, I cd gather, he had been afraid of lungs, kidneys or something serious of internal; but he finds nothing of that “a mere cold,” he says, “& no cause for alarm.” It is horrible suffering at any rate;—and I cannot but wish with all my soul it wd abate & go away!TC wrote later: “‘Monday evening, November 23’ (as I laboriously make out the date); ‘the F—s’ [Froudes], F—and his wife, the pleasantest, indeed almost the only pleasant evening company we now used to have; intelligent, cheerful, kindly, courteous, sincere (they had come to live near us, and we hoped for a larger share of such evenings, of which probably this was the first? Alas, to me, too surely it was in effect the last!) Cheerful enough this evening was; my darling sat latterly on the sofa, talking chiefly to Mrs. F—; the F—s gone, she silently at once withdrew to her bed, saying nothing to me of the state she was in, which I found next morning to have been alarmingly miserable, the prophecy of one of the worst of nights, wholly without sleep and full of strange and horrible pain. And the nights and days that followed continued steadily to worsen, day after day, and month after month, no end visible. It was some ten months now before I saw her sit with me again in this drawing-room—in body weak as a child, but again composed into quiet, and in soul beautiful as ever, or more beautiful than ever, for the rest of her appointed time with me, which indeed was brief, but is now blessed to look back upon, and an unspeakable favour of Heaven. I often think of that last evening with the F—s, which we hoped to be the first of a marked increase of such, but which to me was essentially the last of all; the F—s have been here since, but with her as hostess (in my presence) never more, and the reflex of that bright evening, now all pale and sad, shines, privately incessant, into every meeting we have. // Barnes, for some time, said the disease was ‘influenza, merely accidental cold, kindling up all the old injuries and maladies,’ and promised speedy amendment; but week after week gave dismally contrary evidence” (Froude, LM 3:178–79). Her first
sleep was two nights ago, by aid of morphine: I think they are continuing that; but indeed I do not know. She speaks little to me; and does not accept me as a sicknurse, whh truly I had never any talent to be. We have written for Maggie Welsh: I hope much she will come at once,—but there is some engaget of the kind already with her Brother Alick’s Boy at Liverpool, and things are not done there, tho’ mending.

Ld Ashburton is always reported to us as doing well; and I believe it is so, tho’ he gathers strength at a most slow rate. Thursday last, we heard of some whiff of cold or of gout, but they made light of it. Christison himself wrote lately in a hopeful strain altogether. Jamie my Brother was here, for 22 hours, Tuesday-Wedy last!Tues., 1 Dec., and Wed., 2 Dec.; James Carlyle, also John A. Carlyle’s brother. He had gone to Birminghm for a Cattleshew,The Birmingham Cattle and Poultry Show and Exhibition of Dogs was held Mon., 30 Nov. thence here: I never in my life was more surprised! We did very well; & I had much pleasant talk till he went. “Sight of St Paul’s“;St. Paul’s Cathedral. he cared for nothing more.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 6 and 7 Dec. Addr: Scotsbrig, Ecclefechan. PM: London, 7 Dec. 1863. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am glad to learn by Jenny’sJames Carlyle’s da., Jenny. Note that you got safe home after yr Excursion. Jenny does not say whether you saw TomPossibly Thomas Aitken, TC and James’s nephew; see 33:19–20TC to JCA, 12 Aug. 1857; otherwise unidentified. at Birmingm; but I suppose you wd, as Jamie Aitken wrote both to you and to him.Presumably at Birmingham; James Carlyle apparently returned home via Birmingham. Jie Aitken is at Dumfries himself by this time; he was to go on Friday Night,Fri., 4 Dec. he told me, for a fortnight of holiday.

Your sudden appearance here, and the bright little visit you made us, is
very strange and interesting to think of, ever since you went away! Poor Jane was very sorry she cd take no better charge of you.

Her case, I am sorry to say, is not improved since you were here; on the contrary, if anything. Her suffering is very great: nothing but pains and restless misery; no sleep (except by opiates), no food hardly except what the Doctor peremptorily orders. The day before yesterday I felt so uneasy about he[r] weak way I specially questioned the Doctor: he is a rational honest kind of man; he assured me it was nothing but a Cold, “mere Influenza whh had stirred up all the old pains and ailments into a violent state of activity,“—and there was “no cause for alarm.” I was considerably relieved to hear him talk so. In the mean while it is very miserable; and I heartily wish it were over! We have sent for a Cousin of hers from Auchtertool (properly Liverpool where she now is), “Maggie Welsh,” a nice discreet creature; and we hope she will come directly (tho’ it is not quite certain), whh wd be a great comfort & help.— I will write to you again,—at once if anything particular occur. Good be with you all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Monday [7 December 1863]
Miss Welsh is coming “tonight at 6” to nurse her poor Cousin; that, I believe & hope, may have more help in it than any Doctor stuff.
T. C / (in uttermost bother)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 Dec. MS: NLS 517.66. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:217–19 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
We are in considerable distress and confusion here; but since today & yesterday I strive to be in hopes it is diminishing. Yesterday Dr BlakistonDr. Peyton Blakiston. from Hastings (who is skilful & full of kindness to Jane, but noisy & loquacious) came up, with Bessy (a most kind semi-volunteer movet—for the purpose of seeing her, and holding a consultatn with Barnes. He confirms Barnes in every particr: indeed the case seems medically plain,—nothing wrong internally, but the irritation, restlessness, pain and nervous weakness very great. I send you B.’s “Diagnosis,” whh he had written for me, and came stumping up to my garret with, after his consultatn. Send the Paper back, after you have read it. Before he came (by the aid of opiates or otherwise) poor Jane was considerably easier, and I think evidtly continues so today: but she is so low, one can get little out of her own acct; I seldom get above a word or two,
hardly audible even with industry, and little elucidation of her state. Never before have I have seen her in such misery so long. She does, I believe, sleep a little latterly; she also eats better (whh is still very ill),—is to try a fractn of minced mutton today; seems to affect nothing, but lemonades, small bits of ice (a bundle of it lies always in the back-area, under hay), soda-water & milk &c. A sick-nurse (Irish “sister-of-mercy,“TC wrote later: “A year or … two before this time, she had gone with some acquaintance who was in quest of sick-nurses to an establishment under Catholic auspices, in Brompton somewhere (the acquaintance, a Protestant herself, expressing her ‘certain knowledge’ that this Catholic was the one good kind);—where accordingly the aspect of matters, and especially the manner of the old French lady who was Matron and Manager, produced such a favourable impression, that I recollect my little Woman saying, ‘If I need a sick-nurse, that is the place I will apply at’” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 170). Presumably the Sisters of Mercy, 10 Brompton Lower Grove. See TC to JAC, 29 Dec. with blarney in her whh may be useful too) sits up with her all night; Maggie she wd not have, nor her own maid: Maggie nurses thro’ the day, and does cheerily whatever she can. We keep down noise all we can; but there is of course a good deal of jingling abt, whh cannot be prevented outside her doors. I do pray and hope the worst may now be past.

I myself, what is a mercy, am tolerably well; and even manage, all thro’ the sad hurlyburly, to get some work done. My one consolatn. The fall of my HorseSee TC to JAC, 15 Nov. has set me upon forbearing carefully the high-trot (at whh he never was good, & was suspected even before he fell); “butter-and-eggs,“A jog-trot; see 18:141JWC to TC, [17 July 1844], (a “decent butter-and-eggs trot“); or possibly a canter. very rapid, is now our pace on the hard roads; gallop, when we get a bit of soft. A beautiful, nice swift little Horse; but unfit for my work. Send Jean this,—and Jamie.— Ever yrs T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [16 Dec.]. MS: NLS 517.64. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the addition of Richard Quain to JWC’s doctors; the previous week only Barnes and Blakiston were involved; see TC to JAC, 11 Dec.; by 21 Dec. there were three doctors; see TC to LLA, 21 Dec.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean,—A new Dr (Quain, whom she had consulted at The Grange)See JWC to MR, [16 Sept.]. came “on Consultatn” last night. “Neuralgia, all,” he said (as they have all done); but did not seem to know certainly how it was to be helped! However, he did agn order quinine (essence of bark); & Barnes and he contrived some “draught” (composing, they called it); whh produced no sleep (alas); but did
abt 4 this morning produce perfect “tranquility” (of a baddish kind, I doubt), whh still continues. Miss Welsh declares her to have been “asleep,” but she is rather easily blessed with “sleep.“—You never saw such a tempest of restless misery, more tossing to and fro as preceded this for days and nights;—painful even to look at by an indifft person, I shd think!
This then is a drug that has fulfilled its intentn? I am in hopes so; and that perhaps we are at the halfway house for sleep. Oh me!—
By an odd minute, I send you this in ansr. Will write if anything more definite occur. Horse come! Cold intense; but road black, and good, when the wind doesn’t blow them in clouds.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 21 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 516.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I meant writing to you yesterday; but people invaded my garret, and I could not. This morng, comes yr Letter.

We have had a terrible four weeks since you heard last! Rheumatic fever, or I know not what it is, and has been: the Doctors call it mere “influenza whh has kindled into a general paroxysm all the neuralgias, hurts &c“;—they are agreed, all Three of them,Drs. Barnes, Blakiston, and Quain. on this definition; and to my own mind, so far I can form any judgt, this does seem probably the nature of the case. The Drs are all agreed;—but, alas, it seems very evidt their art can do nothing for her; and indeed all their opiates, morphines, soporifics, produced the very reverse of sleep or help,—no improvet visible till then were entirely abandoned. I never saw a being in such continuous agony!— Since yesterday week, we have tried to flatter ourselves that there was a perceptible change for the better. And she does sleep a little more, eat a little more (all drugs being withdrawn); and certainly, one wd say, is a little better;—“round the corner,” as we fond[ly] hoped, and hope;—but there is such a depression of spirits, so very little sleep or eating, and such capricious returns of the ancient miseries and universal pains (from no visible cause), as keeps us in continual fluctuatn and anxiety.TC wrote later: “‘Neuralgia!’ the doctors then all said, by which they mean they know not in the least what; in this case, such a deluge of intolerable pain, indescribable, unaidable pain, as I had never seen or dreamt of, and which drowned six or eight months of my poor darling’s life as in the blackness of very death; her recovery at last, and the manner of it, an unexpected miracle to me. There seemed to be pain in every muscle, misery in every nerve, no sleep by night or day, no rest from struggle and desperate suffering. Nobody ever known to me could more nobly and silently endure pain; but here for the first time I saw her vanquished, driven hopeless, as it were looking into a wild chaotic universe of boundless woe—on the horizon, only death or worse. Oh, I have seen such expressions in those dear and beautiful eyes as exceeded all tragedy! (one night in particular, when she rushed desperately out to me, without speech; got laid and wrapped by me on the sofa, and gazed silently on all the old familiar objects and me). Her pain she would seldom speak of, but when she did, it was in terms as if there were no language for it; ‘any honest pain, mere pain, if it were of cutting my flesh with knives, or sawing my bones, I could hail that as a luxury in comparison!’ // And the doctors, so far as I could privately judge, effected approximately to double the disease. We had many doctors, skilful men of their sort, and some of them (Dr. Quain, especially, who absolutely would accept no pay, and was unwearied in attendance and invention) were surely among the friendliest possible; but each of them—most of all each new one—was sure to effect only harm, tried some new form of his opiums and narcotic poisons without effect; on the whole I computed, ‘Had there been no doctors, it had been only about half as miserable.’ Honest Barnes admitted in the end, ‘We have been able to do nothing’” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:179–80).— We have had good “Maggie Welsh” for the last two weeks; who is
the staff of life to us all! From her or from me you shall hear agn, before long. Take care of your Patients; self included, who seem to be one! I am unspeakably hurried abt,—seldom been in such a whirlpool. Adieu, with blessings.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AJS [AJSY], 26 Dec. Pbd: A. J. Symington, Some Personal Reminiscences of Carlyle (Paisley and London 1886) 61–63 inc. Andrew James Symington (1826–98), Glasgow merchant, poet, biographer, and an old acquaintance of the Carlyle family; see 36:biographical notes.
div3.head: TC TO ANDREW JAMES SYMINGTON

docBody.p: Your two birds arrived safe—excellent birds, of new foreign flavourSymington wrote later: “Having in December received some ptarmigan from Iceland, I forwarded a brace to Chelsea” (Symington, Reminiscences 61). Symington visited in May and talked with TC about John A. Carlyle: “whom I … long corresponded with, chiefly in connection with Icelandic subjects and the old Icelandic translations of the Bible which I had the pleasure of being able to lend him. // Dr. Carlyle was … a good Icelandic and Danish scholar, which led Carlyle to remark that the Danish language was easily acquired by Scotchmen, as, under the skin, it was all Scotch and German” (Symington, Reminiscences 30–31). —and did duty here yesterday, keeping Xmas far away from home. Thanks for that mark of your attention. My wife has had a bad fit of illness, and, indeed, still has, tho’ now, we hope, recovering.

closer.salute: With many thanks and good wishes, Yours sincerely,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-SSR, 28 Dec. MS: NLS 2883.238. Hitherto unpbd. Stephen Spring Rice (1814–65; see TC to JOST, 28 July 1842), eldest son of Thomas Spring Rice (1790–1866; ODNB), 1st Baron Monteagle (also a friend of TC, since the late 1830s); m., 1839, Ellen, b. Frere (d. 1869). Spring Rice was previously commissioner of customs, 1836–56, and deputy chairman of board of customs, 1856–59; TC’s most recent correspondence with him was in 1854; see TC to SSR, 16 April 1854, TC to SSR, 16 May 1854, and TC to SSR, 4 July 1854.
div3.head: TC TO STEPHEN SPRING RICE

docBody.p: Thanks for yr kind word from afar.Possibly Spring Rice was abroad for his health; he retired from govt. service due to ill health, 1859. My poor Wife is in great pain and misery (neuralgia, for whh no Doctor can do anything, but only misdo if he try with drugs): we hoped, and still try to hope, there was a visible abatement almost two weeks ago; but there has come no sleep yet, no real sleep (“only one night for six weeks“: what a fact by itself),—and of course we are all deep enough in anxiety & trouble.
I am endlessly hurried too,—whh perhaps is rather a benefit to me in the circs.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 28 Dec. MS: NLS 553.259. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:534.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I do not know Catto,Catto not further identified. I know only the face of him (whh is the image of a cock’s, and quite unlovely to me); I shd have to apply at secondhand, to &c &c. I cannot read that flourishing bit of cursiv-schrift,Old German script.—not in less than 2 hours, whh I have not to spare for it.

I have applied direct to the Gallery Director:Presumably the director of a German gallery. if you will fill in his Name, and give him a German Translatn on the opposite page, I dare say that will do it.
I owe you much for Postages (never to speak of other things)! The Postages I can and will pay;—not the “other things,” I fear, ever.
No improvement here today, alas, alas! No glimpse of sound sleep to be had; tho’ the pain does seem to abate in violence. I strive to work all I can, by way of refuge to myself.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Dec. MS: NLS 526.13A. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:274 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—It does seem absurd that I cannot get two minutes to write a word to you: but such is the sad fact; nor will I take up time explaining it.

We are in great trouble, anxiety, confusion: poor Jane’s state such as to fill one with the saddest thoughts. She does not gather strength: how can she? There has been, since that good night, next to no sleep, oftenest none whatever. She is quieter in regard to pain, the neuralgia and other torments have sensibly abated (not ceased); she also eats daily a little,—that is the one clearly good symptom. But her state is one of weakness, utter restlessness, depression and misery: such a scene as I never was in before. If she cd only get a little sleep:—but she cannot hitherto. Tonight by Barnes’s advice and her own reluctant consent, she is to try morphine again; God of his mercy grant that it may prosper! There has been for ten days a complete cessation of all druggings and opiate abominations: they did her a great deal of mischief, instead of any good.— One of our servants took sore throat;Mary or Lizzie. and went away: it is to be regarded as a blessing that we have got one in her stead, talem qualem [of whatever kind], who comes home tomorrow. We have had “Sisters of Mercy” (so-called),TC wrote later: “We had sick-nurses, a varying miscellany, Catholic ‘Sisters of Mercy’ (ignominiously dismissed by her third or fourth night, the instant she found they were in real substance Papist propagandists. Oh, that ‘3 a.m.,’ when her bell awoke me too, as well as Maggie Welsh, and the French nun had to disappear at once, under rugs on a sofa elsewhere, and vanish altogether when daylight came!) Maggie Welsh had come in the second week of December, and continued, I think, at St. Leonards latterly, till April ended” (Froude, LM 3:180). See also Carlyle, Reminiscences 170–71. Charwomen &c &c. Friends are really kind in intention;—the result of whh is endless Notes to write; yesternight I did four;—tonight I have at least Milnes to answer (see Inclosure)!— I still try to hope, and believe that my poor little Woman is a little thot better; & Barnes keeps up his heart: but it is miserable to see how low and wretched she is; and under what wearing pain she passes her sleepless nights and days.— In health I am myself as well as usual (which surely is a blessing): I keep busy too, in all available moments: work done is the one consolatn left me. FuzJohn Forster. came in tonight; his kindness cost me my after-ride nap of sleep, and give me a headache for the night.— Tomorrow, before post, I will write another word. Enough of this kind of thing. Good night.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord H [RMM] , 29 Dec. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:112–14. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:522, 532; Ashton 435.
div3.head:
TC
TO LORD HOUGHTON

docBody.p: Dear Lord Houghton (quocunque nomine care [with whatever name you wish]),Richard Monckton Milnes was elevated to the peerage as Baron Houghton, 20 Aug. —I hoped to have made my congratulations on the new grace of Fortune last time you wrote, but when I called at Brook Street you had gone out. Speaking of it or not, it is a thing we are all glad of, and wish well to. I will say only, May the noble British Peerage, once one of the noblest things in all the world, and still a very noble, find you an honour and possession to it, and you it a ditto, ditto, to you!It was a very popular elevation. The Examiner reported, 1 Aug.: “When a Commoner is raised to the Peerage it is the custom of the Press to hold an Inquest on his remains, to find out how he came to his end, or, in other words, to his title. In the case of Richard Monckton Milnes, the verdict delivered most emphatically and cordially is Honestly and Meritoriously. A Devil’s Advocate would be at a loss to ascribe Mr. Milnes promotion to any unworthy cause, his political conduct having been so thoroughly independent as occasionally to wear the appearance of waywardness. … Few men are better informed, few have read more extensively and profitably, and he has written well, and would have done better if he had not given to politics what his inclinations would rather have bestowed on literature. He was a poet early, but a politician by descent, his position would not allow of his making a business of a pleasure.”

My poor wife is in great pain and distress; general neuralgia, the doctors call it—pain of that hurt limb, all manner of latent hurts and injuries, kindled into a flaming paroxysm by some fit of influenza: such a tempest of misery, as fills us with pain even to witness it; for about two weeks since the doctors, who were all agreed, but could do no good whatever, gave up the opiate abominations, and left matters alone. We have struggled to hope, and do still hope there was an improvement; but it is sadly slow—sleep, in particular, almost refusing to return as yet, and the progress towards better hardly discernible amid many interruptions. God help us, and send us better days again! I can find no consolation, except in struggling to get a little work done in spite of the dire element, which in every atom of it is saying, “No, you shan’t!” The doctors confidently call it a superficial “merely nervous” torment of pain, and assert that, “except by failure of strength,” it is not dangerous—“except,” indeed! But let us be silent—let us hope in this place of hope.

Poor Thackeray!Thackeray d. Christmas Eve. I saw him not ten days ago. I was riding in the dusk, heavy of heart, along by the Serpentine and Hyde Park, when some human brother from a chariot, with a young lady in it, threw me a shower of salutations. I
looked up—it was Thackeray with his daughter:Either Annie or Harriet. the last time I was to see him in this world. He had many fine qualities, no guile or malice against any mortal; a big mass of a soul, but not strong in proportion; a beautiful vein of genius lay struggling about in him. Nobody in our day wrote, I should say, with such perfection of style. I predict of his books very much as you do. Poor Thackeray!—adieu! adieu!Thackeray’s funeral took place at Kensal Green cemetery, Wed., 30 Dec.; apparently TC did not attend; the London Express reported, 1 Jan.: “Some who were aware of the long-established friendship between the deceased and the author of ‘Sartor Resartus’ looked for him too in the group, but Mr. Carlyle dislikes crowds, and is all but a septuagenerian, and he was not recognised among the spectators.” Over 1,000 people attended the ceremony, including Dickens and G. H. Lewes.
Illustrated London News, 9 January 1864
Courtesy of National Library of Scotland

My unfortunate history has bulged into a sixth volume; the fourth is coming out so soon as the engraver (Wilhelmina’s portrait) has done. The sixth volume—a poor thing—is partly ready in the rough. The fifth and it cannot be out within eight months or ten. Alas! I, too, am getting weary.

The no blockhead, several blackguards kindred,“Several blackguards … but not one blockhead”: a comment on his ancestors attrib. to JWC’s paternal grandfather, John Welsh (ca. 1760–1823); see Carlyle, Reminiscences 110. was not the —’s, but an obscurer Scotch kindred, whom also the definition fits. The Welshes of Druscore descended from John Welsh and a daughter of John Knox.“Druscore”: mistranscription for Dunscore, the parish from which the Welshes came; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 74. For Elizabeth Welsh, b. Knox, and the Rev. John Welsh, see JWC to JAF, [ca. 2 March]. I think it was my wife’s granduncle (himself rather a black) who made use of the phrase.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

ps.p: P.S.—Lady Ashburton (generous impetuous soul!) came running up one day, ran sick-nursing about till the evening train. Lord Ashburton is considered to be in a satisfactory state, slowly gathering strength; still weak, but cheerful, and mostly free from pain. I had a letter from him since the lady was here. “Come and see us,” he said.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [30 Dec.]. MS: NLS 526.13B. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Wedny 4 p.m.— Dear Brother, The Morphine of last night (25 drops) proved a total failure:—you may fancy what a day my poor Woman has! Barnes (junr,Dr. Herbert Sedgwick Barnes. in absence of senr) has ordered 25 drops again this night at 10,—to be followed,
in case of non-effect, at 12 by 20 drops more.— I know not when my poor Jane, worn down to this pitch, is fit for such heroic practice in opiates! But we will consider.— She does eat,—morsels of sole, cups of brown soup, a new egg &c: I saw her “dining” today; really almost, you wd have said, with an appetite or semblance of one. It is the one good symptom; and it is a good one.

I have had to stay in from riding; to clear off wreck no longer endurable. Done now, or on the edge of done.TC wrote later: “December was hardly out till there began to be speech among the doctors of sea-side and change of air: the one hope they continued more and more to say; and we also thinking of St. Leonards and our Dr. B— and bountiful resources there, waited only for spring weather, and the possibility of flight thither. How, in all this tearing whirlpool of miseries, anxieties, and sorrows, I contrived to go on with my work is still an astonishment to me. For one thing, I did not believe in these doctors, nor that she (if let alone of them) had not yet strength left. Secondly, I always counted ‘Frederick’ itself to be the prime source of all her sorrows as well as my own; that to end it was the condition of new life to us both, of which there was a strange dull hope in me. Not above thrice can I recollect when, on stepping out in the morning, the thought struck me, cold and sharp, ‘She will die, and leave thee here!’ and always before next day I had got it cast out of me again. And, indeed, in all points except one I was as if stupefied more or less, and flying on like those migrative swallows of Professor Owen, after my strength was done and coma or dream had supervened, till the Mediterranean Sea was crossed! But the time altogether looks to me like a dim nightmare, on which it is still miserable to dwell, and of which I will after this endeavour only to give the dates” (Froude, LM 3:180–81). Richard Owen (1804–92; ODNB), naturalist and paleontologist; see 38:211TC to RO, 15 Sept. 1862.— Our weather is excellt;—dry for most
part, calmish, cool rather cold. Aims at sharp frost (sharp, you wd say) sometimes; but next morning has given it up again.

You will tell Jean, and the rest. AdieuEdward Twisleton wrote, 29 Dec., enclosing a leaflet from the “Scavengers of this Parish” (MS: NLS 1768.59; see opp.above): “I enclose a valuable Historical Document, which it is not too late, I hope, to take notice of in your History. What more striking proof can there be of the heroic qualities of Frederick the Great, and of the durable impression which he made on the minds of men than that 100 years after the close of the Seven Years War, the Scavengers of the Parish of St Margarets Westminster should have as their Device a Medal representing him, and perpetuating the memory of his great achievements? // There is another point worthy of notice in the Document, viz, its illustrating the fitness of the English for enlarged Socialism, and fraternal co-operation in Parallelograms or Phalanstères. These noble Scavengers have ‘no connection with Dustmen.’” TC wrote on Twisleton’s envelope: ” Dustmen & their Frk Medal 1864,—for the 2d time:—Ach Himel.” The scavengers (street sweepers), Richard Hawthorn and Frederick Thompson, were collecting for their Christmas box; they were employed by William Winn, scavenger and contractor, New Wharf, Little Abingdon St., Westminster; he also had three further addresses in other London districts.

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

div1.p: Notes on the Carlyles’ contemporaries referred to more than once in the present volume are given below, cross-referenced to earlier information. Some relatives or old friends who had died before the starting date of this volume are retained because of frequent references to them. Otherwise, individuals are accounted for in headnotes and footnotes as they appear in the letters.

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921; see 26:30226:biographical notes), 7th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81; see 26:28926:biographical notes), 7th earl; for their children, see 37:26137:biographical notes. They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, Jean ("Craw") Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, May 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–1836 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–1871), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858 and lived in a suburb in S London; Thomas (1841–69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Albert Edward (1841–1910; ODNB), prince of Wales, m., 10 March 1863, Princess Alexandra ((1844–1925; ODNB), da. of Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein (1818–1906).
Anderton, Sarah; see Dilberoglue.

Anstruther, Mary Frances, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), sister of Lady Louisa Ashburton, m., 1838, Philip Anstruther (1802–22 May 1863). They had 11 children, Mary Helen (ca. 1840–1912), m., 1858, William Reierson Arbuthnot (1826–1913); Annie Nairn (ca. 1841–1931), Robert Durham (1841–90), Jemima Stewart (1845–74), Philip Morrison (1846–99), Stewart Mackenzie (1848–98), John Newdegate (1850–1915), Caroline Petre (1852–1928), Keith Francis George (1854–1915), Henry Lewis (1856—after 1900), and Charles William (1858–87). They lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London.

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles 1839 and became close friends. Ashburton m., second, 1858, Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903); JWC expected not to like her, but was swiftly won over. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). They lived at Bath House, Piccadilly, London, and The Grange, Alresford, Hampshire; they also had a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844), who m., 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).

Ballantyne, Thomas (1806–71; ODNB; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839, and 30:xviii30:introduction), author and journalist; associated with several publications including the Manchester Guardian, the Leader, the Illustrated London News, the Statesman, and the St. James’s Chronicle; he anthologized TC and other writers.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; m. Susannah (ca. 1804—ca. 1855); their children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella (see Simmonds); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829), now dead.
Barnet; see Blakiston.

Blakiston, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–91), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–78), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, m., 1825, was Frances, b. Powell, d. 1858; their sons were John Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (1831–65), Douglas Yeoman (1832–1914), and Matthew Folliott (1835–1906).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944) and Elaine Mary (b. 1862). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea in 1860. His sister was Julia Sophia (1823–95), and his elder brother was Henry George Scawen Blunt (1821–99), m., 1846, Charlotte, b. Daniell (1818–86).

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1 Dec. 1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC. The Carlyles called her “Lark,” “Die Lerche,” or “Flight of Skylarks.” Her brother was William Davenport Bromley (1821–84).
Brookfield, William Henry (1809–74; ODNB; see 20:156TC to JWC, [30 March 1846]), clergyman and school inspector; m., 1841, Jane Octavia, b. Elton (1821–96).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario; m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91). They had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1833–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1833–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and other writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their eldest child was James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; he m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin. The three younger children were John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario; m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867). They had five children: Janet (1818–89), Mary (1821–50), John (1825–97), James (1830–1900), and William (1833–1911); the two youngest were schoolteachers.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor") (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator; m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b.
Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons (see Watt brothers). She d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Chamberlayne, Maria, from Hampshire, servant at Cheyne Row July 1861–Nov. 1862. Her mother was Ann, b. Weldon, m., 1838, Jeremiah Chamberlayne; Ann worked for the Ashburtons at The Grange.
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin d. (1866); they had one son, Frederick.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, [Aug. 1845]), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to HL, 18 Aug. 1858).

Christison, David (1830–1912), physican and archaeologist. He had served as an army physician during the Crimean War, but had become ill, and since then had largely given up medicine and taken up archaeology; he was Lord Ashburton’s physician for the last two years of Ashburton’s life (Surtees, Ludovisi 99).

Chrystal, Jeannie, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95), JWC’s cousin; m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), a wine merchant from Glasgow (see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849, and 26:81JWC to JW, [11 May 1851]); they had a da., Mary (1857–1937). Her regular correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage.

Colenso, John William (1814–83; ODNB), theologian and scholar, bishop of Natal, S. Africa, 1853–83; he m., 1846, Frances Sarah, b. Bunyon (1816–93). Tried for heresy and deposed from office, Dec. 1863, by Robert Gray (1809–72; ODNB), bishop of Cape Town, he was excommunicated when he ignored the bishop’s ruling; the verdict was set aside in 1865 by the privy council on the grounds that Bishop Gray had no jurisdiction over Colenso.

Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907), American clergyman and author; m., 1858, Ellen, b. Dana (d. 1897); friend of Emerson. Came to Britain 1863; pastor at South Place Chapel, Finsbury, London, 1864–84.

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207JWC to SS, [20 Sept. 1835]), author, prof. of English lit.and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, [30 Aug. 1838]). They had
one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (1827–1909), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, 8 Dec. 1842), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist.
Craven, Mary May, b. Welsh (1829–85), da. of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert; m., 1859, Dr. Robert Martin Craven (1824–1903; see 35:26735:biographical notes), as his second wife.

Cushman, Charlotte Saunders (1816–76), actress. Raised in Boston, she came to Britain 1844, where she became friendly with Geraldine Jewsbury, among others; see 20:109JWC to JW, [19 Jan. 1846]. She returned to the U.S. 1849, but moved to Italy 1852, spending winters there and much of the summers in England. From 1858 she lived with the American sculptor Emma Stebbins (1815–82). Friendly with Sarah Anderton Dilberoglue, with whom she had acted in Boston in 1852.

Delepine, Elizabeth Marie Louise, b. Jäger, known as Madame Elise, milliner and dressmaker at 170 Regent St.; she m., 1857, Frederick Wooton Isaacson (1836–98), silk merchant. She had been left the business by her aunt, Jane Clarke (d. 1859), milliner (see also 33:141JWC to DD, 29 Dec. 1857). TC noted on a photograph of her: “‘Madame Elise’ I think a fashionable Dressmaker, whom she [JWC] thot a real artist, and who valued her approval in a marked manner” (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 2; Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.)

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her since 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Dilberoglue, Stauros (1818–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector. Born in Smyrna, he moved with his family to Corfu, where they were naturalized Ionian. Stauros lived in England from the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London. He m., 1859, Sarah Anderton, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–69; see 28:21–22JWC to KS, [28 Jan. 1853]), actress (Anderton was her stage name). They lived at 13 Barnsbury Park. He became a naturalized Briton in 1861. His sister, Calliope (b. 1835), m., 1858, John George Honiere (b. 1814), general merchant.
Dobie, Grace, b. Welsh (1836–2 Oct. 1863), da. of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert; m., 1859, William Henry Dobie (b. ca. 1809).

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to GEJ, [11? Sept. 1857]), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC; he m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:26537:biographical notes. He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, [19 Sept. 1857]).

Donaldson sisters of Tenterfield (Sunny Bank), Haddington: Jean (1770–1860), JWC’s godmother; Jess (1774–1860); and Catherine (Kate) (1779–1852); friends of JWC’s mother. For other members of the Donaldson family, see 37:26637:biographical notes.
Donne, William Bodham (1807–82; ODNB), essayist; chief librarian of London Library 1852–57; see 32:107; examiner of plays in the lord chamberlain’s office 1857–74.

Downes, John (1827–64), writer; originally intending to be a minister in the Free Church of Scotland, he abandoned theology for philosophy; he wrote later, “Carlyle tore my nature to pieces; Thackeray built it up again” (William Knight, Some Nineteenth Century Scotsmen [Edinburgh, 1903] 118). He was subeditor, 1852–61, under Thomas Stewart Traill (1781–1862; ODNB), of the 8th edn. of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

Eliot, George (1819–80; ODNB), pen name of Marian (previously Mary Ann) Evans, author; her novels were much admired by JWC. From 1855 she lived with George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB; see 11:205TC to UC, 16 Oct. 1839), author and journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1835.
Elise; see Delepine.
Elizabeth, from Haddington, servant at Cheyne Row June—Dec. 1862; referred to by the Carlyles as the “mooncalve.” Her last name was possibly Gray or Lyall.
Elizabeth ("Lizzie"), servant at Cheyne Row from mid-Feb. 1863. Her aunt Mrs. Winslade came as cook mid-Jan. to mid-Feb.
Ellice, Edward ("Bear") (1783–17 Sept. 1863; ODNB; see 21:148TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1847), M.P. for Coventry, and a close friend of Lord Ashburton; see 32:24832:biographical notes.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, andtranscendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB); see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters, who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.
Farie, Robert (1813–82; see 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846), translator of German works, old friend of the Carlyles.

Forster, John ("Fuz") (1812–76; ODNB); see 6:118TC to GE, 15 Feb. 1832, and 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); they lived at 46 Montagu Sq.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m.,
second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline (1809–86).
Garibaldi, Giuseppe (1807–82), Italian patriot.

Gilchrist, Anne, b. Burrows (1828–85; ODNB), writer; m., 1851, Alexander (1828–61; ODNB), biographer. They had four children: Percy Carlyle (1851–1935), Beatrice (1854–81), Herbert (1857–1914), and Grace (1859–1947). The family lived at 6 Cheyne Row 1856–62; after her husband’s death, Anne Gilchrist and her children moved to Brookbank Cottage, Shottermill, nr. Haslemere, Surrey. Her mother was Henrietta Burrows, living at Earls Colne, Essex.

Godby, Mary, b. Binnie (1826–86), m., 1848, Frederick Godby (1819–57), chief clerk of General Post Office, Edinburgh; they had four children: Hardy Augustus (b. ca. 1850), Mary and her unidentified twin (b. ca. 1853), and Binnie (1855–60). Mary Godby moved to London, late 1850s, where she was matron of a “Post-office Establishment,” St. Martin’s le Grand (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 163).

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.
Hunter, Jane; see Watt.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB); see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.
Jeffrey, William (1826–77), photographer; he lived with his mother, Mary (b. ca. 1807), and his aunt Ellenor Ruding (b. ca. 1817), who helped him in his studio at 114 Gt. Russell St.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. For her sister, Maria Jane (1800–1833), also a writer, see 30:251. Her brothers were Thomas Smith (b. 1802), Henry Richard Smith (1803–73), Arthur (b. 1815), and Francis (Frank) Harding (1819–78), who m., 1853, Emily, b. Vandeburgh. Jewsbury lived with Frank in Manchester until summer 1854; now living in London at 41 Markham Sq. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856 and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.
Jones, John Edward (ca. 1824–93), assistant librarian, London Lib.

Kerr, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901),
marchioness of Lothian, m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess of Lothian, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. His mother was Lady Cecil Chetwynd Kerr, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1808–77; ODNB), dowager marchioness of Lothian.
Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary, and librarian of the Signet Lib., Edinburgh, from 1837 until his death.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business. His Extra Physics and the Mystery of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, [19 July 1858]. He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff (b. 1837), and they lived at 6 Cheyne Row. A son, Alfred Edward, was b. March 1863.
Lewes, George Henry; see Eliot.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–65), lawyer and politician; president of the U.S. 1861–65. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–82), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. Lincoln was shot by an assassin 14 April 1865, and died the following day.
Lothian; see Kerr.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), politician and naturalist; b. in Sussex, England, he settled in New Zealand in 1840. He met Geraldine Jewsbury, late 1856, and corresponded extensively with her on his return to New Zealand in 33:276–7733:biographical notes, and 37:27037:biographical notes.
Mary (b. ca. 1838), servant at Cheyne Row Dec. 1862–Nov. 1864.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist, administrator at India House since 1823; m., 1851, the widow of John Taylor (1796–1849), Harriet Taylor (1807–58), who strongly influenced his thinking. Mill met TC in Sept. 1831 (see TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 18315:398); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage.

Milnes, Richard Monckton (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE,6 Jan. 1840), author, M.P. for Pontefract 1837–63; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and
Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties and championed progressive causes such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:biographical notes. In August 1863 he was created Lord Houghton.
Morrison, Florence (b. ca. 1847), servant at Cheyne Row Nov. 1862–Jan. 1863.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British 1845, and retired from business 1849–56; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858;). From 1856–63 Neuberg lived at Oakley Villas, 25 (renumbered 140) Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–98)—who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32)—and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). In 1863 he moved to Roslyn Park, Hampstead. After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.

Oliphant, Margaret Oliphant, b. Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; she m., 1852, her cousin Francis Wilson Oliphant (1818–59; ODNB); their children were Margaret Wilson (1853–64), Marjorie (1854–55), a son who d. at birth (1855), Cyril Francis (“Tids“) (1856–90), and Francis Romano ("Cecco") (1859–94). Her mother was Margaret Wilson, b. Oliphant (ca. 1789–1854) and her father Francis W. Wilson (ca. 1788–1858).

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (1807–70 according to French genealogy website, but she must have been born earlier as TC had left the school in Ecclefechan by 1806), known to TC as a child; her mother, Margaret Carlyle (d. 1830), fled with her from a brutal husband, James Johnston (d. 1809), to France. Jean m., 1832, Nicolas-Julien Otthenin (1785–1845), a French cavalry officer, who d. in a carriage accident; see 20:18–19TC to JWC, 10 Oct. 1845. Now living at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh, with her das. Margaret (the elder) and Irma (1838–97).

Palmerston, Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; m., 1839, Emily, b. Lamb (1787–1869), widow of 5th Earl Cowper (1778–1837). Whig prime minister 1855–57 and 1859–65.

Pepoli, Elizabeth, b. Fergus (1792–1862; see 28:223JWC to JC, 25 July 1853, and 13:86JWC to TC, [9 April 1841]); old Kirkcaldy friend of the Carlyles; m., 1839, Count Carlo Pepoli (1796–1881; see 8:194–95JWC to JCA, [Aug. 1835]), poet, prof. of philosophy at Bologna, and political exile after
the failed revolution against the papal govt., 1831; he returned to Bologna 1859; she lived at Felsina House, 11 St. George’s Ter., Kensington.
Pike, James Shepherd (1811–82), journalist and abolitionist; m., first, 1837, Charlotte, b. Grosvenor (d. 1847); m., second, 1855, Elizabeth, b. Ellicott. U.S. minister to the Netherlands 1861–66.

Plattnauer, Richard Eduard (b. 1814), son of Nathan Plattnauer and Jeanette Breit; originally named Salomon, he was christened, age 24, at Sankt Nikolai, Brandenburg, Prussia, 17 Nov. 1838; political refugee from Prussia; see 22:10JWC to HW, [5 July 1847]. Friend of the Carlyles since the mid-1840s; see 18:194JWC to JW, 29 Aug. 1844; he suffered periods of insanity. For his sister, see Reichenbach.

Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart diseases, and with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–91); they had four das.

Reichenbach, Oskar Heinrich Karl von (1815–93; see 18:202–3JWC to TC, [13 Sept. 1844]), count, m. Fredrike, b. Plattnauer (b. 1817); they had two das., Elisabeth (b. 1843) and Hedwig (b. 1844), and one son, Oskar (b. 1845), later a civil engineer. Previously a Silesian landowner and liberal deputy to Frankfurt parliament, 1848–49, Reichenbach was exiled and came to London with his family, 1850; emigrated to U.S. 20 April 1853. By 1865 they had returned to London.
Robson, Charles, of Robson, Levey, & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane. Robson had been TC’s printer since 1837.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), wine merchant, and mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). He was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to MN, 8 April 1831), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat; she had two sons, Arthur John Edward (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–85, with whom she lived at 2 Audley Sq., and Odo Leopold William (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat. She was always known as Lady William Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187.

Sandwich, Mary Anne Julia Louisa Harriet, b. Lowry-Corry (1781–1862; see 23:103TC to MAC, 3 Sept. 1848), dowager countess; da. of Armar Lowry Corry (1740–1802), 1st earl of Belmore, Irish politican. She m., 1804, George John
Montagu (1773–1818), 6th earl of Sandwich; her children included Lady Harriet Ashburton and John William Montagu (1811–84), 7th earl of Sandwich; see 38:28438:biographical notes. Lady Sandwich had lived at Hinchinbrook in Huntingdonshire (see 36:103TC to JWC, 27 April 1860) and at 46 Grosvenor Sq. in London.
Silvester, John, livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865).

Simmonds, Isabella Emily, b. Barnes (b. 1837), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188JWC to IEB, 24 Aug. 1859. She m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829), barrister; they lived at 82a Oakley St., Chelsea. Their first child, Ethel Jane, was b. 1 Nov. 1863.

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19JWC to AB, [10 April 1849]), politician; living in Thurso Castle, Caithness. He m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–17 March 1863). They had a son and three das. (see 36:28636:biographical notes); the youngest, Olivia Sophia (1823–94), became a travel writer. Sir George’s sister Catherine (ca. 1801–64) was also an author. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid until June 1861; see 37:27337:biographical notes. She continued to visit and correspond with them both.
