She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880).

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59TC TO JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical notes). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915); John ("Johny") Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925); Katherine Louisa (1842–74; ODNB); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921).
Stebbins, Emma; see Cushman.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 10 April 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, [12 Nov. 1844], and 19:9JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845]); they lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge; his brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for John Sterling’s children, including Julia Maria Sterling (1836–1910), see 35:264–6535:biographical notes.

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart
(1832–69), farmer at Hollybush; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861) and a son, William (b. Feb. 1863).

Stewart-Mackenzie, Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie; she m., second, 1817, James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. They had lived at Brahan Castle, Ross-shire. They had six children, including Lady Louisa Ashburton, Mary Frances (see Anstruther), and George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52) who m., 1850, Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826); she was always referred to as “Mrs. George."

Taylor, Henry (1800–1886; ODNB; see 6:40TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831), author and civil servant; m., 1839, Theodosia Alice, b. Spring-Rice (1818–91; see 10:168JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1838]); they had two sons and three das.; see 37:27437:biographical notes. He lived at Sheen Common, nr. Richmond.

Thackeray, William Makepeace (1811–24 Dec. 1863; ODNB; see 9:271JWC to TC, [3 Aug. 1837], 288, and later vols.), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s. He m., 1836, Isabella, b. Shawe (1816–93), who was mentally ill from 1840. His das. were Anne Isabella (1837–1919; ODNB) and Harriet Marian (1840–75; ODNB); they lived at 36 Onslow Sq., London.

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB), naturalist; m., 1835, Lady Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–66; ODNB), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a great friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton.

Twisleton, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), from Boston, Mass.; JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s account of Craigenputtoch, [Nov. 1855]). She m., 1852, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd Twisleton (1809–74; ODNB), also a close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); they lived at 3 Rutland Gate.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and of Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).
Victoria (1819–1901; ODNB), queen of Great Britain and Ireland; m., 1840, Albert (1819–61; ODNB), prince consort.

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector; see 29:123–4TC to CAW, 6 July 1854. He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64TC to TB, 27 Sept. 1860.

Watt brothers, John A. Carlyle’s stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856), then joined the army in Jan. 1861; Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854), m., 9 April 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161) and Helen, b. Vary (1804–85); Arthur (b. 1840), at
school in Edinburgh from 1856; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 11 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828,, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853]), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–60), Margaret, and Mary.

Welsh, John Amelia ("Jackie") (ca. 1812–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott (b. 1782). Jackie lived with her mother and her aunt Jane Scott (1787–20 March 1863).

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, [Feb. 1841], and 20:128JWC to MW, [Feb. 1846]), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, [20 Aug. 1842]), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Robert (1786–1841; see 13:118TC to JWC, 29 April 1841, and 14:217JWC to MW, 8 July 1842), JWC’s paternal uncle, Edinburgh solicitor; m., 1821, Mary, b. May (b. 1796). Their children were John May (1824–56; see 19:98–99JWC to MR, 12 July [1845]), Sarah (b. 1825; d. before 1832), Elizabeth (b. 1828), Mary May (see Craven), Sarah (1832–56), Robert (1833–66?), Annabella (1834–55), and Grace (see Dobie).

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–79; see 16:12JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843]), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him.

Whigham, Jemima Lucy Maxwell (1827–80); she lived at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire, with her sisters Mary (1821–1905), farmer and coal proprietor; Georgina Helen (1829–1915); and Elizabeth (1833–84);
das. of George Whigham (d. 1842), of Allanton, Dunscore, nr. Dumfries; see 10:191TC to JWC, 27 Sept. 1838.

Wilson, Thomas (b. 1811; see 26:30426:biographical notes, and 34:28434:biographical notes), moved to Weimar about 1854 and conducted schools there for the archduke of Saxe-Gotha-Eisenach; his Catholicity Spiritual and Intellectual (1850) was dedicated to TC. He and his German wife, m. 1861 (not further identified), made frequent visits to London; in 1861 they were living in Paragon, Blackheath (see 37:170TC to JAC, 2 June 1861); more recently they were at 17 Addison Ter. (probably lodging with Miss Brown), from where he wrote to TC, 3 April 1863.
Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to JCA, 2 March 1851, and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London.
